column2: Robert P. Gardener, financial officer of the Dommerich division of the Chemical Bank, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 William Kay, president of the Phillips Manufacturing Company of Newark, a maker of advertising and campaign buttons and badges, died today in St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 69 years old and lived at 320 South Harrison Street.

Governor Rockefeller and James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator were ahead of their opponents in the second survey of The Daily News's straw vote, which was published today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today asked Nicholas Johnson of the Federal Communications Commission to disqualify himself from all regulatory proceedings involving the Bell system because of what it called the "deep-seated bias and prejudice" it said he revealed in a speech in Chicago 10 days ago.

Big, bluff John Wright sailed into town from Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday, "dropped anchor" at the New York Yacht Club and proceeded to dispense common sense about stock while the club stewards dispensed distilled waters.

One of the cruel injustices of the American legal system has long been the fact that many people who go through bankruptcy often at considerable personal sacrifice walk out of Federal courts with the exhilarating feeling that they now are free of past debts.

The Standard Oil Company of California attained record sales and earnings in the third quarter but profits for the first nine months receded despite an eight per cent gain to a new peak in sales and revenues.

Except for your paycheck there is no such thing as a clean buck. It is just as corrupt to tolerate the bookmaker as it is to ignore the drug pusher. It is just as dishonest to accept the favor of the traffic violator as it is to exact a gratuity from the liquor licensee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The United States looks to the Soviet Union to take the major initiative at what is expected to be a fairly brief round of the talks on limiting strategic arms starting Monday at Helsinki, Finland.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday asserted his "vigorous opposition" to a Penn Central request to increase passenger fares by 10 per cent from New York to Albany.

Officials of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., met in virtually continuous session yesterday in an attempt to ascertain whether to acquire all or part of Goodbody Co., a major brokerage house in financial distress.
Radio station WLIB, whose FM outlet has been off the air since Oct. 13 and whose AM operation went off the air on Oct. 17 because of a community-labor dispute, will return to the air this morning.

A battalion of Rockefeller workers is on the telephone six hours a day and has been for weeks reaching Democrats and independents to identify the Governor's supporters outside Republican ranks, put them to work and make sure they vote on Nov. 3.

The role in which Marianna Ciraulo made her debut with the New York City Opera, that of Florinda in Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo," is not easy. As in most contemporary opera, the vocal line is disjunct, declamatory rather than lyrical, overridden at times by heavy orchestration.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP) Al Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., became the highest money-winner for one season in auto-racing history, the United States Auto Club said today.
Jockeys started getting an extra $10 at Aqueduct yesterday for riding losers, and some of them earned extra jeers for doing it.
QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 28 (Reuters) Kidnappers holding Ecuador's Air Force commander have demanded the release of several political prisoners in exchange for his freedom, informed sources said today.

TORONTO, Oct. 28 (UPI) Ron Ellis, Guy Trottier, Dave Keon and Norm Ullman scored third-period goals as the Toronto Maple Leafs snapped a four-game losing streak by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 6-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

When the United States announced last month that it was resuming shipments of planes, tanks and other heavy arms to Greece, a State Department spokesman said of that country: "The trend toward a constitutional order is established." If that is true, America's European allies have failed to detect it.

Mrs. Nancy McCarthy, a former WPIX news writer, testified at a Federal Communications Commission hearing yesterday that she and other writers at the station repeatedly complained about what they considered unethical news practices by WPIX during the latter part of 1968.
MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (Reuters)-Two messages purporting to be from the Front for the Liberation of Quebec were found last night, but one proved a hoax.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 Switzerland has refused to grant asylum to Odumegwu Ojukwu, who commanded Biafran forces in the Nigerian civil war, it was announced in Berne today.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 Premier Eisaku Sato, following his election to an unprecedented fourth term as president of the governing Liberal-Democratic party today announced that he would make no changes in the Cabinet or in high party posts.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a $17.2-million profit for the September quarter, up from $3,872,000 in the same quarter last year.
Twelve rabbis who are leaders of Orthodox Jewish organizations yesterday endorsed Governor Rockefeller, praising him for his defense of the "sanctity of the law." The sanctity of the law is ...
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and the New York Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday to rescue Goodbody Co., a major brokerage house threatened with insolvency.

An advertisement addressed "to the Jewish community" and favoring positions taken by Mr. Buckley on relations between the United States and Israel, Soviet Jewry and anti-Semitism on the New Left appears in today's editions of The New York Times.

Mrs. Nancy McCarthy, a former news writer for WPIX and the prime public witness in the Federal Communications Commission's hearing on WPIX's license, yesterday contradicted earlier testimony by executives and officials of the station.

Platinum futures continued their downward path yesterday in fairly heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Five of the options hit new lows for the life of the contract, compared with four the day before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 A panel of the National Research Council urged today that blood banks increase their testing for the presence of hepatitis virus to reduce the risk of infections that can be transmited through blood transfusions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Nixon Administration carried its concern over the "bluecollar blues" to the doorstep of private industry today, urging job reforms to improve the safety, satisfaction and security of millions of lower-paid workers.

KENOVA, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP) Maj. Gen. Edwin H. Burba, on his way to Morehead, Ky., to present the Army's highest civilian award to a friend, was killed with two chief warrant officers today when their crippled twinengine military plane crashed at Tri-State Airport.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 29 Jack Nicklaus had to use borrowed clubs and a substitute caddie in a last-minute dilemma today before he teed off in the $100,000 Sahara Invitation golf tourney.

CODY, Wyo., Oct. 29 Robert Meyers, a magazine illustrator who in recent years alternated his work as an artist with the operation of a dude ranch south west of here, was shot fatally in the head shortly after noon yesterday as he and his wife were digging post holes for a fence. He was 51 years old.

Continuing an up-and-down pattern that has prevailed for much of this year, contracts for future construction placed in September throughout the country slipped downward on a seasonally adjusted basis.
WACO, Tex., Oct. 29 George Bush is 6 feet 2 inches tall, handsome, conservative, a multimillionaire, 46 years old and a Republican. In World War II, he was a combat pilot.
Grey Advertising has sold its six-year-old direct-mail subsidiary, Grey Chapman, to Wunderman, Ricotta Klein. The amount of the cash deal was not disclosed.
A Federal Court jury awarded $2.5-million in damages yesterday to the families of two men who were killed in an automobile accident in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., in 1967.
Enthusiasts who like to watch displays of top-class bridge will have a rare opportunity at the New York Hilton this weekend.

AMMAN During the recent civil war in which they received a bloody nose from Jordan's army the greatest accomplishment of the Palestine guerrillas was a decision to unite their bickering factions under the command of a single man, Yasir Arafat.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct, 29 Only three other sophomores will oppose Most Happy Fella, Columbia George and Truluck in the 15th annual Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway on Nov. 7. With the gross set at $123,450.92, the purse will be the smallest since 1959, when Adios Butler captured the classic, then worth $110,994.29.

PNOMPENH, Friday, Oct. 30 (UPI) A barrage of mortar shells struck a Cambodian troop-ship convoy on the Mekong River last night, killing 13 soldiers, a crewman, and wounding 50 others, a Government military spokesman said today.

A Harlem wire manufacturing company pleaded guilty yesterday to 50 criminal charges of polluting the Harlem River and was ordered to pay $125,000 in fines if it dump any more acid or metal wastes into the water at any time in the next two years.

The Legislature to be elected Tuesday will have the consequential responsibility of reapportioning Congressional and state legislative districts under the 1970 census. The best assurance of equity in the carrying out of that assignment lies in the establishment of a nonpartisan reapportionment commission, a project to which the Democratic leadership in Albany is committed but the normally dominant Republicans are not.

The Egyptians and their supporters have had a chance to let off steam in the United Nations General Assembly this week; that is certainly preferable to their shooting off the new weapons they have packed into the Suez front in violation of the standstill cease-fire. But, as feared, the Assembly debate so far has produced more propaganda than progress toward peace.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, lashed out today at a series of advertisements that have appeared in more than 60 newspapers in at least six states accusing Democratic candidates of being "easy on crime," trying to "tear down America" and encouraging student violence.
LONDON Eartha Kitt, the singer who has sought to play Cleopatra, Medea and a Henry James heroine, has finally resolved one of her professional yearnings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 The United States called on the United Nations General Assembly today to recommend a three-month extension of the Middle East ceasefire and to urge the parties in the conflict to restore "conditions of confidence" necessary for the resumption of peace talks. The 90-day truce in the Suez Canal area is scheduled to expire next Thursday.
The tyranny of the polls and the timidity of Governor Rockefeller are combining to thwart a true expression of the will of New York voters in next Tuesday's election for United States Senator.
Nine million dollars originally allocated to a future passenger terminal for luxury liners on the Hudson River were formally transferred to a Brooklyn container port project yesterday.

An undercover force of hospital security guards and city detectives, some posing as patients and staff members, has been at work in Bellevue Hospital for the last 18 months "to ferret out pushers and buyers" of narcotics.
The stock market's brisk rally on Wednesday ran aground yesterday after the opening hour. Then, stock averages settled lower in desultory trading.

The New York Times/ Yankelovich survey, which began Sept. 15, is based on a daily series of 40 to 60 interviews conducted by telephone with persons whose names were selected from state voter registration lists.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 29 President-elect Salvador Allende said today that under his left-wing Government Chile would consider establishment of relations with Communist Governments on a step-by-step basis. He also said that nationalizations would be carried out only after each case had been carefully studied.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 29 The police, acting on a tip, seized 200 pounds of explosive material in the basement of an apartment building a mile from the downtown area tonight.

The city's Commissioner of Air Resources, Dr. Robert N. Rickles, says he has been under pressure to drop the designation "unhealthy" which his department has applied to the air New Yorkers breathe more than seventy times so far this year. The Commissioner's standards are too tough, critics say, and his labels too alarming.

SANTA CRUZ, Oct. 29 (UPI)--John Linley Frazier was arraigned today on indictments charging him with killing five persons at Dr. Victor Ohta' mountain mansion. persons at Dr. Victor Ohta' mountain mansion Judg Charles Franich warned all parties to the case not to tall about it.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 A public health physician reported findings here today that challenge widely held theories that urban air pollution is a direct cause of respiratory disease.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 29 Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, called here today for a relaxation of the "rigid and inflexible" United States policy toward Cuba.

Northeast Utilities raised $35.58-million with the competitive sale yesterday of 3 million common shares to an underwriting group managed by the First Boston Corporation. The group, which bid $11.861 for the shares and priced them on reoffering at $12.25, reported the stock selling "very well."
TOKYO., Oct.29 "DodeskaDen," Akira Kurosawa's first film in five years, had its premiere at the Yurakuza Theatre here Tuesday night.
The Knapp Commission, which is investigating allegations of widespread police corruption here, will begin issuing subpoenas next week to policemen, businessmen and people engaged in crime.

Miss Susanna Louisa McKemie and Clinton Howard Drexel were married Saturday. The civil ceremony took place on the lawn of Footpoint Plantation, which is owned by the bridegroom's uncle, Henry Sargent Cram, in Blufftnn S.C.
The invasion is on Paris couture houses, not content with exporting their scarves and perfume, are concentrating on sending their readyto-wear to the United States, too.
LONDON, Oct. 29 Some Soviet Jews living in Latvia have appealed to 23 Communist parties in the West to intercede with Moscow to allow them to join relatives in Israel.
WARSAW, Oct. 29 Two Cyrus S. Eatons were in Warsaw today one to receive an honorary degree and the other to negotiate construction of an 800-room hotel.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
While Braulio Baeza broke a 25-race riding slump, Aqueduct's apprentice jockeys kept looking yesterday for the break-through that could restore the "bug" to fashion here.

Despite Mayor Lindsay's recent gloomy forecast of possible payless pay days for city employes, Dun Bradstreet has informed its clients that the city's long-range financial future has "extraordinary economic strength."
If Harry Nagler is right, the layman can get the whole story on his investments.

PALATINE, Ill., Oct. 29 (UPI) A late-model Oldsmobile, described by the police as either black or red with a black top, was the only clue today in the murder of the millionaire horseman George W. Jayne.

The Flexner Report of 1910, which has formed the foundation of medical education for the last six decades, developed the concepts that medical care should be based on a thorough inowledge of biomedical science, that accreditation should be reserved for top quality medical schools emphasizing both laboratory work and clinical experience, and that medical schools should be affiliated with universities.
Unlimited hydroplane racing, once the glamour sport of the future, has suddenly realized it is in danger of becoming extinct.

The New York City Cultural Council had its first benefit Wednesday, and it was one of those now in. frequent events everybody thinks of as a gala. Most of the ladies were iced up with masses of diamonds and such. Ballgowns far outnumbered the new, more casual, evening attire. And the men, who have been turning up recently in almost anything after dark, were in plain old black tie.
An agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified yesterday at the trial of 13 Black Panthers here that a defendant had threatened him the previous day.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 The United States Embassy pressed the Soviet Union today for the immediate release of the plane and the four officers Major Gen. Edward C. D. Scherrer, head of the United States joint military mission in Turkey; Brig. Gen. Claude M. McQuarrie Jr., his aide for ground forces; Maj. James P. Russell Jr., the pilot, and Col. Cevdat Deneli, a Turkish liaison officer.
The Baltimore Orioles, who got the loser's share in last year's World Series, learned yesterday that their 1970 victory over the Cincinnati Reds was worth $18,215.78 a man.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 28 When the doors to Bayfront Center in St. Petersburg were opened this morning, among the first in line were 20 long-haired students who had come to heckle President Nixon.

Dr. Alexander Levitt, a leader in osteopathic medicine here For nearly four decades, died Tuesday night after a heart attack at his home, 45 Tennis court, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed today that the United States and the Soviet Union had taken a major step toward space cooperation by agreeing to develop mutually compatible rendezvous and docking systems for spacecraft.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 Following are excerpts from a report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education on medical education in the United States:

Senator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican incumbent, and Representative Richard L. Ottinger, his Democratic opponent in the race for the United States Senate, went to Harlem last night for a scheduled debate. But they failed to confront each other.

The help-wanted index, a measure of the volume of help wanted advertising in 52 major newspapers across the country, dropped last month to its lowest point since Auhust of 1965, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Gordon Van Cise have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Woodruff Van Cise, to William O'Connor Harnisch, a lawyer with the New York firm of Cahill, Gordon, Sonnett, Reindel Ohl, where his future father-in-law is a senior partner.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) Alex Delvecchio scored his 400th and 401st National Hockey League career goals and Gordie Howe registered his 1,000th regular season assist to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-3 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
Candidates for tomorrow's Jockey Club Gold Cup at the Big A won't have to contend with Nodouble.
The Republican and Democratic National Committees have purchased five minutes of television time each during half-time of next Sunday's professional football games.
Eastern Airlines plans to test two unorthodox weapons for possible use by its pilots against hijackers.

Smith, Barney Co., Inc., announced yesterday the election of Robert A. Powers as chairman and chief executive officer to succeed Hugh Knowlton Jr., who is retiring at the age of 47 to pursue "personal interests."

WASHINGTON, Oct 29 The United States charged the Soviet Union today with a "clear violation" of the consular convention between the two countries and called for the immediate release of the United States Army plane and passengers detained in Armenia since they landed there eight days ago.
Twenty-five pro basketball players who carved a legend of greatness in the National Basketball Association were nominated yesterday for the career All-Star team to be named next January in San Diego.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, said today he had information indicating that a special Federal grand jury would be empaneled by January to investigate the killing last May of four Kent State University students by Ohio National Guardsmen.

FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 29 The leadership of Italy's three major trade-union organizations, including Communists and non-Communists, agreed today to step up efforts to build a united labor front that would strive for drastic social reforms.
BONN, Oct. 29 The East German Communist leadership invited West Germany today to resume talks on the relaxation of tensions in Central Europe.

Reduction in DC-8 and DC-9 deliveries and some delays in acceptance of these aircraft by airlines pending completion of financing arrangements have continued to depress sales and earnings of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

The Lindsay administration has charged in an affidavit made public yesterday that Controller Abraham D. Beame awarded two consultant contracts totaling more than $100,000 without submitting them to the Board of Estimate.

ALGIERS, Oct. 29 (UPI) Dr. Timothy Leary, the LSD advocate who escaped last month from prison in the United States, returned to Algiers today with three American companions after an unsuccessful attempt to make contact with Palestinian guerrilla leaders in Lebanon and Egypt.
PARIS, Oct. 29 Four of the world's largest banks announced today a $50-million cooperative venture. It was the second agreement for a multinational banking link-up to be announced this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 A high-jumping contest on horseback was won tonight by Brendan, an open jumper owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill of Collegeville, Pa., for the highlight of the Washington international horse show. Roderick Jenkins, a 26-year-old professional, was the rider as he had been when another Gill leaper, Idle Dice, won the event a year ago.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday losses for the third quarter and first nine months and announced it was again passing up the quarterly dividend.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29 At the Nacka Prison near Stockholm, inmates travel each morning to civilian jobs and return to their quarters at night. In the university town of Uppsala, convicts live beside students, who offer them tutoring help for academic degrees. Around Sweden, nearly 4,800 convicts received twoday and three-day furloughs through the year to help ease the difficulties of adjustment after release.
Dr. Harold W. K. Dargeon. pediatrician who pioneered in the recognition of cancer as threat to children, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital following a long illness. He was 73 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UPI) Third-period goals by Wayne Hillman, Earl Heiskala and Serge Bernier gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) The Secretary of State's office reported today that 7,930,798 New Yorkers were registered to vote in the elections next Tuesday for Goverror, United States Senator and other offices.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire the Transnation Development Corporation and would also make an exchange offer for the stock of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., it did not now own.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 A basic overhaul in medical training was recommended today by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education in a report that called for a 50 per cent increase in medical students, a 20 per cent increase in dental students and more allied health personnel to meet American health needs in the nineteen-seventies.

A $59.4-million contract for 144 new electric cars for the New Haven rail commuter line was signed here and in Hartford yesterday by the respective state agencies that plan to take over the service on Jan. 1. The formal take-over agreement was signed last Tuesday.

The Jets may be limping and they may be 10-point underdogs for their game against the healthy Giants on Sunday. But they received a long-range vote of confidence yesterday from the man who probably knows them better than anyone Dr. James A. Nicholas.
"Did you, at any time during the taxable year, have any interest in ... or other authority over a bank, securities, or other financial account in a foreign country?"

Barry Farber, the Republican-Liberal candidate for the House of Representatives from the 19th District, was driving through the Upper West Side one afternoon recently when he spotted his Democratic opponent, Mrs. Bella S, Abzug, campaigning on the corner of 72d Street and Broadway.

This letter to Secretary of the Treasury Kennedy by the dean of the University of Pennsylvania's law school concerns the decision of the Internal Revenue Service to suspend tax exemptions for organizations specializing in litigation (such as on defective products or against polluters) in the public interest.
"Tradition is slovenliness," according to Mahler, as quoted by Lili Kraus during opening remarks before her piano recital at Hunter Collebe Assembly Hall Wednesday night.

Most of those in the crowd of 16,934 at Madison Square Garden last night, almost incredibly, sidetracked their emotional involvement with the Knickerbockers to cheer for Cal Murphy, the 5-foot-9-inch rookie backcourt man of the San Diego Rockets.

TRENTON,Oct. 29 Mayor Arthur J. Holland ordered a curfew here tonight after a day of sporadic racial disturbances in which bands of black youths invaded the downtown area, smashing windows, breaking into stores and pelting policemen with stones and bottles.
Ilia A. Tolstoy, noted ichthyologist and grandson of Leo Tolstoy, the Russian author, died Wednesday in New York Hospital of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 300 East 57th Street.

Overriding the Mayor's recommendation, the Board of Estimate voted 14 to 8 yesterday against allowing a broadly based community group to lease a 16-story city-owned building on the Lower East Side for 35 years.
The American Stock Exchange sustained its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as the list declined in slow trading.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 29 (AP) The Utah Stars started slowly, but picked up momentum in the third period tonight and went on to defeat the New York Nets, 114-105, in an American Basketball Association game.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct 29 The management of Union Carbide Corporation's metal lurgical plant at Alloy, W. Va. agreed today to clean up 99 per cent of the plant's emissions in four years or close down under a schedule set by the West Virginia Air Pollution Control Commission.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 29 Federal and state water pollution control agencies today took a step toward establishing limits on the amount of thermal pollution that can be dumped into Lake Michigan.

A group of parents called on Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton yesterday for public hearings into conditions that they said had turned George Washington High School into "a cauldron of racial hatred and community warfare."

Item. The Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, when passing through Cambridge recently, asked me why an advanced technology like America's should insist on producing low-productivity textiles and common shoes. I touched a nerve of a New England radio audience when I quoted my answer. "We should move our resources to more efficient uses and turn over to the developing countries primitive activities that any emerging economy can do with law-wage labor."
Following are lists of the members of the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education and of the members of the commission's Advisory Committee on Medical Education:

Fredell Lack, a violinist who for many years ornamented the New York musical scene and now is artist-in-residence at the University of Houston, returned here on Wednesday night in recital at Alice Tully Hall with a Houston colleague, the pianist Albert Hirsch. Academic residency has done nothing, apparently, to diminish the skills of either musician, and they collaborated in a program marked by excellent musicianship and highly polished teamwork.

Critics are masters of pretense. (Some of us are also masters of pretentiousness, but that comes as a special bonus offer to our readers.) We pretend that all plays are of equal intrinsic interest to us but dear friends, they are not. We each know the plays that we would, individually, be prepared to pay good green money to see, sight unseen.

Apprehension as to what the British Government's statement on money policy, expected next week, would mean to investors perhaps stricter controls on credit and bank lending depressed prices on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and traders cut their commitments.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 29 Conceding that he had very little support in the black community, James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for Senator, said today that if elected he would appoint a Negro as a staff liaison officer.
Supreme Court Justice George J. Balbach ruled yesterday in Queens that Alice Crimmins must stand trial on charges of manslaughter and murder in the deaths of her two children in July, 1965.

Most elections are decided by issues, candidate personality and party loyalty. The findings of The New York Times / Yankelovich survey, conducted among a sample of 1.912 registered voters from all over the state, suggests this may be less applicable in the election for Governor and Senator.

CAIRO, Oct. 29 President Anwar el-Sadat toured the Suez Canal front yesterday, a week before the expiration of the 90day cease-fire, and watched Egyptians at an antiaircraft missile base prepare "within seconds" for battle.
Two conservation organizations yesterday accused Mr. Buckley of being connected with an oil company whose activities in Florida allegedly pose a threat to the environment.
LAMBERTVILLE, N. J. Distant tinklings of bells across the Delaware River from this residential New Jersey town break the autumn stillness.

Two new faces graced the New York City Opera's performance of "Faust" Wednesday night. Johanna Meier, who sang her initial Marguerite with the company, at first seemed a bit too pallid and retiring even for this sweet girl next door, but her performance gained in profile as the evening wore on and in the final prison scene her acting was most affecting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Attorney General of Alabama moved the legal struggle over Southern school desegregation to a new forum today, suing the Federal Government in the United States Court of Claims for the value of Alabama schools closed by Federal judges to promote desegregation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Federal scientists reported today that toxic levels of mercury had been found in the livers of Alaskan fur seals that live in the Pacific Ocean scores of miles from land.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 29 Dr. Paul L. Adams, Conservative candidate for Governor, today took the day off from campaigning and spent most of the day at his home in suburban North Chili.

SONMY, South Vietnam, Oct 29 The Vietnamese of Sonmy say that 570 civilians were massacred here on March 16 1968, when an American infantry company entered the area but none of them know the name of Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., nor what he looks like nor do they understand why he was in Quangngai Province today.
Last spring, college football coaches fretted over the prospects of student unrest and the effect continued disruptions would have on football programs this fall.

Money and bank credit expanded at a moderate pace during the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday showed, but the demand for business loans at the major moneycenter banks was notably weak.
YONKERS, Oct. 29 The Old Glory fall horse sale ended at Yonkers Raceway today with 188 head bringing a total of $598,800, an average of $3,185.

Thomas Ryan, an impetuous young artist, is at war with the city's cautious Landmarks Preservation Commission. And small wonder. Zealously watching over the Greenwich Village Historic District, it has ordered him to remove a mural he has painted on an outdoor wall at the fourth-and-fifth-story levels of a building at 52 West Eighth Street.

Eric Braun, formerly a principal dancer with the Ballet Theater, died Tuesday evening while teaching a ballet class at the North Shore Academy of Dance, a school he founded in Highland Park, Ill. Mr. Braun, who was 46 years old, suffered a heart attack.

Harry Markson is the director of boxing at Madison Square Garden and the absolute antithesis of the prototype. He is no cigarchomping semi-literate, but a man of culture with a taste for fine music and the higher arts. He doesn't normally go searching for analogies to drop into a strange context, but when one pops into his mind he doesn't hesitate to offer it.
ALBANY, Oct. 39 Adam Walinsky, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, is seeking the dismissal of State Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood.

A scant two months after he took over as the city's first School Chancellor, Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the former Vermont Education Commissioner, is embroiled in a major conflict with the organizations that represent the school system's 60,000 teachers and nearly 4,000 supervisors.

Jerome Kretchmer said yesterday that some areas of the city had become "visibly cleaner" since he became Acting Commissioner of Sanitation about 10 weeks ago. He noted, however, that the city was still "not clean" and that the present situation was "unacceptable."
The irresistible force will collide with the immovable object or is it the other way round? when Dartmouth faces Yale in a clash of undefeated Ivy League teams at the Bowl tomorrow.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (AP) The United States command reported today that 43 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, three more than the week before.
HARTFORD, Oct. 29 Senator Edward M. Kennedy took a day off from his own Massachusetts campaign today for a six-city swing through Connecticut to bolster the uncertain Democratic forces here.

PARIS, Oct. 29 The Communist delegations at the Vietnam Peace talks in Paris insisted today that they had "buried deeply" President Nixon's latest peace proposals and refused to comment on reports from Washington that they might still be interested.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold said today he would appeal a United States District Court decision barring the Government printing office from printing and distributing a list of allegedly radical speakers compiled by a House committee.

POPULATION There are about 445,000 people in this economically and racially mixed district. Jews make up the largest ethnic bloc; there are also large concentrations of Puerto Ricans, Italians, Chinese and blacks, as well as pockets of Poles and Ukrainians. The area ...
The Continental Telephone Company announced yesterday record earnings and revenues for the nine months ended Sept. 30.

Sandra Lloyd Lesser, vice president and director of editorial services for Reportes Medicos, a publication for physicians in Latin America, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, after a long illness. She was 45 years old and lived at 412 East 55th Street.

Nadine Gordimer's last novel, 'The Late Bourgeois World," was published four years ago, and we know now what she has been doing all this time. She has been writing this one. "A Guest of Honor" is a long, spacious, comprehensive work of fiction. It has all the lineaments of a traditional story. It is leisurely and detailed ...

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Cohen of New York and Koneonga Lake, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Cohen's daughter, Miss Margaret Waldinger, to Leslie Seff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Seff of Queens Village, Queens.

Spider Lockhart, the New York Giants' all-pro defensive back, was wishing yesterday that Joe Namath was not injured and he could play against the star New York Jets quarterback on Sunday. Lockhart feels that somehow he'd have a chance of doing something spectacular if Namath were playing.
Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday he would not approve a contract between Curt Flood and the Washington Senators if it included any modification of the reserve clause.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP) Bill Wishnick, 45 years old, of New York, and Dr. Robert Magoon, 35, of Miami Beach, were declared the national champions of offshore powerboat racing today.

PORT TALBOT, Wales, Oct. 29, (Reuters) David Lloyd of Britain scored an upset victory today over Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the top-seeded player, in the quarterfinal round of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament. Nastase lost, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.
As one professionally interested in negotiation, I went to Paris to see if it looked like a negotiated settlement in Vietnam is possible.
Two Chicago street gang leaders were arrested here yesterday as fugitives sought on charges including murder, kidnapping and fraud.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
LONDON, Oct. 29 The Bank of England tightened the credit squeeze another notch today in a new attempt to damp down Britain's inflation.
The Treasury's $7.67-billion refinancing ended with a flourish yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The last few days of a political campaign are always the most dangerous, for then candidates are vulnerable to damaging and misleading attacks which they have no time to answer. The lastminute smear is one of the oldest and ugliest tactics of American politics, and lately it has been used against Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, among others.

The Newspaper Guild announced last night that it had set a deadline of 6 A.M. Monday for a strike against either The New York Times or The Daily News if new agreements had not been reached by that time.

Joseph Coles's wages are about half what they were a year ago when he drove a laundry truck. He works longer hours and collects no overtime. Yet, when the fabrics printed with leopard masks, elephant-tusk carvings and African bronzes come rolling off the production line under his direction, there is a proud look in his eyes that his purple sunglasses cannot conceal.

Marsden J. Perry, a retired commander in the Naval Reserve and a collector of books on war and on naval and military strategy, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 322 East 57th Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 A group of parents of children enrolled in Project Head Start in Buffalo today protested the Nixon Administration's cut in funds for the preschool program.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 29 (AP) The Laotian Government today accepted the pro-Communist Pathet Lao's formula for a meeting between the two sides in the civil war.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 Four days before the start of the second round of United States-Soviet negotiations on limiting strategic weapons, diplomats here are puzzled over the harsh words passing between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The 1968 murder conviction and sentence of a Green Beret captain involved in clandestine missions into Cambodia were set aside today by three judges of the Army Court of Military Review.

Thomas A. Fitzpatrick Sr., who retired in 1943 as a battalion chief of the New York Fire Department to serve as a lieutenant commander in charge of fire control at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 246 Beach 119th Street, Rockaway Park, Queens. His age was 77.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29 Vice President Agnew conceded today that, as some politicians do but do not admit, he sometimes tailors his different campaign statements to different campaign audiences.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 29 Demonstrators threw eggs, rocks, and placards at President Nixon's limousine tonight as he left the San Jose Municipal Auditorium following a political speech.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 She may not have been a successful spy for Cuba, but she did demonstrate how easy it can be for an attractive woman with a bent for espionage to be invited almost anywhere in Washington.
Until recent years, we have looked upon the oceans of the world as inexhaustible. That they could be overfished seemed impossible; their vast expanse alone made such a thought ludicrous.
PIERRE, S. D. The candidate who yearns for old-style politicking would do well to come to South Dakota this fall.
A 22-year-old schoolteacher Who had lived here for less than three months, was found dead in her apartment yesterday at 310 West 73d Street.
Two days after The Daily News straw vote indicated that James L. Buckley was leading in the three-way race for United States Senator, Oliver Quayle Co. released

"Curiosity Shop," a new series of hour-long children's programs combining animation, film, live-action and music and purporting to answer the myriad questions of youngsters, will be televised Saturdays starting next fall on the American Broadcasting Company.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct 29 Two journalists were found dead on the side of a highway today, bringing to seven the total of newsmen known to have been killed while reporting on the war on Cambodia.
BELGRADE When I visited Great Britain and the United States in 1968, the most frequent question directed at me was: What will happen after Tito?

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 Earlier this year, a Governor up for re-election submitted his strong public stand on a controversial tax issue to Decision Making Information, Inc., public opinion analysts here, to gauge the voters' reactions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) A Federal Trade Commis sion hearing examiner today ordered dismissal of deceptive trade practice charges against publishers of the now defunct Saturday Evening Post.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (UPI) Senator George Murphy called Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight champion, a liar today and accused Mr. Tunney's son of basing his election campaign on a "deliberate political smear" about Technicolor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Justice Department is broadening its drive on questionable campaign spending to investigate the executive political funds set up by some corporation officials to funnel money to favorite candidates.
BERLIN. Oct. 29 Foreign Minister Gromyko arrived in East Berlin today for talks with East German leaders.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The United States Treasury has ruled that Japan has dumped on the United States market ferrite cores used in electronic products, with a value of more than $650,000.
LACKAWANNA, N.Y., Oct. 29 Mayor Lindsay came here today to praise Arthur J. Goldberg but talked as if he came to bury the Nixon Administration.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 29 South Africa's governing National party received its second electoral setback of the year today as results of provincial council elections showed a shift toward the United party, the main opposition.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 Rich and poor nations joined today in pledging contributions to the United Nations Development Program that should give the aid agency $249-million in resources for 1971.

The Consolidated Edison Company agreed yesterday to rescind an announced increase in electric and gas rates for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation that would have cost the corporation an estimated $730,000 a year.
Last season, when the Knicks were soaring to their first National Basketball Association championship in 24 years, they met the challenge on every occasion when excellence was demanded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Tasso, from the string of the West German Equestrian Team, ridden by Hartwig Steenken, and Keswick, owned by Mrs. William Hewitt of Palmetto, Fla., won identical but separate jumping classes today at the Washington International Horse Show.

Extra police patrols searched the tense Upper West Side yesterday for the slayer of a 22year-old assistant teacher at the Brearley School who was found dead Thursday afternoon in her apartment at 310 West 73d Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) Trailing by 14 points early in the third quarter, the Baltimore Bullets rallied for a 123110 victory tonight over the Philadelphia 76ers. Earl Monroe and Wes Unseld paced the Bullets' attack.

Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday that Abraham D. Beame was "a double-standard Controller" who had previously cooperated with a Democratic Mayor in regard to consultant contracts but who now obstructed Mr. Lindsay's efforts.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 30--Gerard C. Smith, the head of the United States delegation, said tonight that progress could be achieved in the Soviet American talks on limiting strategic arms despite current strains in relations between the two countries.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 30 (Reuters) A young Indonesian village woman pretended for 19 months that she was bearing a child that was able to talk and that prayed to Allah five times a day, as Moslems do.

Soybean futures, which had been declining for a couple of sessions, rebounded yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices ran up as much as 3 cents a bushel at the top end of the list, but a wave of profit taking chopped away much of the gains.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association asked the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday to rule that the Knapp Commission, which is investigating allegations of corruption among New York policemen, is invalid. Argument on the P.B.A.'s motion was scheduled for Dec. 3.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Treasury announced today a new technique for borrowing funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Democrats are coming to the end of a significant Congressional election without any national spokesmen or publicity devices to pit against the massive homestretch efforts of President Nixon and Vice President Agnew.
A scientist from Yale Univer sity has found new fossil evidence that may help settle a long-debated mystery of evolution what sort of life style prompted the first "birds" to start flying?
The exhibition of Ming Porcelains at the China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, is a must for ceramics collectors and a fascinating display of fine craftsmanship that is worth anyone's time.

PARIS The Rue Paul Bert is a quiet residential street in suburban Puteaux. It is lined with middle-class houses occupied by quiet middleclass people, but the one at Number 17, has, to all intents and purposes, gone to the dogs.
Miss Caroline Alker Arbon and Anthony Kane Baker, a filmmaker she met when they were summer school students at C.W. Post College, plan to be married in May.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second-largest food chain, announced today that it would list the prices of several hundred products in 255 supermarkets by the pint or pound as well as by the package.

WASHINGTON The African intelligentsia has more than a passing interest in the future of the American of African extraction. To begin with, there is between Black Africa and Black America a synthesis of blood and culture. We have both suffered in slavery and in colonialism at the hands of the white man.

John Christopher Rogan, a former reporter who covered police headquarters for The New York Mirror from its inception in 1925, died of a stroke Thursday in Coney Island Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 The Supreme Court today annulled the 10-year sentence imposed on Representative Tran Ngoc Chau, the controversial Deputy jailed earlier this year.

Thousands of Penn Central commuters were delayed as much as three hours yesterday morning by an accident in the Bronx in which two passengers alighting from a disabled train ware struck by a train on an adjacent track.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 Photographs introduced into evidence at an Ohio State University disciplinary hearing have indicated that undercover State Highway Patrolmen played a role in the incident that touched off several days of disorders here last spring.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 The Soviet Union agreed today to permit two United States consular officials to make a second visit to the four officers who have been detained in Soviet Armenia for nine days, since their plane violated Soviet airspace and landed in the border town of Leninakan.
Lord Wakehurst, the former John De Vere Loder, was born in London on Feb. 5, 1895, had a wide-ranging career in the military, the Foreign Service and in the arts.

The unfreezing of customer accounts at Robinson Co., a brokerage house in bankruptcy proceedings, is expected to begin shortly due to a petition filed yesterday by the firm's court-appointed receiver.
Mayor Lindsay recommended additional capital spending yesterday to finance a total of 30 prefabricated so-called minischools, most of them in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 Dr. Joseph T. English president of the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation, said today that the nation needed a "new coalition" of doctors and consumers to offset the Nixon Administration's "callous disregard" for the health needs of the American people.
For the first time since the Jets' season opener, George Sauer and Don Maynard appear to be available for full-time duty against the Giants tomorrow at Shea Stadium.
LE HAVRE, France, Oct. 30 (UPI) The French Line took the liner France out of service today when strike negotiations with tourist-class waiters broke down.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct, 30 The South Vietnamese national press center has withdrawn the press accreditation of the American journalist and former social worker who first publicized the "tiger-cage" prison cells on Con Son, an island 60 miles off South Vietnam.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 The Long Island Bulls, after six defeats, posted their first victory of the season tonight by turning back the Hartford Knights, 24-20, in an Atlantic Coast Football League game.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 30--Nathan Winarick, a founder and secretary of Ar Winarick, Inc., cosmetics manufacturers of New York and this city, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 34 Perry Road, Edison.

In our time, here and now, when there is a would-be Robespierre haranguing us on every other street corner, what more exciting chance would any opera company want than "Andrea Ch nier"? Almost in spite of Giordano, who hacked together a conventional Puccinilike score, this tale of the French revolution should give a 1970 listener the chill of recognition.
Dr. Paul H. Curts, emeritus professor of German at Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn., died Thursday in Durham, N.C., to which he recently moved. He was 86 years old.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (UPI) Soviet space scientists launched two unmanned Cosmos satellites today, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (AP) The Soviet airline Aeroflot is taking "serious precautionary measures" against hijackers and other persons who might board planes "with criminal intent," the Civil Aviation Ministry reported today.

Voters in the 17th Congressional District, Manhattan's socalled Silk Stocking District, have a choice on Tuesday between two major candidates Edward I. Koch, the DemocratLiberal incumbent, and Peter J. Sprague, a political neophyte who says he would have voted exactly as Mr. Koch did had he been in Washington instead.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30 President-elect Salvador Allende named a 15-man Cabinet today that includes three members of the Communist party's Central Committee.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 The United States Command disclosed today a rise in deaths of soldiers from drug use in Vietnam and ascribed the increase to greater use of hard drugs and a more accessible supply of "high potency heroin."

The Tokyo Kid Brothers the delightful people who gave us, and indeed are still giving us, "The Golden Bat" at the Sheridan Square Playhouse have extended their operations. They have been offering in a series of midnight performances (the last so far scheduled are tonight and tomorrow night) at Cafe La Mama a brand new show, "Coney Island Play."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Jack De Ment, a research chemist, was granted a patent this week for a gunbarrel method of "pumping" lasers stimulating them so that they flash.

POPULATION: There are about 500,000 residents in Manhattan's 17th Congressional District, which extends from 97th Street on the north to Houston Street on the South, from Ninth Avenue on the west, to the East River. The area is largely middle and upper class, but there are pockets of poverty on the Lower East Side, in the Nineties and East Thirties.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 30 Dr. Aaron W. Bortin, director of psychiatry since 1964 at Brunswick Hospital Center, Amityville, L.I., died in United Hospital here yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived at 18 Juneau Road, Woodbury, L.I.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 30 President Nixon called on the nation's voters tonight to reject candidates who had condoned, excused or "failed to speak up against" permissiveness among America's "violent" youth.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP)--The British Government, alarmed by the pollution of the country's coasts by oil, introduced legislation in the House of Commons today to impose tighter controls on ships that dump fuel into the sea.

Arnold C. Sherwood, who retired as corporate secretary of the Union Pacific Railroad Company in 1960, died Thursday at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived at 13-60 Sanford Road, Fair Lawn, N.J.

A woman called a polling organization that had been making voter surveys of the New York Senate race and asked the other day: "Tell me how to vote. If I vote for Goodell, will that help elect Buckley?"

Some top-ranking Roman Catholic theologians called on the church yesterday to recognize the validity of the Lutheran ministry and the real presence of Christ in the Lutheran administration of holy communion.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 30 Sol Rubin, a lawyer, died today at his home here, 21 Avis Drive. He was 71 years old.

David D. Smith, the Republican-Conservative candidate for the House of Representatives from the 16th District (Staten Island and Brooklyn), violated the Fair Campaign Practices Code on three counts in his race against the Democratic incumbent, John M. Murphy, the American Arbitration Association has ruled.
Photoengravers Union 1-P reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract with The New York Times, The Daily News and The Long Island Press.

PHOENIX, Oct. 30 Sam Grossman, a newcomer to Arizona, to the Democratic party and to politics, threatens to unseat Senator Paul J. Fannin with an aggressive television campaign financed mainly out of his own pocket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Army said today that Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, the Judge Advocate General, would appoint an officer to determine whether Capt. John J, McCarthy Jr. of the Special Forces will be retired for the 1967 murder of an alleged Vietnamese "double agent."
Early this year American Metal Climax, Inc., let it be known that it planned to buy up the 57.7 per cent interest in Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., that it did not already own.

The advantages of Jersey City as a back-office operations center for Wall Street financial concerns were extolled yesterday by officials of that city at a meeting and reception for New York financial executives at Oscar's Delmonico restaurant. The meeting was sponsored by the Jersey City Area Development Council.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 30 Although Albatross has been installed as a 1-to-5 favorite in tomorrow's $92,360 Roosevelt Futurity at Roosevelt Raceway, Harry Harvey, the colt's trainer-driver, is far from convinced his pacer should be considered a sure thing.
Two officials associated With Bronx community action corporations funded by the city were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges alleging the theft of money from payroll checks.
Dr. Elizabeth Brennan Hinckley, former attending pediatrician at St. Luke's Hospital, died Thursday in Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.
Investors continued the profit taking yesterday on the London Stock Exchange that began earlier in the week, but selling appeared to decline toward the close and the market steadied.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30--The Soviet Union called today for the immediate and unconditional resumption of the Arab-Israeli peace talks.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 Forwood C. Wiser, president of Trans World Airlines, said today that the Anglo-French supersonic jet liner, the Concorde, would lose money unless the traveling public was willing to pay 30 to 40 per cent more than they now pay for first-class fares across the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 Charles E. DeLeuw, a prominent consulting engineer in the field of transportation planning and construction, particularly subways and highways, died Wednesday in a nursing home here. He was 79 years old.

MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP) Tom Bailey rolled up 108 yards in the third quarter tonight to become Florida State's top career rusher and paced the Seminoles to a 27-3 victory over Miami.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 30 Raymond Cyrus Hoiles, president of the Freedom Newspapers Inc., a chain that publishes 20 daily newspapers, died today at the age of 91. He had been under treatment for kidney disease in Santa Ana Hospital.
The Brooklyn and Queens District Attorneys announced grand jury indictments yesterday of 28 inmates accused of initiating jail riots earlier this month.

LONDON, Oct. 30 For those in Europe who care about the United States, this has been a painful election campaign. And now it has produced the outrage of violence against the President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Attorney General John N. Mitchell and 13 representatives of the nation's police chiefs agreed today on recommendations that will be submitted to President Nixon for cooperation between Federal, state and local officials to combat terrorist bombings and attacks on policemen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Output per man-hour, the most common measure of productivity, rose substantially in the third quarter for the second quarter in a row, the Labor Department announced today. The rise amounted to 4.6 per cent, on an annual basis.

When Angel Cordero Jr. takes Twogundan out for the $109,900 Jockey Club Gold Cup today at Aqueduct, he'll be steering him as gingerly as a first-timer at a riding academy.

Because additional low-cost public housing is desperately needed and present levels of state subsidy have been exhausted, voters are urged to approve Proposition One on the state ballot Nov. 3. Approval of this proposition is essential under the State Constitution which requires direct voter acceptance of levels of state housing subsidies.

Senator Charles Goodell visited the site of the World Trade Center yesterday and was booed and heckled by a lunch-hour crowd of 200 construction workers when he tried to tell them why they should not support James L. Buckley, his Conservative party opponent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Ford Foundation announced today a new program for providing capital to fledgling mortgage bankers from minority races.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 A Justice Department summary of the inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the shootings at Kent State University last May 4 differs sharply from the conclusion reached later by an Ohio grand jury that exonerated National Guardsmen on the ground that they believed they were physically threatened.

In the last 25 years, Erroll Garner, the jazz pianist, has gone from 52d Street, where he sometimes worked in three clubs at the same time, to Carnegie Hall, where jazz is frequently heard, and now to the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, where jazz has never been heard before. He will play in the Persian Room twice each night.
HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 30 Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative candidate for Governor, predicted today that he would win "somewhere in excess of 700,000 votes and possibly a million."
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP) A British Army patrol came under machine-gun fire early today as violence broke out in Belfast for the second consecutive night.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company filed a report with the Federal District court in Philadelphia yesterday showing that the railroad had operated at a net loss in the first eight months this year of $208,930,467. This compared with a $50,917,939 net loss reported by the railroad in the corresponding period last year, when it still was operating under private ownership.

The New York City Opera gave its first performance of the season of "Rigoletto" on Thursday night. It might have been the fifth or sixth. There was energy to spare onstage and in the orchestra pit, but little of it seemed disciplined.

Three bombs exploded within 15 minutes early yesterday morning, damaging two armories in Queens and the city headquarters for motorcycle policemen, situated in the Bronx. No one was injured or arrested.

Dr. Irvin J. Cohen, who retired in 1969 as executive vice president of the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Thursday in the Veteran Administration Hospital, Washington, after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The price of gold slumped today with some dealers slashing the price by as much as $1 an ounce.

Howard W. Foote, vice president in charge of textiles of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven. He was 46 years old and lived at 478 Catamount Road, Fairfield, Conn.

LAS VEGAS, Oct. 30 Tommy Aaron, who traveled 12 miles into the desert to score a leading 64 yesterday, played a course within the city limits today and set the pace again with a 36-hole aggregate of 135 in the $100,000 Sahara invitation golf tourney.

TORONTO, Oct. 30 Canadian banks cut today their prime interest rate on loans by a half point to 7 per cent Interest paid on savings accounts also was reduced.

A FORM of whist which was popular a century ago was known as "double-dummy." It was a twohanded game in which both players had a dummy hand exposed on the table. The opponent's hand could therefore be calculated without difficulty, making the game one of pure analysis. Guesswork, psychology, inference and probabilitywhich are the life-blood of bridge-- were not involved.

Mr. and Mrs. I. Roy Psaty of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Merry C. Psaty, to George Everitt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everitt of Washington.

EARLY IN THE morning devotees gather on the beaches--Ipanema, Lebton, Flamengo, Copacabana and the rest. Huge fires are lit and there are occasional sacrifices of black goats, black cats, black chickens and frogs, all believed to be signs of evil. This festival takes place in and near Rio de Janeiro on Dec. 31--for the practitioilers of macumba it is the Day of Iemanjama, Protector of Women, Goddess of the Sea, and of the Immaculate Conception.

It was a mood in sharp contrast to that of many manufacturers in the men's suit and overcoat industry.

COLOGNE. GIGANTIC in dimension and enormously diverse in presentation and content, the 1970 Photokina biennial photographic exhibition that closed here on Oct. 11 after a nineday run was truly an international collection of the newest in photographic hardware. Although the United States participated, with 23 other countries, Germany, the host country, and Japan, dominated the scene--mostly with camera and lenses.

A floating restaurant is to be constructed in the East River close to the Manhattan shoreline at 30th Street and should be open by next summer, the city's Department of Ports and Terminals reported yesterday.

President Nixon's first domestic priority on assuming office was to temper excessive inflationary pressures while avoiding a recession. Now there are some signs that prices are rising less rapidly and that the economy is beginning to pick up steam (adjusting for the General Motors strike). Yet, the cost of the Administration's policy of economic restraint in terms of unemployed resources has been considerably higher than originally planned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- The Nixon Administration is moving to make the hydraheaded Federal science and technology apparatus more responsive to the nation's needs, a feat that has eluded the most herculean efforts of policy planners since the research and development boom began a generation ago.
Dartmouth scored a 10-0 victory yesterday over Yale in a meeting of unbeaten Ivy League football teams.
