Samuel S. Vaughan, executive editor of Doubleday Co., has been named publisher of the 73-year-old company. He becomes the first executive to be given the title since it was retired in 1928 with Frank Nelson Doubleday, founder of the publishing house.

On Oct. 7th the President announced an Indo-China peace initiative as a serious effort to lay the basis for a settlement of the conflict. This comprehensive program containing a number of features new to the U.S. negotiating position has the agreement and support of the governments of South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) Two predawn dynamite explosions ripped a military induction center and the office of a conservative newspaper today.

MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. John Wyckoff Van Siclen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Van Siclen, to David Bruce Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riger Wilmoth Townsend of Nutley, N.J. The wedding is planned for next month.

At both the national and state level, this campaign has been disfigured by deceitful advertising and ruthless distortion. President Nixon has set a bad example by his effort to link the Democrats with "thugs and hoodlums."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Federation of American Scientists charged today that the Nixon Administration's proposals for strategic-arms control was a "sham" because they would "legalize an accelerated arms race" through improvements in weapons.
Ernest Paris Seelman, a member of the Board of Higher Education from 1934 to 1943, and a retired lawyer, died Saturday at his home, 1062 84th Street, Brooklyn. He was 94 years old.

HASTINGS, N.Y., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wilson Roesing of Hastings and Manchester, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Roesing, to John Marinovich Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marinovich of Lake Intervale, N.J.

The Daily News, publishing the results of its third and final straw poll yesterday, predicted victory by a wide margin for Governor Rockefeller, but it described the United States Senate contest in New York State as "too close to call."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 (AP) Coach Clive Rush of the Boston Patriots suffered an apparent minor heart disorder today and missed most of the first half of the National Football League game with the Buffalo Bills.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Republicans completed arrangements today to put a final election appeal by President Nixon on television tomorrow night. Democrats, meanwhile, considered whether they should counter with an appearance by Senator Edmund S. Muskie.

Renata Scotto, a popular figure at the Metropolitan Opera since her debut there in 1965, is also a superb recitalist. Inaugurating a new series of Sunday afternoon concerts at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, the soprano delighted a large and friendly audience with a diverting assortment of Italian arias and songs, ranging more or less chronologically from Carissimi (1605-1674) to Verdi.

BRAINTREE, Mass., Nov. 1 (AP) William P. Marshall, 51 years old, of Braintree, identified by District Attorney George G. Burke as second vice president of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, was found dead in a cell at the Braintree police station at 7 P.M. yesterday, Mr. Burke disclosed today.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Nov. 1 A leading Puerto Rican educator called on the United States here today to grant conscientious objector status to young Puerto Ricans of draft age who favor total independence of their country from the United States.
Heinrich Bluecher, professor emeritus of philosophy at Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., died Saturday after an apparent heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 370 Riverside Drive.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 (Reuters) The commander of the Israeli navy, Maj. Gen. Avraham Botzer, today described Soviet naval bases in Egypt and Syria as the foundation for Soviet military activity in the Mediterranean.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 2 Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh, one of the most popular figures in South Vietnam, broke a year-long political silence yesterday with a broad hint that he would challenge Nguyen Van Thieu for the presidency next year.

Mrs. Willie Walker brought five pounds of chicken fried the way her mother taught her in Phoenix City, Ala., and Mrs. Winifred Kagwa brought a large container of rice and peas prepared in the Jamaica, West Indies, style.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 1 Miss Barbara Jay Arenberg, a teacher at the All Day Neighborhood Schools in New York, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Eric Green, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank M. Green of Rockville Centre, L.I.

Jim Duncan, who played under Don Shula for only one year, and Ron Gardin, who never played for him at all, helped the older Baltimore players frustrate their former coach yesterday as the Colts handed Miami its second straight shutout, 35 0.

The American Symphony has made Carnegie Hall its home ever since the orchestra was founded 10 years ago by Leopold Stokowski. This season, in addition to its Carnegie concerts, a new Philharmonic Hall series has been inaugurated, and the American Symphony presented its first program there yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Sunday Times expressed belief today that Jack the Ripper, infamous London murderer of nearly 100 years ago, was Ed-, ward, Duke of Clarence, grandson of Queen Victoria and older brother of King George V.

A midnight strike deadline threatened by Actors Equity Association against the Off Broadway theaters passed early today with both parties continuing their talks but with "absolutely no progress" reported on the major wage demand issues.

WAYNE, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) Two brothers who went hiking were found dead today in a sand pit where they apparently had been playing, just 75 yards behind their home. The police theorized that the boys were building a fortress, which collapsed and suffocated them.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 Torao Aramaki, president of the Isuzu Motor Company, Japan's fourth largest automobile manufacturer, announced today that his company has reached a broad agreement with the General Motors Corporation covering technical knowledge and sales. He said a vice president of Isuzu would visit the United States shortly to negotiate the details.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 1 Dr. Frederic Pomeroy Lord, a retired professor of anatomy at Dartmouth Medical School, died yesterday in a nursing home at the age of 94.
The District Attorneys of New York City have told the Police Department that a "vast majority" of the arrests made under one section of the state narcotic law have been "unwarranted and unlawful."

CAIRO, Nov. 1 Their spirits buoyed by price reductions on a range of products that include the allimportant tea and sugar, the Moslems of Egypt endured the second day of Ramadan today going without food, drink and even a soothing puff on a water pipe from dawn until sunset.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 1 Bryant (Babe) Hiskey of Hous ton wrote a new success story for the golf tour today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 Despite the financial plight that has forced many medical schools almost to bankruptcy, medical schools generally have sharply increased their total enrollment and the number of minority students this fall, the Association of American Medical Colleges reported at its annual meeting here today.
Aroused by a fist-swinging scene typical of a neighborhood rivalry, the Giants emerged yesterday as New York's pro football team for all seasons until 1974.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 Most of the news was bad for steel producers last week.

Young Rubicam has worked out an interesting deal with Cox Cable Communications under which it will handle the local programming and some of the advertising sales for a community antenna television system and then get half the ad revenues.

For years, Fran Tarkenton played the square to Joe Namath's swinger. Yet, the quarterbacks traded roles on the field. Tarkenton, the nonsmoking, nondrinking son of a Methodist minister, was a scrambler who put on, said one observer, "a high-wire act on a football field."

TOKYO Even in the most royal of families, children don't always tell their parents what they are going to do. And so it was when Mrs. Takako Shimazu, daughter of Emperor Hirohito, decided to break with family tradition and take a job.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) Dave Keon scored twice and assisted on another goal tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs rallied from a two-goal deficit and defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5-4.

LONDON, Nov. 1 The Rose and Crown, Wimbledon, has just won the prize as Pub of the Year. The proprietress, Mrs. Ann Jones, was delighted with such awards as a hand-knitted suit, 750 cigars and her own weight in sausages. But she has refused to accept a music system installed by Rediffusion Reditune, a British variant on Muzak.
Britain's defense program announced last week slows but does got stop her gradual withdrawal from global military responsibility.

Elizabeth of New Jersey opened the defense of the United States Challenge Cup yesterday by routing Trenton, 10-0, in one of more than 80 contests held throughout the country for the most coveted prize in American soccer.

Imagine a spacious nonreprepresentational painting in shades of gray against which a splash of bright orange red is placed somewhat to the right and slightly above the center. This is one man's visual equivalent of Gyorgy Ligeti's "Lontano," which was given its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night by the Los Angeles Philharmonic under the direction of Zubin Mehta.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 Cambodia declared herself a republic last month, but she has not decided what kind of a republic she wants to be.
Senator Thomas J. Dodd declined to say yesterday how he would vote on reorganization of the Senate if he was reelected.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 1 The "End of the Trail" the statue of an Indian warrior slumped over the back of an exhausted war pony was moved to a special exhibition hall here this weekend.

Mrs. Annette Rubinberg Schapiro and Marvin Krauss, vice president and marketing director of Esquire magazine, were married here yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Judah Cahn in his study at the Metropolitan Synagogue.

The Leo Burnett Company, the Chicago giant that began its overseas move last year with the biggest acquisition in agency history, has done it again. It has just announced that it has merged with Jackson Wain Co., Australia's second largest agency.
FORT LEE, N.J., Nov. 1 Dr. William I. Singer, a dentist with an office in Journal Square, Jersey City, died yesterday at his home, 1331 Anderson Avenue. He was 75 years old.
LONDON, Nov. 1 Diplomats who burned silently at the behavior of George Brown when he was Foreign Secretary are getting their own back.

Economics Laboratory, Inc., said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the business of the process chemicals and marine divisions of the Drew Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Slick Corporation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (UPI) Lou Hudson, hitting on 19 of 26 field-goals attempts, pumped in 43 points to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 131-107 victory tonight over the Cleveland Cavaliers in a National Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Nixon's primary political goal of 1970, Republican control of the Senate, appears to lie beyond his reach.

Tuesday, June 9, 1964. A day in the life of Lady Bird Johnson. In the morning she flies to Boston to deliver the baccalaureate address at Radcliffe, an event she has been dreading. But, first, a small luncheon at Radcliffe president Mary Bunting's residence. Then her talk. She performs well.

Twenty-five years after the start of the nuclear age in 1945, policy-formulating ideologists of the American establishment continue to advocate an American world mission: Pax Americana based upon U.S. military power. In the name of goals like a sustained U.S. armed presence in Asia, thinkers like W.W. Rostow and Henry Kissinger rationalize the priority use of this country's treasure and brains for building and operating ever more powerful nuclear and conventional forces.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 1 More than 100 Roman Catholic "traditionalists" staged a well-mannered revolt here today against what they described as the "modernist takeover" of the church's liturgy and teaching.

Stanley Charles Allyn, who retired at the end of 1961 as chairman of the board of the National Cash Register Company, died Saturday night in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital at the age of 79. He lived in Day ton, Ohio, and also had a home in Greenwich.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 2 (AP) Vietcong gunners were reported to have shelled Saigon early today for the first time in three months, and authorities reported six Vietnamese were killed and 15 wounded and a cluster of houses was destroyed.

Governor Rockefeller and Arthur J. Goldberg, debating for the last times in the gubernatorial campaign, sharply dis- agreed yesterday on the need for changes in the state's abortion law, a possible commuter tax increase and the campaign tactics of President Nixon and Vice President Agnew.

New York's three Senatorial candidates attacked one another, with such phrases as "misrepresentation and fraud," "despicable" and "if, you can read English" yesterday in their fourth and final television debate of the campaign.

A consortium of four giant European banks, which already has joint ventures all aver the world, announced yesterday the formation of a new company, designed, in effect, to coordinate the operations of its members even more closely than before.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 1 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa captured his second major Australian golf tournament in two weeks today with a final round of 71 for a 282 total in the Dunlop international. His prize today was $4,480.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 1 "Agnew Is Doing Our Thing," declared a placard waved in the air by a white-haired woman in Tulsa, Okla., the other day. A retort came, in effect, on the sign of a young man in Lubbock, Tex.: "Silent Majority, shut up."
WARSAW, Nov. 1 Candles flickered on graves throughout Poland today as the nation paused to remember its dead on All Saints Day.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 1 (AP) Gen. Cesar Rohn Sandoval, commander of Ecuador's Air Force who was kidnapped Tuesday, was freed today. A Government communique said he had stepped off a bus alone in front of an air force base on Quito's outskirts.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 1 The Soviet delegation arrived by train from Moscow today for the resumption to- morrow of negotiations with the United States on the limitation of strategic arms.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 1 The young radicals who planned the demonstration against President Nixon here last Thursday feel that the President has exaggerated what happened that night for his own political advantage.

The near-collapse of Goodbody Co., coupled with earlier brokerage house failures during the bear market, may lead to drastic revisions of the capital rules under which Wall Street's investment concerns traditionally have done business.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 1 "Here Is No. 19," a police official said as he handed out photographs to newsmen yesterday.

Dr. Dan F. Bradley, professor of polymer chemistry at Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, and a leading specialist in biopolymer research, died Saturday of a massive cerebral hemorrhage. He was 41 years old and lived at 32 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

SAINT-LAURENT-DU-PONT, France, Nov. 1 A fire in a dance hall in this village killed 142 persons early today, trapping them behind emergency exits that firemen and survivors said had been padlocked and then nailed shut with planks to keep out anyone without a ticket.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 1 A claim for $14,000 damages has been lodged against the Minister of Police and a security branch interrogator by the widow of an African who was found hanged in a prison cell last year.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he might consider a partial return to the system in which only one policeman was assiged to a patrol car.
Fires that have taken 100 or more lives have struck around the world 28 times in the last 100 years, including the latest fire, at Saint-Laurent-du-Pont, France.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyers gained a 3-0 lead over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight and then had to stave off a rally to score a 3-2 victory.
Governor Rockefeller announced the approval of six grants totaling more than $800,000 to youth drug abuse programs in the New York City metropolitan area yesterday.

The team of Lew Mathe, Don Krauss, John Swanson and Dick Walsh, all of Los Angeles, won the right to represent the United States in the 1971 world championship by staging an astonishing recovery in the international playoff match, which ended at the New York Hilton here yesterday afternoon.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 1 Rum Customer is the evenmoney favorite tomorrow night in the $50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. A field of six will go postward in the mile-and-a-half race.

KENWOOD, Mr., Nov. 1 (AP) Joseph T. Geuting Jr., a developer of the light-aircraft industry and a founder of Project Hope of the International Health Foundation, died at his home here yesterday after a short illness. He was 61 years old.

Austin Philips Montgomery, who retired in 1968 as president of A.P. Montgomery Co., over-the-counter stockbrokers, died Saturday night in Midtown Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 51 East 90th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The chairman of the House Banking Committee said today that the nation's economic troubles were the result of the Nixon Administration's letting bankers and businessmen do as they please.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 1 The extra $330-million financial burden imposed by the revolutionary Libyan Government on United States and British oil producers is having repercussions throughout the oil world.
Men who served with Richard M. Nixon in the Navy in World War II say he was a consistent winner at poker, Life magazine said yesterday.
The formation of a committee on environmental affairs has been announced by the American Association of Port Authorities.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (UPI) Four persons were injured today when an antique, muzzle-loading cannon discharged prematurely during a football half-time show. The show, during the New Orleans Saints-Los Angeles Rams football game, featured a re-creation of the Battle of New Orleans.

A cocktail buffet will be held at the National Art Museum of Sport at Madison Square Garden Center Wednesday evening to preview a two-week exhibition and sale of English field and yachting paintings of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.

NORTH CASTLE, N.Y., Nov. 1 After five months of con troversy, a proposal to put up office buildings on 311 acres of residential land here appears to be dead because the development would cost the town millions of dollars.

In a spot check of 46,731 trucks, highway tractors, trailers and semi-trailers inspected last year by the Federal Highway Administration's Bureau of Motor Carrier Safety, 10,781 or 23.1 per cent, were found to be mechanically unsafe, the agency has reported. The rejected vehicles were removed from service for repairs.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) Denis Hulme of New Zealand led from the start today as he captured the 201.3mile annual Times Grand Prix by 8.2 seconds from Jackie Oliver of England. It was the final event of the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup series.

At half-time, losing, 7-3, the Giants were told off in blunt and impassioned tones by Alex Webster, their coach, who isn't ordinarily given to locker-room oratory. The Giants weren't hitting, they were letting the Jets come at them instead of the other way round, and they were letting, their most important game get away.

Rhetorical attacks on "radical liberals" by those seeking to accentuate a conservative swing in American political thought have all but obscured the startling degree to which such a swing is actually taking place. This is not the year of the "radical liberal" at all. It is, instead, the year of the "radical reactionary."
ATHENS, Nov. 1 Greece has announced plans to build a new Athens international airport inland from the present seaside site and designed for the air traffic of the nineteeneighties.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 1 Dr. Noam Chomsky told the third annual convention of the Association of Arab-American University Graduates today that neither Israel nor the Palestinian commando movement could really win the Middle Eastern conflict.

Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, in prohibiting the publication and distribution at government expense of a Congressional list of allegedly radical campus speakers, has eloquently defined the issue before the court as the suppression of free speech through the abuse of official powers.

The city's Budget Director said yesterday that mandatory increases in costs alone could result in an increase of $100million in spending out of city tax funds above the original estimates for the current budget.
Bertram B. Geyer, long a leader in the advertising agency field, died on Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Tucked away in the Smithsonian Institution, if one may trust the telephone directory, is an organization named the Center for ShortLived Phenomena. Without knowing what the center does, one would nominate it on name alone as an ideal sponsor of contemporary music festivals. By nature, such festivals must deal overwhelmingly in the frailest and most perishable of phenomena newborn musical scores.

At their peak which came with five minutes to go in the third quarter the Jets held a 10-3 lead over the Giants they had just halted the Giants on the 1-foot line and they had held their own in a brief free-for-all on the field.

Midtown Eighth Avenue, where crowds lingering seven days a week include drug addicts, homosexuals, prostitutes, vagrants and thieves, has one of the highest arrest records in the city and some of its toughest problems of law enforcement.

HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 2 Communist China has revived a proposal, advanced occasionally in the past, that a conference of big and small powers be held to discuss the prohibition and destruction of nuclear weapons.

Preliminary reports on contributions filed with the State Bureau of Elections added still more heat yesterday to what has been a subject of debate in the three-way race here for United States Senator campaign spending.
ROME, Nov. 1 Pope Paul VI said today that "all must pray" for an extension of the cease-fire in the Middle East after Thursday.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight R. Little Jr. of Haydenville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Bradshaw Little, to Warren Bicknell King, son of Mrs. Elizabeth King of Cleveland and the late Ralph T. King.

Albert Pleydell, who served as Commissioner of Purchases under Mayors Fiorello H. LaGuardia and William O'Dwyer, died yesterday at his home. He was 65 years old and lived at 88-23 Gettysburg Street, Bellerose, Queens.
When Dr. Emil P. Dolensek says, "The next patient, please," it will probably be an elephant, tiger, giraffe, snake, alligator or flamingo.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 Premier Eisaku Sato, reviewing the 20th anniversary parade of Japan's Self-Defense Forces today, reaffirmed his Government's policy of reliance on its own defense efforts plus its security treaty with the United States to maintain peace and security in the Far East.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 1 Princeton University finished today's racing with the low total of 21 points to win the Shields Trophy after two days of sailing in Long Island Sound off the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) A new study by an economist shows that half the nation's urban poor belong to families locked so deeply into poverty that they cannot escape unaided "at any time in the future."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1 (AP) Joseph Rhodes Jr., a member of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest, charged today that President Nixon had "deliberately ignored our real problems" and had "sought to play on our fears and hatred for his own political gains."

POPULATION The vast majority of the 409,358 people in the 18th Congressional District are blacks' who live in Harlem, while smaller proportions of the population are made up of Puerto Ricans in a slice of East Harlem and middle-class whites in a sliver of the West Side.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 Gary Cuozzo, earnest, soft-spoken and quiet, had his best game as the regular quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings today when his team humbled the Detroit Lions, 30-17, in a contest that was difficult for the first half, easy the second.
INDIAN TOWNSHIP, Me., Nov. 1 The Economic Development Administration has granted $436,000 to the Passamaquoddy Indians.

Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, charged yesterday that an aggressive diversification program that the Penn Central Transportation Company began in 1963 "contributed significantly" to the railroad's ultimate financial collapse last June 21.

Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and for The Daily News and The New York Times attempted last night to work out agreements in separate sessions that would avert a strike at one of the newspapers today.
In the 23 years since the fall of Hitler's Third Reich, an Israeli bibliographer has hunted down and recovered more than a million Jewish books looted by the Nazis.

The second installment of James Flexner's multi-volumed life of Washington left the general at Yorktown a vindication of nine years' battling in the field. However, that earlier book did not show Washington as an altogether brilliant commander.

Miss Rose Ann Stargardter, a doctoral candidate at Harvard, was married here yesterday afternoon to Tilden G. Edelstein, a history professor at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., where the bride is a lecturer.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 In the midst of an acute housing shortage, St. Louis is boarding up 26 eleven-story apartment buildings, part of a $36-million housing project built 15 years ago and not yet paid for.
The taxpayer who can tally up several hundred dollars worth of business expenses has quite an advantage over the taxpayer who cannot take such deductions off the top of income.

LONDON After the first week of the Royal Court Theater's new season, the critic of the British Broadcasting Corporation's literary magazine, The Listener, asked: "Can this clannish and intimate cellar-work stand the cold scrutiny of strangers in Chelsea?"
The credit markets are thoroughly convinced that the sluggish economy and the General Motors strike will force the Federal Reserve to take some step toward monetary ease this month.

If prices of items that are predominantly advertised by the nation's department, specialty and general merchandise stores are a criterion, it appears that inflation was practically halted in September.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1 When a massive antiwar demonstration was proposed recently for the Town Green here this weekend, many people at Yale fretted that it might hurt local peace candidates because voters were getting weary of all demonstrations. There were other misgivings, too.
CONGERS, N.Y., Nov. 1 Thomas V. Winn, vice president in charge of sales of Montfort Bros. of Fishkill, manufacturer of concrete building blocks, died in Nyack Hospital today. He was 71 years old.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 1 A sable-and-white Shetland sheepdog, Ch. Pixie Dell Epicure, did the "impossible" today, when the 6-year-old was named best of the 608 dogs at the 31st Union County Kennel Club fixture at the Elizabeth National Guard Armory.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 1 President Nixon conferred with Vice President Agnew today and later sent the Vice President out to accuse the Democrats of "fear and scare tactics," particularly on economic issues.

The Hartford Life Insurance Company, with nearly $3-billion of life insurance in force, has announced what it termed "a completely new business approach" for the company, with the formation of a general agency system to supplement its independent agents and brokers.

The International Dancers of Brigham Young University are bright, shiny and' enthusiastic. The dancers, all students, are also something less than professional but more than amateur. They have folk dances from a dozen countries in their repertory and present them with the relentless gaiety of a color spread in the National Geographic.

Nelson G. Gross, the Republican candidate in New Jersey's campaign for United States Senator, and his Democratic opponent, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., challenged each other yesterday on their relationship with the Hudson County Democratic organization.

TRENTON, Nov. 1 The school board voted tonight to reopen the city's public schools, closed last Friday because of clashes between black and white youths over a plan to bus students between predominantly black and white schools.

The amazing versatility of the late Kurt Weill, the composer, has been suitably remembered on television since his death in 1950 but not often quite so interestingly as in last night's hour starring Georgia Brown, the British vocalist. The program was seen on the Public Broadcasting Service (Channel 13).

ROCHESTER, Nov. 1 (AP) Forty persons were held up early today at a party by three masked men who fled with four hostages and then wounded two policemen. Two suspects in the robbery were captured in a shootout and the hostages were rescued unharmed.

The work jacket in dark brown mink for men isn't revolutionary, see, because the revolution is over. That's the word from Bonwit Teller, which began agitating for men's fashion reform just five years ago.

OKLAHOMA CITY Oklahoma Democrats, shut out of the statehouse for eight years, are making a united effort to unseat Gov. Dewey F. Bartlett, a 51-year-old Tulsa oilman. Mr. Bartlett is the first Oklahoma Governor eligible to succeed himself.

A 25-year-old Philadelphia woman, apparently outraged that her car had been towed away, staged a drive-out at the city's car pound, the police said, crashing the chain barrier and knocking down a policeman before being captured 13 blocks away.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 A Polish Deputy Foreign Minister, Zygfryd Wolniak, and three Pakistanis were killed today at Karachi International Airport when an airline van ran into a reception line formed to welcome the Polish President, Marshal Marian Spychalski, here.

DUBLIN, Nov. 1 The Irish banks, slowly recovering from a six-month strike that was devastating in its effects, still face a severe test Nov. 17 when they finally open their doors to the public.

The New York Athletic Club placed five runners among the first seven finishers yesterday and won the national Amateur Athletic Union 3,000-meter team title at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The Winged Foot runners triumphed with 21 points. C.W. Post College was second with 63.
DALLAS, Nov. 1 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate; released an 80-page report today alleging massive undervaluation of oil, timber and commercial land in Texas.

WASHINGTON A few years ago Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee gave a good example of the historical play with "Inherit the Wind." A radio network to enable crewmen on 160 Penn Central commuter and rail-diesel cars on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines to report trouble immediately instead of having to stop the train and go to the nearest wayside telephone will go into operation today.

Service on local BMT lines between Manhattan and Brooklyn was suspended for three hours last night after a Transit Authority employe found what he thought was a bomb on the Court Street station platform.

WATERVILLE, Maine, Nov. 1 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, asked Attorney General John N. Mitchell today to investigate "possible violations of federal law" by the Committee for a Responsible Congress.

The German-built Opel automobile line for the United States market has been expanded to 10 models for 1971 with the introduction of four new cars in the 1900 series. All the cars are manufactured in West Germany by the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Idle Dice, a 6-year-old open jumper owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill, was first the second time in a row and won the President's Cup tonight at the close of the Washington International Horse Show.
STRASBOURG, France Alsace, the most disputed and war-ravaged region of France, is building new defenses against a new form of challenge from her German neighbors.

An experiment that will seek to solve the continuing crisis of inadequate care for the city's 3,000 homeless children by intensive door-to-door efforts to recruit foster parents was begun yesterday by three religious federations.

ATLANTA, Nov. 1 (AP) Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth, Tex., a 10-year competitor on the women's professional golf tour, has been named the Ladies' Professional Golf Association 1970 Player of the Year, an award Kathy Whitworth had won annually since its inception in 1966.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 1 (AP) Bill Melchionni scored 23 points tonight to lead the New York Nets to a 121109 victory over the Virginia Squires, snapping a three-game American Basketball Association losing streak.
Jeannine Altmeyer, a tall, slender blonde from La Habra, Calif., won first prize yesterday in the finals of the Metropolitan Opera National Council's 1970 auditions at the Met.

Prime Minister Heath projects an economic and social policy for Britain dramatically different not only from that of the preceding Labor Government but from those of his Tory predecessors from 1951 to 1964. The professed aim is to enable the individual to keep more of his earnings and have more incentive to increase them, but some experts say it may not work that way for many middle-class Britons.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 1 (UPI) Wally Lemm, the head coach of the Houston Oilers, told his players last night, after a humiliating 44-0 loss to St. Louis, that he would resign at the end of the season.
Eight persons, three of them Canadians, were killed and two others were injured yesterday afternoon in separate collisions of light planes in the Western United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Justice Department is investigating campaign donations by bankers after the disclosure that large contributions went to lawmakers closely involved with a bank bill now pending in Congress.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that liberals were just as concerned with law and order as conservatives. The difference, is that the conservatives' "only remedy is repression" while the liberals are ready to attack the causes.
President Nixon led many persons prominent in religion, in national life and in the arts yesterday in paying tribute to Richard Cardinal Cushing, who died in Boston at the age of 75.

SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 2Gerald J. Burke, vice president in charge of advertising for the international divisions of the Sterling Drug Company, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital here. He was 59 years old and lived here at 43 Harvey Drive.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 The nation's last overnight passenger steamboat, the Greene Line's Delta Queen, finished what was probably her last trip today. The Queen does not meet the requirements of a Federal safety law.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 2 The Caracas Stock Exchange, a tiny clublike institution, is eagerly awaiting the Government's new tough Securities and Exchange Law that will be sent to Congress here this month.
The three men seeking the Senate seat once held by Robert F. Kennedy made their final appeals to New York voters yesterday, closing the campaign with much the same strategies that began it.
HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Wally Lemm, the Houston Oilers' head coach, said today, "When the game starts eating your guts out, it's time to quit."

WESTBURY, L. I, Nov. 2 Horton Hanover captured the 1 1/2-mile 50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. With Joe O'Brien in the sulky, the 5year-old son of Star's PrideHighland Lassie was moved late but vigorously by O'Brien and the result was a one-length decision over Super Wave, who saved the place by a neck from the favored Rum Customer.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Nov. 2 (UPI) Emile Griffith, former world middleweight and welterweight champion, was released on $1,000 bail today after being booked as a material witness in connection with a shooting in his apartment here.

Bring together three excellent musicians who are strangers, and you do not necessarily have an excellent trio. Bring together three excellent musicians who have known one another professionally for 15 years, and you have no guarantee either, but the chances become considerably better. The AlsopBernstein Trio, which made its New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, fell in the latter category and landed squarely on its feet.

Pentecostalism, a form of religious piety that emphasizes spontaneous and emotional outpourings of prayer and has generally been identifed with Protestant Christianity, is rapidly becoming an important new force among Roman Catholics.

PHNOMPENH, Cambria, Nov. 1-A Cambodian Army lieutenant who recently escaped after six weeks as a prisoner of war has said in an interview that under persistent pressure large numbers of Cambodian peasants are joining the Communist forces commanded by Vietnamese invaders.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (UPI) Terry Hanratty, a substitute quarterback, rallied the sluggish Pittsburgh Steelers to two fourth-quarter touchdowns and a 21-10 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals tonight. The Steelers moved within a game of the lead in the American Football Conference's Central Division.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 2-- The United States and the Soviet Union resumed their talks on limitation of strategic arms in a cordial atmosphere today, with both sides expressing hope that gains could be made in curbing the nuclear arms race.
PARIS, Nov. 2 Gold prices have swung within an unusually wide are in the last week, demonstrating more than anything else that the metal is responding to market forces just like any other commodity.

The Manchester Bank, Manchester, N. H., opened for business yesterday as the state's largest commercial bank, with $145-million in assets. The opening completed the conversion of the Manchester Savings Bank from a depositor-owned mutual savings bank to a stockholder-owned commercial bank.

Three persons now serving as "community" principals of schools in Manhattan announced yesterday that they had withdrawn from the licensing examination for elementary school principal that is scheduled to be given today.
LISBON, Nov. 2-The Rev. Billy Graham has come to Portugal for the first time, and his visit reflects a new religious tolerance among the leaders of this largely Roman Catholic country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 Nearly two thousand Roman Catholics gathered in the rain today around the unmarked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem while the city around them took a Government holiday to celebrate President Dlem's overthrow and assassination seven years ago.

BOSTON, Nov. 2-- There was only one active professional resident theater left in Boston--until today. Now there is none. The 14-year-old Charles Playhouse gave its final performance last night of the first play of the season, Wilford Leach's "In Zones." It is closed indefinitely, perhaps permanently.

About six million New York voters will choose today between two of America's bestknown men for Governor and decide a three-way race for United States Senator that has at least temporarily shattered the state's two-party system and become the most closely studied contest in the country.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Nov. 2 (AP) A group of armed inmates seized four hostages early today and threatened to kill them in an attempt to win freedom from the Cummins Prison Farm. But the inmates surrendered 13 hours later.
Miss Susan Goulding Clark, an actress with Universal Studios, and Robert L. Joseph, a writer-producer there, plan to be married in December.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Construction activity continued to rise in September, reaching a near-record annual rate of $92.7-billion, the Commerce Department said today.

PARIS Nov. 2-Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, chief negotiator for the Vietcong at the Vietnam peace talks here, indicated today that her side might be prepared to deal with a South Vietnamese government headed by Gen. Duong Van Minh.
DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 2 -Beekeeping in this poor West African country is suddenly being brought up to date, thanks to the advice of an expert on loan from a kibbutz in Israel.

HOUSTON, Nov. 2 Representatives of a coalition of 12 liberal and radical groups, most of them antiwar, accused the Houston Police Department today of protecting two "nightrider" members of the Ku Klux Klan who allegedly committed vandalism.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2-A three-member United Nations investigating committee today urged the General Assembly to demand that Israel immediately cease what the committee called continuous violations of human rights in Israelioccupied Arab territories.

Waiters and dining-room employee in more than 350 restaurants here agreed yesterday to put off a strike until this afternoon. They acted after the state's top mediator had asked union officials to delay the walkout.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell announced yesterday his endorsement of Charles Taylor, the Liberal party candidate, as his successor in the House of Representatives.

The Newspaper Guild, the 10th and last of the newspaper unions negotiating new contracts here, reached agreements early yesterday with The New York Times and The Daily News, averting a threatened strike.

Not long ago, Dr. Benjamin Spock overheard a college psychiatrist say at a symposium that many students who don't consider themselves ready to enter into a premarital affair are made to feel "abnormal, frigid or perverse."
LIVONIA, Mich., Nov. 2 (AP) The final race at Hazel Park Race Track was canceled today when authorities reported four of the scheduled seven thoroughbred starters had been tranquilized.

Six persons reportedly involved in "a Weatherman operation" were seized here yesterday in raids that the police said yielded material for making bombs, equipment for forging draft card's and maps of major buildings in New York and Chi-. cago.

Mrs. Dollree Mapp, the' appellant in a landmark decision of the United States Supreme Court barring the admission of evidence seized without a warrant, was arrested in her Queens home yesterday by police who said they found $250,000 in narcotics and stolen property. They had entered with a search warrant.

The New York Times/ Yankelovich survey, which began Sept. 15, is based on a daily series of 40 to 60 interviews conducted by telephone with persons whose names were selected from state voter registration lists.

Schubert's 600 songs cover a wide scope of moods and attitudes. While exploring this vast reservoir, Hermann Prey hit upon the idea of taking 20 lyrics and fashioning a cycle from them. The results, entitled "Life's Journey in Song," were presented by the baritone Sunday night in Carnegie Hall.
The price of Qiana, a luxury nylon yarn that was introduced in June, 1968, is being cut for the first time, it was announced yesterday.

Robert S. Lynd, one of the founding fathers of modern American sociology and coauthor, with his wife, Helen Merrell Lynd, of "Middletown" and "Middletown in Transition," died Sunday in Warren, Conn., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 560 Riverside Drive here.
The stock market, playing another round in its favorite current game of wait-and-see, managed to creep slightly higher yesterday.

In the spirit of Pope John XXIII, Cardinal Cushing was an ecumenist who dealt with people rather than with the niceties of theology. Thus, in appealing for brotherhood, he preached in Protestant pulpits, visited a Masonic lodge and courted Jewish congregations, firm in the conviction that most people "may not be too well informed on faith, but they loved God."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 In an attempt to combat the growing problem of oil pollution on the high seas, the United States has proposed a sweeping international agreement to do away with the practice of flushing tankers at sea.

PARIS, Nov. 2-- French authorities filed a charge of homicide by negligence against persons unknown today in the fire that swept an Alpine dance hall early yesterday. Two more youths died of burns today, raising the toll to 144, the worst in recent French memory.

Elina Mooney's dancing has a pert animal vivacity that borders on the untidy primal at its most uninhibited but infuses pulsing life into all of her works. Last night at the Cubiculo she offered a program of four pieces that touched upon the poignant, the playful and brute love.

Despite a new safety code for cranes adopted by the city about a year ago, there have been 17 crane or derrick accidents since then.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) President Nixon arrived here by helicopter in midafternoon today to visit his 90-year-old aunt, Mrs. Edith Timberlake, who is a patient at Beverly Manor, a convalescent home.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP)-- Buckingham Palace said today that "we have no comment" to make on an account of Jack the Ripper published here yesterday suggesting that the notorious l9th-century murderer was a member of the British royal family.
There are a number of key races for Senator and Governor in today's election among the contests for those offices throughout the nation.
WARSAW, Nov. 2 Walter Scheel, the West German Foreign Minister, arrived here today for what is expected to be the final round of talks leading to diplomatic relations with Poland.

Philip J. Levin will become president, chairman of the executive committee and chief operating officer of the Madison Square Garden Corporation upon completion of the merger of the Transnation Developmen Corporation into the Garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 Britain urged today that the General Assembly cut through "the miasma of charges and countercharges" about cease-fire violations in the Middle East by adopting a simple call for an extension of the truce and for an early resumption of Arab-Israeli peace talks.
The Consolidated Edison Company was fined $5,000 yesterday after pleading guilty to discharging oil from an East River plant and from a Hudson River barge.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 2 Joe Moresco of the Woodmere Club was re-elected president of the Metropolitan Section of the Professional Golfers' Association today at the annual meeting at Westchester County club.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 New Jersey's campaign for United States Senator drew to a close this evening in the populous northern counties where tomorrow's election is likely to be decided.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 3-- The United States command has doubled the leave time available to soldiers serving in Vietnam to enable them to hitch a free ride back to the United States for a two week visit.

With boxing's appeal enhanced by Muhammad Ali's successful comeback last week, Madison Square Garden is negotiating to display the unrecognized champion against Oscar Bonavena on Dec. 7 in a heavyweight bout that originally had been arranged with Miami Beach as the site.

Dr. Jonas E. Salk said yesterday that mankind is in the midst of a transition from an epoch of competition and individualism to an epoch of cooperation and interdependence. The new era, he estimated, is about three generations away.
James F. O'Leary, newspaperman and press spokesman since 1943 for District Atorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County, died Saturday in Montefiore Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

The new president and publisher of Newsday, William Attwood, announced four major editorial appointments at the Long Island newspaper yesterday.
TORONTO, Nov. 2 The Ryerson Press, Canada's oldest publishing house, will be sold to an American multinational corporation.

Earnings of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation were pushed down sharply by substantially larger aircraft costs, a rise in interest expense and general and administrative expenditures, it was reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 (UPI) -Top-seeded Manuel Orantes of Spain defeated Patricio Rodriguez, of Chile, 6-3, 5-7, 6-2, 6-1, in the second round of the South American open international tennis championships today. The event is part of the $200,000 world Grand Prix.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2-- The Administration's top spokesman on energy matters said today "we believe that a near-term balance between domestic needs and supplies" of fuel oil "generally has been achieved."

Time Inc. yesterday named Worthington S. Mayer the advertising director of Life. He succeeds Lee Heffner, who after 18 months as ad director and associate publisher, is becoming assistant to Bernhard M. Auer, executive vice president of Time Inc.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 2-It was a completely average game -almost for the New York Knicks tonight as they squandered a 24-point advantage, but hung on and defeated the San Francisco Warriors, 111-99, at Oakland Coliseum.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 Policemen patrolled the almost-empty Trenton High School as schools reopened today for the first time since Thursday.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., raised its regular quarterly dividend and declared an extra yearend payment to shareholders yesterday after reporting, that sales and earnings in the third quarter and first nine months of 1970 reached record levels.

Nancy McCarthy, a former WPIX news writer, yesterday depicted Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, as intimately involved with the presentation of news on his station, calling during and after newscasts to complain or make suggestions.

PEKING, Nov. 2-Prince Norodom Sihanouk indicated today that he was watching the American political scene closely.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 2 (Reuters) Four-nation talks scheduled in Amsterdam tomorrow on whether Britain should rejoin the European airbus project have been postponed at the request of Britain, the Transport Ministry confirmed here today.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 2 Hertha I. Hanssen, who headed the comparison shopping service for Macy's New York for many years, died on Friday at her home here after a long illness. She was 80 years old.

An Argentine citizen was held here yesterday in $350,000 bail after narcotics detectives described him as the head of a ring that supplied 90 per cent of the cocaine brought into the United States from South America.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) Najeeb Halaby, the president of Pan American World Airways, suggested today that prospective buyers of the Concorde, the British-French supersonic airliner, be given a chance to try the plane in passenger service before deciding whether to buy it.`

A detective testified yesterday that Robert Collier, one of 13 defendants on trial for allegedly participating in a Black Panther conspiracy, admitted owning a can of gunpowder and "pipe bombs" found in his apartment.

In the last day at an intensive campaign, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and his Democratic opponent, Adam Walinsky, contrasted once again yesterday their views of the office they have been contesting.

After five years of Sunday afternoon jazz concerts at Your Father's Mustache, Seventh Avenue and 10th Street, the Southampton Dixie, Racing and Clambake Society Jazz Band has moved those performances to the Red Garter, 15 West Fourth Street. Its place on the bandstand at Your Father's Mustache has been taken by a sextet called Balaban and Cats.

MIAMI, Nov. 2 (UPI)-- A Mexican-American took one stewardess hostage, instructed another to take care of his two small children, and hijacked a United Air Lines commuter flight to Cuba, the crew reported today.
Project Hope, which is marking its 10th anniversary in New York, will benefit from a supper dance at the Tavern-on-the-Green tomorrow night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 2 The United States has ordered the accelerated closing of three United States Air Force scientific observation stations in Chile, Where Dr. Salvador Allende, a Marxist, takes office tomorrow as President.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 Richard Cardinal Cushing died at his home today, a day celebrated in the Roman Catholic Church as All Souls Day, when the faithful pray for the dead. He was 75 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 After a year of relative quiet, a group of reformers in the State Department has revived efforts to unionize the career diplomatic service.
BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 2 An Atomic Energy Commission scientist said today that small amounts of radioactive plutonium had been found in desert soil outside the agency's Nevada test site.

New York State voters will elect a Governor, a United States Senator, 41 Representatives, 207 state legislators and members of the Judiciary in today's election. They will also fill certain local offices, and decide a proposition that housing subsidies be increased. Polls open at 6 A.M. and close at 9 P.M.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 27 Unless Turkey gets firm American support for the drive to halt the smuggling of art and antiquities, American archeologists who have been excavating here for years may have to go else where to dig.

DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 2 The engagement of Miss Margaret Watson Thompson to Thomas Sumter Weekley Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Weekley of Scotch Plains, N. J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William David Thompson. A wedding in the spring is planned.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 2Henry G. Alsberg, who headed the Federal Writers' Project of the Works Progress Administration during the Depression, died of uremia yesterday in Stanford Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived here with his sister, Elsa Alsberg.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau introduced in Parliament today legislation to limit the sweeping powers of the War Measures Act, which he had invoked to suppress terrorism in Quebec.

Steel production rose last week by 2.3 per cent, compared to output the week before. It was the first gain in the last six weeks, but production has held remarkably firm in the face of the seven-week General Motors Corporation strike and other factors tending to soften the steel markets.

Prices advanced and interest rates declined throughout the money and capital markets yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 2 World military expenditures leveled off last year but nuclear stockpiles were vast enough to blast every person in the world with the equivalent of 15 tons of TNT, a wide-ranging survey of armament and disarmament said toddy.

Peter M. Brown, a personal assistant to two publishers of The New York Times, died Sunday in Union Hospital in the Bronx at the age of 68. Since his retirement in 1963, he had been living at 2400 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) The Soviet Union has been testing a satellite designed to destroy United States military satellites, a British scientist said today.

Warriner of Ardsley and Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy, Rutter Warriner, to Stephen Condict Walke Jr., son of the Rev. BRUSSELS, Nov. 4--Britain took the lead today in rejecting a United States proposal for a European contribution to the post-Apollo program. The move came at a 13-nation conference of members of the two European organizations for space and launching research.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--The United States warned Britain today against proposed import levies that threaten to jeopardize United States grain exports to the United Kingdom. These exports last year were worth $114.5-million.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 4 --The recent flurry of tranquilizing cases that has struck race tracks in this country and Canada has put virtually all courses on special alert. The French bridge world mourned this summer the loss of Dr. Georges Theron, who died of a heart attack at the age of 48. They represented France in four world events, including the Team Olympiad here in 1964, and won one European team title.
A second independent maker of copper products has quietly filed an antitrust suit against the nation's leading producers of primary copper.

Two London newspapers said yesterday that President Nixon had suffered a setback in the off-year elections. The Moscow press said Republicans had failed in a campaign to take control of Congress. And Japan saw the voting as a swing toward conservatism in American politics.

John Harmon Noble, who retired in 1965 as sales manager and chief executive of the Improved Machinery Corporation, died Wednesday in a convalescent home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived at 4810 Boston Post Road, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

Milton M. Stuart, senior partner of Stuart Brothers, investment brokers of 55 Broad Street, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 895 Park Avenue and in Cos Cob, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla.
DETROIT, Nov. 4--The Detroit automobile makers, as an industry, are heading for their worst sales year since 1962.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4-- The Democrats of the Old Confederacy frustrated the Nixon Administration's so-called Southern strategy in all but one state yesterday and proved that their own party was not so near death in Dixie as some had thought.

HARTFORD, Nov. 4--Political power that has been in the hands of the Democratic party in Connecticut for the last 16 years shifted yesterday to the Republicans with the solid victory of Thomas J. Meskill for Governor.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4--Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he now envisioned his role in the Democratic party as that of a "harmonizer" who would try to prevent Democratic Presidential aspirants from cutting themselves to pieces before they could decide who would run in 1972.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 4--Nebraska's senior Senator, Roman L. Hruska, received the fright of his political life in yesterday's general election before being assured of a third full term.

Edinboro State College has played varsity football for 44 seasons and produced only four winning teams prior to this year. The best of the winning squads was the 1928 team, which had a 5-2 wonlost record.

The London stock market extended Tuesday's rally yesterday following the upsurge on Wall Street. Buying support was limited, however, while investors awaited the imminent Government monetary policy statement.

Muhammad Ali and Oscar Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight champion, will sign today to meet in a 15round bout at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, Dec. 7.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)-- Sharp goaltending by Glenn Hall and Ernie Wakely paced the St. Louis Blues to a 2-0 victory tonight that ended the Boston Bruins' unbeaten home streak at 22 games.
The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would nationally market the office copying machine that it introduced in April on a regional basis.
TRENTON, Nov. 5--A controversial new law that gives the state vast power to regulate the development of New Jersey's coastal wetlands was signed here today by Gov. William T. Cahill.
The Jets aren't the only ones with quarterback problems. Terry Bradshaw has them, too.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1969.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--A minor additive in leaded gasoline has been found to produce adverse genetic effects in mice.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5-- The Sierra Club carried its fight against a Walt Disney resort in the Sierra Nevadas to the Supreme Court today.

"The Battle of Algiers," a dramatic re-enactment on film of the urban guerrilla warfare waged in the nineteen-fifties against the French, was shown in State Supreme Court yesterday at the trial of the 13 Black Panthers.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 5 --South Korean defense officials appeared embarrassed today by the United States decision to withdraw American troops from the demilitarized zone.

John E. Porta has been appointed president and a director, and Richard E. Baiter Jr. has been made a senior vice president and director of the Union Commerce Bank in Cleveland. Heinz Schneider was promoted to vice chairman from executive vice president.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 5-- President Salvador Allende Gossens, making his first political speech since taking office Tuesday, said today that his Government would create "a republic of the working class" in Chile.

Six persons were in hospitals here yesterday as a result of injuries sustained Wednesday night when a Pan American World Airways 747 jetliner encountered air turbulence and went into a sudden, steep descent near Nantucket Island.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) --The 6-cent 1970 Christmas stamps--which for the first time come in a choice of five pictures--went on sale today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3--Though there are maxiskirts and new-model cars on the streets and Christian Dior dresses in shop windows, austerity, Yugoslav leaders hint, may be just around the corner.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (UPI) --The final prosecution witness at the Sharon Tate murder trial told the jury today her story implicating Charles M. Manson and two of the female defendants in the slayings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, challenged today President Nixon's assessment that, as a result of the midterm elections, the Administration had established a working majority in the Senate on foreign policy and military issues.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the largest merchandising company in the nation, and five other leading retail chains, reported yesterday higher sales in October compared with the yearago month. Only Montgomery Ward Co., the retailing division of Marcor, Inc., said it had a decline in sales for the month.
The United States Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the election of James J. O'Leary, its chief economist, as a vice chairman of the board.

SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Nov. 6--Four heavily bearded men on a log raft arrived in Australia last night, ending a 7,000-mile voyage from Guayaquil, Ecuador. The journey across the Pacific, believed to be the longest ever made by raft, took 161 days.
Doubleday Co. has concluded an agreement with the Soviet Union in which that country for the first time formally recognizes the copyright of an American publisher.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 5 (AP)--Bolivia's military government took charge of El Diario today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5--The United States command reported today that 24 American soldiers were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the lowest weekly toll in five years.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 5 --A public meeting to discuss police and community relations ended in wild disorder here tonight 35 minutes after it had begun.
PARIS, Nov. 5--American and Communist negotiators at the Vietnam peace talks here charged each other with discourtesy today as the conference settled back into a familiar routine of non-negotiation.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 5 (AP) --A former paratrooper has admitted that he helped kidnap the commander of the air force Oct. 27 as part of a plot to overthrow the Government, the Defense Ministry announced today. It said he had implicated the sons of a former presidential candidate.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (UPI)-- Unofficial Soviet sources said today that the Russians would soon release three American Army officers and a Turkish colonel detained since their light plane strayed into Soviet Armenia on Oct. 21.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) A top-level military review board has blamed the Johnson Administration for some of the mistakes of the Vietnam war, asserting that long-range contingency plans were ignored by not calling up the reserves and by planning for a short war.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 5 (AP)-- the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled unanimously here today that the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory near Buffalo could be sold by Cornell University to a private, profit-making company.

The General Telephone and Electronics Information Systems, Inc., and the Control Data Corporation announced yesterday the joint formation of a company to provide computer and data transmission services to brokerage houses.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 5The Rev. Leo Yacykewych, assistant pastor of St. Vladimir's Ukrainian Catholic Church here for 14 years, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Passaic. His age was 64.

Ten mothers on welfare were arrested on charges of petit larceny and possession of stolen goods yesterday after participating in what they termed a "shop-in" at Macy's department store at Herald Square.

For nearly all of America's arts institutions and a great many of its creative and interpretive artists, the nineteen-seventies are becoming a time of acute financial distress in the midst of abundance.
It looks as if DKG, Inc., of New York and Collett, Dickenson, Pearce Partners, Ltd., of London have discovered a new way to broaden their international horizons.
MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Fire raced through a home for the elderly today and killed 17 persons in a Montreal suburb, Pointe-aux-Trembles. The police said all died of asphyxiation.

NEWARK, Nov. 5 (AP)-- The American Civil Liberties Union announced today that it was suing to revoke the taxexempt status and liquor licenses of New Jersey Elks lodges because the Elks' national charter contained a "whites-only" membership clause.
LITHONIA, Ga.--One Sunday morning, not long ago, O.G. Lee wheeled his car from an asphalt road near here and smiled ever so slightly when he heard the familiar crunch of gravel against the tires.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Robert Calhoun Creel, a senior Foreign Service inspector with the Department of State, died yesterday of a heart attack while on assignment in San Jose, Costa Rica. He was 57 years old.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5--The Soviet Union tonight assessed Tuesday's American election results as a defeat for President Nixon and the Republican party.

QANTARA, Israeli-Occupied United Arab Republic, Nov. 5 --Israel's front-line troops greeted the extension of the truce with the United Arab Republic tonight with cautious relief, and a new confidence behind their strengthened fortifications along the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

Malcolm Sinclair Lonon, vice president of Consolidated Natural Gas Service Company, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home. He was 61 years old and lived at 72 Pondfield Road West, Bronxville, N.Y.

Nathan Milstein once lost his violin, and it was recovered some weeks later in a warehouse full of stolen instruments. When the policeman was asked how he was able to walk right up to Mr. Milstein's Guarneri and pick it out of the pile of hot fiddles, he replied that it was easy: "Milstein's was playing the Mendelssohn Concerto."

A week ago Thursday in this column I said nice things about Shirley MacLaine's autobiography and expressed some reservations about Shulamith Firestone's "The Dialectic of Sex." The mail from both sexes has been heavy, angry and deserving of reply. In general, the objections fall into three categories: (1) the autobiography of a ...

Dr. Clarence J. Schein, a New York surgeon who was addressing an assemblage of fellow Phi Beta Kappa members, warned that the society should never relax its standards for admission. He added bluntly: "It should recognize what is too often neglected-- the elegance, relevance and importance of the work ethic."

The line-up of the $50,000 added Roamer tomorrow will offer an unusual situation locally--a breeder may ride one of his own homebreds. Leroy Moyers, a competent rider for more than a decade, has also been in the breeding industry for the past few years in Maryland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) --David Packard, Deputy Secretary of Defense, has ordered the armed forces to stop activating National Guard and Reserve units and then letting them sit idle for long periods of time.

Forty thousand schoolchildren in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were left without bus transportation today when one of the largest school bus operators on Long Island announced late yesterday afternoon that it was ceasing its operations.

HOLLISTER, Calif., Nov. 5 (UPI)--Charlie Root, the star Chicago Cubs pitcher who threw the pitch Babe Ruth successfully "predicted" he would hit into the seats in the 1932 World Series, died in a hospital here today. He was 71 years old.
LISBON, Nov. 5--Lunch is late at the Grand Hotel of Portugal but the scholarly chef serenely stirs his ingredients and counsels waiters to give impatient clients warm smiles until the meal is ready.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP)-- The University of Detroit's entire varsity basketball team-- three white and 13 black players--has announced that it would no longer play under Coach Jim Harding.
The city promised yesterday to finance fully or in part nine day-care centers operating under the principle of community control.

The president and principal stockholder of the Curtis Publishing Company said yesterday that The Saturday Evening Post, which ceased publication 22 months ago, would return to the newsstands next spring as a 200-page quarterly directed toward "middle American."
These remarks by Daniel P. Moynihan, Counselor to President Nixon, are excerpted from his recent address to the American Council on Education at St. Louis.
Another name from the Yankees' glory days joined the Mets yesterday when Hank Bauer was named manager of the Mets' Tidewater, Virginia, farm club of the International League.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 5--An America's Cup atmosphere pervades this island community on the eve of tomorrow's world championship Hennessy Key West powerboat ocean race. But that doesn't mean it's good.

The Conservative party, fresh from electing a United States Senator, will wield "sharply heightened influence" in shaping New York laws and New York politics, the party's two co-founders predicted yesterday.

GRENOBLE, France, Nov. 5 (Reuters)--An official investigator said today that a dancehall fire that killed 145 people Sunday was started unwittingly by a young man who dropped a burning match onto a foam cushion.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) --The Justice Department announced today that it had broken up a multimillion-dollar, eight-state bookmaking operation on the East Coast.

The engagement of Miss Kimberly Ann Harcleroad, a descendant of Hendrick Pannebecker, a founder of the State of Pennsylvania, to Jonathan Dale Farkas, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Farkas of New York, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Carolyn Beatty Harcleroad of New York.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP)--The Detroit Pistons spurted late in the third quarter tonight and went on to crush the Buffalo Braves, 121-109, in a National Basketball Association game.

John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, sharply criticized the Lindsay administration yesterday for ridiculing new contract demands of policemen and firemen and asserted that he would not permit this to happen to his union.

OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 5 (UPI) --A fire of suspicious origin destroyed two storage barns at St. Bonaventure University early today, five hours after students called a truce in a dispute with school officials that had threatened to close the institution.

One of the profound ironies of the present crisis in the Middle East is that some of the most violent opposition to United Nations efforts to settle the Arab-Israeli dispute has been nurtured and has exploded under the banner of the U.N.--that is, in camps operated by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA).
WARSAW, Nov. 5--West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, today canceled his scheduled return to Bonn in an effort to conclude a treaty establishing normal relations with Poland.

Dr. Raphael Tardera, a dental surgeon with offices at 520 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, L. I., and a former assistant professor of oral surgery at New York University Dental School, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home. He was 67 years old and lived at 101 Mineola Avenue Point Lookout, L. I.
The president of the American Cancer Society called yesterday for more funds for cancer research to help slay "this Goliath of an enemy."
Prices continued to ease on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in very light trading.

Western Air Lines, which is already being wooed by American Airlines, Inc., has received a marriage proposal from another suitor. Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, said yesterday that he had sent a telegram last Friday to executives of Western, offering to buy that carrier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--It is a cliche to say that Presidential campaigns begin the day after midterm elections.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 5 (AP) --A member of the team that helped recover the Apollo 13 astronauts when they splashed down from their troubled flight to the moon has been killed by a land mine in Vietnam.
A medical team in Los Angeles has found that drug abuse may cause a potentially fatal disease of the arteries known as periarteritis nodosa, sometimes after as little as three months of abuse.
Sparked by an improvement in the end products--soybean oil and meal--soybean futures prices rose sharply yesterday in active trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Mrs. Sally Sprague Cook Munroe, widow of former Mayor Vernon Munroe of Englewood, N.J., a J.P. Morgan Co. associate from 1920 until his retirement in 1941, died yesterday in her home, 116 East 66th Street. Her age was 89.

The European Championship played last week in Estoril, Portugal, resulted in a convincing victory for France. The winning team included Pierre Jais, Roger Trezel, Henri Svarc; Jean-Pierre Boulenger, Jean-Marc Roudinesco and Jean-Louis Stoppa, who will certainly be strong challengers for the world title in Taipei, Taiwan, next May.
The Bronx moved a step closer yesterday to making official its tricolor banner and to becoming the first of the five boroughs to legalize its flag.
There was more talk--mostly of the hopeful variety--than action in the stock market yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Twenty-four defendants were arraigned today at a tumultuous court session under the wartime emergency powers invoked after the kidnap-slaying of Quebec's Labor Minister last month.
COTUIT, Mass., Nov. 5-- Richard Pigeon, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, who retired here in 1951, died today after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

Some 6,000 employes of the New York City Housing Authority, angered by the death of one of their co-workers yesterday, threatened to walk off the job today in a demand that they be allowed to work in teams to insure their personal safety.

Pianists occasionally get funny programing ideas, and Emil Gilels, the great Soviet pianist, is not immune. For some reason he elected to devote the first half of his Philharmonic Hall concert, on Wednesday evening, to Schubert. That, of course, is perfectly all right. But the idea of following the A minor Sonata (Op. 143) with the six "Moments musicaux" was not a very smart thing to do.

Investors bid aggressively for the Treasury's new issue of 18-month notes yesterday as interest rates dropped decisively in major sectors of the money and capital markets. In the Government's $2-billion sale of 6 per cent notes --the first at competitive bidding in 35 years--the Treasury accepted bids that produced an average yield of 6.21 per cent, well below the rate it said it would permit when the terms were originally announced Oct. 30.
COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Nov. 5 --The English women's touring field hockey team scored five goals in the second half today to defeat Philadelphia, 5-2, before 1,600 fans at Ursinus College.

As they have for most of the past century--and almost without interruption for the past half-century--Republicans have retained control of both the State Senate and the Assembly. How that control is used holds grave implications for New York City, which sends precious few Republicans to Albany, and for other urban areas as well.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 5-- Stanley Dancer and Roland Beaulieu, who will drive Most Happy Fella and Columbia George, respectively, in Saturday night's Messenger Stakes, were not at Roosevelt Raceway for tonight's meeting of the New York Chapter of the United States Harness Writers' Association. However, the two reinsmen in a pretaped interview, told the members "Truluck is the horse to beat."

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP)--A series of meetings in United States cities "to foster a national debate on the possible need for a new constitutional framework for the American government," was announced today at the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions.
EVIAN, France--For every man who sings the praises of wine, there is another who bymns the wonders of water.
Some 1,200 city building inspectors are expected to begin a . work slowdown today to exert pressure on the city in current contract negotiations.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a decline in net income for the first nine months of 1970 although operating revenues for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30 ran higher than a year ago.
MADRID, Nov. 5--Some 30 Spanish film directors shut themselves in the offices of the Government-run entertainment syndicate today to protest the arrest of two of their fellow directors.
