Bob R. Dorsey, president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, tried yesterday at Columbia University to bridge the gap between industry and students.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--As an alternative to its beleaguered welfare reform measure, the Nixon Administration has suggested a new plan that would replace food stamps with money and incerase the national income base for a family of four to $2,200 a year from $1,600.
"The First Circle," the highly praised novel by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, who recently won the Nobel Prize for Literature, will be filmed in Britain this spring.

When you look at Richard Nixon's record, particularly after the 1970 elections, it is hard to avoid a crazy paradox. Though he has spent most of his mature life in politics and is supposed to be a master politician, his record as President is much better than his record as politician and party leader.
GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Nov. 5 (AP)--Mrs. Julia J. Dodge, widow of Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Budget under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died yesterday at her home here. She was 78 years old.

Mariner's Joie came to the rescue of the favorite players at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4year-old filly owned by Neil Hellman won the featured seventh event on the card at a payoff of exactly even money and, in so doing, became the first public choice on the program to score before 19,537 customers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5--The United States Secretary of the Air Force, Robert C. Seamans Jr., reported today that the North Vietnamese had carried out an extensive buildup of supplies in their southern provinces.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 (UPI) --Bob Carmichael of Australia eliminated top-seeded Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., from the International open tennis championships, 7-6, 4-6, 6-3, in the quarterfinals today.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Contempt of court convictions of 45 State University at Buffalo faculty members were dismissed today by a three-judge appeals panel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 --With 200 pounds draped on his 6-foot 4-inch frame, he is a big man, and the gray that flecks his black, closecropped hair is echoed in the clipped mustache.

ROME, Nov. 5--The Roman Catholic Church tradition excluding women from acting as acolytes during mass was retained in new instructions for reform of the liturgy published by the Vatican today. Other roles for women during mass are permitted, however.

A new ingredient, and a good one, has been added to American election campaigns--the candidate's record on improving the environment. In most contests the issue is probably not yet decisive enough to elect or defeat, although few other issues can possibly be more farreaching. In at least three instances, however, it was a major factor in this year's elections, with results that have been all to the good.

In a drawn out session in which four jump-offs were staged, the United States, West Germany and Ireland shared top honors last night in the international Puissance jumping class at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5-- Because California's air seems to energize Walt Frazier to a startling degree, the Knicks were still on a winning streak today as they arrived here for a game against the Lakers tomorrow night at the Forum.
Laurence R. Connor, who retired in 1963 as president of the First Agricultural National Bank of Pittsfield, Mass., died Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. His age was 72.

Angela Davis, the 26-year-old black militant and former assistant professor at the University of California, obtained a hearing date yesterday for Nov. 20 on her allegations that she was illegally arrested and jailed because of her membership in the Communist party.

High winds with gusts reaching 47 miles an hour forced the barring of vehicles last night from West 44th Street between Eighth Avenue and Broadway because of a possible hazard from construction materials on the site of the building to be known as One Astor Plaza, on the north side of 44th Street. Patrolmen diverted pedestrians around the danger area.
After months of issuing grim financial reports, City Hall yesterday produced some surprisingly good news about its ability to borrow money.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 5-- A 20-year-old youth who matched the description of a young man reportedly seen with two student nurses before they were found murdered in Pennsylvania was detained here today by the state police.

ATLANTA, Nov. 5--High mercury levels have been detected in the eaters of seal meat in the Pribilof Islands of Alaska, where seals were recently found to be contaminated by the heavy metal, Federal scientists said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- William McChesney Martin Jr. said today that the Nixon Administration's policy of refusing to interfere in private price and wage decisions would be "self-defeating" and he called for some form of "incomes policy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) --The Justice Department filed suit today to block the merger of two of the largest commercial banks serving the Bennington, Vt., area, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--Attorney General John N. Mitchell's press spokesman denied today reports that Mr. Mitchell would leave public office in January to serve as President Nixon's campaign manager for re-election in 1972.
BOSTON, Nov. 5 (AP)--Friday will be an official day of mourning for 1.8 million Roman Catholics in the archdiocese of Boston in tribute to the memory of Richard Cardinal Cushing.

A recount will be made Monday of the unofficial election night tally showing Edward H. Lehner, the Democratic candidate, winning an Assembly seat in Manhattan's 73d district with a six-vote plurality in a five-way race.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 5 (UPI)--Romalie Hanover, a yearling filly by Dancer Hanover-Romola Hanover, brought a world-record price of $101,000 today for a yearling harness horse filly sold at auction. The sum was paid by Dr. George A. Smith of Byram, Conn., at the Harrisburg standardbred sale.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--President Nixon is expected to name William D. Ruckelshaus of Indiana as head of the new Environmental Protection Agency, according to informed sources here.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., announced yesterday that it had signed formal agreements to acquire Goodbody Co. and said approval of the consolidation by the New York Stock Exchange membership would be vital to its consummation.
The nation's money managers continued to pursue a moderately expansionary credit policy during the most recent twoweek period, according to banking data published yesterday.
Factory workers' buying power in New York and northeastern New Jersey remained stable in September as earnings increases were largely offset by consumer price rises.
Radio station WBAI-FM went off the air for 35 minutes last night as a result of a bomb threat that proved unfounded.

If you read a critical essay in The New Yorker, you can be reasonably sure of at least three things: (1) It is beautifully written; (2) it comes very close to the truth; (3) you are satisfied: no reason to get frightened, everything will be all right--or beyond your (and anybody else's) power.
Very interesting. Two years ago, a schoolboy quarterback at St. Mark's in Dallas attracted numerous scouts, including a few from the Ivy League.
Radio astronomers have detected a cloud of alcohol far out in space toward the center of the Milky Way Galaxy.

After a 35-year relationship, N.W. Ayer Son and the Michigan Bell Telephone Company are splitting up on Feb. 1. The agency, through its 12-man Detroit office, had been handling both the corporate and the Yellow Pages accounts.

PARIS, Nov. 5--The European Economic Community has decided to let West Germany negotiate a five-year trade agreement with the Soviet Union. It would be the first time since 1962 that the two countries have had a treaty governing their commercial relations.

Bonwit Teller, one of the country's most prestigious retail fashion chains, took the unusual step yesterday of informing its 3,000 employes that it was not closing any stores, not making any management changes nor being sold to Sears, Roebuck Co.
Jim Plunkett has been sending out vibrations that he would prefer to play profes sional football on the West Coast, near his home, his friends and his family.

Merce Cunningham is the least literary of all choreographers. Even Alwyn Nikolais's magic kinetic sculptures suggest things an enchanted forest or a forbidden city. Balanchine, at his most chaste, can never resist a love duet. Paul Taylor is alive, well and kicking with humanity, and for many, many choreographers, dance is a way of drama as much as a way of life. Not so Cunningham.

Treasury Under Secretary Charls E. Walker complained sharply last night about the television networks' coverage of economic news. In an address at the St. Moritz Hotel, he said: "Sad to state, television runs a poor last when it comes to the quantity and quality of economic coverage. It is more than sad it is dangerous to the public interest."
A bartender dubbed by the F.B.I. as Dashing Dan, who pleaded guilty to robbing 10 banks in the metropolitan area last spring, was sentenced yesterday to two concurrent 20year prison terms.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 Mikhail A. Suslov, a member of the Soviet Communist party Politburo, emphasized today the prospects of improved Kremlin relations with France and West Germany, while accusing the United States of continuing "a policy of criminal aggression and the arms race."

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (Reuters) Quebec's Justice Minister, Jerome Choquette, said today that the authorities had received a photograph of James Cross, the British Trade Commissioner, and a statement from extremists of the Front for the Liberation of Quebec who kidnapped him Oct. 5.

Miss Anne Marie Regan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Regan of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour to Roderick Alexander Cordiner, owner of the Cordiner art galleries at 301 East 61st Street and Job's Lane, Southampton, L.I.
In an all-or-nothing effort, Hans Guenther Winkler guided Terminus, an agile brown gelding, to an inspiring victory last night in the international jumping class at the National Horse Show.

NEWARK, Nov. 6 Henry S. Puder, a founder of the accounting firm of Puder Puder, and a civic leader here, died last night at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 77 years old and lived at 131 Blanchard Road, South Orange.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The nation's unemployment rate moved up slightly in October to 5.6 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Department reported today.
Despite their assortment of casualties this season, the New York Jets had escaped a knee injury, perhaps the most common in pro football until now.
LONDON, Nov. 6 Robert Carleton Goodell, cultural affairs officer at the United States Embassy, married Mrs. Anne Wilshere today at the Marylebone Registry Office here.

Peter G. Peterson, chairman and chief executive officer, has relinquished the title of president and Henry E. Bowes was named to that position and Everett F. Wagner was appointed vice chairman at the Bell Howell Company. Both men were formerly executive vice presidents at the camera and electronics manufacturer.

MADRID, Nov. 6 About 50 of Spain's leading painters began a sit-in at the Prado museum today to obtain the release of a jailed art critic. After two and a half hours, the police entered the museum and evicted them peacefully.
SAN LEANDRO, Calif., Nov. 6 (AP) The Lucky Stores supermarket chain gave away today perishable food it valued at more than $300,000 rather than let it spoil in a strikebound warehouse.
BATHURST, Gambia The season of the heavy rains is over now, the evening breeze is less oppressively hot and this drowsy littie capital is getting ready for the Swedish tourists again.

A 68-year-old Brooklyn physician?Dr. Michael Michaels?collapsed and died yesterday while chasing two youths who a few seconds earlier had stolen his watch and wallet as he was entering, his parked car three blocks from his home in the Crown Heights section.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 A panel of leading poverty lawyers sharply criticized today a proposed reorganization of the controversial Federal legal services program. The proposal, they said, "imminently threatened" the integrity of the program.

Prime Minister Trudeau has acted wisely in introducing new legislation to deal specifically with the Quebec troubles and to cut back the sweeping powers assumed by the Canadian Government under the War Measures Act. He had promised a less drastic emergency bill in any event and he was already getting considerable backlash from the inevitable discomforts and injustices for Canadians in keeping the country virtually on a war footing.
A 45-year-old inmate of the Tombs fashioned a noose from some shoelaces late Thursday night and hanged himself from a crossbar at the rear of his cell, prison authorities said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) The tar content of 34 cigarette varieties has been reduced since May, the Government disclosed today, but the brands relatively high in tar and nicotine continued to sell best.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 6-- Harness racing's richest event in the seven weeks remaining in the season, the $123,450,92 Messenger Stakes, will be presented tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company said yesterday that it would close a large part of its steel-finishing capacity and lay off more than 4,000 production workers for a week unless the strike against the General Motors Corporation had been settled by Nov. 15.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 6 The United States called here today for United Nations action to press North Vietnam to allow identification of war prisoners and to allow access to them by the Red Cross.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 6 Mrs. Oliver Lazare of Metropolis was re-elected president of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association at the 21st annual meeting yesterday at the Apawamis Club to serve a third one-year term. Mrs. Douglas M. Moody, Wee Burn, was elected vice president to succeed Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot.
ROME, Nov. 6-- Italy and Communist China announced their agreement today to establish diplomatic relations and to exchange ambassadors within three months.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C. Nov. 6 (UPI) Fourteen of 18 shipwreck victims from the motor vessel Caribbean Mist were rescued today after a night afloat in life rafts and jackets amidst wild, 25-foot waves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Techniques that have become available in recent years may make it possible to start screening the population for environmental influences that could be producing genetic effects, a scientist said today.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Nov. 6 Curtis B. Brooks, a senior vice president of the Industrial National Bank of Providence and a director of the Providence Journal Company, died today at his summer home here. He was 62 years old and lived in Providence.

This happens in response to a take-out double when the responder's only length is in the opponent's suit. And it can happen in a more acute form when a player is required by a convention to choose between two suits.

A funeral was held yesterday in a small Harlem chapel for James Rudy Gibbs, a 19-yearold heroin addict. Like a growing number of teen-agers in recent years, he died of an acute reaction from the use of heroin. As in the past, the grieving parents and relatives expressed deep regret that the victim had died senselessly at an early age.

The extension of the Middle East cease-fire, the most positive outcome of a largely counterproductive United Nations debate, gives quiet diplomacy one more chance to break the deadlock in peace talks. It is an opportunity that must not be allowed to slip away.

Michael Freyberg, former president of the City Tax Commission, pleaded guilty yesterday to a perjury charge that grew out of an investigation of former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.

Murray Roth, associate director of the FAR Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue, and an appraiser and authenticator of graphic art, died Thursday at his home, 152 East 94th Street, after a long illness. His age was 61.
An East Coast filly with earnings of $249,358 and a West Coast filly with earnings totaling $221,192 will match bankrolls today in the $188,360 Gardenia Stakes at Garden State Park.

He entered a claim for his losses, which were covered by a home-owner's comprehensive policy he held with another company. Soon after he had received the covering check, he was notified that his policy would not be renewed.

A battered marble head that had been in the dust and gloom in the basement of the British Museum in London since 1859 has been identified as that of the Aphrodite of Cnidus, the statue carved by Praxiteles in the fourth century B.C. as the first nude representation of the goddess of love.

IT WAS THE 29th day of July when I set out on a low-budget trip around the world. It was exactly the kind of journey that travel "experts" tell you never to take--20 countries in 30 days. It meant I spent one afternoon "doing" Jerusalem, 90 minutes seeing the temples of Luxor and Karnak. But I got exactly what I was after a whole smorgasbord of swift, rich, first and lasting impressions.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (AP)--Louisville, with its sophomore quarterback, John Madeya, running for two touchdowns and passing for another, beat Memphis State, 40-27, tonight to win a trip to the Pasadena Bowl on Dec. 19.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- Miss Elizabeth Cobb Matheson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Cobb Matheson of Alexandria, Va., was married in the Bethlehem Chapel of the National Cathedral here this afternoon to Ens. Robert Carl Arberg, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Arberg of Arlington, Va.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8--Miss Laurie Frances Urdang of New York, the editor of The Fed, a magazine of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was married today to Jess O. Gregory, also of New York, a public relations manager with the American Express Company there.

The state's Health and Mental Hygiene Facilities Improvement Corporation has awarded contracts totaling $7-million for the final stage of construction of the Kings County State School in Brooklyn, Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 8-- The United States Merchant Marine Academy won the freshman dinghy sailing championship of the Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate Association today on Long Island Sound, the Mariners scored 67 points in the regatta. New York State Maritime was second with 77 and Navy third with 87.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 8 --At least one reporter has been asked by the Federal Bureau of Investigation about unverified reports that a shot may have been fired during a rock-throwing demonstration against President Nixon on Oct. 29 in San Jose, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) --The international air fare agreement for the next two years, reached at Honolulu last month but not yet ratified, is in danger of foundering over a plan of some foreign governments to impose a new tax on the airlines that could cost their passengers $70-million a year.
ROME, Nov. 8--Some 300 homeless Romans shouted "Houses, Houses!" in St. Peter's Square today while Pope Paul VI was addressing pilgrims before his customary Sunday blessing.

WIESBADEN, West Germany, Nov. 8--The minority partner in the Bonn Government--the Free Democratic party--held its ground today in elections for the state parliament of Hesse, thus improving the prospects for continued rule by West Germany's national coalition.

According to a senior American executive in the international steel trade, who has just returned from visits to several Japanese mills, Japan could well surpass the United States and become the world's largest steel producer as early as 1973.

Emory, who met at a dance when she was at the Kent School for Girls and he was at the South Kent School, were married here yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. John B. Coburn performed the ceremony before a few members of the bridegroom's family.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 8 --Samuel J. Graham, a founder and former vice president of the Dixie Cup Company, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at Otter Rock Drive, Belle Haven.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 8--In race track parlance, the form ran true at the 44th annual show of the Onondaga Kennel Association at the Onondaga County War Memorial today. Of the six finalists from a field of 1,421 facing Maurice L. Baker of Minneapolis, five had been previous best-in-show winners.

Keep an eye on the C.P.I. This advice that rhymes is good for every consumer. These days American families live with prices on their minds, and the basic measure of price trends is the C.P.I.--the consumer price index.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 8 --The nation's first rabbi to serve on the faculty of a Roman Catholic college has been installed as the fifth rabbi of Sinai Temple, a Reform synagogue, in an unusual ecumenical investiture.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP)--Milton Rector, executive director of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, and Dr. Alfred R. Lindesmith of Indiana University have received the two highest awards of the American Society of Criminology.
State Public Service Commission check-ups have found even more public telephones out of order than reported by the New York Telephone Company, according to Joseph C. Swidler, commission chairman.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8--Another negative for the New York Jets emerged today as a positive.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP)--Ni Chih-chin of Communist China set a world record for the men's high jump with a leap of 7 feet 6.1 inches, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

Mrs. Estela de Lime Luria, widow of Frank Luria, who was vice president of the Luria Steel and Trading Corporation, died of cancer yesterday in Wickersham Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 115 East 89th Street.

OSWIECIM, Poland, Nov. 8 --Walter Scheel, West Ger many's Foreign Minister, today visited Auschwitz, largest of the Nazi extermination camps, to honor the memory of four million victims of Hitler Germany.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 8--Bill Melchionni scored 26 points and set a team record with 14 assists tonight as the New York Nets defeated the Denver Rockets, 114-104.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8--Dr. George O. Gey, director of the Finney-Howell Cancer Research Laboratory at Johns Hopkins Medical School and Hospital, a cell biologist internationally known for his tissue culture and cancer research, died today in the hospital. He was 71 years old.

Mistakes by the masters are the rare phenomena ascribed technically to what may be called a fingerfehler, German for slip of the finger, or hallucination, or a blindspot. Grandmasters are never charged with the crass blunder.

The New York Stock Exchange, in a rare foray into the field of economic forecasting, has undertaken a private survey of the views of more than a dozen nationally known economic forecasters and has come up with a fairly optimistic prognosis.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 8 (UPI)--Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that the Nov. 3 elections showed that President Nixon had misread the temper of the South and would probably have to scrap his "Southern strategy."

Arthur Tarshis, who retired in 1960 as president of Arthur Tarshis Associates, Inc., formerly Expositions, Inc., producer of trade and business shows and exhibitions, died Saturday in Mount Siani Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 12 West 72d Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--A report by Ralph Nader's Center for Study of Responsive Law charges that the American medical profession is doing a poor job of safeguarding the quality of health care delivered by the nation's doctors.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 --The winners of this year's Rockefeller Public Service Awards to distinguished career officials in the Federal Government were announced today by Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president fo Princeton University, which administers the trust through its Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 8-- The setting was incongruous. Here in the plush surroundings of the Boca Raton Club, bathed in brilliant Florida sunshine, the savings bankers of New York state gathered last week for their annual convention.

REHOVOT, Israel, Nov. 8 (UPI)--An Israeli scientist said today that Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science initiated research on a possible anticancer drug for which Princeton University has claimed credit. He said the drug had been produced in Israel for more than a year.
The credit markets roared through an almost incredible amount of financing last week, and its remarkable momentum will continue this week.

CAIRO, Ill. Nov. 8 (UPI)--At least one person was shot and this historic Civil War river port's largest lumber company was destroyed as conflict between blacks and whites continued last last night and early today.
HENDERSON, N.C., Nov. 8 (AP)--National Guardsmen and highway patrolmen stood watch in the racially troubled city of Henderson today and a curfew was ordered for the third consecutive night.

WAYNE, Pa., Nov. 8--William Wymetal, managing director of the Pittsburgh Civic Light Opera from 1947 until his retirement in 1968, died Saturday in Lankenau Hospital, Wynnewood, after a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

The Italians of New York do not agree about who they are, what progress they have made since the great migrations of half a century ago and where they should be going. And yet this people whose identity is so difficult to define has recently been thrust very much into the public eye.

Leslie Cole, his wife and three children will sail home to England next month. After five years as an aerospace engineer on Long Island, he has lost his job, sold his house, said his good-byes to his American friends and is reluctantly going back to London to look for work.
PARIS, Nov. 8--A nationwide enforcement of safety regulations closed scores of dance halls and nightclubs in France this weekend.
The New York Civil Liberties Union published today what it called "the first comprehensive handbook" on the rights of public school students in New York City.
Cardinal Hayes and Monsignor Farrell triumphed in Catholic high school football yesterday and remained undefeated, but Hayes had a scare from Holy Cross.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it was awarding grants totaling $600,000 to two conservation groups but was withholding another grant of $310,000 to one of them pending a decision by the Internal Revenue Service on the charitable status of the organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) --The White House Office of Consumer Affairs issued guidelines today for consumer education courses from kindergarten through the end of high school.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 8 (UPI)-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that there were several Democratic Senators he would "gladly" back as candidates for the Presidency in 1972. He did not name them, however.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8--North Vietnamese, troops fired some 500 mortar shells on South Vietnamese posts in Cambodia and bases near the frontier today, military spokesmen said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) --Citing his own survey of police chiefs, student leaders and college administrators, Senator George S. McGovern has urged that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation be barred from campus investigations unless invited in by local authorities.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)--Phil Esposito, the National Hockey League's scoring leader, connected for one goal and assisted on two others tonight as the Boston Bruins registered a 6-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in a game marked by a first-period free-for-all. Three players on each team were given major penalties as a result of the fighting.

New parking, standing and turning rules for automobile drivers in midtown will go into effect this morning as part of the city's two-month experiment in speeding traffic flow and reducing air pollution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) --Senator Edmund S. Muskie, the man most often mentioned as the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1972, charged today that President Nixon has attempted to divide the country in the 1970 elections.

Nine modern-dance choreographers showed their work at Dance Theater Workshop, 215 West 20th Street, on Friday and Saturday nights. For the second time in less than a month a major NATO ally of the United States has recognized the Peking regime as "the only legal Government of China." MARTINSVILLE, Va., Nov. 8 (AP)--Ray Hendrick of Richmond, driving two different cars, swept the Martinsville Speedway's $27,470 Cardinal 500 Classic double-header today.

In the ten months since United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. took office and said he would emphasize prosecution of business crimes and narcotics trafficking, and would speed the handling of a large backlog of criminal cases much of his activity has been concentrated on disposing of old cases.

LONDON, Nov. 8--Dr. D.E. L. Haynes, the keeper of Greek and Roman antiquities at the British Museum, said today he would write to a New York archeologist for evidence to support her report that she had discovered the head of the marble statue of Aphrodite of Cnidus in the museum's basement.

More than 250 of the nation's fastest and most expensive show cars and unusual vehicles will go on display at the ninth annual National Rod and Custom Car Show that opens Nov. 26 at the New York Coliseum for a four-day run.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP)--Three men face arraignment in District Court tomorrow following a riot last night during the Springfield KingsRochester Americans American Hockey League game, which Springfield won, 10-2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8-- The Nixon Administration is conducting a sweeping review of the strategy of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Senior officials say it could ultimately lead to basic changes in the alliance's tactics, the size of its forces and its weapons.

Gogi, the internationally known restaurateur, died Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive with his wife, the former Janet Klavohn, who survives him.

RICHMOND, Nov. 8 (AP)-- Mrs. Billie Jean King won the Virginia Slims invitation women's tennis tournament today by beating Nancy Richey in the final, 6-3, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) --The Republican National Chairman, Rogers C.B. Morton, said today that President Nixon would put more emphasis on environment, transportation and housing and less on defense in 1971.

BERLIN, Nov. 8--Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, said today that "other states" would have to reduce their activities in West Berlin before his Government would enter talks on easing access to the city.

Nathaniel Frey, a stage, film and television actor who had appeared in a number of Broadway shows, died of cancer Saturday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 341 West 24th Street.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Nov. 8-- Miss Joan Van Sinderen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen Jr., was married in the Presbyterian Church here this afternoon to Stephen Edward Mudrick, a doctoral candidate in meteorology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Rev. Thomas A. Hughart performed the ceremony.

A 5,000-pound red ball, 14 feet in diameter, splashed into the murky waters of Buttermilk Channel off Governors Island last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Reuters)--Pilot error caused a plane crash that killed 31 persons, 13 of them Wichita State University football players, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 8--The Israeli Cabinet opened a tense policy debate today over ways to revive negotiations with the United Arab Republic.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 9 (UPI) Apollo 14 was moved by a giant tractor today from its assembly building to the firing pad for its final 12 weeks of launching preparations.

"I always wanted a big glove," said Charles Stendig, joyously punching the pocket of his big fielder's mitt. His fist hardly made a dent in the love-seat-sized baseball glove, but he kept on pounding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) The Pentagon said today that two Soviet ships that entered the Cuban port of Cienfuegos in September, giving rise to speculation about construction of a submarine base, were again nearing the port after a six-week absence.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today a mandatory 15 per cent rate reduction for property damage liability auto insurance. The reduction was part of the state's new "no-fault" auto insurance law.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 (AP) Fort Marcy turned in a sensational workout today, fortifying his role as favorite in the $150,000 Washington, D.C. International at Laurel on Wednesday.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 9 (AP) Ernest W. Mandeville, a writer and priest, former pastor of Christ Church (Episcopal) in Middletown, N.J., died here today, apparently, of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

A police sergeant was fatally wounded in a Harlem gun battle last night with two men who allegedly were impersonating policemen. He was the ninth policeman to be killed here this year in the line of duty.

Dr. Solomon Simon, a retired dentist who continued in his other career as a prolific writer of articles and tales in Yiddish, died Sunday at his winter home in Miami after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 215 East 43d Street, Brooklyn.

The first of several police undercover agents expected to appear against 13 Black Panthers took the stand yesterday and testified that the film "The Battle of Algiers" was required viewing for Panther Party members.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 1 Children in Sweden's rapidly changing school system start sex-education courses at the age of 7. Boys and girls are jointly taught sewing and woodwork. Textbooks depict mothers and fathers interchangeably working and caring for children.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 9 A new radio station, Radio Free South, began broadcasting this week, in opposition to the ruling party in Southern Yemen. The new station urged people to take up arms against the leftist regime of Premier Mohammed Ali Haitham.
Assemblyman John J. Walsh of Manhattan, the unofficial loser in the initial Election Day tally last week, turned out to be the winner by 99 votes yesterday in the official recanvass.

The outlook for averting a taxi strike next week is "dark," Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of Local 3036, New York Taxi Drivers Union, said yesterday, as the deadlock between fleet owners and drivers remained unbroken.

In his discussion of Miss Kaminska's self-exile here, along with other members of her family, Mr. Szurmiej said: "We have heard some voices saying that she is considering coming back. In that event, she would be welcomed with open arms."
The New York Jets apparently have regained Al Woodall for Sunday's game with the Rams in Los Angeles.

Juanita King, the soprano who made her recital debut late Sunday afternoon, has a bright, radiant voice, pure gold in quality and big enough to fill Carnegie Recital Hall, where she sang, 10 times over.

Cabbies, truck drivers and city officials praised new midtown traffic regulations yesterday as "pretty good," but merchants said they feared the holiday-season experiment would cost them business.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9 A peace agreement between the Arab commandos and King Hussein's Government went into force this noon after the palace, taking a tough stance, rebuffed a commando request for a postponement.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) Fiveyear-old Kevin Toston, who died Friday of a narcotics overdose, apparently swallowed a capsule of heroin and not Halloween candy sprinkled with the drug, the police said today.

Unless the industry makes some important move toward self-regulation, advertising will be fully regulated by the Government in from three to five years, an agency president predicted yesterday at the opening session of the Grocery Manufacturers Association.

SEATTLE, Nov. 9 The New York Knicks, who end a tour of the West against the Seattle SuperSonics tomorrow night, arrived here today from Portland, where their 125-113 victory over the Trail Blazers last night was marked by a small episode in the second quarter that resulted in the game's official length being shortened by 18 seconds.

The Hazeltine Corporation said yesterday that it had laid off an undisclosed number of employes, effective immediately. A company spokesman refused "for competitive reasons" to give any figures on the number involved.
Dr. Daniel A. Collins has been named executive director of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich's San Francisco office, William Jovanovich, board chairman of the book publisher, announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 9--A 21-year-old West Berliner confessed today that he shot a Soviet sentry at the Soviet war memorial in West Berlin Saturday for "political motives," the police said.

For a party often derided as a political corpse, West Germany's Free Democrats showed unexpected life and strength in the Hesse state election. The most important result is the removal of the immediate threat of collapse that hung over Chancellor Brandt's Federal Government coalition.

ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, Nov. 10--The Soviet Government today freed two United States generals and a Turkish colonel and delivered them to Turkish officials... ish colonel and delivered them to Turkish officials at the Soviet-Turkish border, a Turkish official reported.

WEST BERLIN, Nov. 9 For four days from Nov. 5, West Berlin's tentlike Philharmonic Hall "Circus Karajani" in local jargon was turned into a palace of the lively arts of jazz, populated by pop attire, cord jeans and sweaters, set off by tapping feet, nodding heads and long hair, and characterized by a refreshing relaxation of rigid German discipline.

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik called yesterday for an investigation into the possibility that "unwarranted influence" might have been exerted in behalf of a school bus company that a city official had labeled "financially irresponsible."

Agreement among the leaders of Egypt, Libya and the Sudan to work toward a tripartite federation is a step although still an uncertain one toward the late Gamal Abdel Nasser's dream of a united Arab nation led by Cairo.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 9 Eighty-two children who were evacuated during the Nigerian civil war from the territory that was Biafra were flown into Lagos today from the Ivory Coast, on their way back home.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 9 (UPI) A Brazilian news magazine, Veja, today published what it said were interviews with Dr. Claude L. Fly and Aloysio Mares Dias Gomide, captives of Tupamaro guerrillas in Uruguay for more than three months.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 9 (AP) Italy's top Davis Cup player, Marty Mulligan, defeated Keishiro Yanagi of Japan, 7-5, 6-0, 6-2, today and advanced to the final of the Japanese tennis championship.
MIAMI, Nov. 9 Mrs. Rose Koshetz Racher, a high school teacher in Dade County, died here yesterday in the Veterans Hospital after a long illness. She was 72 years old and the widow of Morris Racher.

The rent strike by nearly 1,000 residents in dilapidated, heatless, slum-area tenements owned by the City of New York dramatizes a crisis that has been aggravated by the refusal of voters to support a proposition on last week's ballot for greater state subsidy of low-cost housing. The proposition would have given the state authorization to increase its financial aid to localities for housing construction by a modest $20 million over the present $42-million level.
Twelve college seniors who excelled in the classroom as well as on the playing field, were named National Football Foundation scholar-athlete leaders for 1970.
The stop-and-go stock market moved a bit forward yesterday as the General Motors strike, now edging into its ninth week, overshadowed all other investment considerations.

Waving his white gloved hands in a churning motion that might have been from a pantomime by Marcel Marceau, Patrolman Harold Wittig twirled neatly in the middle of 34th Street and Broadway shortly after noon yesterday.

CAIRO, Nov. 9 Comment ing today on a plan of Egypt Libya and the Sudan for ultimate political federation, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, said that he would recommend Palestinian membership in the federation "if I am still alive when a democratic Palestinian state is formed."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The Soviet Union advised the United States today that it would release the two United States Army generals it has been holding: since their small plane crossed the Turkish border into Soviet Armenia on Oct. 21.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the brokerage license of Nadel and Co., of New York, alleging the firm violated Federal securities laws.

The negotiations for a new round of municipal, pay increases have opened with all the usual extravagance of demands and of strike threats by the heads of unions with stop-or-go power over vital services. But there is nothing usual about the city's fiscal condition this year: it cannot afford to repeat much less exceed the increase of nearly $600 million in labor costs that helped swell the current municipal budget.

Roman Totenberg, who in recent years has served as head of Boston University's string department, brought a chamber orchestra of his students to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night and let them show how ably they could support him while he performed as soloist in violin concertos by Handel and Mozart.

Ken Rosewall, at the age of 35, has been awarded the Martini Rossi gold racquet as the tennis player of the year for 1970. He was chosen by an international panel of tennis writers over his fellow Australian, Rod Laver, who won the award in 1969 and 1968.

The murder conviction of a Puerto Rican migrant worker who could not understand English was set aside as unconstitutional yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals on the ground that the defendant had not understood, the proceedings in his trial.
A former Department of Correction officer, indicted last year on brutality charges stemming from an incident on Rikers Island, was acquitted last Friday after the jury deliberated for 25 minutes.

A Manhattan Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a former employe of Blair Co., a major brokerage concern now in liquidation, in connection with a scheme to defraud a Canadian brokerage house of $340,000.

Iris Love, rebutting critics of her claims to have found the head of the famed Aphrodite of Cnidus in the British Museum's basement, said yesterday that those identifying the head as that of Persephone could not support their identification.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first nine months of this year.

Two hundred fifty-six teams took part in a Swiss Team Championship, a turnout that has only been exceeded at "Bridge Week" in California and at the 1970. Summer Nationals in Boston.

Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Stern of New York. The wedding is planned for May l at St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntington Valley.

The choreographic works of the Fred Benjamin Dance Company are like a series of production numbers in search of a star. They have decorative appeal but trickle through the memory like water into sand. One is constantly anticipating some central focus but it never appears. Sunday night at Clark Center the company presented five works: three by Mr. Benjamin and two by Michael Peters.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 As the Big Four representatives to the United Nations continued their consultations on the Middle East today, the Soviet Union and the United States differed sharply on a question of procedure.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 "Can you spare any change?" asked Mario Martinez, an 18-year-old Chicano with flowing black hair and piercing eyes, as he sat on the sidewalk along Telegraph Avenue a few blocks from the University of California campus at Berkeley.
A growing proportion of women on welfare have a "high employment potential," with New York City's proportion reaching nearly twothirds, according to a Federal study made public yesterday.
The election of Dr. Antonie T. Knoppers as chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce was announced last night at the council's annual dinner at the Hotel Pierre.
PARIS, Nov. 9 The Police have never been popular in France, and neither has their boss.

Sterling Manhattan Cable Television announced yesterday the signing of a five-year contract with Madison Square Garden for home games of the New York Rangers and New York Knickerbockers, and another with Janus Films for the showing of 30 movies.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 9 Meshulam Riklis and fellow officers and directors of the Rapid-American Corporation violated their fiduciary responsibilities, practiced nepotism and conspired to pay a fraudulent finder's fee of $6-million, according to a stockholder damage suit filed here today.
The New York Stock Exchange has announced that four registered representatives and a former back office employe were suspended in September for various violations.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 9 (AP) Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, Colombia's ailing former dictator, returned today from Miami to plan what he described as a "revolution Colombian style" before the 1974 presidential elections.

Firemen and the police of the bomb section and the West 68th Street station roped off an area near Lincoln Center yesterday morning because of the discovery of a Package that was thought to contain a bomb.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) Gen. Sir Robert Mansergh, commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in northern Europe from 1953 to 1956, died yesterday at the age of 70.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Recent advances in technology give promise of new aid to those whose lives depend on regular use of an artificial kidney machine, a Goverment expert indicated today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today for 10 days over-the-counter trading in the common stock of Globus International, Ltd., of Washington.

The barometer of tensions between the U.S. and the Soviet Union has fluctuated wildly lately between "detente" and "confrontation," and there is a danger that an opportunity is being lost to bring some sanity to bear on the one problem on which the two countries have overlapping interests strategic weapons competition.

A reward of $1,500 was offered yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the slayer of 22-yearold Patrice Leary. Miss Leary, a teacher at Brearley School, was killed in her apartment at 310 West 73d Street on Oct. 29.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers indicated today that the condition of the balance of international payments should not by itself bar a policy of re-expanding the economy toward full employment.

The city's Deputy Chief Medical Examiner testified yesterday that he had found no evidence that mariuana causes any physical damage. But he warned against legalizing its use because it could cause psychological problems.

The new first deputy commissioner of the Police Department, William H.T. Smith, said yesterday the best way to teach the public to stop corrupting the police was to encourage individual patrolmen to arrest those who offered bribes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The Federal Government's chief advocate urged the Supreme Court today to leave it to the state legislatures and to Congress to decide how capital punishment should be handled by trial juries.

HORNELL, N.Y. Nov. 9 Long before the sun rises to gild the autumn-brown slopes of Pennsylvania Hill, two miles north of this Steuben County town, Clayton Stutzman and, a crew of young helpers are at work felling, sorting and baling this year's crop of Scotch pine Christmas trees.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Almost a year ago, President Nixon said that the United States was renouncing germ warfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The president of Kent State University said today that the recent special grand jury report on the Kent shootings was not only inaccurate but also reflected a wide assault on all free universities.

Three members of the world champion Baltimore Orioles, including the most valuable player of the World Series, Brooks Robinson, will compete in the fifth annual American Airlines Astrojet Golf Classic Feb. 5 through 7 at Goodyear Golf and Country Club in Phoenix, Ariz. The tournament chairman,

John R. Opel has been named chairman of the management committee of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Opel is a senior vice president in charge of corporate finance and the planning staff.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 According to informed sources, Cambodian officers are discussing with members of the entourage of Prince Boun Oum, the feudal chief of southern Laos, the possibility of sending sizable numbers of Cambodian troops to Laos to be equipped with United States arms.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Nov. 9 (AP) Charges against Capt. Ernest L. Medina in the alleged massacre at Sonmy more than two years ago have been returned to a military investigating officer for further study, the Army announced today.

The first Negro chairman of a major Congressional committee, the House Committee on Government Operations, William Levi Dawson owed his seniority to the heavily Negro South Side slum wards of Chicago.

The Department of Transportation informed Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey yesterday that it was starting action on a program to correct the electromechanical problems of the Penn Central's Metroliner. More than $3-million will be spent on the program.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Paul A. Samuelson says he "cannot imagine anything more malignant" for the nation's economy than the trade bill before Congress.
LONDON, Nov. 9 A battered marble head identified by an American archeologist as that of the love goddess Aphrodite went on display at the British Museum today amid a major archeological controversy.

Leif H. Olsen, senior vice president and chief economist of the First National City Bank, said yesterday that he did not believe the Nixon Administration had committed itself as yet to the forced-draft expansion of the money supply needed to drive the unemployment rate below 4 per cent by mid-1972.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 The principal of a Brooklyn elementary school and one of his teachers, with whom he allegedly was romantically involved were charged today with conspiracy to murder the principal's wife.
BUFFALO, Nov. 9 (AP) Elbert Hubbard 2d, manager of the old Roycroft Shops in suburban East Aurora and son of the author of "A Message to Garcia," died Sunday at the age of 88.
Advances outnumbered declines on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a slight margin in stepped-up trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Reuters) The Supreme Court let stand today a ruling that Chattanooga, Tenn., must surrender to Kennesaw, Ga., a shiny little locomotive that starred in a romantic episode of the Civil War.

Theodore W. Kheel, lawyer, mediator and arbitrator, has been appointed executive board chairman of Pace College's Edward Corsi Labor-Management Relations Institute, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward J. Mortola, president of Pace.

Boxers and boxing officials appeared at an informal hearing before two Congressmen from New York yesterday and all reaffirmed that they favored Federal control over the sport through a national commission.

Louis A. Capaldo, founder and president emeritus of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief, illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 205 West 15th Street.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 The average Nassau County homeowner would pay about $130 more in county taxes next year based on a county budget for 1971 proposed by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today.
Shipments of mobile homes registered a modest advance during September from the level a year earlier, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

Fifteen of pro football's 26 teams are still in contention for the National League's eight playoff positions. There is a four-team race in the National Conferences's Eastern Division; three-way races in the American Conference's Central and Western Division and two-team affairs...

A dozen reasons flashed through Tom Dempsey's mind yesterday as he tried to put into perspective the magnitude of his record 63-yard field goal on Sunday that made him the focus of pro football's millions of fans.

The Lindsay administration took the unusual step yesterday of appealing to a small New Jersey town to deny a zoning change that would allow the Western Electric Company to move part of its headquarters out of New York City.

Public broadcasting should stop having the jitters. Morton Silverstein's documentary entitled "The Banks and the Poor" was a job well worth the doing for nonreaders of The Wall Street Journal. Bankers may have some legitimate reservations about the television study of credit policies of the banking industry, but for the layman the program was a fine and laudable example of pinpointing crucial economic practices that require wide discussion.

FORT LEE, N.J., Nov. 9 The engagement of Miss Barbara Lynn Filenbaum to Donald Kenneth Piermont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Piermont of Fair Lawn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Filenbaum.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Nov. 9 Mr. and Mrs. M. Rhodes Blish Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Judson Blish, to Peter Franklin Thomas, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Peter Thomas of Palmerton, Pa. The wedding is planned for June.

LONDON, Nov.9 Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the Foreign Secretary, announced today that the Conservative Government had begun one last effort to settle Britain's dispute with the Rhodesian Government, which delcared its independence from Britain in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Three black college presidents complained today that their schools were "invisible American institutions," ignored by those who allocate money and pass out grants.

Prices on the London stock exchange fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading following the extension of the wildcat strike by coal miners and warnings of increasing inflation from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (O.E.C.D.). Reports of serious financial difficulties in British Leyland's Austin-Morris division also helped push the market down.

PARIS, Nov. 9 (A.P.) Arthur Ashe of Richmond was extended to two sudden-death games in beating Owen Davidson of Australia in the first round of the Paris indoor tennis tournament today, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6.
The theft of about 30 antique objects of art from the Staten Island Historical Museum of Richmondtown was discovered by a cleaning woman when she arrived for work yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Contributions to Protestant churches increased slightly during the 1969 fiscal year, but not enough to keep pace with inflation, a financial report indicated today.
For Pearl Nudelman, life began at a time when it seems to cease for most people when she entered a hospital for the chronically ill, with no expectation of ever leaving.
In anticipation of the final auction sale by the Government of its silver stocks today, the silver futures market here rose yesterday in fairly active trading.
BUFFALO, Nov. 9 (AP) A "moderate sprain" to O.J. Simpson's left knee combined with hospital jargon yesterday to give football fans a scare.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 9 Napoleon Hill, a best-selling author of success and inspirational books, died yesterday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

The woman who a recent book says is really Amelia Earhart, the flier who disappeared mysteriously over the Pacific in 1937, said last night that she would attempt to "defabricate" the story at a news conference today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 9 (AP) Nine men, six of them described as criminals being expelled from an Arabian sheikdom for forging documents, seized an Iranian airliner in stormy weather over the Persian Gulf today after overpowering two guards. They compelled the pilot to fly to Iraq.
The Police Department has quietly stepped up its protection of food delivery trucks, which in recent months have become prime targets for holdups in the city.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) Thomas E.A. Stowell, the surgeon and author whose hints touched off speculation that Jack the Ripper was the great-uncle of Queen Elizabeth II, denied today that he had ever suggested that the notorious murderer was of royal blood.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 A Presidential mediating panel proposed today a 37 per cent wage increase compounded over three years for about half a million railroad workers.
PARIS, Tuesday Nov. 10. Gen. Charles de Gaulle died last night of a heart attack, the French Government announced today. He would have been 80 years old on Nov. 22.

No athlete who competes in the 1972 Olympics will be permitted to carry or wear equipment that could constitute advertising or an endorsement, Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, declared yesterday.
Robert T. Shircliff, president of the Pepsi-Cola Allied Bottlers, Inc., Jacksonville, has been elected president of the Pepsi-Cola Bottlers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations charged the 91st Congress today with a "shockingly long list of unfinished business."

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 9 Harold M: Botkin, vice president for international services of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Long Lines Department, died yesterday at his home after a short illness, He was 64 years old and lived here at 7 Vista Place.

LONDON, Nov. 9 Muhammad Ali is back and there is renewed interest in boxing. Only last week Joe Bugner defeated George (Scrap Iron) Johnson here before a standingroom house. But Londoners are not lining up to watch "the greatest fight of the century."

Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., the 38-year-old du Pont family heir who has asked for court protection from his creditors because his liabilities exceed his assets by $37-million, may soon be involved in another bankruptcy, according to one of his associates.

The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase the price of tolyene diisocyanate, a principal chemical used in the manufacture of urethane foams, by 2 cents a pound, to 37 cents, effective Jan. 1.
R.J. Reynolds, Industries, Inc., said yesterday it had agreed to acquire United States Lines, Inc., a subsidiary of Walter Kidde Co., for a $65-million note.

WARSAW, Nov. 9 Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz of Poland said today that Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany would be warmly welcomed in Warsaw upon completion of the treaty that their Foreign Ministers are negotiating.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 Representative William L. Dawson, the dominant political power among Chicago's blacks for many years died early today in Veterans Research Hospital here. He was 84 years old.
Holiday shoppers will find suitable gifts at the Ark, a pre-Christmas boutique that will be open 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. from tomorrow through next Tuesday.

The First Devonshire Corporation, a suspended member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been adjudicated bankrupt by a Federal court referee in what may be the first involuntary bankruptcy case involving a stock exchange firm since the Depression.

TRENTON, Nov. 9 A special management commis sion named by Gov. William T. Cahill proposed today a sweeping reorganization of state government that would reduce the number of cabinetlevel departments from 17 to 6 and save about $60-million to $85-million a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Agriculture Department estimated today the 1970 cotton crop at 10,428,900 bales, 4 per cent more than in 1969 but 2 per cent less than what was forecast in October.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 9 The Suffolk County police held three persons today in connection with the slaying of a 13year-old boy whose body was found in a wooded section of Greenlawn late last night.
Having disposed of Cowboys, the Giants now turn their attention to Indians.
Members of The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild voted, 1,200 to 18, yesterday to accept a new contract providing a 41.69 per cent pay increase over three years, the guild announced.

Noel Coward's "Hay Fever" is almost a classic which is about as good as being almost a virgin. Last night it was produced at the Helen Hayes Theater its first Broadway production since 1931. It should have done better than it did. Yet I laughed a little and sometimes with the play.

An unhurried round ridden with calculated, precision by Hartwig Steenken aboard the 12-year-old mare Simona, made the West German Equestrian Team winner of the Nations Cup at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. What the 29-year-old horse breeder from Hannover needed to beat the United States was a clean ride, and he made sure of it by taking his mount over 14 fences with lots to spare. Speed was not important.

PARIS, Nov. 9 The Government, the judiciary and the po lice are coming under increasingly frequent attack in the press and in liberal and leftist political circles for alleged violations of civil liberties.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 9 The General Motors Corporation lost today its bid to prevent the Department of Transportation from requiring the company to notify owners of a safety defect in 200,000 pickup trucks.

When Art Modell of the Cleveland Browns was doing his personnel juggling last winter, he made one of his frequent calls to his friend Wellington Mara of the Giants, for an exchange of idea. Modell told his buddy that a deal was in the works with Miami whereby Paul Warfield would be traded for draft rights to Mike Phipps, a desperately needed quarterback of high potential.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court dis missed today "for want of a substantial Federal question" an appeal challenging the New York requirement that candidates in a primary election be enrolled members of the political party.

DETROIT, Tuesday, Nov. 10 Negotiators from the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers met into the early morning hours today in an effort to reach agreement on the money issues of the 56-day-old strike.

Bellevue Hospital, noted for both outstanding examples of medical technique and the decrepit state of its buildings, summoned all its resources last weekend when it seemed likely that it would have to evacuate all of its 1,450 patients.

Forced immigration from Africa began in 1619, a year before the Mayflower, and continued for almost 250 years, the last Americans of African birth being still alive in the twentieth century.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (UPI) Cardiac specialists from the Kremlin's hospital were in consultation today on whether to hospitalize former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, informed unofficial sources connected with the Krushchev family said.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (UPI) The president of the United States Savings and Loan League said today that more mortgage money would be available to home buyers during 1971 than during the last two years. TOKYO, Nov. 9 Textile talks between Japan and the United States are reliably reported to have reached a critical stage, with the Japanese textile industry still balking over concessions the Government considers necessary.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Nov. 9 (AP) Mrs. Florence Talpey Williams, widow of the novelist Ben Ames Williams, died of a heart attack yesterday. She was 81 years old.

Federal officials declined to comment yesterday on reports that a Federal grand jury to be empaneled in Albany on Thursday will investigate alleged irregularities in the construction of the state's vast South Mall project, which is adjacent to the State Capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Nixon Administration will ask Congress next year for changes to improve some criminal sentencing procedures, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

CAPE FEAR, N.C. Behind Cape Fear, the southernmost tip of North Carolina thrusting into the surging Atlantic Ocean, is Smith, or Bald Head, Island, a 13,000-acre complex of dunes, tidal creeks, marshes and maritime forest.

TRENTON, Nov. 9. The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the reading of a daily prayer in the Netcong High School, although voluntary on the part of the students, was unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Treasury bill rates declined sharply again at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

General Giraud was then appointed civil and military commander.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 10 When a group of 103 archeology students from Queens College in New York dug in Indian mounds in Northern California last summer, they expected to come up only with relics and a better understanding of the Maidu civilization of the 15th century.

A gloomy, overcast day at Aqueduct yesterday proved a sunny one for the chalk players in the crowd of 21,385 as six favorites came romping home first. Choices also accounted for both ends of the $21.40-for-$2 daily double.
Harry Feder, founder and chairman of Barclay Industries, Inc. of Lodi, N.J., died yesterday at his home, 880 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 10 (AP) Jimmy Ellis, former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, stopped Roberto Davila of Peru with several strong right hooks in the seventh round of a scheduled 10rounder tonight.

ROME, Nov. 10 The Vatican announced today the establishment of diplomatic relations with the European, Economic Community. The Papal Nuncio in Belgium, the Most Rev. Igino Cardinale, was appointed Papal Nuncio the equivalent of an ambassador to the Common Market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 A week after Election Day, five major contests are still undecided and some of them may not be decided until next year.
ROME, Nov. 10 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived today for a three-day visit marking Moscow's heightened interest in Western Europe and the Mediterranean.

The Sperry Rand Corporation entered the new computer sweepstakes yesterday as its Univac division introduced a new data processing system described by Univac spokesmen as three to five times more powerful than any similar machine ever developed by the company.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 (AP) More than half the 26 National Football League teams have been subpoenaed to appear with their records before a Federal grand jury here, but an air of mystery surrounds the action.

"Sesame Street," public television's first sustained smash hit of its own making, returned this week for its second year. It is seen at 9 A.M. and 4 P.M. on Channel 13, with reruns on Saturdays under a grant from the General Foods Corporation.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 Yesterday, at his home in Sde Boker, in the Negev, David Ben-Gurion wrote what turned out to be his last letter to Charles de Gaulle. It was mailed just a few hours before the French leader's death last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 Last week's election results did not constitute a mandate for a change in the Administration's economic policies, Treasury Under Secretary Charls E. Walker said here today.

A small number of sportsmen will head for the Jersey countryside Sunday in an effort to get turkeys for their Thanksgiving dinners. They are not hunters but sports car drivers who will be competing in a 90-mile rally sponsored by the Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey.

The International Paper Company announced yesterday an increase in the base price of its unbleached kraft linerboard to $125 a ton, effective Feb. 1. The material, used in corrugated shipping containers, sold for $123 a ton early this year until the price dropped to $120 a ton last May.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 10 (AP) Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster of the United States Army, supreme allied commander in Europe, warned today against withdrawal of American troops from the Continent.

Prospects for averting a strike of Off Broadway actors and stage managers next week were described yesterday as "very bad" by Sean Callery, Actors Equity Association public relations director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The nation's blight-riddled corn crop shrank another 2 per cent during October and now is estimated at 4,103,973,000 bushels, the Agriculture Department announced today.

Emerson Boozer, one of the three injured New York Jet starting backs, is ready to return for Sunday's game against the Rams in Los Angeles. Gerry Philbin is expected back at defensive end and Steve Thompson will be available for more playing time.
