WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird has renewed assurances that the United States is not trying to improve its strategic missile system so effectively that it would threaten Soviet retaliatory forces and thereby undermine current arms control negotiations.
NETCONG, N. J., Nov. 10 Outside, it was raining. Low-lying fog hung in the valleys, soaking the last of autumn's leaves.

N. George Belury, president of the Abex Corporation has been elected chief executive officer, succeeding Thomas W. Russell Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, who will retire Dec. 31. The company also announced that L. Persbacker was elected a director and a vice president of administration and Rush M. Forquer Jr. was elected vice president and comptroller.
Daniel Charles confirmed yesterday that Gennaro Andreozzi would be joining the agency as senior vice president and co-creative director.

The word "academic" is sometimes thrown at the heads of composers as an intended slur, and sometimes is worn by the same composers like a cockade, defiantly and proudly. More often than not these days, the word simply states fact, as happened at the opening concert of the Group for Contemporary Music's ninth season on Monday night. All the com
A 20-year-old telephone company repairman from Queens was fatally shot and robbed at noon yesterday on a Brooklyn street after he had refused a demand by two men to give them narcotics.
The Seeburg Corporation yesterday announced it has completed previously disclosed negotiations to refinance outstanding debt owed to two insurance companies and has obtained $6,200,000 of new funds.
The Baltimore Orioles, baseball's 1970 champions, averted a shutout in postseason honors yesterday when Boog Powell, their mammoth first baseman, was named the American League's most valuable player.

For Richard Taylor, 33 years old, married and the father of four, being a correction officer in the city prison system meant, he thought, at least more security for his family than he had found as a margin clerk on Wall Street.
Maj. Gen. Edward C. D. Scherrer is known as Pony to close Army associates, and to at least one member of his family, his younger brother, George, as "the most bowlegged general in the Army."

WASHINGTON, Nov.10 White House officials are now saying privately that speculation about Vice President Agnew's being dumped from the Republican ticket in 1972 was deliberately planted to help elect Representative George Bush of Texas to the Senate.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 10 United States delegation sources said today that they did not expect specific agreements with the Soviet Union to emerge from the current round of talks on limitation of strategic arms.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 A 43-year-old Brooklyn school principal and a 26-year-old teacher, who were reported by a Parent-Teacher Association to be having an affair, were arraigned here today on a charge of having conspired with members of the underworld to murder the principal's wife.
"The Gingerbread Lady," the new Neil Simon play starring Maureen Stapleton, will suspend performances at the close of its Boston engagement Nov. 28, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) Arnold S. Johnson, public relations director of the Communist party of the United States, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today for contempt of Congress.

The Western Electric Company issued a detailed rebuttal yesterday to charges by Ken Patton, the city's Economic Development Administrator, that the concern was practicing "evasion or escapism" by planning to move part of its headquarters to the rural town of Bedminster, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 10 (UPI) More than 100 candidates for House seats, iricluding seven who were elected, have failed to submit the mandatory campaign financing reports that were due two weeks ago under a Federal law.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 10 A National Guard officer named in a Justice Department report as being in the middle of the May 4 shooting incident on the Kent State University campus was not called before the state grand jury that absolved the guardsmen of blame.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 The United States Embassy said today that it had complained to the Foreign Ministry that Soviet policemen had prevented a Jew from entering the embassy in an effort to establish American citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The American labor force will reach 100 million workers by 1980, including "a dramatic increase" in the number of young adults and "an explosive increase" in the number of young black workers, the Labor Department forecast today.

Mystery at the heart of merriment, playfulness surrounding loneliness, brightly costumed dancers moving around black draped tripods; all occur in Merce Cunningham's "Objects," which had its premiere last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is a dance full of incongruities, with laughter at times coming on the disappearing heels of sadness.
The shaky Cleveland Browns will start a rookie, Mike Phipps, rather than Bill Nelsen at quarterback against Cincinnati on Sunday, Coach Blanton Collier said yesterday.

The Burroughs Corporation raised $110-million as it placed a million new common shares on the market yesterday through an international underwriting team managed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Justice Department continued its crackdown on reciprocal purchase agreements in the steel industry today with an antitrust suit against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 2 producer.

It was an impressive undertaking for an organization, less than a year old, with fewer than 300 members. It was especially so for an organization that financed its first mailings with $2,400 representing two years dues paid in advance by each of a dozen founders.

A fiddler from the Shetland Islands off the northern coast of Scotland and a singer from the border country of Southern Scotland made an unusual duo at the Washington Square Church, 135 West 4th Street, on Monday evening.

Greece's military' rulers continue to build facades designed to persuade the world that they intend eventually to restore constitutional democracy. Only the Nixon Administration and professional apologists for the Athens regime seem impressed.
The passenger in the black Rolls-Royce is immaculately groomed and sits, ramrod straight, in one of her carefully planned couturier outfits. She is munching on a sandwich.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 10 Miss Margaret Fisher Sayre and Dr. Michael Lewis Wiederhold will be married Feb. 27 in Hanover, N.H., the future bride's birthplace.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 10 Antiwar demonstrators draped a Vietcong flag across the shoulders of Prime Minister John G. Gorton at an election rally in Perth today. The Flag was immediately snatched away by one of Mr. Gorton's aides.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 10 The Jordanian Government is still holding scores of Syrians who were captured while fighting alongside the Palestinian commandos here during the civil war in September, high army sources reported today.
GENEVA, Nov. 10 Joseph D. Revotto, a retired foreign correspondent, died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment here. He was 62 years old.

A state judge ordered the Board of Education yesterday to pay for the use of taxis and other vehicles to transport crippled children to school during the current private-bus strike in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
A surprisingly strong defense, not so publicized or glamorized gas several others, but remarkably effective on the field.

SEATTLE, Nov. 10 Victimized by backcourt men as they had been four nights before in Los Angeles, the New York Knicks squandered an 8-point lead early in the fourth quarter and bowed to the Seattle Supersonics, 93-91, tonight before 11,022 fans at the Seattle Coliseum.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 10 (AP) A. B. Hancock Jr. set a world record at auction tonight when he paid $395,000 for Priceless Gen, a 7-yearold broodmare from the Bieber-Jacobs Stable, at the Keeneland Sales.

Robert Preston, a 28-yearold New York pianist and a product of the Juilliard School, is moving onward and upward. On Monday night he appeared in the Young Artists Series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Since this is a special series, supported by the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, in which the artists are given their only New York recital of the season, it represents an accolade of sorts.

PARIS, Nov. 10 (Reuters) All four delegations to the Vietnam peace talks here have agreed to postpone this week's session because of the death of Chares de Gaulle, a spokesman for the Vietcong delegation said today.

A wholesale drug distributor was arrested yesterday on charges of selling thousands of doses of stimulants and depressants to virtually anyone who ordered them, ignoring requirements for prescriptions.

HONG KONG, Nov. 10 An influential pro-Nationalist Chinese newspaper here today urged the Nationalist Government on Taiwan to bow to the international swing toward Peking and prepare to accept a seat in the United Nations as one of two Chinese regimes.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10-A Saudi Arabian airliner was diverted to Syria today in the first hijacking of an Arab plane, to an Arab country since the Middle East War of 1967.

The Occidental Petroleum corporation showed an earnings decline of 14 per cent in the third quarter and 8 per cent in the first nine months despite record gross revenues for the periods it was reported yesterday from the company's Los Angeles headquarters.
Benjamin F. Biaggini, president of the Southern Pacific Company, said yesterday that he believes more and more manufacturers currently are "living off inventories."
WASHINGTON, NOV. 10 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare published today final 1972 auto pollution standards that were slightly eased from initial-proposals in July.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 10 Two United States Army generals and a Turkish colonel returned to Turkey from Soviet Armenia today three weeks after their light plane landed 12 miles on the other side of the border and they were interned.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 10 (AP) Dr. Linus Richard Foy, who left the Marist Brothers religious order earlier this year but stayed on as president of Marist College here, plans to be married.
BONN It is of trans-Atlantic significance that Western European unity, so long championed by thoughtful Americans, is nearer reality than ever before.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) First-period power-play goals by John Bucyk and John McKenzie powered the Boston Bruins to a 3-port National Hockey League East Division lead in a 6-3 conquest of the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 Governor Rockefeller today invited the entire New York State Congressional delegation to meet with him on the state's "critical fiscal situation" and to try to create a unified effort to "get more of our money back from Washington."

The reforms in bargaining procedure proposed to railroad management and labor by a Presidential fact-finding board could revive the capacity for independent problemsolving in an industry that has let its labor relations degenerate into becoming a battered ward of government.

PARIS, Nov. 10 There were some reddened eyes and a few unashamed tears, but the visible reaction of most Frenchmen to the death of Charles de Gaulle seemed to range from grave reflection to outward indifference.

Joseph Lichtenstein, a consulting engineer who played a part in the introduction of centrifugal pumps 50 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 1304 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, Queens. He was 76 years old.

Despite rumors to the contrary, the Ballet Folkorico of Mexico has more than its costumes to commend it. The folk dance ensemble founded and directed by Amalia Hernandez has come back for its seventh visit. At last night's opening at the City Center, its best pieces were significantly those with a strong dance element.

LONDON, Nov. 10 Henry Cooper; the 36-year-old boxing warhorse, regained the European heavyweight championship tonight. He scored a ninthround technical knockout over Jose Manuel Ibar, known as Urtain, a 27-year-old Spanish Basque who used his head more than either arm.

WYCKOFF, N. J., Nov. 10 A. Vere Shaw, an investment adviser who is generally credited with having originated the term "investment counsel," died yesterday at Christian Sanatorium after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street in New York.
LONDON, Nov. 10 A novel by E. M. Forster, withheld at his request for 55 years because of its homosexual theme, is now to be published.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 Fort Marcy, with Jorge Velasquez riding, and Fiddle Isle, with Willie Shoemaker up, are the one, two choices in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International tomorrow.
PRESTON, Md., Nov. 10 A. Fletcher Sisk, a retired principal in Albert W. Sisk Son, food brokers here, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 84.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) State Department officials said today that Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam would visit the United States next week. For Security reasons, the time and place of his arrival were not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The election has left the Government with a sizable hangover. There is work to be done, in all three branches, but there are already signs that the next campaign will merge imperceptibly into the last and leave the politicians reeling for quite a while.

Blair Co., a major brokerage house in liquidation, escaped involuntary bankruptcy yesterday for the time being when a court referee concluded that the matter should be referred to the United States District Court here for adjudication.

Dr. Robert A. Good, a pioneer in elucidating the mysteries of immunity and using the findings to cure fatal diseases, and Dr. Earl W. Sutherland, who discovered a ubiquitous regulator of body chemistry called cyclic AMP, were named recipients yesterday of the 1970 Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards.
Federal prison authorities have been asked by five Protestant and Jewish religious leaders to let two imprisoned Roman Catholic priests prepare sermons for use live or taped outside of prison.

PARIS, Nov. 10 Although Charles de Gaulle had a long record of disagreements with the United States and made no secret of his fear that American hegemony threatened to dominate the world, he came to believe by the end of his long political career that major differences between Washington and Paris were near an end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The Supreme Court was told today that, if it holds the erotic Swedish film "I Am Curious (Yellow)" is not obscene, live exhibitions of sexual intercourse will be shown in bars and burlesque houses of major American cities.
The director of Odyssey House, which operates a rehabilitation program for adolescent addicts, recommended yesterday a public referendum on whether marijuana should be legalized.

"These new synthetic fields provide such an ideal kicking surface," said Errol Mann, the placement-kicking expert for the Detroit Lions, "that it wouldn't surprise me any if someone kicked a 60-yard field goal some day."
The women of the Young Lords are not called Young Ladies. They are Young Lords, too, and to hear them tell it, they are probably the most liberated women in town.

Samuel Ogus, a co-founder in 1926 and later president of the Sabrett Food Products Corporation of Jersey City, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital of a heart attack. He was 79 years old and lived in New York.

Ever so many charts, charts being a 20th-century art-form perfected by semi-attached policy studies centers like the...

A truck laden with beer dropped from a viaduct near Westport, Conn., and onto the mainline tracks of the Penn Central's New Haven division shortly after 7 A.M. yesterday, delaying thousands of commuters bound for Manhattan for up to two hours.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 Benjamin Britten's good-and-evil opera after Melville's "Billy Budd" was composed in 1951 but has never made the rounds the way some of his other operas have. In this country it has up to now received but one television production, hence the Lyric Opera's current performances are listed as American stage

NOTTINGHAM, England,Nov. 10 At the Theater Royal in Nottingham last night the Royal Ballet opened its first national tour under the new policy introduced by the new directors, Kenneth Macmillan and John Field.

More than 250,000 subway riders were delayed in a fivehour period through the evening rush hour yesterday when riders pulled emergency cords automatically stopping trains and causing an almost complete shutdown of service in Queens and major delays throughout the system.

PARIS, Nov. 10 Following is the text of a letter written by Charles de Gaulle on Jan. 16, 1952, expressing his wishes for his funeral. Sealed copies were given to the general's family and to President Pompidou, who was a long-time aide of the general.

A police undercover agent who had been assigned to join the Black Panther party testified yesterday that New York City Panthers had conducted military drills in public parks, held classes in the care and use of guns, cut wires in police callboxes to annoy "the pigs," and planned to bomb three department stores and a subway station.
F. Clark Cahill, an executive of AIL, a division of CutlerHammer, Deer Park, L.L., died Saturday at his home in Centerport, L.L., after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I, Nov. 10 The Suffolk County Legislature unanimously approved today a ban on the sale of virtually all detergents in the county. The only exceptions are those used in such relatively minor products as dishwashing powder, shampoos and tooth paste.
PARIS, Nov. 10 Was Charles de Gaulle merely a moment in the history of France? Now that he is dead, has the moment passed?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Blacks here have established their own charity fund-raising organization and set a goal of $1-million, thus challenging the established United Givers Fund.
The American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday in slow trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Gary Price, a former employe of the Office of Economic Opportunity, said yesterday there had been no conflict of interest or impropriety in his employment by a contractor for the Office of Economic Opportunity after he left the antipoverty agency.
The maximum penalty up to life imprisonment was imposed yesterday on a narcotics dealer for the first time in the state, under new legislation that became effective Sept. 1.
Fleet Maxi owners here said yesterday that they had to have assurances of more revenue before they could complete negotiations for a new contract with the taxi drivers union.
PARIS, Nov. 10 "General de Gaulle is dead. France is a widow "

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 10 (Agence France-Presse) Sisowath Muni Leakhana, a cousin of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, was shot dead last week by a Cambodian Army captain in Kompong Speu Province southwest of here, the Cambodian press agency reported today.

"Your reply is going to determine the destiny of France," an intense, solemn yet aged voice told the French people on April 25, 1969, "because if I am disavowed by the majority of you, my present task as chief of state would obviously become impossible [and] I would immediately stop exercising my functions."
FOLEY, Ala., Nov. 10 Henry P. Davis, editor of the sporting dogs column in Sports Afield magazine, died here Sunday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
The "cliffhanger at General Motors," as one Wall Street broker put it, remained a mystery yesterday as the stock market held to small changes on the popular averages.

The sanitation workers' union formally opened contract negotiations with the city yesterday' and indicated that it would seek cost-of-living raises to bring members' wages to at least $13,000 in a one-year contract. The,present pay scale is $9,871 a year
The National Broadcasting Company notified its 210 affiliated stations yesterday of its plans to drop one-half-hour of network programing each night during the 1971-72 television season.
A media trade magazine invited some of its most important readers to the Harvard Club yesterday to hear some agency men predict the future.
Harry Belafonte will be the guest of honor on Nov. 20 when the Foundation for International Child Health sponsors a benefit dinner dance at the Pierre.

A Health, Education and Welfare Department official said yesterday that the Nixon Administration was not opposed to consumer groups bringing class actions against environmental polluters, United Press International reported.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 10 President Nixon will attend memorial services for Charles de Gaulle, the White House announced today. Mr.Nixon will leave Washington tomorrow morning with a small official delegation, attend the service at Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris on Thursday, and return to Washington late Thursday night.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 10 William H. Feathers, a former vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died last evening flat his home in Bayberry Lane here after a heart attack. He was 53 years old.
Residents of Rockaway, Queens, filed a suit yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court challenging as unconstitutional the present double subway fare they are required to pay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The Federal Reserve Board announced today a small reduction in the discount rate, in response to the recent sharp decline in other short-term interest rates.
An expansion of the hours when the elderly can ride city subways and buses for half fare was urged upon the Transit Authority yesterday by a City Council committee.

Transfer bids have been growing in popularity recently among tournament players. The idea of making the strong hand the declarer, and therefore decreasing the chance of a damaging opening lead, is a good one theoretically. But in practice such maneuvers can be doubleedged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Government has begun eliminating some of the suspicion cast over microwave ovens last January when a survey showed one-third of the quick-cook ovens emitted excessive radiation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Department of Housing and Urban Development is seeking the first Federal court challenge of a suburb's use of restrictive zoning to exclude Government-assisted, low-income housing. H.U.D. has asked the Justice Department to file suit against the St. Louis suburb of Black Jack, Mo., for allegedly rezoning a 25-acre tract Oct. 25 to prevent construction of a 210-unit interracial apartment development.

NEWARK, Nov. 10 A Federal District Court judge ordered William A. Sternkopf Jr., a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority today to produce all records of financial associations with John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic boss, within 48 hours, or answer to why he should riot be charged with contempt of court.

COLOMBEY-LES-DEUXEGLISES, France, Nov. 10 A middle-aged man in a blue woolen sweater said, yes, he knew de Gaulle by sight, he had always seen him Sundays, at mass, and thus last Sunday. "He looked the same as usual, he looked in good health," he said.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 9 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles drew with Robert Hubner of West Germany in the first round of the eighth interzonal Palma de Mallorca world chess championship elimination tournament yesterday and Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., lost to Tudev Uitman of Mongolia.

Fifteen persons were arrested shortly after 5 P.M, yesterday when they refused to vacate the sixth floor of the nurses' residence at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, which they had occupied for almost five hours.

Mrs. Ida J. Mintzer Krugman, who had practiced medicine here since 1916 as Dr. Ida J. Mintzer, died Monday in Jamaica Hospital, where she was chief of dermatology from 1930 to 1959, after a short illness. She was 78 years old.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 10 The military judge in the murder trial of First Lieut. William. L. Calley Jr. opened the way today for testimony by key prosecution witnesses who were barred from taking the stand at the trial of another defendant in the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.
The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would lay off 342 hourly employes at its Middletown, Ohio, works at midnight Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 10 The British aircraft carrier Ark Royal and a Soviet destroyer collided last night in the eastern Mediterranean, where most of the British fleet was engaged in maneuvers. Neither ship was seriously damaged but two Soviet sailors were still missing late tonight.

Jay Iselin, who joined Harper Row in April, 1969, as vice president and publisher of its trade group, will relinquish his administrative post Jan. 1. A former national news editor of Newsweek, Mr. Iselin went to the publishing house in a major editorial reshuffle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Just in case the British-French Concorde is not enough to spur the supersonic transport program, Neil A. Armstrong said today that the Soviet Union would have its TU-144, which he called "every bit as attractive," on the world market before the American craft is ready.
World leaders, World War II allies and former enemies joined today in an emotional outpouring of tribute to Charles de Gaulle.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 10 Enemy saboteurs early today blew up a 150-yard bridge 30 miles north of Pnompenh, cutting a key land link between the capital and a 2O,000-man Government task force concentrated 20 miles farther north.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy deplored the slaying of a police sergeant in Harlem Monday night and called yesterday for control "on a national scale" of hand guns.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov, 10 The police were searching today for at least two other persons in the "thrill killing" of a 13-year-old boy last week, a killing described in court as wanton, callous and without motive.

In his sophomore season, Pancho Micir decided to forgo football rather than play second fiddle to Bernie Zbrzeznj, Penn's No. 1 quarterback. A year later Micir devoted his gridiron talents to the sandlots. This season Micir thought he could win the varsity job from Coach Bob Odell. Micir's

The credit markets yesterday had a busy day. They snapped up American Telephone's $500-million of notes end bonds, pushed interest rates down sharply on new tax exempt securities and moved more short-term rates lower. Then six of the 12 Federal Reserve banks reduced their discount rate to 5 per cent from 6 per cent.
Off-track betting will "grow like crazy" once the bugs are worked out, the nation's most distinguished odds-maker insisted here yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10 Lee O. Rostenberg, a retired Army colonel and founder here in 1928 of Rostenberg Associates, a real estate firm, died today in White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 10 (UPI) Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Army Chief of Staff, said tonight that the Selective Service law should "remain in force as national insurance" even if a voluntary army is established.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 A key, witness in the Tate-LaBianca murder trial admitted under cross-examination today that she hears voices and that she has trouble with her memory.

Abruptly shook up because of an illness and the earlyseason failure of two rookies to produce, the Rangers return to Madison Square Garden with three new lines tonight to face the Pittsburgh Penguins.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) Chairman Dean Burch of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the commission would not allow educational television to become any more commercial than it is.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 10 Automobile traffic near the villa on Hongthaptu Street has picked up lately. Ambassadors, politicians, retired generals and various religious figures have been arriving with increasing regularity these days to chat with Gen. Duong Van Minh, the man most likely to challenge President Nguyen Van Thieu in the elections next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) The Government will extend its combat-zone tax benefits to military personnel serving in certain Southeast Asian posts outside Vietnam, the Treasury Department announced here today.

Gov. William T. Cahill has done New Jersey a great service in signing the controversial bill to protect that state's wetlands. These remaining quarter-million acres of salt marshes, estuaries and inlet flats-something like 5 per cent of the state's entire area will not be automatically preserved even now; but their further destruction as wetlands can be controlled, limited or stopped by the State Department of Environmental Protection as that agency sees fit.

The I.N.A. Corporation, a $2billion holding company whose major asset is the Insurance Company of North America, disclosed here yesterday that it was buying nearly a 10 per cent interest in the Suez Company of Paris for $30-million in cash.

DETROIT, NOV. 10 The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation pressed their contract talks today as union leaders from around the nation poured into the city either to approve a new pact or learn that they must dig in for a longer strike.
A 15-year-old youth was critically wounded last night by a man who robbed his father's pizza store in the East Flatbush area of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Two Soviet ships have returned to the Cuban port where the United States recently charged the Russians were building a submarine base, but Government officials played down their importance today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today approval of a new, enriched breakfast roll to take the place of fruit juice and bread or cereal served at schools and day-care centers.
The idea of having an ombudsman, to look after the personal welfare of Navy men, has been adopted by the United States Navy, All Hands, a publication of the Bureau of Naval Personnel, reports.
State Senator John J. Marchi predicted yesterday that the new Republican-controlled Legislature would respond to the city's growing financial "agony" despite any hard feelings against Mayor Lindsay.

PARIS, Nov. 10 When, by his own choice, he was still a political exile, General de Gaulle once said to me: "Giants can do nothing now." Some years later I asked, if, under any conditions, he foresaw a new age of political giants and he replied: "I suppose that depends upon the world situation. When that situation is grave the giants come nearer to a return.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (UPI) The Soviet Union announced today the launching of Luna 17 toward the moon.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) State Insurance Commissioner C. Eugene Farnam announced today that automobile insurance rates for property damage would be increased in Massachusetts next year by 38.4 per cent.
The financial woes of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., whose personal liabilities exceed his assets by $37-million, continued to mushroom yesterday with the following developments:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Postmaster General Winton M. Blount is in Paris on the first leg of a journey that might take him to Hanoi to assure that Christmas mail gets to Americans held prisoner in North Vietnam, Government sources reported today.

EDISON, N. J., Nov. 10 The Rev. John L. Callahan, pastor of St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church here, died Sunday in the John F. Kennedy Hospital after a heart attack in the church rectory. His age was 55.

The sculpture, drawings and prints of Louise Nevelson, who is now firmly established as the doyenne of American artists, are the subject of a new exhibition that opened to the public yesterday at the Whitney Museum.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 10 The president of a large railway union threatened today to call a partial rail strike against freight operations Dec. 11 unless the major railroads accept a wage increase well above that recommended yesterday by a Presidential mediation board.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 10 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird authorized additional training and weapons for the National Guard today to make riot control more effective and minimize injuries to guardsmen and the public.

Olivier Messiaen's colossal "Vingt Regards sur L'Enfant Jesus" was played to a turn Monday night at Hunter College Assembly Hall by a pianist who should know how to do it better than anyone. She is Mr. Messiaen's wife, Yvonne Loriod.
A Brooklyn woman asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to make the city's Welfare Commissioner reimburse her for $105 she said she lost.
Stocks on the London exchange put in another dull performance yesterday, closing mixed to higher. The turn-over of shares, however, picked up compared with previous sessions.
Hans Winkler, one of the most experienced and capable horsemen specializing in jumping, won the foremost individual class of the international competition of the National Horse Show last night.

The price of soybean futures showed sharp advances yesterday while corn prices were weak on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and oats futures prices also were lower while the prices of soybean oil and meal and iced broilers futures advanced.

BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 10 Mr. and Mrs.Joseph Becker have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Carol Becker, to Richard Joseph Garzilli. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. N. Nicholas Garzilli of San Juan, P. R.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 Semon Knudsen, who once came close to being president of the General Motors Corporation and was once president of the Ford Motor Company, is back in the automobile business.
LONDON, Nov. 11 The Conservative Government stepped in today to save RollsRoyce, Ltd., the British aircraftengine company, from looming financial disaster.

"Scramble" is one of Merce Cunningham's purest-movement works in a repertory that is pure movement in content. This is one of Mr. Cunningham's light pieces, and his dance company, scattering playfully through it in their brightly colored leotards and jumpsuits like children's marbles gave it a polished performance last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Louis E. Wolfson, the financier who completed a jail sentence in January for violating Federal securities laws, won a new trial yesterday in another case one in which he was convicted of perjury and filing false financial statements with the Government.

Dr. Rene J. Dubos, the microbiologist and experimental pathologist, has accepted an appointment as university professor and director of environmental studies at the new State University of New York College at Purchase.
MANILA, Nov. 11 A largely conservative body of delegates was elected yesterday to rewrite the Constitution drafted in 1935, when the Philippines was still under United States rule.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Senator Edward M. Kennedy is approaching another major test in his political career this time over holding his job as Democratic whip of the Senate.
Posing unofficially in the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday, Manta appeared to have successfully "stolen" the 100th running of the $55,400 Ladies Handicap.

The Third Annual International Artists series, jointly sponsored by Carnegie Hall and Jeunesse Musicales, Inc., presented a capable young Chilean pianist in his New York debut Tuesday night. The Oil Shale Corporation has arranged to eliminate approximately three-quarters of its total indebtedness by the end of this month.
Dr. Henry Goddard Leach, past president of the AmericanScandinavian Foundation, died yesterday in Regent Hospital following a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived at 1021 Park Avenue.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 11 The state's chief law enforcement officer defended in Federal Court today the use of buckshot against black students at South Carolina State College in 1968.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 A rash of proposals by the Quebec Government to give the police continuing "firmer controls" to deal with political terrorism and organized crime is arousing increasing alarm in this troubled French Canadian province.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, one of the turf's most outspoken and respected voices, succeeded Jack Dreyfus Jr. yesterday as chairman of the New York Racing Association.
Two men and a young woman and drugs with an estimated retail value of $250,000 were seized yesterday by the police in an apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens.

A downward trend in dockworker employment in the Port of New York is continuing, the Waterfront Commission reported yesterday.

Picking the right moment to refuse to win a trick is one of the more difficult areas of defensive play. Beginners tend to win every trick they can, and by doing so give the declarer considerable help. Intermediate players often lean in the opposite direction: They duck without a clear motive, only to find that the setting trick has gone out of the window.

Radway of 825 Fifth Avenue, owner of Radway Co., a pharmaceutical concern founded by his grandfather, John Radway, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 86.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 11 Miss Charlotte Russell Meyer, an actress known as Carla Meyer, and James Edward Sniechowski, an actor and writer known as Jim Scott, will be married in the spring.

Three firemen were injured one critically when a blazing four-story building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn collapsed last night, trapping them inside. Two other firemen were treated for smoke inhalation.

He re-established order and stability to end up with a May, 1968. He restored economic confidence. How did he leave the franc? He was a unifier. Above all, divisive.

The nation paid tribute to its war dead yesterday with traditional Veterans Day observances, but cold, damp weather in many parts of the country reduced crowd sizes at parades and other ceremonies.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 11 (UPI) The prosecutor in the case of S. Sgt. David Mitchell, charged with assault with intent to murder in the alleged Mylai massacre of civilians in South Vietnam, says he plans no changes in his case despite a ruling in a similar case in Georgia.
PARIS, Nov. 11 Notre Dame Cathedral, where the great of the world will pay homage to Charles de Gaulle tomorrow, has been a main stage of French history for more than 800 years.
The credit markets, partially closed yesterday for Veterans Day, continued to reflect the news that six of 12 Federal Reserve banks had reduced their discount rate.

A man was killed by a policeman yesterday after allegedly holding up a bar in upper Manhattan, and another was critically wounded last night in Harlem after he reportedly drew a revolver on two policemen.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 Andrei A. Amalrik, the dissident author of "Will the U.S.S.R. Survive Until 1984?", went on trial today in the Urals city of Sverdlovsk and reportedly denied that he was guilty of defaming the Soviet Union.
The Gulf Oil Corporation, the nation's fourth largest petroleum concern, announced yesterday a 25-cent-a-barrel increase in the price it pays for crude oil across the United States.
"The stock market had all the good news in the world this morning," a Wall Street broker declared yesterday. "So some of my customers took their profits."
DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI) Mrs. Adolph Coors Jr. died here last night of a heart attack. She was 85 years old.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 (AP) The Court of Appeals ruled today that the constitutional right of free speech did not apply to the mutilation of the American flag.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 Nguyen Dang Thuc, one of Vietnam's leading thinkers, believes that Americans should play a significant role in postwar Vietnam.
Pilots and co-pilots of Mohawk Airlines went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today after efforts to negotiate a new contract by midnight failed.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday soared in early trading and then dropped almost as fast in the afternoon.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 11 Amos B. Miller of Dalewood Drive, who headed the A.B. Miller Company, a tire concern in the Bronx, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. His age was 70.

WARSAW, Thursday, Nov. 12 Poland's Foreign Minister, Stefan Jedrychowski, said late last night that "we have approached the moment when we can complete negotiations" with West Germany over a treaty establishing normal relations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Nixon Administration has reportedly prepared a supplemental request for roughly $1-billion in military and economic aid for Cambodia, Israel, South Korea, Jordan, Lebanon and Indonesia.

SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 11 Pat Valdo, former supervisor of performance and personnel for Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey Circus, who became its first director emeritus last year, died here Saturday. He was 89 years old. A requiem mass was offered today in St. Martha's Roman Catholic Church.

A New York City official will go to Washington today to plead with State Department officials in the case of a Soviet Jew who was halted by Soviet policemen recently as he tried to enter the United States Embassy in Moscow in an effort to establish American citizenship.

Herman Badillo, who will soon represent the 21st District in Congress, called yesterday for the resignation of all five Democratic county leaders as a first step in rebuilding the party in New York City.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 11 (AP) Two battalions of Cambodian troops were ambushed today 35 miles north of Pnompenh on Highway 7. The scene was about five miles east of the district capital of Skoun. There were no reports on casualties. Two companies were sent to reinforce the ambushed units, officers at Skoun said.
Directors of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., declared yesterday a cash dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 11 and a 2 per cent stock dividend payable Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 A 9-year-old boy named Andrew Clark Hecht died in accident in Yellowstone National Park last summer. His parents, James and Amy Hecht, refused to accept his death as unavoidable and began a personal campaign to make the national parks safer for the millions of persons who visit them each year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 A group of major women's rights organizations announced today their "consensus" that a proposed substitute version of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution was inadequate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 College educators rebuffed today a plea by Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welgare, for support of the Nixon Administration's higher education bill.
An organization of service academy alumni called on President Nixon yesterday to "put aside self-serving political goals" and promptly withdraw all troops from Vietnam.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 11 At least seven members of an oil company's seismograph crew were killed tonight when a truck loaded with explosives blew up.

Vandals and rowdies, along with mechanical breakdowns, panicking passengers and a communication system that was not up to the emergency were blamed yesterday by the Transit Authority for Tuesday's massive subway tie-ups.
Danny Kaye, a truant from the Broadway musical comedy stage for nearly half a lifetime, came back on Tuesday night in the role of a 600year-old man in "Two by Two."
PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 12 President Nixon, on his way to Paris aboard Air Force One, spoke to reporters for 20 minutes and described his admiration for Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Another policeman was shot to death in New York Monday night, leading Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy to call for handgun control "on a national scale." In Baltimore, on the same day, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, who was chairman of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, declared in a lecture that no American should be allowed to own a handgun unless he can prove a need for it.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. J. Herbert Dietz Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Flanders Dietz, to Kenneth Joseph Domanski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Domanski of Wyandotte, Mich. A January wedding is planned.

The impact on a quarter-million New Yorkers, trapped without help or information, provides terrifying new evidence of the overstrain that menaces all the metropolitan lifelines traffic, subway, electricity and telephones.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation agreed today on a package of money and fringe benefits designed to end the union's eight-week strike.

PARIS, Nov. 11 European monetary authorities still view inflation as the No. 1 economic problem of the developed world. And they fear that the stillunsuccessful efforts to overwhelm it may slow, if not check, the present downswing in international interest rates.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 5 Pinball machines have replaced the Arab commandos as prime targets of Lebanese Government wrath under the new administration of President Suleiman Franjieh.
Charles Lochridge, one of the greatest American bridge players, died of cancer in Bethesda memorial Hospital in Delray Beach, Fla., yesterday. He was 65 years old.

BRIDGEWATER, N.J., Nov. 11 An insurance agent was murdered before his wife's eyes during a struggle with an armed intruder at his home here early today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 A member of the Federal Reserve Board estimated today that imposition of Import quotas on textiles and shoes, as provided in legislation pending in Congress, would cost consumers an extra $3.7-billion by 1975 and would raise the Consumer Price Index by almost one full per cent.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 11 Milton Levy, chairman of the Levy Brothers Department Store and a leader in Jewish community activities here, died today in Beth Israel Medical Center in New York after a short illness. He was 66 years old.

Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., who has been unavailable for comment since he petitioned 23 days ago for court protection under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, will face his creditors in an open meeting on Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Two major recommendations for university reform made by the President's Commission on Campus Unrest have already been implemented or are under active consideration at many campuses across the nation. They are that large universities be decentralized and that students be given the opprotunity to evaluate their instructors.

HOUSTON, Nov. 11 Harry J. Hammer, vice president of the Hammer Galleries, Inc., 51 East 57th Street, New York, died today of pneumonia at Methodist Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 781 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan.

NECKARSULM, West Germany, Nov. 11 (AP) The final contract has been signed between the General Motors Corporation, Audi-NSU Auto Union, A.G., Wankel, G.m.b.H., and the Curtiss- Wright Corporation granting G.M. nonexclusive world rights to the rotary-piston Wankel engine, Audi-NSU announced today.

ATHENS, Nov. 11 Aristotle S. Onassis, who won a lucrative oil concession from the Greek Government last January in stiff competition with his archrival, Stavros S. Niarchos, has taken legal action in a bid to force a revision of its terms.

WESTBURY, L.I. Nov. 11 Contrary to the belief of many outsiders, all is not milk and honey for owners of standardbreds. To be sure, much is heard about Duncan MacDonald of Sydney, Nova Scotia, acquiring Fresh Yankee as a yearling for $900 and proceeding to win about $800,000 with the trotting mare.
New crop soybean futures dropped sharply in early trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but a late rally turned prices around and they closed higher.

Grandmaster Larry Evans of Las Vegas produced a positional gem when he defeated National Master Toth of Brazil in the recent 19th chess Olympiad at Siegen, West Germany. Playing White, his double-Indian treatment of the debut befuddled his opponent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Government investigators said today that jammed controls in the tail section may have caused the Sept. 8 crash of a jetliner that killed 11 crew members at New York's Kennedy International Airport.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) Angela Davis has been indicted for murder, kidnapping and conspiracy stemming from a courtroom escape attempt here Aug. 7. Four persons died in the attempt.
The three television networks will provide extensive live coverage by satellite today of the funeral ceremonies and burial of Charles de Gaulle.

The New York Stock Exchange, and presumably most of its members, are sensitive to suggestions that requests for commission increases on small trades are out of order.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI) Teachers approved overwhelmingly today a new twoyear wage contract, ending a dispute that delayed the opening of public schools in September and closed them for three days in October.

COMMACK, L.I., Nov., 11 Suffolk County housewives and stores reacted calmly today to the ban on most detergents that was approved yesterday by the County Legislature.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 12 The Soviet Union's unmanned spacecraft Luna 17 apparently continued to travel toward the moon early this morning on a mission officially described as "the scientific exploration of the moon and near-moon space."
GREENVILLE, N.C., Nov. 11 (AP) Dr. Robert Lee Humber, a co-founder of the United World Federalists organization, which supports the United Nations, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 (UPI) Five major newspapers in the San Francisco Bay area have agreed with 16 unions to extend until the end of 1973 contracts that were to expire next February, it was announced today.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 10 Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, who has ruled Paraguay with an iron hand for 16 years, says he is determined that the political turmoil and terrorism afflicting the rest of South America will remain barred from his country.
ROME, Nov. 11 Raffaele Minichiello, the United States marine corporal who hijacked an airliner from California to Rome more than a year ago, was sentenced tonight to seven and a half years in prison.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 11 (UPI) A left-wing Iraeli magazine, Haolam Hazeh, published today what it termed a top-secret letter sent to the United States Embassy here in 1959 to try to recruit Moshe Dayan, then a private citizen,,into the Central Intelligence Agency.
The gleaming Atlantic salmon, whose incomparable strength, agility, and beauty have delighted man for centuries, is well on its way to becoming an international cause celebre.
The president of Local 3036, New York Taxi Drivers Union, told 300 fleet garage shop chairmen and committeemen last night that negotiations for a new contract had reached a critical stage.

Two defense contractors, the Olin Corporation and Remington Arms Company, yesterday announced that 1,200 workers would be laid off as a result of a Defense Department decision to discontinue procurement of 5.56-mm. small arms ammunition from private contractors.
ATLANTA, Nov. 11 A recently completed study shows that black students make up less than 2 per cent of the total enrollment of integrated law schools in the South.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 11 (AP) A four-year development plan to rebuild war-torn parts of Nigeria and to promote the "meaningful Nigerianization" of foreign companies was announced today by the head of state.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to rule out draft exemptions for men who are conscientiously opposed to the Vietnamese war but not to all wars.
HONG KONG, Nov. 11 President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan of Pakistan is being given one of the biggest welcomes in Peking ever accorded a foreign chief of state on a visit to Communist China.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 Fort Marcy became a millionaire to day. The 6-year-old Virginiabred campaigner owned by Paul Mellon, the financier-philanthropist, won the 19th Washington D.C. International, as expected by most of the 28,764 fans on hand.
COLOMBEY-LES-DEUXEGLISES, France, Nov. 11 President Pompidou and Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas paid private homage to Charles de Gaulle today.

A seven-piece band from Nigeria is replacing the jazz sounds usually heard at the Village Vanguard with the lively rhythms of the Highlife, the Akwete, the Mutaba and other popular African dances. The band, led by Victor Uwaifo, is making its first American nightclub appearance. It will be there through Sunday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 The perils of casting Wagner are illustrated by the current production of "Tristan and Isolde" at the San Francisco Opera. When the 1969-70 announcements were made, John Vickers was the tenor, singing opposite the Isolde of Birgit Nilsson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Brookings Institution published today the second in its new series of technical economic papers on current economic issues. By coincidence rather than design, the conclusions of the papers tended to point to the need for an expansionary government policy in 1971, particularly monetary policy.

Ever since the Nixon Administration tried, more than a year ago, to give special visibility to a flawed study that questioned the effectiveness of Project Head Start, the future of that preschool education program has seemed in doubt.

Housewives who have been paying more and more for their groceries as the food prices have risen in the last consecutive 41 months will probably find the situation worse next year, according to economists and food specialists.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 Jacques KosciuskoMorizet, the French delegate, said today that his Government, in close cooperation with United States officials, had intensified its efforts to curb illicit traffic in narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Government auditors said today that they had recommended, but the Defense Department had rejected, a greater use of private doctors to decide if youths were fit for the draft.

Ford has gotten another of its better ideas and is getting the jump on the other Detroit giants with a massive advertising campaign aimed at major consumer complaints pollution, safety, service and durability. And, for good measure, Ford is taking on foreign cars.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) In a move to spur the nation's housing market, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board proposed new regulations today designed to step up lending by savings and loan associations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 In less than two years, Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the United States Attorney General, has become a household word for three-quarters of the nation's adult population, according to a Gallup Poll.
LONDON, Nov, 11 Summonses involving allegations of bribery and corruption have been served on three London detectives with a total of almost 50 years' service, Scotland Yard announced today.
WOR-TV, Channel 9, which began a nightly half-hour newscast on Monday, dismissed its theater and arts critic, Joel Crothers, five hours before he was to deliver his first review.
The London stock market rallied yesterday in late trading following reports from Detroit that the General Motors strike had been settled.

Anyone who has ever stirred up a batch of pate brisee knows that Julia Child is a co-author of "Mastering the Art of French Cooking," Volumes I and II, and is the hard-breathing cook on "The French Chef" television series, bringing a practical, often humorous, message of encouragement to the aspiring cooks of America.
DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI) Colorado health officials said yesterday that concentrations of poisonous mercury had been discovered in fish taken from Navajo Lake on the ColoradoNew Mexico border.

The Board of Regents yesterday proposed the coordination and eventual integration of the state's 22 public library systems and said that the state should give considerable financial support to the project.
PARIS, Nov. 11 Europe's neutral states have just begun negotiating a formula of accommodation with what may be in a few year's time an enlarged Common Market.
The 1970-71 season of Clarion Concerts opened at Tully Hall on Tuesday night with a typically Clarion kind of contributing to the commemoration of the bicentennial of Beethoven's birth.

Day-care centers will serve 1,700 more preschool children than had been forecast by the city officials under a temporary relaxation of regulations announced yesterday by the Human Resources Administration.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 10 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eight-time United States chess champion, yesterday defeated Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, in the second round of the eighth interzonal tournament of Palma de Malloroa. The event, a 24man knockout, will determine the challenger for the world title.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 11 The Tiz Hazari Courthouse is a human beehive in whose jammed rooms and corridors can be found a microcosm of the problems and grievances of northern India.

COLOMBEY-LES-DEUXEGLISES, France, Nov. 12 Charles de Gaulle was buried today as he wished, in simplicity, surrounded by his family, his fellew villagers, his comrades of the Liberation and thousands of his grieving countrymen.

Corporate bond yields continued to move down yesterday, pushed lower by the reduction in the prime rate by all major commercial banks. The Consumers Power Company sold $50-million of Aaa-rated bonds that were priced to yield 8.55 per cent, or 10 basis points less than a similarly rated issue of Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company bonds marketed Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Internal Revenue Service, under pressure from a wide coalition of conservation, consumer-protection and other interests, backed down today and agreed to continue to grant taxexempt status to organizations that bring lawsuits in the public interest.

Tomorrow is the first anniversary of the launching of the Apollo 12 lunar mission, and to commemorate the event the American Museum of Natural History will display a sample of moon rock brought back by the astronauts of that mission.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 More than 60 years after the relationship between fat and diet and the development of hardening of the arteries was first noted, physicians are still debating whether to recommend a low saturated fat diet to the American public in hopes of stemming the current epidemic of heart disease.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 12 The $44,083 Lady Maud Pace will be held between the fourth and fifth races on Saturday night as a nonbetting event, Roosevelt Raceway announced today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets acquired a forward, John Tresvant, from the Los Angeles Lakers today for a "high future draft choice," a club spokesman said. The 6-foot-7-inch, 31-year-old Tresvant has played seven seasons in the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The National Air Pollution Control Administration announced today that it had asked airlines to halt voluntarily the dumping of 13 million pounds of jet fuel each year into the sky near airports.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 (AP) A 16-year-old boy has been denied the rank of Eagle Scout, scouting's highest honor, because he is an atheist.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A proposed reorganization of the controversial Federal program of legal services for the poor, which leading lawyers feared would weaken the program, has been killed.

LOS ANGELES He, an architect, is 30 years old; she, a teacher, is 45. And because of the age difference, their first six months of marriage supplied a few unpleasant incidents, although they weren't as unsettling as you might expect.

NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J., Nov. 12 Mrs. Evelyn Cosby Jackson, the wife of Joseph Jackson and a former teacher of biochemistry at Middlebury College and at the College of New Rochelle, died Monday in Summit Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived at 233 Mountain Avenue.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 A lawyer for William A. Sternkopf Jr., a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, delivered to a Federal grand jury here today financial records that link him with three corporations in which John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic boss, is "a principal."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Senator Ernest F. Hollings accused President Nixon today of failing to keep his promise to end hunger in America and said the President had, in fact, followed a food assistance policy of "to the rear march."

Beethoven had another opening Wednesday night, a major one at Carnegie Hall. Eugene Istomin, Isaac Stern and Leonard Rose gave the first of eight concerts they are to play there this season, covering all of Beethoven's mature piano chamber music.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) Goals by Gary Sabourin and Tim Ecclestone gave the St. Louis Blues a 2-1 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) A pilots' strike grounded Mohawk Airlines today and Federal mediation efforts to get contract talks started again failed after a two-hour meeting.
Jim Hudson, one of the heroes of the Jets' Super Bowl season, was waived by the injury-battered team yesterday, and will be reduced to taxisquad status next week.

The 32d annual dinner and concert arranged by LADO in behalf of its scholarship fund will take place Nov. 22 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Boris Goldovsky, lecturer on opera and an impresario, will be guest of honor. Gail Robinson, Metropolitan Opera coloratura soprano, will sing.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey today denied a defense challenge to the jury selection system and ordered the murder-kidnapping trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins, the Black Panther leaders, to begin Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A confidential Congressional report warns that the replacement of phosphates in household detergents by a chemical called NTA would not significantly reduce water pollution and might increase hazards to both people and their environment.
SALLISAW, Okla, Nov. 12 (AP) At least 20 horses were killed last night when fire destroyed a barn at the Blue Ribbon Downs quarter horse race track. Cause of the blaze was unknown.
LOS ANGELES, Nov.12 (UPI) Attorneys for Sirhan B. Sirhan appealed today his death sentence for the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Following is the text of the guidelines that the Internal Revenue Service announced it will use in determining whether organizations engaged in litigation in the public interest will be granted tax-exempt status:
BUFFALO, Nov. 12 (UPI) Sherry Lynn Brown, described as a Black Panther party leader, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today during a raid on a Panther committee headquarters.
NOTTINGHAM, England, Nov. 12 (Reuters) A 3-yearold boy was the most important member of a schoolboy housebreaking gang, a juvenile court was told here today.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 (UPI) Lee Trevino almost stopped chattering today.

An accountant and a mortgage broker from Long Island were convicted by a Federal jury here last night of conspiring to arrange kickbacks on a $1-million mortgage loan from the teamster union pension funds in 1964. Eight other defendants were acquitted.

NEW HOPE, Pa., Nov. 12 Miss Nancy Ruth Smith of New York, a freelance writer and fashion publicist, was married here this afternoon to Richard Henry Bate, assistant vice president and associate counsel for the Beneficial Management Corporation of Morristown, N.J. Mayor George W. Bailey performed the ceremony at the country home of the maid of honor, Miss Margot Johnson of New Hope and New York.
Criminal Court Judge Amos S. Basel died yesterday at his home, 45 East Ninth Street, after a long illness. He was 59 years old.
A unanimous decision by the Court of Appeals yesterday ended the last hope that the Liberal party's state leadership might be able to oust J. Stanley Shaw as the party's county chairman in Queens.

"Oh, the Rock Island line is a very fine line!" Chances are you'd Be hard put to find a railroad analyst who would agree with the folksinger's romantic assessment of the deeply troubled Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.
ROME, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Yugoslavia's Ambassador to the Vatican today presented his credentials to Pope Paul, formally ending an 18-year rift.
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, continued his efforts yesterday to break the deadlock in the taxi negotiations, but he described the situation as "extremely critical."

And now the man to whom a Cardin label in his clothes is as important as the key to his Jaguar can sport the French couturier's imprint in his mink coat. Pierre Cardin, who fathered the peacock revolution in the 1960's with his nipped-in men's fashions, has done his first complete collection of masculine furs.

W.E. Hutton Co., the brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it has established what it believed to be the first business organization whose function was to serve as a custody and clearing specialist for financial institutions.

A plan to restructure radically the municipal government by shifting authority for many essential city services from the Mayor to Borough Presidents was offered yesterday by Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams.
Credit expansion continued at a moderate pace during the most recent two-week period ended Wednesday, Federal Reserve banking statistics disclosed.

They Soviets are embarked on a program which reveals a singular awareness of the importance of seapower, and an unmistakable resolve to become the most powerful maritime force in the world. They demonstrate a thorough understanding of the basic elements of seapower: knowledge of the seas, a strong modern merchant marine, and a powerful new navy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 The United States, which has long pursued a policy of all-out opposition to Communist China's admission to the United Nations, today argued instead against the expulsion of Nationalist China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that the Nixon Administration would ask Congress to pass new antisubversive legislation soon after the new session begins in January.
Among the poor and the powerful in Harlem, L. Joseph Overton has long been a force to be reckoned with.
BONN, Nov. 12 The federal Government announced an intensive drive today against the peddling and possession of drugs and narcotics in West Germany.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP) Admiral's Shield ended a five-race losing streak today at Churchill Downs by sweeping past the Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, near the finish line to win the $5,000 Bold Ruler Purse by a neck and return $22.80 straight.
Two weeks before they were indicted here for an alleged bomb conspiracy, the Black Panthers set up a priority list for bombings of public places, a police undercover agent testified yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) Danny Murtaugh, the tobac co-chewing manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, announced today that he would return as skipper of the club next season.
PARIS, Nov. 12 President Nixon chatted briefly and informally late this afternoon with Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet President.

A cocktail dance has been arranged for Sunday evening at the Pierre in behalf of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association. The event, to start at 6 P.M., will include a buffet.

MONTGOMERY, N.Y., Nov. 12 The state's Public Service Commission opened its first public hearing today under the new authority it has to allow power lines to run through any part of the state despite local opposition or even local laws.

BUFFALO, Nov. 12 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a suit here today charging that most local construction unions had "a historical and continued pattern" of racial discrimination that has prevented Negroes from getting jobs on public building projects.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 (UPI) Eddie Arcaro, the only jockey to win horse racing's Triple Crown twice, was reported "extremely well" today following surgery to repair a blocked coronary artery.
LONDON, Nov. 12 A Jewish organization here said today that it expected a Soviet trial of accused hijackers, including at least 20 Jews, to open in Leningrad about Nov. 20.
Woodcock hunters in New York State, Maine and Massachusetts who were concerned about whether the birds they shot were dangerous to eat apparently have little to worry about.
Norman, Craig Kummel resigned yesterday the dwindling Trans World Airlines air cargo account to make itself available for other upin-the-air business.

PARIS, Nov. 12 The simplicity of General de Gaulle's funeral in the little village of Colombey-les-DeuxEglises was suitable to his carefully composed public character and retiring private personality. The contrast between the modest ceremony according with his dictated wish and the splendid commemoration in Notre Dame, attended by the world's most eminent leaders, served only to underscore an essential austerity in the Fifth Republic's founder.
Sam Huff, his old Giant jersey and helmet still part of his living room decoration, returns to Yankee Stadium Sunday with mixed feelings.
ROME, Nov. 12 The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, had an unusually long audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican this afternoon after three days of talks with Italian Government leaders.
Philip Dechert, a lawyer in Philadelphia and a civic leader, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital, New Bedford, Mass., after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Nonquitt, Mass.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 12 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles scored his second straight victory last night, against William Addison of San Francisco in the third round of the eighth interzonal tournament of Palma de Mallorca. The event is a 24-man elimination and qualification round robin.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 12 (UPI) The Kansas Attorney General nullified today the election of Philip C. Hill, a hippie, as justice of the peace.

A $2.1-miliion project to provide scholarships for about 1,000 minority-group graduates of junior and community colleges who wish to further their education was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation, The Associated Press reported.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 Tom Q. Black, University of Tennessee benefactor and expresident and founder of Tom Black, Inc., now the Tom Huston Peanut Company, died of a heart attack at a hospital here this afternoon. He was 66 years old.
GARRISON, N.Y., Nov. 12 More than 200 priests, nuns and laymen met at a Roman Catholic monastery this week in an attempt to determine the women's liberation movement's meaning for religion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Justice Department announced today it would not oppose the proposed merger of two of the nation's largest pharmaceutical concerns, the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and Parke, Davis Co.

Prices plunged yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, as the market hardly glanced at the proposed settlement of the General Motors strike and the quarter-of-a-point reductions in the prime rate posted by the major banks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Perhaps it was inevitable that Robert Charles Mardian would some day wind up in the Justice Department as head of its Internal Security Division.

There has been much talk in the concert business of making the concert and recital format less rigid in order to attract the informally minded young. On Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, two of New York's well-known and well-liked musicians made a mild stab in this direction.

CANBERRA The Public Accounts Committee of the Australian Parliament has been examining witnesses over a budget allocation for the first stage of a naval base facility at Cockburn Sound near Perth on the West coast of this three-million-square-mile continent. A pacifist geologist solemnly raised with the Committee the question of pollution, while a senior naval officer justified the allocation partly in terms of the growing Soviet presence in the Indian Ocean area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of New York State's Public Service Commission, called on the electric power industry to "refrain from encouraging the wasteful use of energy."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (UPI) Tom Van Arsdale scored nine of Cincinnati's final 23 points tonight as the Royals routed San Francisco, 121-107, Van Arsdale finished with 29 points, the high total for the game.

Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., one of the world's largest aluminum producers, had record revenues but lower earnings in the third quarter and first nine months reflecting the impact of the higher rate of the Canadian dollar this year and the 4 month strike that shut down the Alcan smelter at Kitimat, British Columbia.
Lois Holland Callaway, Inc., may have the ultimate solution to the agency-client relationship problem create your own clients.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 106.9 this week from 108 last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Nov. 7 was 13 per cent below the level of the corresponding week of last year.
A City Council committee invited Dr. William J. Ronan to testify before the committee yesterday and said it would hold up an appropriation for the Transit Authority until he did so.
DENVER, Nov. 12 (AP) Joe Belmont was dropped today as coach of the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association, Don Ringsby, club president, announced.
The most serious recent challenge to Einstein's so-called "general" theory of relativity appears to be in serious trouble, but its co-inventor is not yet ready to give up.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 12 (UPI) The biracial Mississippi Council on Human Relations announced today that it would withdraw its funds from two Jackson banks that allegedly made loans totaling $600,000 to private, segregated schools here.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced yesterday that its new film, "Ryan's Daughter," will be marketed nationally with no mention of its "R," or "restricted," rating by the Motion Pictures Association of America. State Summons Producers And Equity to Negotiations Actors Equity Association and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers have been summoned back to the State Mediation Board for negotiations starting at 5 P.M. today, 61 hours short of a new strike deadline.

Cazzie Russell suffered a broken left wrist in the fourth quarter of last night's game that the New York Knickerbockers lost to the Baltimore Bullets, 110-108, at Madison Square Garden. The Knick forward will be out of action for a couple of months.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies obtained a showcause order in Manhattan Supreme Court today barring the Jewish Defense League from committing any disruptive acts at federation headquarters, 130 East 59th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Government announced today a major investigation into the increase in crude oil prices posted yesterday by the Gulf Oil Corporation and followed today by the Atlantic Richfield Company.

The exhibition called "Masterpieces of Fifty Centuries," which opens tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is at once one of the most pleasurable and one of the most irritating exhibitions ever mounted. Since the exhibition is enormous more than 500 objects, according to the museum both its pleasures and its irritations are sizable.
The Secret Service reported yesterday that three arrests had been made in a continuing investigation of counterfeit food stamps that have been circulating in impoverished neighborhoods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Nixon Administration is scheduled to deliver 18 more Skyhawk A-4 jet attack planes to Israel under a $500-million pledge of arms made to induce that country to accept the United States proposal for the Middle East cease-fire, which began on Aug. 7.

Charles Lochridge, who died in Florida earlier this week at the age of 65, was one of the most colorful of the group of experts who dominated the tournament game in the nineteen-thirties and forties. He was notable not only for his imaginative bidding and his lightning and brilliant play of the dummy but also for his quick wit in the post-mortem.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 12 Ludmila Turisheva, the Soviet Union world champion, and Heruichi Okamura of Japan each won four gold medals, including those for the individual over-all championships at the world invitation gymnastic tournament.

The Giants, one game out of first place and one out of fourth in their division race, are favored over Washington by a point in Sunday's game here. The Jets, off to Los Angeles to play the Rams, are underdogs again by 17 points.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 12 Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. voluntarily handed over to Federal agents today the records of the Winthrop Lawrence Corporation, a financial holding company that he controlled with Thomas A. Shaheen Jr. The agents received the records at the company's offices in Chevy Chase, Md.
SANTA CRUZ, Calif. Nov. 12 (AP) A shaggy-haired former auto mechanic, charged with killing five persons at a hilltop mansion Oct. 19, pleaded not guilty today.

The Board of Estimate is expected to act today on a recommendation that the city purchase for about $1-million 450 school buses involved in a strike that has stranded 29,000 Manhattan and Brooklyn students, including 3,000 handicapped children.

LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) The grand jury that exonerated National Guardsmen in the deaths of four Kent State University students saw portions of a Federal Bureau of Investigation document that reportedly said the shootings had not been directly provoked, the special prosecutor in the case says.

Clear Spring Stables' unsung Joya G., a 2-year-old colt who had spent much of his short career chasing victory at Rockingham Park with unimpressive results, suddenly was thrust into the spotlight yesterday at Aqueduct.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
