The Greenwich House annual antiques show, which opened yesterday at 27 Barrow Street, is for browsers with patience and determination. For though the antique is present it is overwhelmingly outnumbered by elderly odds and ends.

DALLAS, Nov. 12 Mrs. Virginia Long Murchison, widow of Clinton (Clint) Williams Murchison, the Texas industrialist whose financial empire was estimated at a half-billion dollars after his death in June, 1969, and Edward David Linthicum, owner of Deep Creek Ranch in San Saba, southwest of Dallas, plan to be married here on Tuesday.

District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx has informed junior and senior high school officials of the legal actions they may take to control drug sales and use among students including their right to search students and their desks and lockers on a "reasonable suspicion" of finding drugs.
ALGIERS, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The Government today announced the nationalization of the holdings here of Mobil Oil and Newmont Overseas Oil, American cmopanies that it has controlled since 1967.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Vice President Agnew defended tonight the tactics used by the White House in this year's election campaign and said that the voters had responded to "as positive a message as ever a political campaign offered the country."
Steeplechase devotees hope to perpetuate the $100,000 Colonial Cup by hitching it to a lottery similar to the Irish Sweepstakes.

PARIS, Nov.12 This morning was for the dignitaries President Pompidou, who arrived at Notre Dame four minutes late. President Nixon, alone and somber in his black limousine. Kings princes, presidents, prime ministers.

CARBONDALE, Ill., Nov. 12 (AP) Ten persons were wounded, including four policemen, during a series of shootings and a gun battle with blacks today at a house in a predominantly Negro area, the police reported.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 President Salvador Allende Gossens announced today that Chile, the country he has governed for 10 days, had re-established full relations with Cuba.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 (AP) Bruce Devlin and David Graham of Australia came home 13 strokes under par with a combined score of 131 today and moved to a threestroke lead over Argentina in the first round of the 18th World Cup golf competition.
The New York City Ballet will present three premieres in its 13-week season that opens Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.
Speed records, boat drivers and women's rights will find themselves in jeopardy at the outboard world championship Nov. 28 and 29 at Lake Havasu City, Ariz.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount will soon appoint the first merit, nonpolitical postmasters in the nation's history, Post Office officials said today.
Senior physicians in the city's 18 municipal hospitals charged yesterday that "hundreds of preventable deaths annually" were being caused by a critical shortage of nurses.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 With the grip of military government in Argentina more relaxed than at any time since 1966, organized labor paralyzed the nation today with a general strike and five political parties demanded an immediate return to elective democracy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The cigarette advertising code has stopped functioning, ending a six-year experiment in selfregulation by the tobacco industry.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday voted to suspend trading in the common stock and 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures of Schick Electric, Inc. because its net tangible assets and average earnings no longer meet the exchange's requirements.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 12 Old figs, goat bones, Arabian coffee grounds, wadded newspapers aflame with red headlines: all the tent trash and villa sweepings of this desert capital have become a problem for its tidy ruler, King Hussein.
AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 12 (UPI) A propane gas plant exploded today killing four persons, including a woman and her two children who burned to death when flames enveloped their car.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, who has been Chief of Naval Operations for the last four and a half months, is taking the "Mickey Mouse" out of the Navy.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 The over all problem of international trade in textiles should be examined within the framework of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the executive head of this intergovernmental agency said today.
Profit taking halved an early rise in the price of nearby soybean futures options but the deferred, or new crop contracts, held their advance on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 Dismissing the arguments of over 400 landlords as "ponderous" and "fallacious," the Court of Appeals today upheld New York City's law governing the control of pollutants emitted from apartment house incinerators and fuel burners.

An urgent plea for approval of the proposed rescue of troubled Goodbody Co. by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., was issued yesterday to the membership of the New York Stock Exchange by its president, Robert W. Haack.

CAIRO, Nov. 12 President Anwar el-Sadat reported tonight that the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, had promised to increase support of the United Arab Republic to offset pressures on the country after the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 The United States Lawn Tennis Association delayed a final decision today on whether to bar all contract professionals from U.S.L.T.A. sanctioned prize money tournaments in 1971.

Walter J. Donnelly, who during his 25 years with the Foreign Service won distinction as one of this country's leading experts on Central and South American affairs, died yesterday of a heart attack in Bogota, Columbia. He was 74 years old and had lived in Caracas, Venezuela.
The American Stock Exchange sustained its biggest daily loss in three weeks yesterday as the list retreated on moderate volume.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 12 Adrian H. Phillips of 494 East Saddle River Road, a wellknown New York realtor, died yesterday in Valley Hospital after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) Ridana, under a strong ride by Jimmy Moseley, won the $15,000 North Hills Purse at Garden State Park today by two lengths. She was clocked in 1:12 for six furlongs.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 12 Two probable themes in the defense of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. emerged today when his court-martial for the premeditated murder of 102 South Vietnamese civilians officially opened more than two and a half years after the alleged massacre at Sonmy.
The Federal National Mortgage Association is scheduled to make a rights offering to stockholders today for an estimated 1.13 million shares.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) A friend of William E. Thoresen 3d testified today that he once interrupted the Chicago steel heir while he was trying to throw his wife out a 20th floor hotel window.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The White House is likely to intensify Federal aid to New York City in its effort to capture the state in 1972, but Mayor Lindsay is not likely to receive much of the credit, Presidential aides said here today.

The annual Jamaica Hospital fund-raising drive, which is in its final two weeks, will be highlighted by the hospital's 79th anniversary dinner dance tomorrow at the Hotel Pierre.

The city's Off-Track Betting Corporation will go into two sidelines consulting and computer time lending according to its president, Howard J. Samuels.

In the Soviet Union under Josef Stalin, at least 700,000 members of the Soviet Communist party were murdered or perished in labor camps, in addition to millions of peasants who were deliberately starved to death.
GENEVA, Nov. 12 The Rev. W. Henry Crane, secretary for Africa of the World Council of Churches mission division, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 49 years old.
JACKSON, Tenn., Nov. 12 Sin not war, crime or social discontent, but old-fashioned sin is hanging heavy over Southern towns like ambivalent Jackson this month.
The terms of the national strike settlement at General Motors make more imperative than ever action by the Nixon Administration to check the wage-price spiral.

WARSAW, Nov. 12 West Germany and Poland began today to put the final touches to their treaty on normal relations, with Bonn agreeing to Warsaw's demand that the controversial ethnic German issue be excluded.

A stevedoring company in which Anthony Scotto, the International Longshoremen's Association official, allegedly had a financial interest was denied a license to operate in the Port of New York yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 Representatives of the striking United Automobile Workers overwhelmingly approved today a contract agreement with the General Motors Corporation. The strikers are expected to approve the contract by a week from tomorrow.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy said here today that the Administration's last official budget estimate was "no longer accurate," but he termed estimates of a deficit of as much as $20-billion "misleading."
The boycott of Intermediate School 142 in South Jamaica, Queens, entered its sixth day yesterday as 300 parents, students and others milled about while the police stood by.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI) Gerald C. Weeks, of East Northport, L.I., a Federal Aviation Administration official, and David McKay, of Wayne, Pa., were killed yesterday when their twin engine Cessna slammed into a heavily wooded mountaintop near here.
PARIS, Nov. 12 The people of France and leaders from more than 80 nations took part today in a day-long farewell to Charles de Gaulle.

Major banks across the nation lowered their basic interest charge on business loans yesterday. The cut, amounting to one-quarter of one percentage point, brought this "prime" lending rate down to 7 per cent, as compared to the record high of 8 per cent the banks were posting last winter.

A Federal judge found yesterday that Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack, along with an official of a Harlem grocery employes' union, L. Joseph Overton, and other union leaders and businessmen had conspired unlawfully to force the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative out of business or into submission by calling a strike against it.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 12 The Chrysler Corporation, whose entry in the subcompact market is still on the drawing boards, announced today that it would do battle against Ford's Pinto and General Motors's Vega with a Japanese import.

Bonnie Cashin is as American as, well, apple pie. There aren't too many fashion designers around who can make that statement. Most of them keep themselves busy jetting to Europe to admire the newest interpretations of the cowboy look or to swoon over the way French girls tie-dye a scarf.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 Seventeen-year-old Dianne Lake a prosecution witness, ended her testimony at the Tate-LaBianca murder trial today saying that she had been kicked and beaten by Charles M. Manson, one of the defendants.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Total business inventories rose about $600-million in September, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase, however, was less than July or August.

Fourteen debutantes, daughters of prominent LatinAmerican families in the greater New York area, will be presented to society at the Debutante Ball tomorrow night by the Latin-American Court of the Catholic Daughters of America in the Hilton Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 Richard Arthur Drew, business manager of the Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Opera Associations for 30 years who was widely known among company managers of touring Broadway shows, died of cancer yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Burbank, Calif. He was 62 years old.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) John Brisker scored 53 points in a losing effort as the Pittsburgh Condors were beaten by the Indiana Pacers, 135-132, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
ATLANTA, Nov. 12 The National Education Association has criticized public school desegregation policies in Louisiana and Mississippi.

Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, president of Columbia University from 1968 to 1970, was given Columbia's highest alumni award last night for "holding the university together" and "creating a more harmonious campus with the skill of an experienced administrator and the deftness of a practical diplomat."

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 Andrei A. Amalrik, the author of a book predicting the doom of the Soviet state, was reportedly found guilty today and sentenced to three years' confinement in a labor camp on charges of having defamed the Soviet Union.

It's now or never for Columbia and Penn. The two Ivy League teams go into tomorrow's Franklin Field football game with identical records, three victories and four defeats. A triumph will give the victor a chance at a winning season.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 12 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers recorded their first victory in the National Basketball Association tonight with a 105-103 triumph over the Portland Trailblazers. They had lost their first 15 games in league play.
The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that, "at the request of the Taiwan Government," it had studied the feasibility of building a steel mill in Taiwan.
Cryptography is coming to the checkout counter as consumer groups have begun to pressure supermarket chains to take the secrecy out of the codes now stamped on almost every item.

The State University of New York at Buffalo reported yesterday that scientists there had achieved "the first artificial synthesis of a living [and reproducing] cell."

Murray Stockman, president of the Queens County Bar Association in 1954, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 125-10 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 69 years old. His law office was in Forest Hills, Queens.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP) Gene Rhodes, who had his team in second place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division, was dismissed today by the Kentucky Colonels.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 Representative Wright Patman, long a critic of the banking industry, held out the promise today that savings and loan associations would be able to operate more like banks.

Now that Charles de Gaulle is gone, it is clear that the remaining political managers of the world are a different breed from the heroic leaders of the last generation. Even on his way to the grave, the dead de Gaulle somehow managed to retain the gift of grace, even a glint of magic, and make the living Presidents and Prime Ministers seem rather plain.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 Mstislay Rostropovich, the virtuoso Soviet cellist, is reported to have written an impassioned defense of the author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, whose selection for the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature has been officially denounced here.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 The Soviet Union and Communist China took another apparent step today toward improving their relations with the arrival of a Soviet delegation in Peking for trade talks.
British Government bonds and some mining shares attracted buyers, but the rest of the London stock market was lower yesterday.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association elected a new slate of officers yesterday at its annual meeting at the Hotel Delmonico.

The annual tour and reception sponsored by the Women's Architectural Auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects will take place Wednesday at the new City University of New York Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. The benefit event, to aid the auxiliary's scholarship program, will be held from 4 to 8 P.M. in the 18-story building.

It's no secret that mail deliveries are neither as fast nor as efficient as they were in earlier years. But that wasn't the reason why Willi Daume bypassed the post office and traveled several thousand miles the other day with an envelope carefully tucked away in his briefcase. It was to be a special delivery of considerable significance.

SUNOL, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) Dick Whetzle of Landover, Md., and Francisco Lopez of Hayward, Calif., shot fourunder-par 68's today to share the first-round lead in the $50,000 Professional Golfers' Association club professionals championship at Sunol Valley.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (UPI) Second-seeded Tom Gorman of Seattle reached the semifinals of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today but needed a tie-breaker to overcome John Paish of England, 6-3, 7-6.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 12 (AP) Zelmo Beaty and Donnie Freeman hit 39 points each tonight in leading a second half comeback that carried the Utah Stars to a 125-115 victory over the Floridians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 "Ladies and gentlemen, I begin by saying you aren't going to have Charlie Goodell to kick around any longer and neither will the President nor the Vice President."

A Federal judge postponed action yesterday on a suit that sought to restrain the Columbia Broadcasting System and its Washington affiliate, WTOPTV, from showing the program "Wild, Wild West" because it "contains fictionalized violence and horror harmful to the mental health and well-being of minor children."
There is at least one man who would object to Big Board economist William C. Freund's argument that the New York Stock Exchange is not a monopoly.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 A Philadelphia group is in Europe this week to drum up interest in the nation's bicentennial exposition year in 1976. But back home the plans already have run into major snags.
Racing's get-rich-enticement of its younger generation will hit a new peak today at Cherry Hill, N.J., with the 18th running of the Garden State Stakes.

LONDON, Nov. 13 Whether the top tennis pros will play at Forest Hills and Wimbledon next year may hinge on secret talks that were concluded this morning. The meetings of British Lawn Tennis Association officials arid Mike Davies, executive director of World Championship Tennis, which controls the contracts of 32 leading professionals, were held to ward off warfare between W.C.T. and the International Lawn Tennis Federation.

PLAINVIEW, N.J., Nov. 13 (UPI)?The end of the manufacture in the United States of Ottmar Mergenthaler's linotype, will come about early next year. Its sole competitor, the Intertype, will continue to be made in Brooklyn.
REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP) Some 3,000 young demonstrators fought the police today in a clash that shattered a month-old lull in rioting in this southern city.
Fleet taxicab owners attempted yesterday to decide how large a fare increase they would require to settle their contract dispute with the taxi drivers.

LONDON, Nov. 13 Bessie Braddock, one of the last of a dwindling band of Labor members of Parliament whose socialism was fashioned in the days of soup kitchens and hunger marches, died today in Liverpool Hospital after a long illness. She was 71-years old.

Thousands of homebound subway riders were delayed for nearly an hour at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday when a 10-car IND D train headed for Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, stalled on the Manhattan Bridge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 Hamer H. Budge has resigned as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective at the end of this year's session of Congress.

SERENGETI NATIONAL PARK, Tanzania, Nov. 11 A conference of African wildlife management officials has been urged to support further efforts to curtail drastically the trade in the skins of leopards, cheetahs, zebras and ostriches.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 13 (AP) James Sugden, 20 years old, and Patricia Berglund, 19, were held without bail today on murder charges in the thrillkilling of a 13-year-old boy.
Cazzie Russell sat in the Knicks' office yesterday at Madison Square Garden, his left hand in a cast that extended down from the elbow. He had spent the night at Roosevelt Hospital.

Sales of new cars by the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation rose in the first 10 days of November, compared with sales in the similar 1969 period, the companies reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned North Vietnam today that the United States stood ready to retaliate against any continued firing at American reconnaissance aircraft.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 A court-appointed psychiatrist in the Tate-La Bianca murder trial described Dianne Lake, a key prosecution witness, today as "an immature girl" but insisted that she was not suffering from any mental disorder.
A California company that produces housing units made a spectacular stock market debut this week, but other new-issue activity was again lackluster.

It was inevitable that President Allende would restore Chile's relations with Cuba sooner rather than later. He had promised throughout his campaign that he would re-establish formal ties with Havana and his prompt action will please many Chileans.
PARIS, Nov. 13 The Place de l'Etoile, site of one of France's most impressive monuments, the Arc de Triomphe, was renamed today as the Place Charles de Gaulle.
The merger of Parke, Davis Co., and the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, two of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies, was completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) The State Department said again today that despite the return of two Soviet naval vessels to the Cuban port of Cienfuegos, it still had no information to indicate that the Russians were trying to establish a naval base there.
LONDON, Nov. 13 The British subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation today reported a record loss of $26.1-million for the fiscal year ended July 31.

For the second of its two concerts on the Carnegie Hall International Festival of Visiting Orchestras the Melbourne Symphony Thursday night again gave the first local performance of a work by an Australian, Robert Hughes.
The London stock market rallied slightly yesterday, but trading was sluggish. Wall Street's drop on Thursday was the main depressant.
Orthodox Judaism tomorrow will start a campaign with a goal of $35-million over the next 10 years to establish 200 new Hebrew day schools in the United States and Canada.

No one should question President Nixon's right to call in nine of his favorite newspaper columnists and use them to advance his contention that the election results last week add up to an Administration victory. What does need questioning on several grounds, however, is the wisdom of substituting that cozy procedure for the giveand-take of the public Presidential press conference.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 13 (AP) A spokesman for R.C.A. said today the company had notified customers to suspend the use of a black and white television model being tested for a possible defect.

As a technician on the classical guitar, John Williams must be peerless. The Australian was a virtuoso by the time he was 17 years old. Now, at 29, his playing has a technical prefection that seems superior even to that of his great teacher, Andres Segovia.

For 69 distraught Corona homeowners who had doggedly fought a city plan to destroy their homes to make way for a new North Queens high school, the final blow came late yesterday afternoon at City Hall.

North Vietnam has informed an American peace group that six United States servicemen it held prisoner have died. Hanoi also confirmed the identities of four additional American prisoners.

Recent animal studies indicate that the manner in which the male hormone, testosterone, operates within the body is far more complex than was previously believed.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn refused to accept a jury's verdict of guilty yesterday against two former Federal narcotics agents after a poll of the jury showed that two members were not convinced of the defendants' guilt.

The Northern and Central Gas Corporation, Ltd., reported yesterday a slight decline in net income for the first nine months of this year despite higher revenues. The report placed revenues at $123,642,000 against $107,542,000 a year ear ier. Net income slipped to $5,304,000, or 42 cents a share, from $5,316,000, or 43 cents a share, in the like period of 1969.

The Rangers, who have dropped off the last five games with two victories, two losses and a tie, will face the Chicago Black Hawks and Toronto Maple Leafs over the weekend.

The American Broadcasting Company television network, in a massive overhaul of its evening prime-time schedule, will drop six of its weekly programs in January, all of them series that had premieres in September.

SEATTLE, Nov. 13 Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" is a popular opera and has been performed many times in this country. But it is safe to say that no previous performance has been like the "Hoffmann" that the Seattle Opera staged last night. Richard Bonynge, who conducted, has the habit of going back to original sources, and this new staging was in many respects a reconstruction of material that had long been forgotten.

The Alarius Ensemble of Brussels explored relatively uncharted territory Thursday night in Carnegie Recital Hall: 17th century trio sonatas, canzonas and suites for violins, violas da gamba and harpsichord in various combinations. Like other European ensembles specializing in music of this era and earlier, the four members of the Alarius played on authentic period instruments, and the mellow tone of their gambas and harpsichord were a delight in themselves.

The Police Department's trial of a detective accused of selling confidential police information to one of the nation's largest private detective agencies was begun yesterday even though the detective is still recovering from a stomach operation in a Long Island hospital.

LONDON, Nov. 13 One of the strong men of Mr. Heath's Cabinet is Lord Carrington, the Minister of Defense, whose very British exterior of amiable jocularity covers a tough intelligence. Early in the game, he is having his qualities of resilience suddenly and unexpectedly tested.

BONN, Nov. 13 A member of Parliament from West Germany's small Free Democratic party charged Today that rightwing politicians had tried to bribe him to defect to them and thereby reduce the Government's parliamentary majority from six to four.

The White Motor Corporation incurred losses in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday. The company attributed the losses primarily to inventory reductions, consolidation expenses in the farm-equipment business, curtailed truck demand, a teamsters' strike and rising operating costs.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 13 (AP) An airline pilots' strike against Mohawk Airline ended its second day today. Weekend travelers sought alternative means of transportation and some furloughed Mohawk employes hoped for an early decision on whether they could file for unemployment benefits.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 13 Dr. Roger W. Heyns said today that he had notified the University of California on Oct. 30 that would liave his post as chancellor of the Berkeley campus no later than June 30 and will go sooner if a successor is named.

Vice Adm. Edward C. Holden Jr., Naval Reserve, retired, a veteran of both World Wars and a leader in efforts to promote safety at sea, died yesterday in Sailors Snug Harbor, a home for retired mariners in New Brighton, S.I. His age was 74. He had been in the home since suffering a stroke five years ago.

It has been a satisfying and stimulating autumn for Coach Ara Parseghian of Notre Dame. The Irish are unbeaten in seven games and are back on top in the national polls; a Parseghian-endorsed Indiana Democrat, John Brademas, won reelection to Congress, and Parseghian, the jogger, has lowered his time for the morning mile from 9 minutes 38 seconds to 6:45.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 13 A Democratic reform commission recommended today that television cameras be banned from the floor of the party's next presidential nominating convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) Many American servicemen whose terms of service are just about up will be given a Christmas bonus in the form of a discharge up to two weeks earlier so they can shed their uniforms before the holidays, the Pentagon said today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Nov. 13 Mrs. Albert Roothbert, who as Baroness Tony Von Horn was a leading fashion and advertising photographer in the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday at her home at Topstone Road. She was 71 years old and also lived at 120 East 48th Street in Manhattan.
Clifton McNeil, the New York Giants' 6-foot-2-inch, 187-pound wide receiver, is not the kind of person who would get his nose broken just to spite his face.

Charles Reich is correct that America faces a spiritual crisis. But like the young people he idealizes, he attacks the wrong enemy. We are not victims of a "mindless and irrational" corporate state, "at war with its inhabitants." Rather we are victims of ourselves and our substitution of the values of the performance chart for the values of our historical and spiritual traditions.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to buy 380 school buses made idle by a strike, and school officials, after a lecture from the board, said that they hoped to have the buses running again Monday.
A change in state law to require public schools to admit some parochial and other private school students to certain courses was recommended yesterday by the State Board of Regents.
With the nearby December contracts the weakest, cocoa futures prices declined as much as the trading limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) The Public Service Commission has granted permission to Consolidated Edison to issue monthly bills to residential gas and electric customers, beginning Dec. 1.

Officials in the Senate campaign of James L. Buckley and Senator Charles E. Goodell agreed yesterday that Mr. Buckley would have won last week's election even if Mr. Goodell had dropped out.

But, he asked rhetorically, "Who would walk out on a meeting like this?"

Three foreign subway experts said yesterday that the design and the maintenance and operating rules of New York's subways were those of a thoroughly safe system. But the experts, who had been called in because of the many delays and occasional accidents in recent months, recommended numerous steps to reduce the "exposure to risk" that resulted from equipment breakdowns and from vandalism and other actions of the public.

The victory moved Fischer into a first-place tie with Tudev Uitemen, champion of Mongolia, who has surprised the chessplaying world. Uitemen drew with Svetozar Gligoric, a manytime Yukoslav titleholder.

SUNOL, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI) Rex Baxter, who quit the tour two years ago for a regular golf job in Cleveland, shot a fourunder-par 68 today for the second-round lead in the $50,000 Professional Golfers' Association club professionals' championship.

BUFFALO, Nov. 13 (UPI) Paul Andrea and Larry Keenan scored third-period goals tonight as the Buffalo Sabres ended the California Seals' four-game winning streak, 4-2, in a National Hockey League contest.
Thomas V. Barber, a former senior vice president of R.H. Mary Co., died Thursday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 501 East 79th Street here.

Dabrowski, project manager of the Sidewinder missile program for the Raytheon Manufacturing Company in Lowell, Mass., and Mrs. Dabrowski of Concord, Mass.

Bruno Sammartino did it again last night. In no mood to give up his heavyweight wrestling "title," the Italian from Abruzzi imposed his will on Dick (The Bulldog) Brower of Canada at Madison Square Garden. Sammartino, a 265-pounder, overcame a strong challenge from the 290-pound Brower. In fact he was almost pinned twice.

TORONTO, Nov. 16?Canada moved into the lead for the international team championship of the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight when Barbara Simpson and Moffat Dunlap won the relay class.

An alarm that transmits a loud, continuous shriek when activated will be given to 8,000 city Housing Authority em ployes, including all maintenance personnel, Simeon Golar, the authority chairman, announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 Bob Foster predicted today that "you're going to see history" in his heavyweight title bout with Joe Frazier, the recognized world champion, Wednesday night at Cobo Arena.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Stuart F. Silloway, president of Investors Diversified Services, denied in part today a report in The New York Times concerning White House involvement in the publication of some controversial political advertisements.

ST. GEORGE, Me., Nov. 16 Col. William E. Parker, who had practiced law here since his retirement from the Army in 1960, died yesterday in a Rockland hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Nov. 16 The Delaware River Basin Commission made public today a series of plans for water supply and waste disposal in a 1,000-square-mile area touching New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

An attempt by the Lindsay administration to block Controller Abraham D. Beame from appointing private lawyers and appraisers to handle mortgage transactions involving city pension funds was rejected yesterday by the board of trustees of the City Employes Retirement system.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16, (AP) Many blank, ballots and abstentions were reported today after yesterday's elections of powerless Brazilian legislative bodies.

Nothing seems more paradoxical, at first glance, than that Congress should in 1970 revert to the kind of protectionist legislation that has not been enacted since Secretary of State Cordell Hull made free trade the cornerstone of his policy in the 1930's. In fact, there are good reasons why it should be so, but even better reasons why President Nixon and Congressional leaders of both parties should combine to frustrate the impulse.
Joe Namath's attitude toward his pro football future apparently has been altered by his fractured wrist.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 16 Premier Golda Meir of Israel charged today that the Kremlin was setting up show trials to crush the spirit of Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate to Israel.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 15 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles defeated Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., today in the sixth round of the eighth interzonal tournament. Fischer has held the United States championship eight times; Reshevsky, the current champion has held the title six times.
Contributions for the relief of victims of cyclone and flood in East Pakistan are being accepted here by the American National Red Cross and representatives of Pakistan.

It takes enormous self-confidence to undertake a history of Western civilization in 13 52-minute television programs, but then Kenneth Clark has been studying the visual record of European man's efforts to rise above barbarism so long that few have dared accuse him of hubris in attempting the impossible.
The Port of New York Authority agreed yesterday, under pressure of a suit by the state, to start pumping out oil discharged into Jamaica Bay from Kennedy International Airport no later than Dec. 8.

The Port of New York Authority agreed yesterday, under pressure of a suit by the state, to start pumping out oil discharged into Jamaica Bay from Kennedy International Airport no later than Dec. 8.
The 19th annual Angels Ball of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be held at the Plaza tomorrow.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 16 (Reuters) King Hussein said today he had turned down an Israeli proposal for bilateral talks on a Middle East settlement under the supervision of Dr. Jarring.

The city's Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin, said yesterday that a preliminary inquiry had uncovered more than $250,000 worth of counterfeit city permits allowing private cartage companies to dump construction waste materials at five city sites.

UPPER BLACK EDDY, Pa., Nov. 16 Mrs. Abigail Laurie Gottlieb, who did publicity in New York for charitable causes, died Saturday in Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J., after a long illness. She was 67 years old.
The Pembroke College Club of New York will hold its annual benefit tomorrow at the showroom of Arthur H. Lee Sons, Inc. and Jofa, Inc., 227 East 56th Street.
The National Petroleum Council yesterday began a high-level study of the energy outlook for the United States from now to the end of the century.
HONG KONG, Nov. 16 A new Burmese Ambassador, U Thein Maung, arrived in Peking today, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

PARIS, Nov. 16 An international organization's tough proposals to restrain global inflation, including a suggestion that full employment be demoted as a policy priority, drew a lukewarm reaction today from major industrial nations.
A 27-year old pharmacy student was arrested last night and charged with raping and robbing 30 women in the Crown Heights Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn during the last year.
The London stock market drifted lower yesterday in quiet trading and was hardly affected by the Government's announcement that there was a trade surplus of 27-million in October.
ROME, Nov. 16 Pope Paul VI today reasserted the Roman Catholic Church's ban on all forms of birth control except periodic abstinence.

Fundamental Investors, Inc., a $1-billion mutual fund, and three other businesses have sued Goldman, Sachs Co. for more than $23-million in an action that charges the big securities firm with "fraud, deception, concealment, suppression and false pretense" in the sale of commercial paper of the Penn Central Transportation Company.
Record earnings were attained by the Coca-Cola Company in this year's third quarter and first nine months, it reported yesterday from Atlanta.

The conviction of Carmine G. De Sapio, once a powerful figure in state and national Democratic politics, for conspiring to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus was upheld unanimously yesterday by a Federal appeals tribunal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Treasury bill rates declined sharply again at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

PARTIES Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union, representing 36,000 drivers and 1,200 inside workers; the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, representing owners of the bulk of the 6,816 fleet-owned cabs; The City Council, which has the power to set fares, and Mayor Lindsay, who is expected to recommend a fare rise.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The House voted today to provide birth control services for all American women who cannot afford them.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 16 Premier Golda Meir indicated today that Israel might be prepared to accept less than a full rollback of the Soviet-Egyptian missile installations in the Suez Canal cease-fire zone as a condition for the resumption of peace talks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The United States balance of international payments apparently improved somewhat in the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Thorwald H. Smith, former senior vice president and a director of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company in Morris Plains, N.J., died at his home here Sunday. He was 71 years old and lived at 530 East 86th Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Is President Nixon one of the giants of our time? If not, may he yet become one?
Miss Betsy Ross, a registered representative with H. Hentz Co., stockbrokerage firm here, was married yesterday morning to Herbert George Kramer, a realty broker with Helmsley-Spear.

The director of the Center for Marxist Education and his lawyer walked out of hearings being conducted here yesterday by the United States Subversive Activities Control Board after challenging the Government's contention that the school was a "Communist front" and calling the hearings "just another exercise in futility."

The nation has elected another House of Representatives, but scarcely a new House. Of the 435 members, all but fifty are holdovers from the previous Congress. More significantly, the committee chairmanships remain in the possession of old-timers who were first elected to the House thirty, forty and even fifty years ago.

The Magnavox Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the La Salle-Deitch Company, Inc., supplier of interior furnishings and floor coverings to mobile home and recreational vehicle producers, for stock worth about $19-million.

PARIS It is not easy for a foreigner to write on China for an American newspaper. All the more so for a former French Foreign Minister who established normal diplomatic relations between Paris and Peking under the authority of General de Gaulle in January, 1964.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The Treasury announced today it would raise $2.1-billion by yearend by auctioning a "strip" of bills consisting of additions to seven outstanding weekly series of Treasury bills.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 The trial of Bobby G. Seale on charges arising from the slaying of a Black Panther party member began quietly, almost inconspicuously, here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The mood in the Senate after the turmoil of the elections is more congenial than might have been expected. Both Vice President Agnew and Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas have noted a change for the better, so the transition to the second half of the 91st Congress in January may be orderly and fair.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 It is a theory that has been accepted in an unthinking sort of way for so long that few even bother to question its practicality any more. The theory states that any time a couple of heavyweights step into a ring they will fling fists at each other with such power that the end could come with only one punch.

IRBID, Jordan, Nov. 17 Northern Jordan still echoed to occasional gunfire today after 10 hours of the fiercest clashes between Arab commandos and the Jordanian armed forces since the civil war in September.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 17 (AP) Chip Young's secondperiod goal gave Brown a 1-0 victory over Middlebury today in a District 1 soccer playoff.

Two days ago, 14-monthold Suzanne sat on her mother's lap in a small room and had her eyes examined with a computerized device that attempts to overcome the diagnostic problem created by the inability of young children to tell others what they can and cannot see.
The principal of a Harlem junior high school who was relieved of her duties Monday was arrested yesterday for trespassing when she appeared at the school.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 "There is an ineffaceable blot that Hinduism carries with it," Gandhi said. "I think that this miserable, wretched, enslaving spirit of 'untouchableness' must have come to us when we were at our lowest ebb. This evil has stuck to us."

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board expects to issue regulations by the end of the year restricting the use of socalled "third party payments" by savings and loan associations, the board's chairman, Preston Martin, said in an interview here yesterday.
MIAMI, Nov. 17 (AP) Thomas M. Gifford, a record- holding sports fisherman who operated a charter boat serv- ice in the Virgin Islands, died of cancer in a hospital here Sunday. He was 74 years old.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI) The profile isn't quite the same, and the insurance executive suit doesn't fit the image either, but the name is still the same Chuck Davey and it's a name to bring back memories of boxing's television heyday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Industrial production dropped sharply in October, with only about half the decline accounted for by the General Motors strike, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 17 (AP) Four black players, including two starters, were dismissed today from the Oklahoma State University basket- ball team for "failure to report to practice." The four apparently boycotted practice in connection with racial unrest on the campus last week.
An advertisement in yesterday's newspapers here offering a $10,000 reward has led to the arrest of a 29-year-old suspect in a Brooklyn bank robbery.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 17 A highway engineer has filed suit in Federal court here to prevent the Alabama Highway Department from dismissing him because he wears his hair long.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Assistant Attorney General Jerris Leonard, speaking at a news conference today after several reporters walked out because he would not speak for the record, reportedly said that the Justice Department had investigated about 500 complaints of discrimination within "desegregated" Southern school districts since classes began in September.

With the launching of a major Government investigation into the recent increases in prices of crude oil and gasoline, the Nixon Administration has moved toward adoption of an "incomes policy," without yet calling it that. However, a spokesman for the President's Council of Economic Advisers...

CAIRO, Nov. 17 Premier Mahmoud Fawzi has put together a new Cabinet with four Deputy Premiers to exercise broad, coordinating authority over the economy, foreign affairs and programs to improve life in the United Arab Republic.
TORONTO, Nev. 17 (AP) Gert Wiltfang of West Germany took his third victory in international show jumping competition at the Royal Horse Show tonight by winning a jumpoff against six riders.
For the first time this season, the Knicks last night reclaimed a "lost" game.

The Antioch Baptist Church at 828 Greene Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, will celebrate Sunday as "Victory Day," when church leaders will report the funds they have collected for the church.

WASHINGTON Nov. 17 The Senate passed today, 82 to 3, a far-reaching occupational safety bill establishing Federal supervision over working conditions, an area of regulation now left largely to the states.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The House passed today a $7.5-billion manpower training bill designed to overhaul the present system and put it under local control.

Officials of the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem obtained a court order yesterday calling on the Young Lords to show why they should not be forced to end their occupation of the building.

CHICAGO, Nov, 17 The building industry cannot be expected to provide single-family homes for wage earners in the $10,000-to-$12,000 bracket unless there are radical changes in building methods and in land use, members of the National Association of Real Estate Boards were told today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 President Nixon and Mrs. Nixon flew here tonight by helicopter to join in a gala preview of an exhibition of l7th, 18th and 19th-century paintings at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, called "To Save a Heritage."

The city's Department of Investigation charged a Brooklyn cartage company yesterday with having submitted at least 491 counterfeit dump tickets valued at $9,574 and asked that the company's president be jailed until he produced his corporate records.

GAITHERSBURG, Md., Nov. 17 James W. Brown, former publisher and general manager of Editor Publisher, the newspaper trade journal, died yesterday at a hospital in Bethesda. He was 68 years old and had retired and moved here from New York two years ago, suffering from emphysema.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 A Navy narcotics investigator told a House Armed Services subcommittee today that a major concern of the Navy was "the alarming increase in LSD use in the naval service."
Trading on the London stock exchange remained depressed yesterday in spite of a technical rally.
Angela Davis was arraigned in State Supreme Court here yesterday on a new warrant resulting from her indictment last week on charges of murder and kidnapping in California.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 President Nixon today pledged $10-million of disaster relief in food and money, to the victims of the cyclone and tidal wave that devastated the Bay of Bengal coast of Pakistan last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 American officials disclosed today that the Egyptian Government had agreed to expand American diplomatic representation in Cairo from 16 to 17 men. Washington has sought the expansion for some time but had been refused twice.

Two brothers were arrested in Queens yesterday and charged with murder in connection with the death of a Housing Authority employe who allegedly was pushed to his death from the sixth floor of a Long. Island City housing project during a robbery two weeks ago.
PARIS, Nov. 17 Manlio Brosio, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, took a firm stand here today against any reduction in United States forces on the European Continent.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 17 Harold H. Munger Sr., an architect for 55 years and a member 20 years of the Ohio State Board of Examiners for Architects, collapsed and died in his office yesterday of a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

Declines of as much as 2 cents a bushel were registered by wheat, corn and soybeans futures prices in early trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. A rally late in the session, however, trimmed the early losses.

The Istomin Rose Stern Trio were having a friendly dispute over a most important movement during the rehearsal of a Beethoven piano trio at Carnegie Hall. Everybody wanted the piano moved to another spot on the stage, but the question was precisely where. The acoustical debating society convened, and the air suddenly filled with expert opinions.

Sister Anthony Marie FitzMaurice, Sister of Charity and for the last 10 years executive director of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York, died at the hospital yesterday after a long illness. She was 63 years old.

"Old Faithful" erupted on the Metropolitan Opera stage again on Monday night; "Aida" made its annual reentry into the repertory. Given more often than any other work by the company, its popularity never seems to diminish. The Verdi opera was, as usual, sold out.

WEMBLEY, England, Nov., 17 (UPI) Pancho Gonzales, who says he hates tiebreakers, survived three of them and 8 match points tonight to beat Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 8-9, 9-8, 9-8, and gain the quarterfinals of the $60,000 Embassy indoor tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17, (Reuters) Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he would not seek a seat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a post often regarded as a good springboard for Presidential contenders.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 17 (UPI) Two mountain climbers, Warren Harding and Dean Caldwell, today inched up the last 200-foot stretch of the 3,400-foot-high "Wall of the Early Morning Light" on El Capitan after nearly 30 days.

The Board of Correction reported to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that a Young Lord who was found hanged in the Tombs last month was a suicide, the victim of an "inhuman" system of criminal justice and detention that "succeeded only in deranging him."
ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (AP) A Fulton County grand jury indicted three men today in the $100,000 robbery of more than 200 persons at a party after the Muhammad Ali-Jerry Quarry fight here Oct. 26.

A cocaine smuggling operation from South America to the Brooklyn waterfront that reportedly brought in cocaine with a "street value" of $30million each month was disclosed here yesterday with the indictments of 20 persons, including longshoremen and crewmen of the Grancolombiana Lines.

The two black musicians who lost their 15-month fight for permanent posts with the New York Philharmonic yesterday challenged the orchestra's finest players to a public test of musical skills at Town Hall or Philharmonic Hall.

Former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had failed to maintain itself as a "disenthralled seeker of truth" and had become intolerant of diversity within its own ranks.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17 Columbia defeated Buffalo State in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament today, when the Lions had the only corner kick during four overtime periods.

Bond prices scored impressive gains yesterday longmaturity issues included pushing the entire spectrum of interest rates to lower levels.
Keyes, Martin Co., easily the biggest advertising agency in Springfield, N.J., and perhaps the biggest in the state, is celebrating its 25th anniversary.

A 10-event Canadian-American Challenge Cup series of international road races for 1971, worth $1-million in prize money, was announced yesterday by the Sports Car Club of America and the Canadian Automobile Sport Clubs.

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 17 William H. Campbell Jr., a former Newark lawyer and Cape May County Prosecutor, died last night at Morristown Memorial Hospital. His age was 77 years old and lived at 176 Green Avenue.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 Signs of a backlash against the environmental and consumer protection movement are beginning to appear in the automobile industry.

Passage by the Senate of a compromise job safety bill has broken a long deadlock over legislation to give better protection to the life and health of industrial workers. It will be a tragedy measured in thousands of needless deaths and crippling injuries if stubbornness by either labor or industry now blocks acceptance of the same compromise in the House.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 17 Herve Filion, feeling as secure as, any harness racing driver who has brought home 423 winners in a season that still has six weeks remaining, permitted himself the luxury of a morning and afternoon of idleness today. People-to-People, President Nixon announced the election of John P. Fraim of California as chairman of the board of People-to-People. Mr. Fraim, 60, is chairman of the board of directors and president of the Mutual Broadcasting Corporation. People-to-People is a privately organized association of persons promoting understanding between Americans and people of other nations.

Back in 1942, Arnold H. Einhorn, then a 17-year-old member of the French underground, was smuggled across the Pyrenees into Spain. Yesterday, as he prepared to leave his office at Lincoln Hospital, he said, "I would do it twice again rather than go through what I have gone.
District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx has warned Mayor Lindsay that overcrowding in the Bronx House of Detention has created a situation that is "explosive" and "fraught with danger."

Dick Nolan, the San Francisco coach, said recently: "In pro football there is an awfully thin line between winners and losers." Nolan was talking about the success of his team, the 49ers, losers a year ago and now big winners.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 The Security Council voted unanimously today for strong and urgent action against the white-supremacy leaders of Rhodesia to end their defiance of earlier United Nations resolutions demanding racial equality.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Miami Floridians de- feated the Pittsburgh Condors, 122-116, tonight in an American Basketball Association game viewed by 8,074, the largest Pittsburgh Arena crowd of the season.

The feminists who are battling their way into men's bars are wasting their time. If it's equality they're looking for, they might eye the posh emporiums that are replacing the old neighborhood barbershops. Few beauty salons are as luxurious as the ones men are claiming for their own.
PARIS, Nov. 17 The unified currency that the Europeans are trying to construct will be of great benefit to the multinational company, an American banker said today.
Her name is Mrs. Daniel Barenboim and she is known to her husband as Smiley. She is known to a good many other people as Jacqueline du Pre.
BERKLEY HEIGHTS, N.J., Nov. 17 John A. Hall, a former patent attorney at Bell Laboratories in New York, died Friday at a nursing home here. He lived at 72 Blackburn Road in Summit.

In referring recently to the "plunder" of New Jersey by criminal elements and corrupt public officials, United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey has categorized it as "unmatched" by anything in his experience. Turning specifically to Hudson County, the prosecutor asserted that "everything has a price on it."

The order issued yesterday by Mayor Lindsay for the first large-scale layoff of municipal employes since the Great Depression is obviously intended to bring home to the unions representing civil service workers the harsh realities of the city's financial plight.

Sales and earnings of the S.S. Kresge Company made substantial increases in the 13-week and 39-week periods ended Oct. 28, it reported from Detroit yesterday. The company operates a national chain of more than 500 discount stores and about 566 variety stores.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would ask for a rate increase averaging 6 per cent on interstate toll calls. If granted, this would be the first general increase in long-distance phone rates in 17 years.

The American Express Company said yesterday that one of its subsidiaries the American Automobile Insurance Company of San Francisco had sued the securities firm of Goldman, Sachs Co. for $2million in connection with sales by Goldman of commercial paper issued by the Penn Central Transportation Company, which, is now in default.

The Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday announced a replacement for Harry Reasoner on "60 Minutes," listed its midseason programming changes and detailed its plans to relinquish 3 hours of network prime time in the fall.

In the last two years the use of drugs among employes has become almost as serious as the alcoholism problem, according to Thomas N. Stainback, executive vice president of the New York Chamber of Commerce. He said the drug problem among employes was only a minor one two years ago.

Robert F. Cahir, manager of employe benefits in the personnel department of The New York Times, died early yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 80-20 86th Avenue, Woodhaven. He was 56 years old.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 17 Three former members of the infantry company that entered the hamlet of Mylai No. 4 more than two years ago said today that they had seen Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shoot into a group of South Vietnamese civilians. But they said they had not seen S. Sgt., David Mitchell near the ditch where the shooting occurred.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17 Kurt Vonnegut Jr., the 48-year-old novelist whose cutting satire, sense of the absurd and dark visions of human cruelty and folly have made him a hero to college youth, has come to Harvard to teach creative writing to undergraduates.

Irving Warshaw, a senior partner in the law firm of War- shaw, Sylvester, Burstein, Franks Lebow, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 20 East 74th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 American space officials expressed admiration today for the Luna 17 accomplishment but said they were not particularly surprised by Soviet capacity to put a rover vehicle on the moon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Senator Edmund S. Muskie apparently outmaneuvered the Nixon Administration today when he introduced an ocean-dumping bill that was almost a carbon copy of one the White House intended to send to Congress early next year.

LONDON, Nov. 17 In the first faint signs of peace on the embattled tennis front, a negotiating team representing three of the world's major tournaments will meet with World Championship Tennis to determine whether W.C.T.'s 32 contract pros will play at Forest Hills, Wimbledon and Roland Garros Stadium in Paris next year.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 17 Citing evidence associating brain damage with many violent crimes, a Boston psychiatrist urged today that the courts screen all such offenders through medical examinations so that they could be treated.

PORTLAND, Ore. The Atlantic salmon, and who has a right to fish for them on the high seas, has become a hot international issue involving the foreign ministries of several nations and our State Department.

PALMA, Spain, Nov. 17 Bobby Fischre of Los Angeles, eight-time United States champion, led the eihgth interzonal of Palma de Mallorca, a qualification, 24-man round robin, after completion of most of the adjourned games, including the sixth round. Fischer has 4 points four victories and a draw and one adjourned game.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Nov. 17 A handful of demonstrators greeted Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam as he landed here today on the third stop of his twoand-a-half-week tour of the United States, but their presence was barely noticeable.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced Tuesday it would increase the price of its standard rails by 7.4 per cent to $146 per ton, effective next Jan. 4.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange turned in its third consecutive loss yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by a small margin in slow turnover.
HUMBOLDT, Tenn., Nov. 17 Jesse Hill Ford, the novelist, was charged with homicide today in the shooting of a soldier in the driveway of his home last night.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12 Iran is seeking recognition as the dominant political and military power in the strategic Persian Gulf once Britain has withdrawn, probably by the end of next year.

Tapes of conversations made from a transmitter concealed on the person of a police undercover agent at a Black Panther meeting during which the Panthers allegedly discussed bombing department stores and other disruptive action were ruled inadmissible as evidence at the trial of 13 Black Panthers in State Supreme Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) President Nixon and Republican Congressional leaders agreed today on a "rock bottom wish list" of legislation they would like Congress to act upon before adjournment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The attempt to override President Nixon's veto of the bill to limit television and radio spending in political campaigns will open in the Senate early next week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 17 The new Chilean Government today formally withdrew from a United Nations commission on Korea in a move that was interpreted as tacit recognition of the Communist Government of North Korea.

Mrs. Nan Ickeringill Callahan of New York and Oswald Francis Richards of Gravesend, Kent, England, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Unitarian Church of All Souls by the Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring.

CAMBRIDGE While appearing to relax its opposition to the seating of Communist China in the United Nations, our Government has actually introduced a new legal theory designed to delay Peking's participation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17 A junior, Charles Thomas, scored four goals to pace undefeated Harvard's soccer team to a 6-0 N.C.A.A. District 1 victory over Worcester Polytechnic Institute.
On the small stage of the Barbizon Plaza Theater last night the German-language Brucke ensemble, opening its third American tour, made a 163-year-old play glow.

Two southbound exits will be eliminated on the Garden State Parkway next Tuesday. They are Exits 127 A at New Brunswick Avenue and 127 at Route 9. Southbound motorists heading for these routes will have to leave the parkway at Exit 129, just to the north, which is the parkway's interchange with the New Jersey Turnpike.

AT THE DEMILITARIZED ZONE, South Korea, Nov. 17 Life is dreary in late fall in the bleak hills where American and North Korean troops face each other without seeing each other and when there is only the icy Manchurian winter to look forward to.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) Bud Horn broke his fouryear bowling title drought last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration rejected last year a request for $2.4-million to improve the hilltop airport involved in the Marshall University charted plane disaster.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 17 Israeli military censorship on reports of high-level contacts between Jordan and Israel was further relaxed today, resulting in much speculative detail in the local press.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 17 Max Grobow, a founder of many major Jewish philanthropies, who was to receive the Brotherhood Award of the New Jersey Conference of Christians and Jews this week, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. Government officials representing Canada, Britain and Australia appealed to the United States yesterday to keep a liberal trade policy.

Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell, who studied law while pounding a beat on the West Side, has appealed to Mayor Lindsay and the Police Department to reinstate a policeman who resigned Monday when he was refused a leave of absence to accept a scholarship to Harvard Law School.

Two New York police commanders demoted Monday by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy for allegedly refusing to cooperate with a Manhattan grand jury investigating police corruption are to have departmental trials today on the same charge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The Labor Department confirmed today that the Administration would seek to restore the $3.7-million.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday directed the layoff of 500 provisional city employes, in an effort to ease the city's budget crisis. Experts at City Hall said this would be the first mass layoff of city workers since the Depression.

School buses that serve 30,000 children in Manhattan and Brooklyn will remain idle, despite an announcement by the Board of Education on Sunday that it hoped to have the 380 buses back in service by today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 17 (UPI) Prices of many chemical industry products are so weak "we could almost be accused of 'domestic dumping,'" C. B. McCoy, prsident of E.I. du Pont de Memours Co., said today.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 17 The Government described First Lieut, William L. Calley Jr. today as a slayer of unarmed and unresisting women, children, old men and babies.

Thanks to the magic of air travel, and the fact that the National Hockey League hasn't found a computer-programmer who can make the machine come up with a coherent, schedule, the Rangers left last night for a one-night stand in California.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Nov. 17 (AP) Melvin H. Evans became the first popularly elected Governor of the Virgin Islands tonight. Unofficial returns gave him 8,259 votes to 7,452 for his opponent, Cyril E. King, in a runoff.

MINEOLA, L.I, Nov. 17 An indictment by a Nassau County grand jury charged today that a 43-year-old Brooklyn school principal and a 26-yearold teacher with whom he was reported to be having an affair plotted the murder of the principal's wife after school board meetings in Valley Stream.

William Derringer's "The Perfect Match" and Barry Litvack's "Slow Memories," two one-act plays presented at yesterday's ANTA matinee at the Theater de Lys, are cliche plays about young love. But there is an important difference.

"At least a quarter, perhaps as many as half of the people who commit violent acts or who are prone to such acts are diagnosable," Dr. Ervin said. "Some are treatable and their acts certainly are by and large preventable."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) The president of a specialty steel products company said today that his industry would bring a "dumping" challenge against imports of stainless steels, tool steels, high-temperature steels and other specialty items.

MANPURA ISLAND, Pakistan, Nov. 17 Five days after a tidal wave engulfed this 25-square-mile island in the Ganges Delta, the stricken survivors have not received any food, drinking water or urgently needed medical relief.
HOUSTON, Nov. 17 Not until next July at the earliest will the United States deliver a wheeled vehicle to the moon. But, unlike the Russians' automated cart of Luna 17, it will be man-driven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Egyptian antiaircraft gunners fired at Israeli reconnaissance planes flying over their lines on the west bank of the Suez Canal about 10 days ago, according to usually reliable sources. No Israeli plane was reported hit.

GENEVA, Nov. 17 The Nixon Administration has informed the International Labor Organization that it will ask Congress, "at an appropriate time," to restore the $3.7-million that Congress has voted to withhold as a protest against the appointment of a Byelorussian to the agency's high command.
A Brooklyn grand jury has found no cause for criminal action against a policeman who shot a disease-ridden vagrant to death with eight bullets last May 1.

WASHINGTON Nov. 17 A House subcommittee began compiling today a brief to persuade the Supreme Court and lower courts that pornography is harmful to individuals and to society and therefore should be suppressed.
Off Broadway felt the impact of its first actors' and stage managers' strike last night as picket lines were posted at 10 of the 17 theaters that were struck.
A "good" track at Aqueduct yesterday meant bad news to handicappers who continued to beat front-runners.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 (AP) Nick Skorich, Cleveland Browns' offensive coach, indicated that questions asked him today by the Federal Grand Jury investigating the National Football League were about player-owner relations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (Reuters) South Vietnamese forces continued their push into northeast Cambodia today after reporting the discovery of big food and equipment dumps.
TRIESTE, Italy, Nov. 17 (UPI) The mother of the Yugoslav dissident Mihajlo Mihajlov has entered Italy clandestinely and has asked to visit her daughter in the United States, the police said today.
BONN, Nov. 17 Responding to recent slight cuts in interest rates in the United States and Canada, West Germany's central bank decided today to lower its bank rate to 6.5 per cent from 7 per cent.
George Foreman, who is favored to defeat Boone Kirkman in Madison Square Garden tonight, said yesterday he "was in no hurry" to meet either Joe Frazier or Muhammad Ali.

NEWARK, Nov, 17 A source close to the Federal investigation of corruption in Jersey City and Hudson County said today that indictments against public officials had been delayed until after the election to avoid charges of politics.
Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, one of the greatest names in the history of the game, has had a rare experience this year. He has become a double world champion without playing a card.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI) Archie Clark scored 24 points and Hal Greer 21 tonight in leading the Philadelphia 76ers to a 113-91 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game.

J. Lucian Smith has been named president of CocaCola USA as Fred W. Dickson moves on to become the senior vice president and corporate marketing director of the parent, Coca-Cola Company. The change is effective Jan. 1.
BONN, Nov. 17 At' noon tomorrow the foreign ministers of the West German and Polish Governments are to initial a treaty aimed at establishing normal relations.
The city proposed yesterday a new air-pollution code that would increase maximum penalties fivefold and allow persons who report polluters to receive a share of the fines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 State Department officials said today that the United States had received private assurances from the Soviet Union that it would not introduce offensive weapons into the Western Hemisphere or establish bases for the use of such weapons. It was understood that "offensive weapons" in this context was synonymous with nuclear weapons.
DUBLIN, Nov. 17 The expected avalanche of customers and business failed to materialize today when banks throughout Ireland opened their doors for the first time in more than six and a half months.

Jerome A. Newman, president of the General Wine and Spirits Company, will be guest of honor at the Dysautonomia Association's dinner tomorrow night at the St. RegisSheraton.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 17 A treaty to prohibit the placement of nuclear weapons on the seabed outside any nation's 12-mile limit was approved here today 91 to 2.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 The China debate in the United Nations General Assembly continued today, with 15 countries restating long-held positions for and against the admission of the Communist Government. There were no changes in positions.

Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said yesterday that he doubted seriously that his committee would look with favor upon the Nixon Administration's proposed tax on lead in gasoline.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 17 Mrs. Loy Claudon More head, a lexicographer and the widow of Albert H. Morehead, the contract bridge expert, encyclopedist and former bridge editor of The New York Times, died of a liver ailment yesterday in St. Francis Hospital here. She was 60 years old and lived in Hopewell Junction.
The largest trans-Atlantic passenger-ship operator, the Italian Line, plans to withdraw gradually from service between here and Europe, industry sources said yesterday.
The head of the city's major antipoverty agency charged yesterday that he had been beaten by policemen last Oct. 22 and that the police were dragging their feet' in checking his complaint.

Pressure, says Alex Webster, is for losers. The Giant coach expounded his straightforward philosophy yesterday when people kept suggesting that the pressure on the championship-minded Giants mounts with each victory.
MONTREAL, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Montreal Canadiens swept into first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League tonight with a 5-1 victory over the California Golden Seals.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 As the next development in the boxing scenerio created by Muhammad Ali's successful return last month, Joe Frazier will defend the recognized world heavyweight championship tomorrow night against Bob Foster, the skinny light-heavyweight ruler.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 17 Mrs. Louise Choo Ault and John Haley (Zoot) Sims, both of New York, were married here this afternoon by Judge Frederick E. Shulman of the Town Justice Court of New Castle in the Shulman home.
LONDON, Nov. 17 A noted naturalist declared here today that each American accounts for more toxic wastes poured into rivers and oceans than 1,000 Asians.
LONDON, Nov. 17 John Francis Prideaux, head of the merchant banking company of Arbuthnot Latham, was named today chairman of the National Westminster Bank, Britain's largest joint stock bank.

Richard Chamberlain, who can only be respected for making the transition from the routine corn of "Dr. Kildare" to the exacting demands of "Hamlet," finally brought his interpretation of the Dane to the home screen last night on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over the National Broadcasting Company's network.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 In a landmark decision today, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit required the Federal Government to show a pressing need for evidence before ordering a journalist to testify in a secret grand jury proceeding.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17 (AP) A 17-year-old girl convicted of burning the flag won a one-year reprieve today by carrying a large American flag on a threemile march through the city.

PARIS, Nov. 17 Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, told an international forum today that the American economy was in a "basic forward trend," having moved into the zone where expansionary policies of early last summer were beginning to bite.
DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 17 Typhoid and cholera were reported today to be complicating relief efforts in the coastal areas of East Pakistan that were devastated last Friday by a cyclone and tidal wave.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The White House indicated today that President Nixon was opposed to the import-restricting trade bill that will be taken up by the House tomorrow.
John R. Foley has been made vice president and divisional display director; Carrick A. Hill has been given the rank of vice president and Gary Ozaroff was named a vice president at Macy's New York.

The 14th annual Easter Seal Home Service art show and sale will take place in the Pacem in Terris Library of the Holy Family Church, 323 East 47th Street, Sunday through Tuesday from noon to 7 P.M. each day.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) A hand grenade exploded in a crowd watching a movie 20 miles northeast of Saigon last night, killing nine civilians and wounded 43 other persons, South Vietnamese military headquarters reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) Pearl Bailey stole the show at historic Ford's Theater tonight as a gala television salute to America's musical heritage was being taped.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 18 (AP) The Boston Bruins, with Phil Esposito, Ken Hodge and John Bucyk scoring two goals apiece tonight, trounced the Minnesota North Stars, 8-4, and moved into a tie with New York Rangers for the lead in the National Hockey League's East Division. Each has 22 points.

There is a new deal at the National Orchestral Association, which opened its season at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. In the old days a single conductor guided its destiny. Leon Barzin was in control many years; and, in more recent years, there was John Barnett.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 After a year of studying data sent from an automated lunar station, American scientists today described the moon as a cold, stiff body bombarded regularly with grapefruit-size meteorites and exhibiting some newfound and puzzling physical traits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18? Despite reported White House misgivings, Senator Jacob K. Javits began a move today to rally support for what he described as the Administration's "new posture" on admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 In a letter to President Nixon today, Senator Philip A. Hart said that several executive agencies were undermining the effectiveness of the National Environmental Policy Act by failing to file required "environmental impact" statements.

Black and Puerto Rican students at New York University's Graduate School of Social Work ended a two-day strike yesterday after winning an agreement for direct representation on all faculty-student committees.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced the reactivation of a separate traffic division in the Police Department yesterday to concentrate solely on the "costly and annoying" problems of traffic congestion in the city.

New figures that became available yesterday show that government employes of New York State and New York City are receiving retirement and insurance benefits at a cost more than double that for workers in private enterprise.

Dr. William J. Reilly, founder and director since 1932 of the National Institute for Straight Thinking, 230 Park Avenue, died Tuesday in Paterson (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Radburn, N.J.

After two days of fractional gains, the stock market dropped sharply yesterday, with prices closing at the lowwater mark of the trading ses- sion.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Two consumer protection groups threatened today to sue the Federal Government in an effort to force eight allegedly dangerous toys off the market before Christmas.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 18 Mrs. Elizabeth Enders Marion, widow, of B. Pope Marion, was married here this morning to Paul DeForest Hicks, a widower. Both are of Rye, where the Rev. Wendell Phillips performed the ceremony in Christ's Episcopal Church.

LONDON, Nov. 17 There is no greater excitement in the theater than the discovery of life in a play long given up as dead. Such is the case with the Mermaid Theater revival of James Joyce's solitary play, "Exiles," which has had a dismal performance record ever since its first Munich reviewer in 1919 dismissed it as "so many tears over an Irish stew."
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 Premier Chou En-lai of Commu nist China met in Peking today with the Soviet Ambassador, Vasily S. Tolstikov, in the latest sign of improved relations between the two governments.

Last Sunday's casualty report in the National Football League listed six performers injured so badly that their seasons have ended, this brings the total of casualties to 40, and five weeks of the regular season are left.
