SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 Policemen held a rally today in front of City Hall to protest what they regard as a decline in public support.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 As if he were a rhinoceros stomping on a cobra, Joe Frazier knocked out Bob Foster with a crushing left hook tonight in the second round and retained the world heavyweight championship.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 18 Tons of relief supplies were flown to East Pakistan today, but the lack of communications with the survivors of Friday's cyclone and tidal wave kept most of the help from reaching them.

The mailing of premium lists and entry blanks for dog shows is a pretty routine operation, but one that began yesterday for the Westminster Kennel Club event was not so routine. The show will be in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 15 and 16.

DACCA, Nov. 18 (AP) A question of which country's pilots should fly relief helicopters has delayed delivery of urgently needed aircraft from the United States and Britain, Pakistani relief officials said today.

In his 26 years on the bench, Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer of the State Supreme Court has set records for the swift disposition of cases. A comprehensive drug education program for the high schools of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn was announced yesterday after the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission approved a grant of $181,000 to help fin ance it.

The transporting of a French-made laser reflector to the moon by the Soviet spacecraft Luna 17 is a major advance in what is becoming a broad, international program that should ultimately show to what extent each continent on earth is drifting relative to the others.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 (AP) Tonight's crowd of 6,300 at Cobo Arena for the FrazierFoster fight was the second smallest turnout for a heavyweight championship in the modern era. The low was the 2,434 at the Cassius ClaySonny Liston bout at Lewiston, Me., on May 25, 1965.
The bond market extended its recent gains yesterday paced by surging demand for United States Treasury issues.

Last June, Elinor Ross made an unexpected debut with the Metropolitan Opera, substituting for an ailing Birgit Nilsson in the title role of Puccini's "Turandot." An American soprano who had spent much of her decade-long career in European opera houses, she was well received here. On Tuesday night, she had an opportunity to sing in another Puccini opera at th Met, the role of "Tosca."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The House of Representatives came close today to defeating the controversial, import-limiting trade bill before it was even debated. The bill will probably be voted on tomorrow, and even leaders of today's opposition predicted it would pass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The Justice De- partment opposes a section in the Senate version of the one bank holding company bill that would exempt some banks owned by conglomerates from the provisions of the bill.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 Joe Frazier and his manager, Yancey Durham, avoided speculation tonight on an eventual showdown with Muhammad Ali to settle the heavyweight championship confusion.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 18 A former Army combat photographer testified today that he had seen American soldiers slay unarmed Vietnamese civilians in four separate incidents in the alleged massacre at Mylai.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Gen. Lewis W. Walt, the assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, today pondered the lessons of the Vietnam war, the things to bear in mind "if we were to go into this kind of war again."

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company the fifth-largest life insurer in the country disclosed yesterday it had filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission to per mit the company to sell individual variable annuities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The State Department said yesterday that the possibility of building defense facilities on British islands in the Indian Ocean was under review but that no decision had been made.

The Marshall University and Wichita State University air tragedies that took the lives of 52 varsity football players and 54 other persons resulted in public interest in the various programs colleges have to cover such accidents. Both these institutions shared in an insurance program ...

WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 18 (UPI) Roger Taylor of England continued the run of upsets at the $60,000 Embassy indoor tennis tournament today by beating sixth-seeded Roy Emerson of Australia, 6-3, 6-2, and reaching the quarterfinals.

Kolarov of Bulgaria in the Kapfenberg 1970 international tourney.

The Charter New York Corporation, the $6-billion bank holding company led by the Irving Trust Company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Nanuet National Bank, based in Rockland County, N.Y., under a formula that provides for Charter to exchange shares worth at least $11.3-million for stock of Nanuet National. The transaction, which must be approved by stockholders and regulatory authorities, would add $55-million in assets to Charter's total.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 North Vietnam is sending near ly twice as many troops southward along infiltration routes in the early weeks of the dry season this year as it did in 1969, senior United States officials said today.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 18 (AP) Two bearded, grinning climbers struggled to the top of El Capitan shortly before noon today, completing a 27-day conquest of the sheer southeast face of the rock 3,400 feet over Yosemite Valley.

The cession of German territory to Poland up to the Oder-Neisse line at the end of World War II may have hinged in part on the outcome of a British election during the Potsdam Conference of 1945.

PARIS, Nov. 18 Geoffrey Rippon, Britain's chief negotiator in talks with the Common Market, said today that effective European defense cooperation would be "much more difficult" if the market was not enlarged.

The Jewish Defense League and its executive director, Rabbi Meir Kahane, brought suit yesterday to prevent the Black Panther party and the Young Lords from meeting tomorrow night at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn.
It was fortunate for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, newly appointed chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, that he was unable to attend the program at Aqueduct yesterday.
Cologne, Germany Juergen Blin, 195 pounds, Hamburg, knocked out Sylvester Dullaire, 180, Hartford, 8 rounds.

MARTINEZ, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI) A park employe was arrested today on charges of starting a $3-million OaklandBerkeley brush fire and 20 other smaller blazes because he wanted overtime pay for helping fight them.
Johnny Bench, the 22-yearold catcher for the Cincinnati Reds, became the youngest man in baseball history yesterday to win the Most Valuable Player Award.

Steps taken by the Government and the oil industry "will probably avert a major fuel crisis this winter." Maurice H. Stans, Secretary of Commerce, told a meeting of the American Petroleum Institute yesterday at the New York Hilton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) The resignation of Maurice Mann as assistant director of the Office of Management and Budget was announced today. He has had responsibility for ecomomic affairs.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 The Soviet Union said today that Lunokhod 1, the self-propelled vehicle it landed on the moon yesterday, was continuing its lunar research program.
The City Commission on Human Rights opened an investigation yesterday into allegations of racism in the ouster of the chief of pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital and his replacement by a Puerto Rican.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 A little-known former teacher, Ahmed al-Khatib, has been named Syrian head of state.
BEDFORD, N.H., Nov. 18 Senior Judge Peter Woodbury of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit died here yesterday. He was 71 years old.
Through the nineteen-sixties, the favorite word around the cosmetics houses was "natural." Women were advised: Look like yourself, look real, don't wear a mask.

A major Wall Street brokerage house, a Connecticut lawyer and a newly elected Congressman are being questioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding their roles in the $2.2-billion merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, it was disclosed yesterday.

Three Broadway seasons ago Tom Stoppard's "Rosencrantz Guildenstern are Dead," was a hit, winning the Tony Award for the season as the best play, and enjoying a decent run. Someone, however, once characterized it as "a snob-hit," meaning, if I recall correctly, that he personally, in common with the majority Broadway audience, couldn't understand it, and that therefore it was out of place on Broadway.

Mrs. Henry C. Alexander of San Anselmo, Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Alexander, to Christopher Thomas Hartford Pell, son of United States Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Mrs. Pell of Newport and Washington. The wedding will take place on Jan. 9 in Ross, Calif.

A state judge ordered the city yesterday to start immediately on a two-week project to drill into a water main, tap it, refill the excavation and resurface the area to supply water to one tenant living in a ram- shackle building on a deserted street in lower Manhattan.
Betsy Kress has a compulsive crush on Fidel Castro. Hence the title of the play, "The Castro Complex," that opened last night at the Stairway Theater.
WARSAW, Nov. 18 A quarter century after World War II, Poland is still recovering from the human and material devastation wrought by the German occupation.

Some of the country's bestknown dancers jumped up and down in their stockinged feet yesterday to help determine what kind of stage flooring would be installed at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

FARMINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 18 The Consolidation Coal Company said today it had reached a tentative agreement, with most of the survivors of the 78 men killed in a 1968 mine accident here, that would end a $3-million underground recovery effort and permit the company to resume the production of coal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The School of Forestry of the University of Montana has strongly criticized the Federal Forest Service, contending that it concentrates on increased timber production and neglects the other "multiple uses" enjoined by law.
Sea Host, Inc., a New York chain of seafood restaurants filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Southern District Federal Court listing liabilities of $1,698 836 and assets of $806,828.
The first casualty of the Off Broadway theater strike, which entered its third day yesterday is the Joe Orton play, "What the Butler Saw," at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel indicated today that his country has been seeking continued military and economic aid and renewed assurances from the United States of diplomatic backing for its negotiating position if it re-entered peace talks with the United Arab Republic and Jordan.
Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, said yesterday that his company's recent bid to acquire Western Air Lines would be considered by Western's directors on Nov. 24.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 Nationalist China picked up a vote in the China debate today when Mauritius announced that she would vote against the Algerian resolution calling for the admission of Communist China and the expulsion of the Nationalist regime.
The 24th fund-raising campaign of the Manhattan women's division of the Heart Fund will get under way today with an awards luncheon at Heart House, 2 East 64th Street.
Two tree-climbing kangaroos, one pregnant, have arrived at the Bronx Zoo from New Guinea and will probably go on public exhibition within a few weeks, according to zoo officials.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18 Mrs. Catherine Barker Hickox, wife of Charles V. Hickox of Boxwood Farm and 10 Gracie Square in New York, died today of emphysema at their home here. She was 74 years old.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 18 (Agence France-Presse) Shooting broke out in the Jordanian capital tonight and continued for two hours. It was not known if there were any casualties.

And now that rarity, the truly great performance last night at the New York City Ballet when Violette Verdy and Helgi Tomasson danced Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux" together for the first time at the State Theater.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The Senate agreed today to vote Monday on whether to override President Nixon's veto of a bill to limit spending on television advertising by political candidates.

The protectionist forces in the House of Representatives get a scare yesterday when the import-restricting Mills bill came close to being smothered in test votes. The thinness of the protectionist majority provides basis for hope that this dangerous trade curb can still be stopped if President Nixon comes out strongly against it.
Three adults and one child were killed early today when the car in which they were riding exploded after a collision in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Broklyn early today.

Injustices in New York's courtrooms and jails have been underscored this week for the Puerto Rican community and for other residents of this city whose frustrations because of language, color and plain poverty result in wild rebellion and wounded lives.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 The fight was over six minutes before it was scheduled to start and Joe Frazier sort of met himself on the way back. He hadn't been anywhere of consequence anyway. He had stepped into the Cobo Arena ring, taken some mild calisthenics in front of Bob Foster and was dancing in triumph well in advance of the 10:30 PM. starting deadline.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP) The Armco Steel Corporation announced today the start of a development program that would eventually give it a coal-mining capacity of 3.7 million tons a year.
Spot television advertising billings, which jumped 12 to 15 per cent annually for the last 15 years, flattened out this year and may actually drop as much as 3 per cent from the 1969 total.
Clifford W. Michel, managing partner of Loeb, Rhoades Co., has been elected board chairman of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms for a one-year term.
VIDALIA, La., Nov. 18 (AP) A small plane, approaching for a landing at the Concordia Parish Airport, collided with another aircraft today, killing five persons.

The National Basketball Association, laying the groundwork for its first postseason playoffs since expanding to 17 teams last spring, announced yesterday a new plan for firstround pairings and a 75 per cent increase in prize money.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) A former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers said today that President Nixon's economic policies might cause a new wave of inflation and high interest rates.

Wall Street was in turmoil yesterday over the declaration of Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in favor of the eventual abolition of fixed commission rates for stock transactions after 178 years under the fixed-fee system.
LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The price of gold fell in all the main European bullion markets today.
HONG KONG, Nov. 18 Communist China reiterated today its rejection of United Nations membership along with the Nationalist regime on Taiwan.

Two large coffee makers, Hills Bros. Coffee, Inc., of San Francisco and the Folger Coffee Company, Kansas City, Mo., yesterday announced wholesale price reductions of four cents a pound effective immediately.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 President Nixon was reported today to be planning a major reshuffling of his Cabinet and the White House staff before the second half of his term begins next January.
Fifty works of modern American art brought $1-million, more or less, at an auction last night that was as remarkable for the audience reaction as for the prices for pop art and minor pieces.
Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh agreed yesterday to hold in abeyance a ruling barring as evidence tapes of conversations in which Black Panthers allegedly plotted to bomb department stores.
PARIS, Nov. 18 Fresh flurries in Europe's currency markets today reflected anxiety over the health of the dollar.
WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 18 (UPI) Harry Kallstrom and Gunnar Haggbom of Sweden drove their battered Lancia to victory tonight in the roundBritain automobile rally, which finished in confusion.

A 22-year-old youth who had been indicted on a charge of strangling his fiancee walked out of a courtroom yesterday a free man because another man had been arrested in connection with the killing and rapes and robberies in and near public parks.
Susan Matheke and Joel Harrison organize dances with the same choreographic eyes. They also tend to dance alike, and it was logical that they should share a program at the Cubiculo Tuesday night.

James Kennedy of 5823 Avenue N. Brooklyn, a night proofreader at The New York Times since 1966 who earlier had been with The New York Sun, The Brooklyn Eagle and The World Journal Tribune, died Monday in Kings County Hospital. He was 55 years old.
SUBITON, England, Nov. 18 (UPI) Naunton Wayne, who for 50 years portrayed "the perfect Englishman" in comedy and straight parts, died yesterday. He was 69 years old.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 The Israeli military administration has quietly started to permit the return of local Palestinian politicians deported from the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River and from the Gaza Strip over the last three years.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 18 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles adjourned his game today with Milan Matulovic, a former Yugoslav champion, in the seventh round of the eighth interzonal tournament of Palma de Mallorca, a 24-man knockout round robin to determine a challenger for the world chess championship.

SCHEGGINO, Italy It is true, both literally and figuratively, that the empire of Carlo Urbani started from scratch. It is an empire of "black diamonds" and, compared with the world's oil and steel domains, it may seem small indeed. But not for the world of high gastronomy.

The seriousness with which the Yugoslav Government regards the recent inflation in that country is indicated by its institution of such drastic measures as a six-month price freeze and harsh restrictions on consumer credit. Belgrade did not take these steps lightly since President Tito's regime is committed to expanding, not narrowing the scope of its socialist market economy. It also seeks to raise the standard of living with all possible speed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) The Senate Finance Committee approved today a proposal intended to make it harder for doctors to evade taxes on income earned for treating patients under Medicare and Medicaid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Nixon Administration has joined with the automobile industry in opposing a deadline for firm limits on the emission of pollutants from auto engines.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) The Memphis Pros dissipated a 9-point half-time lead tonight, then stalled a Pittsburgh rally in the final 3 minutes, and beat the Condors, 114-111, in an American Basketball Association game.

NEW HOPE, N.C. Twice within two hours the turkeys on J. Hanes Lassiter's private shooting preserve in the Uwharrie Mountains demonstrated the sagacity for which the species is famous, avoiding certain annihilation from my fowling piece. That they perished anyway is not relevant.

Employment of blacks and Spanish-speaking people in New York City by the three major television networks has increased sharply as a result of "pressure" brought by her agency, Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, asserted yesterday.

Secretary of Commerce Mau rice H. Stans last night gave assurances to American busi- nessmen that the Nixon Administration would not permit this country to get involved in a trade war with the rest of the world.

George Foreman, the undefeated heavyweight from Hayward, Calif., destroyed the myth that was Boone Kirkman of Seattle last night in 41 seconds of the second round of their scheduled 10-round bout in Madison Square Garden. Referee Arthur Mercante stopped the fight.
TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) Moffat Dunlap rode Grand Nouvel to victory tonight in the fault-and-out event in international show jumping competition at the Royal Horse Show.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) More than 800 scientists, including six Nobel Prize winners, urged the Senate today to kill a defense facilities security proposal they say is "a bill of horrors."

'Tis the season for the Veteran Corps of Artillery (State of New York) to polish memories and medals for the military ball that will mark, on Tuesday at the Pierre, the 180th anniversary of the founding of the corps.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 Konstantin M. Sergeyev, the long-time chief director of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet Company, has submitted his resignation in the wake of the defection of the ballerina Natalya Makarova during the Kirov's visit to Britain last summer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Relations between Roman Catholics and Jews in the United States in the last five years have reached a point of understanding and collaboration "the equal of which has never been witnessed before in Christian history."

NEWARK, Nov. 18 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City, John V. Kenny, a former Mayor and the Democratic boss of Hudson County, and 10 present city and county officials pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of extortion. Mr. Whelan, Mr. Kenny and two others who were also indicted for income tax evasion entered not guilty pleas on those charges, too.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 A professor of psychology at Villanova University proposed today that the Federal Government establish public censors to impede the distribution of pornography throughout the nation.

ROME, Nov. 18 The Financial Guard, the agency charged with enforcing Italy's tax laws, estimated in a report published today that last year tax dodging cost the nation $4-billion one-fourth of the total state revenue.

Pablo (Yoruba) Guzman, minister of information for the Young Lords, refused to answer questions yesterday regarding his earlier charges that a Puerto Rican prisoner named Julio Roldan had been murdered by guards at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18 When Billy Hudson drives the New Zealand-bred Stylish Major in tomorrow's $11,250 overnight handicap trot at Roosevelt Raceway, he will be doing so with the hope that springs eternal even among harness-racing drivers.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 18 Charles J. Monica, Mayor of this community since 1966, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 20 Regent Street. He was 67 years old.

The biggest blitz at Ohio State this week is not against Michigan but against the hundreds of ticket scalpers who are advertising and receiving as much as $100 for a $5 seat to Saturday's game between the two undefeated college football teams.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers. The reports include the following:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 The New York Knicks found out tonight how it was to play without Willis Reed, their captain, high scorer, top rebounder and the National Basketball Association's most valuable player.
One man was killed and two others were wounded by plain-clothes men while allegedly holding up a Queens bar last night. A patron was also wounded.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Janet Fish, a society woman who became a head nurse of a hospital here, died Tuesday at her home, 1624 32d Street Northwest. She was 87 years old.
A. Bernard Kelland, head of the Hack Bureau, said yesterday that the "premiums" being charged by some city-regulated, radio-dispatched taxicabs generally $2 over the meter in Manhattan were illegal.
The International Ski and Winter Sports Show starts its annual four-day stand at the New York Coliseum today with exhibitors represented from all parts of the United States. The doors open at 4 P.M.

Does the efficacy of a penicillin injection depend upon the skin color of the physician who administers it? Is the correctness of a diagnosis dependent upon the nationality, ethnic origin or religion of the doctor who makes it?

PEKING Day care centers, a cause celebre for women's liberation groups in the United States are an established way of life for working mothers here and all over mainland China. Some mothers, in fact, leave their children in the care of the communal nurseries not only for the day, but for the week.
KINGSTON, R.I., Nov. 18 (AP) A Harvard biochemist says civilization will end within 15 to 30 years unless immediate action is taken against problems facing mankind.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) A disturbance broke out at Boston Arena tonight, with many fans trowing bottles and chairs at the screen, when the closed-circuit television picture went dead during the second and final round of the Joe Frazier-Bob Foster heavyweight title fight.

ATLANTA, Nov, 18 (UPI) No sooner had Joe Frazier knocked out Bob Foster over closed-circuit television than Muhammad Ali, also known as Cassius Clay, leaped from his seat in Atlanta City Auditorium and screamed, "I want Joe Frazier. I want Joe Frazier."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 (AP) Two former Cleveland Browns players, Ross Fichtner and Bernie Parrish, were questioned today by a Federal Grand Jury investigating the National Football League for possible antitrust violations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 President Nixon asked Congress today for a sixfold increase in economic and military assistance for the Cambodian Government as part of an over-all supplemental request for $1.03billion more in foreign aid funds for the present fiscal year.

There is one radical-hip hockey player around these days. He's amusing and infuriating and alarming the fans (as well as his owners). Derek Michael Sanderson, known as Turk to his Boston Bruins' teammates, is the most quoted, the flashiest and most disarming competitor in the National Hockey League, an organization that is being tugged forward and backward.

Many New York enthusiasts depart today for Houston, where the American Contract Bridge League's fall national championships begin tomorrow. Those remaining behind have the opportunity in an unusual tournament here.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 18 (AP) A three-judge Federal panel ordered Wisconsin today not to prosecute any physician accused of violating the state's abortion law.
The London stock market closed sharply lower yesterday after an early extension of Tuesday's technical rally, mainly because of profit taking and lack of buying.

The commercial paper market stabilized during October, after five months of sharp declines, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. At the end of October, the total of such unsecured corporate notes outstanding came to $34.4-billion, up $449-million from $33.9-billion a month earlier.

A Harlem junior high school was closed yesterday for the rest of the week on the orders of the district superintendent, who had previously relieved the school's principal of her duties and, when she arrived at the school the next day, had ordered her arrest on trespassing charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Army Corps of Engineers has instructed its regional offices that 50 companies found last summer to be discharging mercury into waterways must obtain dumping permits, as re quired by an 1899 law.

Wall Street has been shaken in the past two years as it has not been since the Great Depression. Since the start of 1969, eighty member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have gone out of business (though not all because they were failing). The dangers to others are far from over.

Tremendous ardor, overwhelming technique and an inside-out knowledge of the piano as a sound-producing instrument were the qualities shown by William Masselos in his recital at the New York Cultural Center Wednesday night.
It looks as though the William Esty Company, the 38-year-old packaged-goods specialist, will be getting the national advertising assignment for the Interbank Card Association's Master Charge card.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 19 The first international auto race in Israel is being fiercely opposed by Orthodox Jews because it is scheduled for the Sabbath.Protest rallies and counterprotests have been scheduled at the site.

For the next six weeks, the most peaceful spot in the Metropolitan Museum, with the possible exception of the storage vaults, is likely to be a small gallery on the second floor where l3 Chinese landscape paintings selected from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Morse are installed in an exhibition that opened yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19 After more than two days of questioning prospective jurors, lawyers in the murder trial of Bobby G. Seale found two persons today who were acceptable to both sides.

ROME Western Europe is slowlybeginning to realize that its prospects of industrial growth are directly linked to continued access to Middle Eastern petroleum, and that if another outbreak of fighting stimulates Arab oil producers to new embargoes, the Common Market's future may be jeopardized.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 The conspiracy case of the Chicago Seven was returned to open court today as Judge Julius J. Hoffman began a hearing to determine whether he or any of the Federal marshals at the trial had improper communications with the jurors while they were deliberating.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 19 A White House adviser on energy matters said today the growing electric power shortage could be partly met by ending the practice of giving big customers favored rates.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 The artificial synthesis of the active portion of the parathyroid hormone, a body chemical that helps regulate bone formation, has been achieved by a teams of scientists at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

PUTNEY, Vt., Nov. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Aldren Auld Watson of Putney and Truro, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy McLeod Watson, illustrator and freelance writer of children's books in New York, to Michael Donald Harrah, a member of the New York City Opera Company.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 19 A witness testified today that Capt. Ernest Medina shot a prostrate Vietnamese woman during the alleged Mylai massacre.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 19 The National Cancer Institute has begun a new series of tests that its scientists hope will establish a strong link between viruses and human breast cancer and might suggest a method of earlier diagnosis and more effective treatment.
The London stock market drified lower yesterday and trading was sluggish.
"If you've had experience running against one millionaire, you should try running against two millionaires coming at you from both directions."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 A strong resolution condemning hijacking and the taking of hostages was approved today by a General Assembly Committee. The vote was 99 to 0, with 11 abstentions.

Fifty-five members of the Society of Guardians, a section of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress, are paying a minimum of $250 each for luncheon Monday at the home of Mrs. Leon Green of United Nations Plaza.
Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, accused the nation's public and private leadership last night of willfully ignoring black America's "fullfledged depression."
Over opposition from conservationists, the Tri-State Transportation Commission approved a new route yesterday for the Richmond Parkway through the edge of the Staten Island Greenbelt.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) A United States Marine helicopter returning from a rescue mission crashed into a mountain yesterday, killing 15 marines, including the members of a patrol that had called for the rescue.
Despite the General Motors strike and unfavorable weather conditions, chain store sales last month rose 7.4 per cent from the level of sales in the corresponding month of 1969.
BONN, Nov. 19 The West German Government announced today that it would resume political talks with East Germany this month.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (UPI) Bernie Parrish, a former defensive back for the Cleveland Browns, said today he believed indictments involving blackballing of players would result from a current Federal grand jury investigation of the National Football League.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive day in light and featureless trading.

A police undercover agent testified yesterday that he was wearing a concealed electronic transmitter during a meeting at which Black Panthers received instructions in sniper firing and discussed the making of Moltov cocktails.

A clutch of elegants of one sort or another turned up at the Plaza Hotel last night for the Fan Ball, for 21 years a substantial fixture of the New York social scene and an event that's making even more money this year despite the recession.

Bob Cooper, a singer with a magnificently bushy black beard, dug into the vital core of American folk song for his program at the Folklore Center 321 Avenue of the Americas, on Wednesday evening. Accompanying himself on guitar and banjo, Mr. Cooper sang songs by Woody Guthrie, by Leadbelly, by Jimmie Rodgers, by Flatt and Scruggs and, occa signally, songs of undetermined origin.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 19 (Reuters) Israel's first domestically designed and produced aircraft, the 20-passenger Arava, crashed today on a training flight. Three crew members were killed and a fourth was injured.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers announced today that Richie Allen had signed his 1971 contract. The club does not disclose salary figures but a reliable source said it could be estimated at $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 A high Treasury official said today that the Treasury would be able to repay "some" debt in the first half of next year even if the budget deficit in the current fiscal year turned out to be as much as $15billion.

Efforts to settle the 'fourday-old Off Broadway theater strike were unsuccessful last night and early this morning. with both sides "still far apart," according to Meyer Drucker, director of mediation services of the State Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Behind the scenes in Washington these days, Dr. Henry Kissinger and others are preparing the Nixon Administration's second annual report on the State of the World. This is a useful and ambitious project, introduced by President Nixon last year for the first time, and it could, if it is carefully prepared and presented, add order end perspective to the national debate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed today to hold hearings on the Nixon Administration's request for $1-billion in additional military aid. A major debate appeared to be building up over $155million for Cambodia that was included in the request.

EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 19 (AP) Hilary Sandoval Jr., who holds the highest Government office ever attained by a Mexican-American is resigning as head of the Small Business Administration effective Jan. 1.

At the ripe age of 35, Seiji Ozawa seems to be settling down as a conductor, a bit less so as a program builder. He was guest conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night. The concert ended with a staple of sorts, Berlioz's "Symphonie fantastique," but it was preceded by Aaron Copland's Short Symphony, played in honor of the composer's 70th birthday the actual date was last Saturday-and Gyorgy Ligeti's Atmospheres.
A Bronx man, Robert A. Greene of 195 West 168th Street, was one of three winners of $100,000 in the state lottery drawing yesterday at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and 41st Street.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 After several weeks of careful silence, Joe Frazier responded sharply today to Muhammad Ali's taunts.

A "construction czar" was appointed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to expedite the city's $3.9-billion backlog of capital construction projects.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission coupled the recall of about 88,000 lightweight women's scarves today with a warning that importers stop accepting dangerously flammable objects.
Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Dudley was named administrative judge of State Supreme Court for Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 Despite the bitter objections of their attorneys, the three female co-defendants in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson were granted the right today to appear as witnesses in their own behalf.
Bond prices surged on all fronts yesterday in one of the biggest advances of the year, with traders and syndicate men shaking their heads in disbelief that interest rates could come down so fast.
School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that he had "no intention of backing off" from his campaign for a serious re-examination of the city's educational system.
New charges were exchanged yesterday as the controversy continued over the removal of an East Harlem junior high school principal by the district superintendent.

The yacht that gets the Cygnet Cup for the outstanding Performance of the New York Yacht Club cruise always is held as a surprise until the race committee makes its selection Public at the club's annual awards dinner.
Two stamps of the United Nations and a single United States stamp commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the peace organization will be issued here this morning.

While those Johnny-comelatelics from Hanover, N.H., invade Franklin Field to put the finishing touches on a perfect season and wrap up the Ivy League championship, everyone knows that the real football season begins and ends tomorrow in Harvard Stadium.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 19 (AP) Dr. Jane E. Hodgson, St. Paul gynecologist, was convicted today of having violated Minnesota's abortion law.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., has announced the election of Richard L. Knight as senior vice president-finance, treasurer and a member of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) Newly elected Governors and members of Congress and their families but not the five new Democratic senators have been invited to join President Nixon Sunday for a worship service in the White House East Room.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) When the police arrested Bernard Lortie, a student sought for conspiracy in the kidnapping of Labor Minister Pierre Laporte, at a Montreal apartment two weeks ago, three other key suspects were reportedly hiding behind a false wall in the same apartment. They later escaped.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The House passed and sent to the Senate today a many-sided trade bill that would impose restrictions on some imports.

On that Friday of November, 1963, we tried to believe that the course of democracy in America would go on as it always had. Our Founding Fathers had foreseen the possibility of violence and had secured the succession.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 President Nixon will meet tomorrow with Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as part of a series of appointments with high economic officials of the Government, the White House disclosed today.
More than 200,000 property owners in New York State largely those in slum areas are facing a possible increase in fire insurance rates of nearly 41 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov, 19 J.Parnell Thomas, a seven-term United States Representative from New Jersey who gained national notice as an anti-Communist crusader in the late 1940's and later went to prison for padding his Congressional payroll, died here tonight after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 The Soviet Union today entered the General Assembly's debate on China in a last-minute effort to swing additional support behind an Algerian draft resolution calling for the seating of the Communists and the expulsion of the Nationalists.
Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company have named Kuhn, Loeb Co., investment bankers, as their financial advisers.
The Rand Institute of New York City said yesterday that the findings of a study on how the Police Department punished policemen "raise doubts" about how the department dealt with police misconduct.
FORT RUCKER, Ala., Nov. 18 Among men who had one of the most dangerous jobs in Vietnam piloting helicopters there are gripes and disgruntlement about how the Army awards its medals.

Even if the city government undertakes no new programs, it will have to raise the equivalent of a major new tax every year in the foreseeable future, according to a book that went into circulation yesterday.

On August 10, 1969, Prince Sihanouk asked the very reticent General Lon Nol to form a government. This decision by the Cambodian chief of state was surprising. Indeed, for many years, Sihanouk had done his utmost to make Lon Nol a scarecrow for his opposition on the left.

CLINTON, N.J., Nov. 19 Hoffman Potter, a retired chemist with the state's Bordentown Training and Research Center, died yesterday in Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington, after a brief illness. His age was 72.

The Giants and Jets are favorites in the weekend wars, the Jets by 9 points over the Boston Patriots here on Sunday and the Giants by 6 over the Eagles in Philadelphia on Monday night. Games to be televised here Sunday are Baltimore at Miami, Channel 4 at 1 P.M., and St. Louis at Kansas City.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 A Soviet Communist party official has accused the West of trying to create a "mood of opposition" among intellectuals. He mentioned the awarding of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn as an example of this activity.

William M. Fine, president of Bonwit Teller, told a group of apparel executives and security analysts here yesterday that retailers will become increasingly selective in picking their consumer markets and new store units during the next decade.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline and showed a substantial drop from the midOctober to mid-November level.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 19 With his eyes brimming with tears, S. Sgt. David Mitchell took the witness stand in his own defense today and testified that he had not seen American troops kill any civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in net income for the three, nine and 12 months ended Sept. 30 despite higher sales in all periods. The company noted that the end of the General Motors strike "should help the Christmas season, particularly if the men get back to work right after Thanksgiving in the several Federated cities where G.M. has plants."

Despite the sluggish economy and the worries among some people over the fractionalization of the agency business, three youngish advertising men have opened what they hope will become a full-service agency Keane McLaughlin. Call it Irish optimism, but they do have $1.3-million worth of business that they can't announce yet and have enhanced their financially stable image by renting space from R.E. Hart Co., investment bankers.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 19 The official death toll from last Friday's cyclone and tidal wave in the Ganges Delta south of here rose today to 150,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., opened his bid for confirmation as the nation's education chief today by rebutting allegations of organized labor that he opposes collective bargaining for teachers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A House Judiciary subcommittee was told today that theft of air freight at Kennedy International Airport in New York City was increasing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-Senior United States officials believe that changes in the Arab world this fall have created a considerably more favorable climate for Arab-Israeli negotiations than existed when the Middle East cease-fire began on Aug. 7.
"Jack MacGowran in the Works of Samuel Beckett" is the quintessence of Samuel Beckett offered by the quintessential Beckett actor, Jack MacGowran. The evening is pure and perfect.

MANILA, Friday Nov. 20 (AP) At least 30 persons were reported to have been killed and hundreds injured early today when a typhoon passed through Manila and densely populated Luzon Island with winds that reached 124 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The National Conference of Catholic Bishops rejected today a proposal to permit communicants at holy communion to take the consecrated wafer in their hand if they wish rather than receive it on their tongue in the traditional manner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A large influx of highly potent, cheap heroin in Vietnam has increased the drug-related death rate of soldiers there, an Army official told Congress today.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 There is something slightly terrifying about the relentless way Joe Frazier barges in on an opponent. His guns fire so ceaseless a fusillade that it appears he never will run out of ammunition. It took the recognized heavyweight champion of the world less than four minutes to dismantle Bob Foster last night in the Cobo Arena and two left hooks delivered the destruction.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19 The New Orleans Police Superintendent called off an armed four-hour confrontation with a Black Panther group today to prevent what he saw as an impending "blood bath." Neither side fired a shot.

PARIS, Nov. 19 North Vietnam warned the United States today that it would continue to oppose reconnaissance flights over its territory and the United States made it clear that it had no intention of abandoning such flights.
PARIS, Nov. 19 Strollers, children, mothers and all the plain pedestrians of Paris have won an important victory against the forces of the automobile.

The attack by, the Elementary School Principals Association on Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner is particularly depressing because it follows a scenario that is at once predictable and obsolete. WEST REDDING, Conn., Nov. 19 Carl A. Kallgren, dean emeritus of Colgate University, died at his home here after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 19 (UPI) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., needed two hours and three sets today to defeat Roger Taylor, a British lefthander and gain the semifinals of the $60,000 Embassy indoor tennis championships, but Pancho Gonzales and Dennis Ralston were beaten.

After two days of debate between protectionists and liberal traders, the House of Representatives has passed the trade-restriction bill. The margin of victory was much narrower than seemed possible even two weeks ago. What it demonstrates is that, at minimum, there would be enough opposition to this bill in the House and almost certainly in the Senate where it now goes to sustain a Presidential veto.

James C. Goggins of Los Angeles, a former New York lawyer and liquor importing executive, died Tuesday in Payson House of New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
Wheat, corn and soybean futures prices fell from 1 to 2 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but recovered late in the session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19(AP) Bowing to White House pressure, the House Appropriations Committee approved today a new $17.7-billion omnibus money bill, $300-million below an earlier measure that President Nixon had vetoed.

Pollution is an "in" topic. The newspapers are awash with stories deploring the condition of the environment and with stories warning that civilization will end within 30 years unless the tide is turned.

ALBANY, Nov. 19-Governor Rockefeller, in a grim assessment of the state's fiscal condition, said today that the members of the Democratic-controlled New York Congressional delegation were "the only ones who have the capacity to take the kind of action on a scale that will save New York City and New York State from destruction."

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 19 John Chapman had eight driving assignments at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Before the action began, he hoped to win at least three, the number needed to give him 200 for the first time in any of his 23 years as a harness driver.

A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that part of the proceeds of thefts of thousands of welfare checks was used by a fence to buy real estate, ostensibly for the benefit of the Bedford-Stuyvesant community.

Paintings, graphics and sculpture by Israeli artists will he shown and sold tomorrow evening and all day Sunday at the Riverdale Jewish Center. The event will take place in the center's Social Hall at 3700 Independence Avenue in the Bronx.

Three individuals and nine business organizations were honored for their contributions to the arts yesterday at the New York Board of Trade's fifth annu1 Business and the Arts luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

A Federal grand jury charged yesterday that members of three organized crime syndicates in New York and Florida had infiltrated the stock market by taking over a Miami investment company through threats and beatings and then parlaying the value of its shares up to artificially high selling levels to make large profits.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange issued a bland acknowledgement yesterday of the controversial stance on commission rates and other matters assumed earlier this week by Robert W. Haack, the exchange's president.

HOUSTON, Nov. 19 An exciting exhibition match between the world champion Dallas Aces and a team of Houston experts served as a curtain-raiser here for the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships, which begin at the Rice Hotel tomorrow.

Young lawyers from the city's gilt-edged law firms gathered for a conference on the "Legal Revolution" yesterday and were challenged by Ralph Nader to show a sense of "personal sacrifice," which he said was lacking in their ranks.

Miss Judi L. Hochman, a program officer for the Community Development Agency of the Human Resources Administration, was married here last evening to Allan M. Rudnick, an investment portfolio manager with the Oppenheimer A.I.M. Fund.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 Marshal Andrei I. Yeremenko, a prominent World War II military leader who commanded Soviet forces at Stalingrad, died today at the age of 78.

Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson made some optimistic predictions yesterday about the economy and the employment picture in the nineteen-seventies, but added that the present picture was far from encouraging.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 12 Religion may be declining in America's churches, but it has never been healthier in the nation's motels.

Layoffs in the airlines continued yesterday with the announcement that Trans World Airlines, Inc., plans to dismiss between 1,500 and 2,000 employes between now and the end of the year. A spokesman said the layoffs were due to the present "critical situation" of the airline.
Negotiators for the Taxi Drivers Union and the fleet owners continued their efforts early today to reach agreement on a new contract and avert a citywide taxi strike.

Sydney M. Goldman will retire as vice president of the Radio City Music Hall Corporation on Dec. 1. Mr. Goldman joined the Music Hall staff as assistant manager when the house opened in 1932. His duties will be assumed by Charles R. Hacker, a vice president of the corporation since 1964.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 President Nixon was reported today to be drafting a letter to Republican Senators urging them to sustain his veto of the television campaign spending bill as a matter of political loyalty as well as responsible law-making.

Frederic Waldman can always be counted upon to find good neglected music, and then to shuffle the elements of a program around so that it comes out entirely absorbing. The Wednesday night Musica Aeterna program in Alice Tully Hall was representative, ranging from Handel to Weber to Ravel and Kodaly, and not a weak work anywhere.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19 The Christian Democratic party, whose support assured the election of President Salvador Allende Gossens by Chile's Congress last month, has begun opposing his new government.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 Fifteen years ago, when Algeria was fighting for independence from France, a husky young Algerian with a nonchalant air appeared at the United Nations and quickly became known here as "the voice of rebel Algeria."
Reductions of coffee prices initiated Wednesday by several companies spread yesterday to other big producers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19 The new rulers of Syria moved today to garner popular support by staging a demonstration in Damascus and by announcing that a "people's assembly" would be convened to elect a new head of state.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Representative William R. Anderson of Tennessee wrote Secretary of the Army Stanley Resor today protesting the case of a West Point cadet who was obliged to quit the Military Academy because he lied about whether he had shined his shoes.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) Steve Mix's driving layup on a pass from Bob Lanier with, four seconds left enabled the Detroit Pistons to beat the Phoenix Suns, 112-110, in a National Basketball Association game tonight. The victory snapped a six-game losing streak for Detroit.
Mayor Lindsay called yesterday upon the Federal Government to provide "emergency relief" to ease the budget crises that he said afflicted many of the nation's largest cities.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 19 (Reuters) Four Greek Cypriotes were each sentenced to 14 years in prison today for attempting to murder President Makarios and his helicopter pilot last March.

ROME, Nov. l9 Ultraleftist students denounced the Italian Communist party as a member of the Establishment in demonstrations in Rome and other cities today.

The F. M. Schaefer Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Arnold Bakers, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., for a maximum of $9.5-million of Schaefer's preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The White House allowed to stand today without serious or direct challenge widespread reports that some shifts in the Nixon Cabinet Were likely before the second half of the President's term begins next January.

Dissatisfied with the progress of negotiations between the city and its employes' service unions, the Board of Collective Bargaining said yesterday that it would step into the picture Dec. 1 if no substantial progress had been made.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 19 (Reuters) American and Soviet negotiators in the talks on strategic-arms limitations met for an hour and 45 minutes at the United States Embassy today.

California, which imports more doctors than it produces, was urged yesterday to double by 1980 its output of doctors, dentists and other health professionals and to train new categories of health personnel such as physicians' assistants.
The stock market continued to drift yesterday as prices ended mixed in relatively quiet trading.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 19-Premier Golda Meir is engaged in a delicate political technique familiar from her dealings with Washington, the tactic of keeping all the options open. Daily, it is becoming more difficult.

The Council on Foreign Relations is accepting applications for the Edward R. Murrow Fellowship for the 1971-72 academic year, according to an announcement by David Rock-, efeller, chairman of the council.

Money and bank credit expanded at a moderate pace in the last few weeks, banking data Published yesterday showed, but the demand for business loans at the major money-center banks in New York was notably weak, as it has been for some time.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 A West Berliner being held in the shooting of a Soviet sentry earlier this month escaped from a police guard here today and fled through a subway tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Saul D. Alinsky, who has spent a lifetime preaching and practicing radicalism, today called the "New Far Left" a "horribly sick cult," which, if unchecked, would inevitably make a police state of America.

The International Ski and Winter Sports Show opened its annual four-day stand at the New York Coliseum yesterday with ski exhibits representing 150 resorts from the Sierras to the Rockies and from Canada's Laurentians to the Alps.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 19 (UPI) All political prisoners held by the Government under state of emergency powers have been released, it was announced today. The prisoners include labor, student and black power leaders.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 79 (UPI) The widows of 35 of the 78 men killed in the disaster in the Farmington No. 9 coal mine two years ago filed suit in United States District Court today for nearly $4-million.
PRAGUE, Nov. 19 (Reuter) -The Czechoslovak Communist party leader, Gustav Husak, returned today from Moscow and then met with Marshal Ivan I. Yakubovsky, Soviet commander of Warsaw Pact forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a farm program that would limit Federal subsidy payments to any one farm to $55,000 a year on each of three basic crops cotton, wheat and feed grains.

State Senator Basil A. Paterson, the defeated DemocraticLiberal candidate for Lieutenant Governor, is being promoted as a possible successor to the Democratic state chairman, John J. Burns, when he steps down.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 The head of the Federal Housing Administration, defending his agency against charges of being a handmaiden of private industry, said today that the F.H.A. was in fact becoming more consumer-oriented.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. Nov. 21--Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, challenged undefeated Dartmouth to play Dec. 5 for "the Eastern championship." Hitchcock, the German-bred colt purchased by Sigmund Sommer last year for $130,000, scored the first victory of his American racing career yesterday, at Aqueduct. MILWAUKEE, Nov. 21 (AP) --A woman has been ordered to pay her former husband $25 a week in child support.

The nation's economic slump appears to have had one incidental benefit. By slowing the explosive growth of air travel in the United States, it has given Federal aviation officials a respite from the pressures that led in part to last spring's crippling 'sick strike' by about 3,000 of the nation's 14,000 air traffic controllers.

Plans have been announced for the first annual American film festival to be held in Dallas from March 8 through March 14 at the Bob Hope Theater of the Owen Arts Center, Southern, Methodist University. The program will be given over entirely to American movies, featuring 12 to 15 films to be selected by a panel of regional and national critics.
KUWAIT, Nov. 17--Behind the nouveau-riche facade of Kuwait, the monarchy of Sheik Sabah-al-Salem al-Sabah is grappling with economic and political strains.

CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 21-- Miss Joanne Mariett Piskor and William Waddell Chase were married here this afternoon in the Gunnison Memorial Chapel of St. Lawrence University, of which Dr. Frank P. Piskor, father of the bride, is president.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 21 (UPI)--Mike Adamle of Northwestern set a Big Ten season rushing record today and his teammate, Bill Planisek, kicked a 27-yard field goal with 47 seconds to go to give the Wildcats a 23-20 victory over Michigan State and their best conference record in 22 years.

Mrs. Ruth Dunbar Cushing of New York and Terence Carson Flood of Montreal were married here yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls. A reception was given at the River Club.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 21 (AP)--Bob Mollicone's 21-yard field goal in the first period made the difference today as Northeastern snapped a fourgame football losing streak by beating Bridgeport, 9-7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--A defeated candidate for the House of Representatives from Vermont has openly defied the Federal law on reporting campaign expenditures and so far has been ignored by the authorities.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 21 (UPI)-- Iowa held Illinois one foot short of the tying touchdown at the final gun today and gained a 22--16 victory and a fourthplace finish in the Big Ten Conference.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21-- Ed Marinaro, who covers more ground than a worker laying sod on a football field, wrapped up the national college rushing championship and broke a few more records today. BAOSICI, Yugoslavia--I nearly tripped over a priceless ancient Roman wine jar as I sauntered into one of the most jumbled and rewarding museums I have ever seen, here or anywhere else. The jar was standing amidst a veritable litter of old swords, Greek pottery, a medieval pikeman's helmet, logs from old sailing ships, a rifle inlaid with jewels, turbans and uniforms from a dozen forgotten armies.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana Prime Minister Forbes Burnham's first move toward state ownership of basic industries here will start Dec. 7, when his Government will begin negotiations to obtain a "meaningful participation" in the vital bauxite mining operations of the Aluminium Company of Canada and the Reynolds' Metals Company.

F. Jerome McNultry, an assistant city corporation counsel during the administration of Mayor James J. Walker, died Saturday in Tulsa, Okla., of injuries suffered in a riding accident. He was 67 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 2--Fears of a large outbreak of cholera and typhoid mounted in East Pakistan today despite stepped-up foreign relief efforts in the race to keep alive the sick and hungry survivors of last week's cyclone and tidal wave.

Tom Fleming of Paterson State College won the ninth annual Eastern Regional road runners cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The 19-year-old Fleming covered the nine-mile course in 40 minutes 18 seconds.
Gambling that its choice would produce college football's version of a super bowl, Notre Dame accepted an invitation yesterday to return to the Cotton Bowl in Dallas on New Year's Day.

The sense of imminent danget that makes hockey the violent, explosive game it is nearly went into the realm of tragedy last night as the! Rangers scored a 2-0 victory over the Minnesota North Stars at Madison Square Garden.

Forty symphony orchestras in 26 states have been awarded grants totaling $1,820,060, it was announced by Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Private sources provided $333,000 of the endowment, with the remainder coming from Federal funds. Last August, grants totaling $1,680,000 were awarded to 34 orchestras.

The Police Department announced yesterday that Com. missioner Patrick V. Murphy had dismissed a detective charged with selling confidential information, but the detective's lawyer immediately charged that he had been prevented from finishing his defense in a departmental trial.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 22 The police announced today that Israel security services had broken an Arab terrorist cell responsible for bombings at the central bus station here that killed 2 Israelis and injured 23 on Nov. 6.

The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York, has applied to the Federal Reserve Board for permission to open an international banking subsidiary in Miami. This is the second such move in recent weeks. Last month the Federal Reserve gave the Bank of America in San Francisco a green light to open in Miami.
The Interpublic Group of Companies is merging Jack Tinker Partners and Pritchard Wood Associates and is putting James R. Heekin Jr., former president of Ogilvy Mather, in charge.
VERSAILLES, France, Nov. 22 Defense Minister Michel Debra was hooted today when he told a convention of women that they had a duty to increase the birth rate.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Samton have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Annette Samton, to Paul N. Marcus of New York. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Marcus of Katonah. The wedding will take place on Dec. 27.

ROME, Nov. 22 Pope Paul VI, speaking from a window in the Apostolic Palace to a crowd in St. Peter's Square, said today that Italy was "restless and divided, for reasons that involve most important religious, moral and social interests."

PARIS, Nov. 22 The first borrowing in a European monetary unit is being arranged by the executive authority of the European Economic Community in cooperation with seven banks in the six member states.

WASHINGTON Nov. 22 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott, released a letter from President Nixon today promising Administration help in drafting election reforms that would substitute for a vetoed bill limiting campaign spending on radio and television.

Cloudy, cold and windy weather accompanied by scattered snow flurries will occur from the Northeast to the Midwest today. Unseasonably cold conditions will prevail over the East, South and Midwest. For a ballet company that is not big on sets, the addition of scenery by Jo Mielziner to the New York City Ballet's "Who Cares?" rates as something of a special occasion. The new decor for the ballet was unveiled Saturday night at the State Theater.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 Secretary of State William P. Rogers assured Canadians today that their American neighbors would help them develop a nation "distinct" from the United States. However, he reminded them that Canada was heavily dependent on United States markets and capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that a person accused of a crime should be permitted to plead guilty to a lesser offense and avoid the possibility that a jury might impose a stiffer sentence, even if the defendant insists that he is not guilty.

DACCA, Nov. 22 The foreign-dominated relief effort for the victims of the cyclone and tidal wave increased in intensity today, but it still was believed to be far short of what is needed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) A special committee of the American Hospital Association recommended today reforms that it said would provide "optimum health care for each and every person" at a "reasonable cost."

ROME, Nov. 23 Pope Paul VI ruled today that Cardinals who had reached the age of 80 years could not take part in the election of a new Pope. The reform, which goes into effect Jan. 1, increases the chances for the next Pope to be non-Italian and, possibly, a progressive.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 23 Radio broadcasts from neighboring Guinea said that Government forces battled a band of fascist invaders today for the second day.
