OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 23 (AP) An Indianapolis pilot said today that his name had been used to set up a dummy company through which Golden Eagle Aviation Inc. leased some planes.
The National Biscuit Company yesterday announced plans to enter the toy and hobby field by agreeing in principle to acquire Aurora Products, Inc., for about $17.6
The London stock market drifted down in quiet trading yesterday. The Financial Times index of 30 industrial stocks closed at 327.4, off 2.2, and the 500-stock index settled at 136.42, off 0.47.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov 23 The State of Mississippi has shelved charges against the only person indicted in connection with the violence last May 14 at Jackson State College a Negro charged with inciting to riot and participating in a riot.
The stock market shed its heavy bag of worries long enough yesterday to produce a rally that responded to the latest cut in the prime rate.
BERLIN, Nov. 23 The Big Four ambassadors failed to make any progress here today in the eleventh round of talks aimed at improving the situation in and around Berlin.

Every critic sooner or later is asked the question: "Why are critics so cruel?" The answer, I suppose, is related to a play such as "The Candyapple," which was written by John Grissmer, produced by William F. Deseta, and opened at the Edison Theater last night.
A handbook for those who wish to join in the struggle to save our estuarine areas from development, dredging or pollution has been published by the American Littoral Society.

DELTA JUNCTION, Alaska Nov. 20 Fifty-six individually selected head of Iowa's finest corn-fed hogs were flown in this week to become pioneer participants in a closely watched Arctic agricultural experiment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Joint Senate-House Conference Committee completed work today on a compromise version of the mutual-fund legislation, thus bringing to an end, except for formalities, a legislative fight that has consumed four years. Passage of the compromise version by both the Senate and the House and President Nixon's signature are still required before the bill becomes law, but there appeared to be no likelihood of any snags.

The Knicks, whose stature in the National Basketball Association has diminished considerably in recent weeks, will be 11 inches taller when they face the Atlanta Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden.
Bond prices surged for the fourth straight session yesterday, extending a rally that has veteran Wall Streeters hard pressed to remember any previous advance that has been so steep.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Nineteen church, social service and civil rights leaders said today that President Nixon had not kept a promise to give free or reduced-price lunches to all needy school children by Thanksgiving.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday that tuition in its 10 high schools would be raised $100 to an annual total of $700, starting next September.
Dr. Arnold H. Einhorn indicated strongly yesterday that he might never return to Lincoln Hospital, despite his "reinstatement" over the weekend as chief of pediatrics.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Nov. 23 Five miles due west of Manhattan, there are large numbers of muskrats, and an occasional mink or raccoon, in a vast, largely undeveloped area called the Hackensack Meadowlands.
ROME, Nov. 23 Policemen used tear gas to break up a fight between neo-Fascist and left-wing students on the Rome University campus today.
About 350 guests are expected to attend the annual donor luncheon of the Westchester Hartman-Homecrest League of the Jewish Child Care Association next Tuesday at the Plaza.

PLANDOME, L.I., Nov. 23 Otto B. Blackwell, a retired executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday in a nursing home in Sands Point. He was 86 years old and lived at 15 North Drive here.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 The Harvard Community Health Plan has moved out of the experimental stage one year after it began and is becoming financially self-sustaining, Dr. Robert H. Ebert, the plan's president, announced today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 The Soviet Union and Communist China today signed a trade and payments agreement in Peking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) The Commerce Department reported today that new orders for durable goods in October declined $1.2-billion from the September level.
Postal. The President appointed Howard Elliott, Jr., 37 years old, of St. Louis, and John L. Ryan, 49, of Indianapolis, to be members of the Postal Rate Commission.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday its final prices for its 1971 model cars, tacking on an average of $24 to the "tentative" increase of $208 announced last Sept. 24.

The Federal Government charged yesterday that five Paraguayans and a Frenchman conspired to bring almost 94 pounds of pure heroin, said to be worth at least $10-million, into a small airport in Florida, where customs agents seized the narcotics shipment last month.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Treasury bill rates declined dramatically at today's auction from last week's levels, recorded a three-year low, the government reported late this afternoon.

A continent apart, George Blanda of the Oakland Raiders and Gino Cappelletti of the Boston Patriots did their things again the day before yesterday. They kicked field goals. For Blanda it was another of his last-second dillies to rescue the Raiders from defeat and keep them alive for possible Super Bowl nomination. For Cappy it was a relatively empty gesture because the Pats are going nowhere, unless it be to a cruel New England winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 The six-game winning streak that had transformed the hapless Giants into a pennant contender froze to death at Franklin Field tonight in a 23-20 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, who had won only one of nine previous games.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Walter J. Hickel, Secretary of the Interior, banned United States imports of whale products today to help prevent the extinction of whales.
The first of 500 provisional city employes to be laid off because of the current budget crisis received pink slips yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) Federal law prohibits the mailing of information on lotteries, but the Post Office has bent the rule slightly in the case of drawings run by two states.
Except for pains in his neck and the back of his head, Jack Egers said from his hospital bed yesterday that he felt fine.
CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Nov. 23 (AP) A chain of explosions ripped a propane storage area today on Charlotte Amalie's eastern edge, injuring at least 76 persons.
The American Civil Liberties Union will mark its 50th anniversary Dec. 8 at a dinner in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. Former Chief Justice Earl Warren of the United States will be guest of honor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23 A small Vietnamese girl in pajamas, who has no idea of what Dec. 25 means to others, is a sudden reminder of Christmas on a noisy Saigon street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Representative Henry S. Reuss reiterated today that Congress would "never assent to any increase in the value of monetary gold."
President Nixon's request to the Congress for $500 million for arms to Israel makes urgent the immediate reconsideration of how we should aid Israel in her struggle for survival.
Jacinto Vasquez entertained the 22,175 customers at Aqueduct yesterday by guiding home three winners in seven attempts, in the nine-race program.

Dartmouth College, undefeated and untied in its nine football games this season and winner of the Ivy League championship, was named yesterday as winner of the 1970 Lambert Trophy for the "outstanding Eastern major college performance during the season."

MIAMI, Nov. 22 Ichthyologists have warned that the environment is being seriously threatened by the importation into Florida of 50 million live tropical fish yearly and the inadvertent release of many species, including the rapacious piranha.
Mrs. Grete Gans Globus, a leader in neuropathology and neurology, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 960 Park Avenue.
It is perhaps too much to say that rock music is getting religion, but a large number of current records are dealing sympathetically with religious and spiritual ideals.

Bloomingdale's is opening four new shops just in time for the Christmas season. Two of the shops will replace probably the most famous one the store has ever had: Place Elegante, which had been a preholiday fixture for about 20 years on the third floor.

The International Ski Racers Association, hoping to set up a tour comparable to that of professional golf, yesterday announced a schedule of nine races for the coming season, six in the United States and three in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has formally relayed to the Federal Communications Commission a warning from Wall Street that the company could lose its present top-quality credit rating unless its earnings improve substantially.
A 70-year-old building superintendent was killed and 18 tenants were overcome by poisonous gas emitted from a Harlem tenement's defective coal furnace yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24 Harvard's unbeaten soccer team advanced to the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate playoffs today by beating Brown, 2-1, for its 12th victory and second straight New England title.
Essentially there are two types of choreographers, those who laugh and those who do not. Robert Streicher does not and Jan Van Dyke does. Last night they shared a program at the Cubiculo.

Special to The New York Times HOUSTON, Nov. 24 Two unheralded Middle Western players captured the life master men's pair championship here last night in the American Contract Bridge League's fall national tournament. Heading a field that included several internationally famous experts, Ronald Andersen of Madison, Wis., and Hugh McLean of Edina, Minn., totaled 992 match points to take the title.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's open hearing in Washington yesterday on the rescue mission in North Vietnam as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News. Among those questioning Secretory of Defense Melvin R. Laird were Senators J.W. Fulbright, Frank Church and Claiborne Pell, Democrats, and George Aiken, Republican.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 While food prices dropped last month one of the few heartening elements in a rising Consumer Price Index all indications point to another rise next spring.

Ronald Wilford has been elected president of Columbia Artists Management, Inc. and chairman of the board of Community Concerts, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Columbia. He succeeds Kurt Weinhold, who has held both posts for 11 years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24 Robert DeWitt Clinton Meeker, board chairman of the Meeker Company, radio and television sales representatives, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived here in Deer Park.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Nguyen Cao Ky, South Vietnam's often controversial Vice President, pictured himself today as a misunderstood moderate, "an ex hawk turned dove," whose primary interest is in ending the fighting that has wracked his country for 20 years.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 24 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., and Ken Rosewall of Australia kept alive their hopes of sharing the first prize in the international tennis Grand Prix with easy first-round victories tonight in the Stockholm open indoor tournament, the last event of the $150,000 series.

The New York Urban Coalition called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to dismiss Housing and Development Administrator Albert A. Walsh, saying that Mr. Walsh had, in effect, rejected its plan to rehabilitate abandoned slum buildings for welfare families that are now housed at high rents in hotels.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 24 On the campuses of the United States these days politics seem to be in a slump and pretty girls have made a remarkable comeback. The post-election mood seems comparatively calm, serious and personal after the spectacular mass rumbles of last spring.
City College announced yes terday that it would close its off-campus classroom center for students in the SEEK program at the end of next June.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator William Proxmire urged the Administration today to suspend oli-import quotas and immediately free crude oil production in the Federal domain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator Harold E. Hughes, who nominated Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1968, appears to be moving to the right as he ponders whether to seek the Presidency himself in 1972.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 A strong rise in consumer prices in October for the second consecutive month was reported today, reversing the improvement in the inflation picture that emerged last summer.
The New York Times announced yesterday plans to publish on microfilm the entire collection of Liberty magazine, one of this country's leading family weeklies from 1924 to 1950.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The House passed a $17.7billion appropriations bill today as a replacement for an $18billion version that President Nixon had vetoed on the ground it was inflationary.

A reorganized city government with about 45 neighborhood districts, headed by elected local directors and taking over many functions from City Hall, was proposed yesterday in a study sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
These comments are from a recent talk by Leonard Bernstein to students at the Berkshire Music Center.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, Nov. 24 Henry G. Barnhurst, a manager for the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company in New York, died today in his office at 270 Madison Avenue, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived here a 11 Pokahoe Drive.
Welfare officials estimated yesterday that the city's relief budget for the next fiscal year would increase to $2-billion, with the average monthly case load rising to 1.27 million persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Senate Appropriations Committee sent the supersonic transport's development budget to the Senate floor today, setting the stage for a showdown vote sometime next week, probably on Thursday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24 Robert F. Janes, a lawyer, died today at a convalescent home in Stamford. He was 90 years old and live at 1 Fifth Avenue, New York. He was a retired attorney for the New York Telephone Company.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 24 In a crowded Federal courtroom just three miles from the spot where his great-great-great-grandfather founded the du Pont dynasty 166 years ago, Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. today faced his creditors and spent two and a half hours answering questions about his $55-million in personal liabilities.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 The trend toward higher oil costs in North Africa and the Middle East spread further today with the announcement that the Kuwait Oil Company jointly owned by the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, had agreed to a $90-million increase in payments to the Kuwaiti Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The new Federal program to ease school desegregation with money has amounted so far to "a fraud upon Congress," six civil rights groups charged today.

The first-rate German-language troupe Die Brucke has every right to return home smiling like the audience last night at the Barbizon Plaza Theater. Having opened last week with a perfectly elegant, earthbound "Amphitryon" by Heinrich von Kleist, the company rounded out its visit, through next Wednesday, with two even earthier goodies, a pair of one-acters with no leftover crumbs in either play or playing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 David M. Kennedy, the Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the United States must reject "harsh and arbitrary trade restrictions."

The most trenchant comment on the Committee for Economic Development policy statement, "Further Weapons against Inflation: Measures to Supplement General Fiscal and Monetary Policies," comes in a footnote by Frazer B. Wilde, chairman emeritus of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company...

A management consulting concern has advised Long Island University not to build a library at its Brooklyn Center if it expects "to survive as a viable university during the next five years both educationally and financially."

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 Israeli officials believe that the Suez Canal, which has been blocked since the Arab-Israeli war of June, 1967, could be restored to operation in two or three months if a political agreement to reopen it could be concluded.
The fourth annual Winter Glow Ball will take place Dec. 4 at Rod's Shadowbrook, Shrewsbury, N.J. The evening will begin with cocktails at 7:30 and dinner will be served at 9.
On an afternoon when the geese in the infield lake could have used ice skates, Larry Adams discovered a good way to beat the cold yesterday at Aqueduct. He rode three winners.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) Raymond R. Tucker, an engineer anti educator who became the firs three-term Mayor of St. Louis, died here last night. He was 73 years old.

Similar messages, in different languages, are being distributed to the parents of other pupils in the city schools. The leaflets 500,000 copies printed in English, 300,000 in Spanish and 5,000 each in Chinese, French and Italian are intended to acquaint parents and schoolchildren with pupil-suspension procedures, a matter of considerable controversy here in recent years.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 24 Defense attorneys and two defendants in the conspiracy trial of the Seattle Eight repeatedly last pleas today that prospective jurors be asked to make statements regarding their social and political attitudes rather than merely giving yes or no answers to questions from the judge.

Alan Rich, music editor of New York Magazine, received two prizes yesterday in the presentation of the ASCAPDeems Taylor Awards given by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers for books and articles on music published in 1969.
Western Air Lines announced yesterday that it had recessed a special meeting of its board of directors until Dec. 7 to study a new and "enhanced" merger proposal made by Continental...

RAS SHUKAIR, United Arab Republic, Nov. 23 In a silent chapter of the Arab-Israeli conflict, Israeli tankers sail boldly down the Gulf of Suez past this Egyptian-American offshore oil site, headed toward Elath, Israel's southern port, with oil produced from fields in the Israeli-occupied Sinai Peninsula.

PALMA, Spain, Nov. 24 The two top players in the Palma elimination and qualification knockout round-robin tournament for the world challenge match, Yefim Geller of the Soviet Union. with 8-3, and Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, with 7-2, and two adjourned games, met in the 12th round today and their game was adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Mississippi Democratic party that won recognition by the national body at the 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago is organizing a challenge to the seniority of the five members of the House from that state.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (AP) A helicopter carrying South Vietnamese troops collided today with a light United States plane in the Mekong Delta 80 miles south of Saigon.

While the Negro Ensemble Company has hitherto been very highly regarded by the white community, including the white critics, I have been slightly conscious that its standing among some blacks was less, say, than that of the Lafayette Theater of Ed Bullins. Perhaps something of this can be detected in the company's fourth season, which takes as its general subject matter "Themes of Black Struggle."

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP) Negotiations between representatives of Mohawk Airlines and its pilots, who are on strike for higher pay, were recessed indefinitely today after a twohour morning meeting, a company spokesman said.

The National Audubon Society said yesterday that it had its first reported sighting in New York State of the ash-throated flycatcher, which thrives in the heat of Death Valley but also is found in other areas in Southern and Western states.
The London stock market, helped by the rise on Wall Street, was slightly firmer yesterday, but trading was quiet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Rube Goldberg is the cartoonist who invented the fantastic machine that struck the universal chord. His drawings spoofed man's ability to make the simple complex, and showed man a lot lower than the angels downright human.

Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach will appear in a special program Monday night at the Stage 73 Theater, 321 East 73d Street, to raise funds for the Manhattan Theater Arts Center, a nonprofit corporation that is scheduled to open next year.
Mayor Lindsay and 25 of his top officials agreed yesterday to take $1,000-a-year pay cuts as part of the city's response to its current budget crisis.
Andre Watts will give a piano recital the evening of Dec. 9 at the Cosmopolitan Club at 129 East 65th Street in behalf of the Harlem School of the Arts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 Plans for a coalition of bluecollar workers and members of the academic community to seek solutions of problems facing the nation were discussed last night at an informal meeting at the University of Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Senate Finance Committee tentatively voted today to restore to states the right to impose one-year residency requirements for welfare applicants.

The Nixon Administration's highly desirable welfare reform proposal is trapped in an ironic crossfire of criticism from both conservative and liberal members of the Senate Finance Committee. It must not be left to die in this political no-man's land.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) Tickets for New Jersey's new state lottery go on sale Dec. 16 at 50 cents apiece, with the first weekly drawing for the $50,000 top prize set for Jan. 7, Gov. William T. Cahill announced today.
Once, people bought bathtubs to bathe in. Times have changed. Nowadays, bathtubs are doubling as aquariums, settings for baths a deux and even as objets d'art.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Nixon Administration scaled down its offer of loan guarantees for troubled railroads from $750-million to $500-million today.
Three Coast Guardsman who had been on a search and rescue mission in Long Island Sound were rescued unharmed yesterday after spending the night in rubber "wet suits" clinging to a life raft.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 24 (UPI) After a review today of films of the finish of yesterday's National Collegiate Athletic Association cross-country race, Villanova University was declared the team champion instead of Oregon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The president of the American Bar Association rebuked Donald Rumsfeld, head of the Federal antipoverty program, today for suggesting that the dismissals of two top poverty law officials were endorsed by the A.B.A.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Senate Appropriations Committee today restored $555-million that the House had cut from the foreign aid appropriations bill for this fiscal year and sent the $2.2-billion measure to the Senate floor for an early vote.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 If history can repeat itself, Southern California's Trojans do have a chance Saturday against the undefeated Fighting Irish of Notre Dame.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) Governor Rockefeller spent almost $6.8-million on his successful campaign for reelection, according to figures filed with the Secretary of State's office.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 Devaluation of the dollar is in prospect unless the United States curtails its inflation and its continuing balance of trade deficits, Gaylord A. Freeman Jr., chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, contended here today.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines began handling conventional cargoes in Brooklyn yesterday after a sudden move from Hoboken.

PARIS The peace negotiations in Paris have changed very little during the past eighteen months but the war in Indochina has. Nothing confirmed this fact more strikingly than last weekend's U.S. air raids on the North.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 President Nixon has rejected a proffered resignation of Secretary of the Treausy David M. Kennedy and Mr. Kennedy will stay at his post indefinitely, official sources said today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 24 (UPI) A Federal grand jury today indicted the Southern Airways Company, Inc., a Delaware corporation, and 12 of its employes on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by supplying it with defective artillery shells.

Earnings plummeted during the first fiscal quarter at R.H. Macy Co., Inc., New York's Largest retailer and operator of 61 department stores, but sales since a sluggish August have continued to rise, shareholders were told here yesterday.
Leaders representing the government, organized labor and industry took a look at the economy yesterday and agreed that inflation and unemployment were the most pressing issues.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 24 Col. Gus Dielens, Army's director of athletics, explained the Army-Navy football rivalry as something rarely felt by athletes in any competition these days. He said it was a contest in which "you hit that other guy like it was the last time you'd hit anyone in your life."
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 24 It took 23 years, nearly 15,000 races and lots of blood, sweat and tears, but John Chapman finally achieved his goal 200 winners in a single season.

Bowling Green, Ohio, ranks right up there with the great evocative American place names, along with Slippery Rock, Pa., and What Cheer, Iowa. And besides a lovely name, Monday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall gave one to know, the town claims an astonishingly fine string quartet.
ROME, Nov. 24 Vatican informants said today that Pope Paul VI was planning to broadcast an appeal for a negotiated peace in Vietnam and Cambodia when his plane passes over or near Indochina Friday.

The American Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its sales of new cars increased 34 per cent in the Nov. 11-20 period. During the middle 10 days of November the nation's fourth largest major car maker sold 6,111 automobiles, up from 4,551 in the year-earlier period.

Consumer confidence during September and October, buffeted by the approaching elections, the General Motors strike and rising unemployment, appeared to be lower than it was, in July and August, according to a survey by the Conference Board. Nevertheless, consumers said they were more hopeful about business and job prospects in the next half year.

"What can I say to my children?" asked Mrs. Elaine Wilson, a sad-eyed mother of five, who was one of the provisional employes laid off by the city yesterday for economy reasons. Many of them will have to go back on welfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he would recommend to President Nixon the resumption of full-scale air attacks on North Vietnam if the enemy engaged in major violations of a tacit understanding with the United States that halted the bombing two years ago.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 The Vietcong "shadow government" apparently has changed its name from the Provisional revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam to the Government of the Republic of South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 King Hussein of Jordan will visit the United States early in December to confer with President Nixon.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 24 Joseph I. Dobrow, a sales engineer with the Berton Plastics Company in Hackensack, and formerly president of the Paterson Tallow Company, died today. He was 58 years old and lived at 637 Maitland Avenue.
PARIS, Nov. 24 A Gaullist member of Parliament, Michel de Grailly, was beaten and stabbed by four men tonight as he was parking his car in front of his home in the residential Passy district here.

Leon J. Davis, president of the Drug and Hospital Union's Local 1199, said yesterday that 20 per cent of city hospital workers received such low wages 10 years ago that they were on welfare but that his union had raised the pay scale so that none were welfare recipients now.

BATTAMBANG, Cambodia, Nov. 16 As usual at this time of year, yellow-green seas of rice stalks stretch to every horizon in this most fertile of Cambodia's provinces, but the approaching harvest season seems to be bringing with it a sense of foreboding.

The American Cancer Society has arranged its Holiday Boutique for Dec. 3 through Dec. 18 in its offices at 44 East 53d Street. The sale, a weekday project of the society's women's committee, will be from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

The much rumored, longawaited merger of D'Arcy Advertising and MacManus, John Adams was announced yesterday, along with a little surprise. Intermarco, Europe's fourth largest agency, is in on the act.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24 Lawyers in the Bobby G. Seale trial set a brisk pace today as they, questioned and rejected 25 persons in an effort to seat a jury to try the Black Panther party chairman on charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy.
More than 37,000 commuters who ride the Penn Central and (Jersey Central Railroads within New Jersey face increases Jan. 1 in their monthly commuting rates ranging from 15 per cent to 25 per cent.

SEATTLE, Nov. 24 (AP) An announcement by four sophomore black athletes yesterday that they would not return to the University of Washington football team next year appeared to surprise the athletic department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 Under persistent questioning by a defense attorney, Deputy Federal Marshal Ronald Dobroski said today that the jury in the conspiracy trial of the Chicago Seven had sent only one deadlock message during five days of deliberations and this had been sent on Saturday, the day the deliberations began.

RIDGELAND, S. C., Nov. 24 An all-black jury tonight acquitted Ben Chaney Jr., the 18-year-old brother of James Chaney, slain Mississippi civil rights worker, on a charge that he murdered a white South Carolina man last spring.
Jim Plunkett calls himself "just a simple guy," but his friends, football teammates and officials at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., know better.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, whose request for a special audit of the municipal finances and fiscal methods he inherited from former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio was blocked by the City Council in August, has been holding informal talks with Councilmen in an effort to get them to reverse themselves.

The special commission investigating allegations of corruption among New York policemen, despairing of winning additional funds from an economy-minded City Council, has applied to the Federal Government to finance its graft inquiry for an additional six months.

As a sequel if not an answer to Channel 13's recent controversial program on "Schoolhouse or Jailhouse," the noncommercial outlet offered 90 minutes last night under the title of "Schools Can Work." The value of the program was that it underscored the fact that in a complicated urban school system no one has a single pat answer to all the system's problems. Not principals, Board of Education officials teachers, parents, students or bystanders.

STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) Rock-throwing demonstrators broke 49 windows at Stanford University last night in a protest against the United States bombing of North Vietnam last weekend.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 24 (AP) A young Navy officer who signed a petition to the Pentagon objecting to the war in Vietnam is getting his discharge by order of a Federal judge.
When President-elect Nixon in late 1968 named Charles W. Yost to be chief United States representative at the United Nations he said it was "probably one of the best appointments I have made."

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 24 Mrs. Carlton M. Fishel and Mrs. George J. Gillespie will again serve as co-chairmen of the series of six benefit dances to be held at two country clubs here, to aid St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison. Last year, $23,000 was raised from these parties. The beneficiary provides psychiatric hospital and out-patient care for disturbed adults and children.

"The Japanese Hemingway" and "Japan Renaissance Man" are two of the appellations that were given to Yukio Mishima, who made himself a living legend in a Japan seeking new directions and new idols following defeat in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The House handed organized labor a major legislative defeat today by rejecting the union version of the occupational health and safety bill and adopting instead the bill backed by business interests and the Nixon Administration.
The stock market extended its prime-rate rally yesterday as the Big Three automakers, selected glamour issues and some of the oils joined the list of gainers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) In a surprise move, the nation's railroads announced today that they were reluctantly ready to accept a White House panel's proposal for a contract settlement providing a 37 per cent wage increase over three years.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 24 (UPI) Robert C. Wilke, a racing-car owner and president of Leader Cards, a printing concern, died of a heart attack today in Florida at the age of 62.

Sharply rising costs in the midst of the economic downturn penalized earnings of the Westvaco Corporation for the year ended Oct. 31 by 22 per cent, but sales set a record for the 18th consecutive year, David L. Luke 3d., President, reported yesterday.

The final New York City vote tally, certified by the Board of Elections yesterday, shows that Governor Rockefeller finished only 17,041 votes behind Arthur J. Goldberg, his DemocraticLiberal opponent, in winning re-election Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Treasury bill rates at today's monthly auction of 274 and 365day bills, announced by the government late this afternoon, were dramatically lower compared with rates reported by the government a month ago.

Samuel A. Gay, a former partner in Francis I. duPont Co., has been chosen to replace Charles Klem as vice president in charge of administration and finance at the New York Stock Exchange in the second highlevel staff change at the Big Board to come to light this week.
PARIS, Nov. 24 Alain Geismar, the idol of Maoist students, was sentenced today to two years in prison for illegal political activity.

By THOMAS W. ENNIS Alexander's Inc., the chain of specialty stores, told stockholders at its annual meeting yesterday that earnings declined in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 17, although sales grew 4.6 per cent from a year before.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan declared yesterday that he intended to serve out his term despite reports that he would resign to make way for the selection of State Senator Basil L. Paterson as his successor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 About 700 parents of children in the Head Start program, after day-long demonstrations yesterday, announced the formulation of a board to advise the Federal Government on running the programs.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 24 (AP) Colorado accepted today an invitation to play in the Dec. 12 Liberty Bowl football game here.

Javier Romero moved with the solemnity of one engaged in a ritual. In his own mind it was a tiny commencement, for he had just climbed up a rung in Class 4-4's reading program, becoming the fifth member of a small elite able to read slightly above what is calculated to be their "grade level."
The New York City Ballet's "Scotch Symphony," an unabashedly enchanting work, had its first performance of the season last night at the State Theater.

The consumer price index rose sharply, by 0.6 per cent, in the New York metropolitan area in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. It was the 42d consecutive month that the index had shown an increase.

"I'm an optimist," said Mrs. Cora Walker, looking at halffilled shelves and dozens of people filling their carts with everything from Thanksgiving turkeys to Delicious apples. "I think we can get this market back into shape in two or three weeks."

Thurman Munson, the New York Yankees' fine catcher, yesterday was named the American League's rookie of the year. He was an almost unanimous choice in the voting by the Baseball Writers Association of America. Munson received 23 of the 24 votes cast, with two writers voting from each city in the league. Roy Foster, the Cleveland outfielder, got the other vote.

BARCELONA The extraordinary trail of Picasso's early assertions, disguises, concealments, reappearances and transformations winds through five rooms of Montjuich Palace on a hill overlooking Barcelona.
A new Federal investigation of possible misuse of House Speaker John W. McCormack's office, and of other Government agencies, was disclosed yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) Johnny Unitas said today he had signed a new three-year playing contract with the Baltimore Colts. The pact also guarantees him 10 years of employment in the Colts' front office.

The New York Giants re-assemble at 1 o'clock this afternoon at Yankee Stadium to begin four days of preparation for what has become a painfully simple assignment: win at Washington Sunday or forget about glory in 1970.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 24 Miss Lynn Murray Spalding and George Arvid Peterson will be married Jan. 2 in Palm Beach.

More than 500 persons, including former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, attended a dinner last night at the Plaza Hotel in honor of Miss Helen M. Harris, the executive director of the United Neighborhood Houses, who is retiring at the end of the year.
Bond prices swung down yesterday as traders and investors took profits following nearly a week of the most intense demand for fixed-income securities in recent years.
Frank Ilya Samet, an electronics engineer, died of cancer on Sunday at his home, 230 Riverside Drive. He was 68 years old.
There are so many good young instrumentalists around town that it is not surprising that chamber ensembles keep popping up all the time.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 24 Six years after he picked up a basketball for the first time in a schoolyard and thought. "Hey, I can make a living at this game," Leslie Cason announced today that he had selected Long Beach (Calif.) State as the college of his choice.

Lester J. Rosner, dean of administration at Bernard M. Baruch College, collapsed during a faculty meeting yesterday and died shortly afterward at nearby Columbus Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 60 Gramercy Park South.
PARIS, Nov. 24 A French court cracked down hard today on a Belgian bookmaker and his network of cafe owners operating just across the border in northern France.

Leaders of four of the nation's leading civil-rights and human-relations organizations announced yesterday that they had joined forces for a concerted attack on "racism and polarization" throughout the country.
The United States took a stride forward as a rugbyplaying country last night as a New York all-star team defeated the highly touted Fiji national squad, 12-11, at Randalls Island.
Jim Plunkett, who turned down an opportunity to play professional football this fall, received college football's highest individual honor yesterday, the Heisman Memorial Trophy.
Willis Reed returned to the Knicks' line-up last night and became a 10,000-point career scorer as New York defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 128-119, at Madison Square Garden.

Miss Arlene Nadel, an actress with the New York Shakespeare Festival, and Richard Hammer, an author and a writer on the staff of The Week in Review section of The New York Times, were married here yesterday evening.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had enacted new rules requiring member firms to make periodic counts of securities under their control.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24 United States and Canadian ministers worked toward a policy of freer trade between the two countries at a conference completed here today.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 24 (UPI) A jury of 11 men and a woman today acquitted Jerry William Ray of a charge of aggravated assault in the shooting of a 17-year-old Nazi. Mr. Ray, 35 years old, is the brother of James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator Jacob K. Javits raised the possibility today that he might try to block Senatorelect James L. Buckley of New York from joining the Republican minority when the Senate reorganizes next January.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 24 (UPI) A City judge was critically wounded early this morning by five pistol shots when he answered a knock at his door.

Retail merchandise chains showed a mixed pattern in their third-quarter results, with four out of the nine companies that reported yesterday turning in higher sales and earnings over last year. However, for the nine-month period, only two made more money, reflecting the slowdown in the economy, sluggish consumer purchasing and in part the conflict over fashion styles.

With time running out on Capitol Hill, the airlines seem determined to create an endless wind tunnel to stop Congressional approval of the New York-New Jersey compact empowering the Waterfront Commission to combat cargo thefts at metropolitan airports.

The Alan Wood Steel Company said yesterday it would close its plate mill at Conshohocken, Pa., for at least a week before the end of 1970 unless orders pick up at a rate that "doesn't seem likely."

As may have been expected, the gloomiest reaction to the Ford Motor Company's announced withdrawal from nearly all forms of auto racing comes from the four factory stock-car teams, which now must look elsewhere for support of their expensive efforts.

Negotiators representing the taxicab fleets and their union drivers appear to have agreed on a formula for dividing up the riders' money a formula that will take every penny of the fare increase recommended by Mayor Lindsay and perhaps even a bit more.

The 18th annual art tour of the Radcliffe Club of New York will be held Dec. 5. The tour is the club's chief method of raising funds to provide scholarships to promising students from the New York area.

PAWLING, N.Y., Nov. 24 Thomas J. Costello, who retired as chief supervising engineer of the New York Telephone Company in 1966, died last evening in the St. John's Parish Hall here, where he had been teaching a class in Christian doctrine.
To thaw a frozen turkey, place the bird on a tray in the refrigerator in the original wrap, which has been punctured for two to four days or about 24 hours for each five pounds of turkey.

That approach simply does not work.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 25 Yukio Mishima, one of Japan's most highly regarded novelists, committed suicide in traditional hara-kiri fashion today after leading a raid by a group of right-wingers on a headquarters of Japan's SelfDefense Forces here.

The University of Delaware was named yesterday winner of the Lambert Cup for the third consecutive year. The award is given annually for outstanding performance by a middle-sized Eastern college football team.

The appointment of Jane P. Cahill as secretary of the management review committee of the International Business Machines Corporation was announced yesterday. Miss Cahill had been executive assistant to Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of I.B.M.

After a week of fiscal gloom about budget deficits, service cuts and employe layoffs, New York City's government produced some good economic news yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Cabinet will meet in extraordinary session tomorrow to draft an amnesty for all political prisoners, including Regis Debray, a French Marxist writer sentenced to 30 years imprisonment for participating in guerrilla activities in 1967, it was reported in Government circles today.
A Federal judge fined Transit-Mix Concrete Corporation $25,000 yesterday on a plea of guilty to discharging waste concrete into the East River at the foot of 20th Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Fegan of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane A. Fegan, to Thomas W. Covey of New Britain, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Covey of Wethersfield, Conn. The wedding is planned for January in Westbrook, Conn.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 (AP) Five alleged counterfeiters were arrested today as Secret Service agents confiscated $250,000 in counterfeit money and raided a North Bergen printing plant where they took possession of numerous items allegedly used in an interstate counterfeiting operation.

Mohawk Airlines, Inc., a financially troubled carrier that operates primarily in upstate New York, said yesterday that it probably would not be able to comply with certain key provisions of its loan agreements with its senior creditors. As a result, the company said, "interest payments to the subordinated note holders due by Dec. 10 would be prevented unless the company's senior lenders consent."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 In the late stages of the Texas senatorial campaign, Democrat Lloyd Bentsen sharply attacked Republican George Bush for his support of President Nixon's welfare reform bill. Appearing in Dallas on Oct. 28, just a week before the election, Mr. Nixon himself came to the defense of his proposal the socalled Family Assistance Plan.

The Chemical New York Corporation, the one-bank holding company that owns the Chemical Bank, announced yesterday an increase in its quarterly dividend to 72 cents a share from the 65 cents a share paid in former quarters. It is payable Jan. 1 to stockholders of record Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The head of an antiwar group accused Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today of having distorted for political purposes information on American prisoners in North Vietnam that the group has been providing.
MIAMI, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Air Line Pilots Association today demanded authority for flight crews to carry firearms during commercial flights for use in hijackings.

Nathan Milstein, returning to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, again made clear his position as one of the pre-eminent violinists of the century. Andrew Soltis, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, recently acquired an additional accolade champion of all the Marshall Club champions, past and present. This distinction was awarded Soltis after he won the recent round robin of the "Marshall Champions, 1970."

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Nov. 25 A special State Supreme Court grand jury today cleared Thomas (Tommy the Traveler) Tongyai, the controversial undercover sheriff's deputy, of any wrongdoing in the May fire bombing of the Reserve Officers Training Corps building at Hobart College in nearby Geneva.

TOKYO, Nov. 25 (AP) Miss Barbara Bye of Brooklyn, who has been confined to her hotel room at Tokyo's Haneda Airport for 26 days because immigration authorities sought to prevent her entry, may not be deported summarily, the Tokyo Appellate Court ruled today.
With the arrest of two New Jersey men, the police said yesterday that they had broken up a counterfeit-watch and stolengoods operation here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The Federal Trade Commission challenged today the fairness of advertisements by two major toy manufacturers and the producer of a leading automobile antifreeze.
Michael F. Whalen, president of Breezy Point Cooperative, Inc., a real estate development in Queens, died Tuesday. He was 66 years old and lived in Breezy Point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Administration and Federal Reserve Board officials expressed satisfaction today with compromise language agreed upon by Senate and House conferees late yesterday on probably the major issue in the legislation on one-bank holding companies.

A locomotive fire in the tunnel under Park Avenue at 73d Street halted all service in and out of Grand Central Terminal for an hour in the rush hour last night and delayed many commuters and holiday travelers for two hours or more.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 25 (UPI) Frank Shorter, clad in women's panty hose to keep his legs warm in 20-degree temperature, won the United States Track and Field Federation cross-country championship today. His time of 29 minutes 1.3 seconds set a record for the Penn State course.

The United States Court of Appeals here held yesterday that Walter G. Pietsch, of Rego Park, Queens, could not bring a court challenge to the right of Congress to authorize funds for the war in Vietnam just because he is a taxpayer.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 25 (UPI) Commissioner Theos J. Thompson of the Atomic Energy Commission and two other persons were killed today in the crash of a light plane into Lake Mead.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 25 Some called it frostbite golf, but Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer didn't complain. Nicklaus scored an unusual 30 for nine holes that was accepted as a competitive record during today's pro-amateur event, a preliminary to the $100,000 Heritage golf classic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) A nationwide drive is under way to collect 100 tons of mail for a Christmas display of concern for missing and captive United States servicemen in Southeast Asia.

ROME, Nov. 25 Pope Paul VI, on the eve of the longest journey he has undertaken during his pontificate, stressed again today that he would be traveling as a bishop, pastor, missionary and "fisher of men."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The recent run of bad news on the price front was broken today when the Labor Department reported that wholesale prices declined slightly in November.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union flew to East Berlin today for consultations with Walter Ulbricht, apparently in an attempt to coordinate Soviet and East German policy on Berlin.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25 The third panel of 50 prospective jurors summoned to try the murder and kidnapping case of Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party, was exhausted today in an abbreviated morning session.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 25 A Foreign Ministry official said today that Malcolm W. Browne, a correspondent of The New Yok Times who was barred from Chile last September, would be permitted to enter again.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 25 Miss Dale Page Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah Herman Chapman Jr. of Miami, was married in the First United Methodist Church here tonight to Dennis Louis Webb, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Webb of Plantation.
Bond prices turned in a mixed performance but with an upward bias yesterday as many issues gathered strength in the afternoon for what some believe to be an assault on still higher levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The Nixon Administration, embarrassed by a string of incidents against Soviet offices here and in New York, issued a strong statement today condemning the "senseless, criminal" bombing of the Soviet airline office in New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov 25 (AP) A Government official said today that he would call roundthe-clock negotiations next week in an effort to head off a nationwide railroad strike.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UPI) Bryan Campbell scored twice tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and run an unbeaten string in the National Hockey League to nine games.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Top leaders of Orthodox Judaism in this country denounced the Jewish Defense League today as "destructive" and "irresponsible."

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Industrialists from every West European country today warned the United State that protectionist trade policies if pursued, could lead to demands for restrictive reprisals by European governments.

Shopping for a new job an occupational hazard for football coaches became a reality yesterday for five men in the collegiate ranks.

The stock market's creepand-crawl rally, spurred mainly by the recent decline in interest rates, managed to inch forward yesterday, but the rate of progress slowed perceptibly as investors bundled themselves in blankets of caution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 A Harvard psychiatrist said today that the "brutalizing of the soldier by combat experience, especially in guerrilla warfare," was causing the Vietnam veteran serious problems of readjustment to civilian life.

Perhaps "fear" is the wrong word; a shrillness travels across the Atlantic that sets up...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The idyllic existence being led by soldiers at Fort Carson, Colo., may soon spread to the rest of the Army.

HOUSTON, Nov. 25 Two of the country's top-ranked women experts led the field of 56 pairs into the second semifinal session of the Blue Ribbon Pair event at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight. Dorothy Hayden of New York and Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, Tex., led at the half way mark with a total of 427 points.
The marriage of Miss Brenda Beth Eckstein to Dr. Arthur B. Zimmer took place yesterday at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens. Rabbi Ben Zion Bokser performed the ceremony.

The unemployment rate in New York State and New York City remained constant last month while the unemployment rate in the New York metropolitan area showed a slight decline from its September level, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

U.S.-Spain. President Nixon sent to the Senate for ratification an updated treaty on extradition with Sprin that enlarges the jurisdiction to include aircraft hijackings and narcotic offenses. The treaty signed at Madrid last May 29 terminates and replaces the existing treaty signed between the two countries in 1907.

Pierre Vladimiroff, a leading ballet dancer in Czarist Russia who later became Anna Pavlova's partner in the West and teacher to scores of American dancers at the School of American Ballet here, died yesterday of a stroke at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 77 years old.

The home-made bomb that exploded yesterday in front of the Soviet airline and tourist offices in this city was set off by the same criminal madness that has rocked Federal buildings, police stations and college campuses. The perpetrators of these outrages are linked by the same pathology. Their actions merit the same unmitigated condemnation, whether they are motivated by extremism of the left or of the right.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 President Nixon today dismissed Walter J. Hickel, his Secretary of the Interior.

The Great Southwest Corporation announced yesterday that it had passed up payment of the November quarterly dividend on nonvoting preferred stock and had filed an action against four former executives challenging the validity of certain employment contracts.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 25 (UPI) A group of Representatives urged today that secret Congressional testimony concerning the alleged Mylai 4 massacre be turned over to the Fort Benning military tribunal hearing the courtmartial of First Lieut William L. Calley Jr.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 Willis Reed missed three straight foul shots in periling a slim New York lead in the last minute of play tonight, but made up for his errors. A few moments later he connected on a rebound basket and a free throw that held the Knicks above water at Alexander Memorial Coliseum.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 26 Joe and Charles Greene are a Harness-racing brother act in which Joe, 33 years old and the elder by five years, is the "top banana."
Wall Street speaks with many voices and that's just the trouble, says James P. Thompson, a partner in Paine Webber, Jackson Curtis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 President and Mrs. Nixon have far outdistanced the hospitality record of any preceding Presidential family in their first 18 months in the White House, personally inviting 60,000 guests to inspect and enjoy the Executive Mansion.

The Firenze at Aqueduct today has attracted a field of eight fillies and mares for its 23d running. The 1 1-8-mile handicap will be over early, for the holiday card will start at 11 A.M. with the main event going off about 2 o'clock.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 25 Simon Cohen, a clothing manufacturer and philanthropist, died today in Mid-Island Hospital, of which he was executive director. He was 63 years old and lived at 174 Broadway in Lawrence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) Emotions in Congress were mixed today on the ouster by President Nixon of Walter J. Hickel as Secretary of the Interior.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 25 (AP) The United States command said today that bombing by B25's and fighter-bombers continued today against North Vietnamese supply routes in Laos and Cambodia and that reconnaissance operations were conducted over North Vietnam.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 From reveille to taps today, the members of the Navy football team wore the jerseys worn by last year's team in its game against Army. That was meant to serve as a reminder of the 27-0 defeat suffered by the 1969 team.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it was increasing prices for liquid and dry caustic soda, a workhorse chemical used widely by the chemical, pulp and ...
TEL AVIV, Nov. 25 His Beatitude Alberto Gori, Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, died today at the Patriarchate. He was 81 years old.
ISFAHAN, Iran Some 350 years ago, Russian craftsmen were imported from the border area to help build the mosques, domes and bridges that still make Isfahan the most splendid city in Iran.

HOUSTON, Nov. 25 Mr. and Mrs. August W. Look Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Look's daughter, Miss Sheryl Zoe Bolton, to Robert Livingston Johnson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

Two Bronx men were arraigned on attempted murder and assault charges in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday in a case that involved the shooting of an offduty Queens patrolman and an employe of the Provost Auto Salvage company at 3640 Provost Avenue last Sept. 30.

A former assistant district attorney, Gino E. Gallina, denied on the witness stand yesterday that he had coerced key witnesses to testify falsely against William A. Maynard, who was charged with the murder of a marine in Greenwich Village in 1967.

DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 25 (Agence France-Presse) Sekou Toure, the Marxist-oriented President of neighboring Guinea, appealed by radio today to "friendly countries outside Africa" to send as much aid as possible at once to help combat a new series of "enemy incursions."
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 25 (UPI) An experimental rocket craft that may be developed into a space shuttle made its first powered flight today over the desert.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 Beating the Rangers to the puck and hitting them harder and more often, the Philadelphia Flyers ended their streak of ties with the New Yorkers tonight by scoring a 3-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Senator George S. McGovern said today that the Nixon Administration's pledge to provide subsidized lunches to all needy schoolchildren by Thanksgiving "has turned out to be about 3 per cent food and 97 per cent empty promise."

If you are one of A.T. T.'s three million shareholders, you must have received notification not long ago that you are eligible to take part in a dividend reinvestment program being conducted for the giant phone company through the First National City Bank of New York.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 25 (UPI) A hearing examiner ruled today that the Federal Aviation Administration had acted correctly in lifting the air taxi license of the company that provided the crew for a Wichita State University charter plane that crashed Oct. 2.
Sales of new cars in the United States fell 46.7 per cent in the Nov. 11-20 period to 150,038 units from 281,145 in the year-earlier period.

As he worked with union and taxi industry negotiators yesterday to bring their contract dispute to a peaceful conclusion, Vincent Daniel McDonnell was the same easy-going, witty and relaxed mediator that he has been throughout the difficult negotiations.
Producers and performers met yesterday in an effort to resolve the 10-day-old Off Broadway theater strike of actors and managers but pessimism dominated the scene despite the resumption of talks.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 25 William D. Benjes, a major figure in the shoe industry, died yesterday in Goddard Hospital, Boston. He was 62 years old and lived here at 91 Strawberry Avenue.
CHAR JABBAR, Pakistan, Nov. 25 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan made his first visit to the cyclone-devastated area of East Pakistan today.

Three unconscious children were rescued from a burning building in Harlem last night by a fireman who carried them to the roof of an adjoining building and revived them by mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 25 ?Two lawyers representing creditors of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. questioned today the propriety of listing a value for certain trusts in his personal financial statements.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 15 A pale green telephone is the Calcutta police force's latest weapon against the Maoist Naxalites, whose latest terror tactic is a cold-blooded campaign against policemen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The planners of the commando raid on a North Vietnamese prison camp last weekend had to take into account the position of the moon and Soviet satellites and to gather men from all over the world.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP) State Prosecutor Robert L. Balyeat says a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry has discredited a report from a Justice Department summary that Ohio National Guardsmen at Kent State University last May fabricated a story that their lives were in danger.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP) Zora G. Clevenger, a longtime football coach and athletic director, died here yesterday.
New York City Democrats yesterday disclaimed any intention to unseat John J. Burns as state chairman or to take over the party organization in the state.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) In a switch from last year, President Nixon plans to spend the Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday periods at the White House.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that United States war planes killed at least 49 North Vietnamese civilians including 28 in one restaurant and six in a hospital during the air raids last Saturday.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 25, (Reuters) Cliff Richey tonight clinched one of the richest purses in tennis, the $25,000 first prize in the International Lawn Tennis Federation's Grand Prix series.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (Reuters) The Justice Department sued today to prevent United Banks of Colorado, Inc., the largest banking organization in that state, from acquiring the Colorado Springs National Bank. The acquisition was approved by the Federal Reserve Board on Oct. 29.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The merger of two major pharmaceutical companies one of them a client of the former law firm of President Nixon and Attorney General John N. Mitchell was consummated earlier this month over the objection of the Justice Department's antitrust chief.

A dispute over whether L. Joseph Overton is or is not chairman of the District 5 Local School Board developed in Harlem yesterday after Mr. Overton apparently resigned, then was discharged and then asserted that he was still chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The Social Security Administration reported today that Medicare costs in the last fiscal year were $371-million below what had been forecast.
PARIS, Nov. 25 Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, Dean of the Sacred College, told a French television interviewer tonight that Pope Paul was visibly ill.

CARMEL, Calif., Nov. 25 Mrs. Nancy Schallert Lofton, widow of Richard Morrison Lofton, was married here this morning to Dwight W. Morrow Jr., an associate professor at the Monterey Institute of Foreign Studies.
Prices on the London Stocks Exchange closed lower yesterday after dull trading.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Court of Appeals unanimously agreed today that the Playboy liquor-scandal trial conviction of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman, had not been tainted by electronic eavesdropping.
Wild turkeys and deer roam John Elliott's backyard in Camp Wood, Tex., not far from the Mexican border.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The morning before he killed himself, Yukio Mishima reportedly handed to his publishers in Tokyo the final chapter of the fourth volume of a tetrology titled "The Sea of Fertility." Perhaps the title helps explain why this 45-year-old writer, who enjoyed fame, wealth and critical acclaim, took his own life.

Trading in soybeans, soybean oil and meal and grain futures was delayed for 30 minutes yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The delay was caused by the fact that the volume of business in the previous session had created a huge bookkeeping problem that had not been resolved at the time of yesterday's opening.

State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Brust criticized the city administration yesterday for assertedly failing to provide adequate hospital facilities for defendants who, the Legal Aid Society complained, are being unlawfully confined in prison while awaiting court-ordered psychiatric examinations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Senate Finance Committee rejected today a proposed 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits as too costly but voted to allow retired people to earn more without losing benefits.

Smith, Barney Co., Inc., is to head an international underwriting syndicate. The issue will come due in 1985 and will he noncallable before 1980.
Operations of the Rohr Corporation in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31, resulted in higher sales but lower earnings, the diversified transportationsystems company reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (UPI) A Texas millionaire, John W. Mecom, saying his business debts are piling up faster than he can pay them off, has asked the Federal courts to reorganize his vast oil and real estate holdings to prevent his creditors from foreclosing.
NORTH CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 26 Benjamin O. Davis Sr., the first Negro to be named a general in the United States armed forces, died today at Great Lakes Naval Hospital here. He was 93 years old.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed sharply lower yesterday in light trading.

SERONERA, Tanzania, Nov. 12 A group of experienced African game and national park wardens recently listened with surprise as a young zoologist described the mating habits of the male impala antelope.

Federal and local police officials increased security at the Soviet Union's diplomatic and commercial buildings here yesterday as an investigation continued into the explosion early Wednesday morning of a pipe bomb in the doorway of the Soviet airline and tourist office at 45 East 49th Street.

A quotation book, arranged by idea and performing for wit and wisdom the same service that "Roget's Thesaurus" performs with words and phrases, has just been compiled by a comely brunette library-school graduate with a passion for the sayings of the famous and the not-so-celebrated. She is Mrs. Rhoda Thomas Tripp, and the book is "The International Thesaurus of Quotations."

Westfield and Thomas Jefferson of Elizabeth, New Jersey's two best high school football teams, completed perfect seasons yesterday by recording their ninth victories. Westfield, rated No. 1, walloped Plainfield, 49-6, and Jefferson spotted Cranford a touchdown lead before rolling to a 54-7-triumph.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 26 Herve Filion didn't miscalculate recently when he flatly declared that he would terminate his 1970 driving activities once his season's total of win nets reached 444. "A nice, square number," the FrenchCanadian reinsman called it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) Government experts will submit next week a report that may uphold some of the charges that Ralph Nader has raised against General Motors in their dispute over the safety of 600,000 Corvairs, Transportation Department sources said today.

The New York Philharmonic passed another milestone in its history on Wednesday night when Dean Dixon became the first black conductor to lead the orchestra in a regular subscription concert. Mr. Dixon first appeared with the Philharmonic as a guest at Lewisohn Stadium in 1942 and returned this past summer for a week of Philharmonic concerts in New York parks.

MANCHESTER, Conn., Nov. 26 John Vitale, a North Branford school teacher and former University of Connecticut runner, captured the annual 34th Manchester five-mile road race today before an estimated 12,000 onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 Tenants of public housing are rebelling in several cities across the country against what they consider to be paternalistic, arbitrary policies of management, ranging from unfair eviction to imposition of ugly decorating schemes.

The Police Department, increasingly worried about the failure of patrolmen to protect themselves from attack, has prepared a film of the tactics of defense, beginning with a warning by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy about the dangers of the street.
They came from all over the Eastern Seaboard to enter their chromed, glazed and custombuilt cars and motorcycles in the ninth annual National Rod and Custom Car Show at the Coliseum yesterday.

MANILA, Friday, Nov. 27 35-year-old Bolivian who identified himself as a surrealist painter and a foe of hypocrisy and superstition hurled himself, brandishing a knife, toward Pope Paul VI at Manila Airport this morning. The Pope was unhurt and apparently untouched.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) Delegates to the second phase of the Black Panther party's Revolutionary People's Constitutional Convention began arriving today while a dispute over a site for the twoday meeting remained unresolved.

Persistence finally paid off $33,900 worth for the Christiana Stable's Obeah yesterday at Aqueduct. She earned that amount as she won the $56,600 Firenze Handicap by a head, with Taken Aback second and Lunation third among the eight that competed in the 1 1/8-mile test for fillies and mares.
Far Rockaway completed its football season undefeated and untied yesterday by outscoring Brooklyn Tech, 28-6, at Far Rockaway Field. It was the eighth victory for the Sea Horses.

CARSON CTTY, Nev., Nov. 26 Gov.-elect Donal N. O'Callaghan moved quickly this week to fake control of the administration of this state's licensed gambling system by appointing his own chairman of the State Gaming Control Board.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) The first officer of a doomed Air Canada jetliner apologized three times to the pilot, apparently for deploying the aircraft's "spoiler" landing system prematurely. Minutes later last July 5, the plane smashed into a farm field, killing all 109 persons aboard.
KUALA LUMPUR; Malaysia, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Malaysian jets today were reported to have attacked suspected guerrilla sites in Sarawak for the second successive day.
Edward Patrick Lenahan will be doing the Time-step, gliding smoothly on Tuesday from the post of advertising sales director of Fortune to that of general manager of Life.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 26 Defense Minister Moshe Dayan suggested tonight that Israel and Egypt reach a new and detailed cease-fire agreement before resuming peace talks so that negotiations could proceed without the constant threat of attack.
DENVER, Nov. 26 (AP) Bill Forington lofted his homemade flying machine six inches off the ground on Feb. 25, 1959.

A taxi driver was shot in the stomach after being robbed in Harlem last night. The driver, Robert Goodwin, 45 years old, of 179 Marcey Avenue, the Bronx, was reported in fair condition at Harlem Hospital.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 26 Norwegians are hopeful that something may at last be done about the acid rain that pours down on them because of sulphur emissions from the burning of oil abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov.26 The combined pressures of continued inflation and a declining tax base are forcing many of the nation's major cities to lay off workers, trim services and adopt other belt-tightening measures.
Miss Susan Matilda Schell of Arlington, Va., was married here yesterday afternoon to Capt. John Richard Symons, U.S.A.F., also of Arlington.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 Miss Fredelle Paula Gross of Houston, a graduate student at the Washington University School of Social Work, and Dr. John Charles Robinson of New York, a surgical interne at The Jewish Hospital here, were married this morning on the grounds behind Temple Emanuel by Rabbi Elihu T. Rosenbloom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 Simple changes in some American living and eating habits can bring a measure of immediate relief from much of the pollution and depletion that threaten the United States, according to a World Wildlife Fund manual.

William Bourne, a pianist who was born in Santa Fe and has studied at the Curtis Institute and here, gave a debut recital at the New York Cultural Center on Wednesday evening. In his mid-twenties, the young artist showed a sensitive musical approach to different compositional styles.
A 5-year-old boy was critically wounded Wednesday night by two bullets fired through the wooden door of his Bronx apartment, the police reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is making ambitious plans for its opening weeks next September, but two of its long-range projects could have a deep impact on the nation.
WASHINGTON The avalanche of communication inventions of the last two decades is making public diplomacy an essential element in the successful formulation of foreign policy.
HONG KONG, Nov. 26 Communist China has granted Rumania a long-term, interestfree loan, the first of its kind ever provided by Peking to a member of the Soviet-dominated Warsaw Pact.

The J.J. Newberry Company, after two abortive attempts to enter the discount field by acquisitions, has opened its first discount store in a proposed chain for small towns and cities to be started by the company.

When Joe Kapp was with the Minnesota Vikings last year, the roughneck quarterback had a pet nickname for his workhorse running back, Dave Osborn. The happy-golucky Kapp he's neither happy nor lucky with undermanned Boston this season invariably referred to Osborn as "Hard Yard." The name would pop up in the huddle during pressure situations.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 26 Having no other diversions at hand for a frosty Thanksgiving Day, C.W. Post College (5,500 undergraduates) and Hofstra College (6,200) played a football game here today for what is facetiously called the Route 25-A championship of Long Island.

Wayne Valley, Hawthorne and Butler completed unbeaten football seasons yesterday.

But both sides of this old Wagnerian dispute could agree on at least one point about Wednesday night's third performance of the Metropolitan Opera's new production: Christa Ludwig's portrayal of Kundry ranks as one of the season's artistic peaks.

Central Islip and Sayville, by virtue of victories yesterday, gained a deadlock for second place in their respective leagues. The Musketeers defeated a stubborn East Islip squad, 12-6, while Sayville ran up a three-touchdown lead in the first period and coasted to a 25-12 triumph over Bayport.

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 26 John Wesley Smith, former head of the switching equipment department at Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, died Monday in Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 3 Dellwood Drive. He retired in 1962.

BANGUI, Central African Re public. Nov. 26 (AP) Until last week, 17-year-old Martine sold cigarettes on the streets of Saigon in South Vietnam and lived in a shack built with flattened beer cans. Today, she is the daughter of a President and riding in a limousine.

BEIRUT, Lebanon Leila Khaled, who became famous as a hijacker for the Paletine liberation movement, still has the ring fashioned of a bullet, but the piece of jewelry that's attracting attention to her this week is a plain silver band an engagement ring.

Twenty-one young women were formally presented to Terence Cardinal Cooke last night at the 21st Gotham Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. The event is a yearly benefit for the New York Foundling Hospital.
The first American serviceman to be expelled from Sweden has been returned to the United States and been apprehended by military policemen waiting for him at Kennedy Airport.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 26 (AP) The Pro Football Hall of Fame will place the jersey of George Blanda, the Oakland Raiders' 43-year-old quarterback who has been pacing the team to some spectacular victories this season, on display here tomorrow.

A new lightweight portable camera enabling a layman or embryonic producer to take up to 12,000 still pictures in full color or make a half-hour moving picture at one loading has been patented by Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System Laboratories, and his associate, William E. Glenn Jr., of Stamford, Conn. They have assigned the patent to C.B.S.

Washington sources said yesterday that the Nixon Administration was finding it difficult to replace Representative Rogers C.B. Morton of Maryland as chairman of the Republican National Committee, partly because at least some potential candidates considered the job to offer no real power.

St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square turned its annual interfaith service of thanksgiving yesterday into a special tribute to a Roman Catholic priest who calls himself a "lobbyist and ombudsman" for the poor.

WEST GLACIER, Mont., Nov. 26 In this season, when almost everyone is concerned with the turkey, the bird that Benjamin Franklin proposed as the national symbol, in Glacier National Park there is an annual flocking of the bird that did become the national emblem-the bald eagle.

A grand jury investigation into the death of a 14-year-old resident of the Spofford Juvenile Center and the dismissal of the center's top administrators were demanded by City Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday, one day after the boy's death.
About one-fifth of installed capacity of American business is more than 20 years old, according ho a survey released yesterday by the department of economics of the McGrawHill Publications Company.
SEATTLE, Nov. 26 (AP) Helene E. Madison, winner of three gold medals as a swimmer in the 1932 Olympic Games, died here last night. She was 56 years old, and had suffered from cancer and diabetes.

PARIS, Nov. 26 North Vietnam continued to insist today that American bombers ranged far north of the 19th Parallel last Saturday and Sunday, and a spokesman here said that 49 civilians had died in the raids and 40 had been wounded. The Hanoi radio gave the same figures in a broadcast earlier today.

Environmental problems will be the subject of a one-week seminar that will start Monday at the American Press Institute at Columbia University.
River Dell Regional, able to win only once in nine games last year, completed an unbeaten season yesterday with a 45-8 victory over Demarest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 Many Democrats believe that the setback suffered by organized labor on the occupational health and safety bill can be attributed to labor's misjudgment of the effectiveness of its lobbying campaign.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) The police broke into a Black Panther group's headquarters in a Negro housing project today and arrested six persons after a brief gunfight.

Fairfield Prep upset Stamford, 13-7, before 8,500 fans yesterday in the 26th annual contest between the Connecticut rivals in Stamford's Boyle Stadium.
