For its second annual "Celebration of the Arts for Children," the City Center is holding a "Moon Rock Festival." Two programs alternate Saturday and Sunday, this, and next, weekend a Rock musical, "Moon Walk" (which I have seen), and a three-part show consisting of two movies and Tom Glazer singing space songs (which I have not seen).

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 26 (UPI) Joe Reed, taking advantage of a pass-interference call, ran a yard for a touchdown midway in the final period today to give underdog Mississippi State a 19-14 victory over Mississippi.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 26 The Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith took another major step today toward total racial segregation.

Governor Rockefeller will soon fill an important judicial post here that was given up by a judge after he had concluded that he would be unable to reform the court's procedures,which have allegedly been a source of vast political patronage.

Mrs. Nancy Waiters Hutchings of Southampton, Bermuda, was married yesterday to Richard Hewlett Valentine of New York. The Rev. Dr. George Buchanan performed the ceremony in Christ Presbyterian Church in Warwick, Bermuda.

Two shows currently in town, one which I admire and one which I don't, seem to cast a special light on the nature of theater. One of them is "Orlando Furioso," which this weekend finishes an engagement in a bubble in Bryant Park, and the other is the triumphant Jack MacGowran and his uncanny embodiment of Samuel Beckett at Joseph Papp's Public Theater on Lafayette Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 A former chairman of the Tariff Commission has concluded that if the pending trade bill becomes law "within a year, there would be descending upon the President's desk a steady, and steadily growing, number of 'escape clause' recommendations (from the Tariff Commission) calling for restriction of imports through tariff and quota relief."

The City Council, which is awaiting final details of the money package that is being worked out to avert a taxicab strike, will not take up the creation of a taxicab commission while considering a fare rise, City Hall souces said yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (UPI) Thanksgiving Day was no holiday for negotiators of the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers who planned meetings throughout the holiday weekend in an attempt to come up with a new contract agreement before a Dec. 7 strike deadline.
AUGSBURG, West Germany Signs hanging on all the outside walls of the big M.A.N. diesel engine factory here announce vacancies for skilled, semiskilled and unskilled laborers at "good pay."

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP) Henry J. Tomaszewski Sr., the police chief of Linden and a member of the force for 39 years, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Adm. Willard J. Smith, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, has called for a detailed report on the incident in which a Lithuanian sailor attempted to flee from a Soviet fishing boat off Martha's Vineyard.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 29 The Chilean Government has dropped an investigation into the sudden withdrawal of a United States Air Force scientific observation station on Chile's Easter Island and has publicly accepted diplomatic explanations made here "by the United States in the interest of maintaining good relations.

Alan Daniels, a business consultant and former president of the Baby World Corporation, a top manufacturer here, died Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 300 Central Park West.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 The St. Louis Cardinals, out to convince themselves and others of their championship potential, rallied to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 23-14, today.
Maybe Notre Dams should skip the 10th game on its regular-season football schedule, stopping at nine games or adding an 11th game as other major colleges have done to solve fiscal problems.

Universally available day care for American children is inevitable, experts in the field say. They note that women, who make up 38 per cent of the work force, want and need it, and that many politicians back it.
NIAMEY, Niger, Nov. 20 Ten years after its conception, the Peace Corps is charting a new course and radically changing some basic tenets.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 29 Miss Beverly Anne Fanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Fanger, was married at Temple Beth-El here today to Herbert Stanley Chase Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi William Braude performed the ceremony.
DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 29 (Agence France-Presse) President Toure called on Africa today to switch from the defensive to the offensive in all African regions under foreign domination.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks used a four-goal first-period burst to defeat the Los Angeles Kings 5-3, tonight, stretching their National Hockey League West Division lead to 4 points over idle St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) The number of job openings in manufacturing industries edged down again this fall, reflecting a continued lag in business activity, the Labor Department reported today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) W. Braddock Hickman, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, died last night of a heart attack at his home. He was 59 years old.

Michael F. O'Connor, vice president and treasurer of the Pierre Hotel from 1932 to 1942, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital, after a long illness. He lived at 144-80 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
The city's Environmental Protection Administration may seek a ban on places of business putting out garbage more than one hour before the Sanitation Department is scheduled to pick it up.
More than 60 per cent of New York City's out-of-wedlock births are taking place among women on welfare rolls, according to a new study of data from the city's Health and Social Services Departments.

The forcible removal of a defecting Soviet sailor from a United States Coast Guard cutter with the cooperation of its American officers is surely one of the most disgraceful incidents ever to occur on a ship flying the American flag. It flouts the American tradition of granting political asylum and it may constitute a violation of the Geneva convention on refugees.
Fifty-nine contestants took part yesterday in the 60th annual Coney Island 10-mile boardwalk walking race. Among them was Stella Palamarchuck, the first female to compete.
LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz., Nov. 29 (AP) Bill Sirois of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the $64,500 world outboard championship race in record time today.
ATHENS, Nov. 29 Some 1,240 electors designated by the military-backed regime voted today to select 92 candidates for seats on a consultative commission sometimes described as a "mini-parliament."
For many Americans, 1970 has been a loss year. Perhaps you are in the army of professionals without jobs. The year 1970 brought an extraordinary phenomenon the well-to-do unemployed.

WARSAW, Nov. 29 A longstanding church-state dispute in Poland over Roman Catholic administration of dioceses in the "Western Territories," lands taken from Germany after World War II, appears to be nearing solution.

BECKDORF, West Germany, Nov. 20 Hermann Vollmers, a former Hitler Youth leader whom the British interned for a year and a half, has emerged as a pacesetter in rural reform on principles diametrically opposed to the Nazis' "blood and soil" glorification of farming.
MANILA, Nov. 29?As Pope Paul left here on the flight to Samoa, his "Message to Asia" was rebroadcast from here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 The Los Angeles Rams upset the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 30-13, today and deadlocked the Western Division of the National Football Conference with three weeks to go.

John Wayne, who has proudly proclaimed his patriotic fervor for his country, put together last night one of television's most expensive TV specials a sorry cavalcade of American history that mixed TV celebrities in disconcerting incidents of miscasting, inspirational flag-waving and sermonizing, perfunctory attempts at video humor and repulsively intrusive commercials.

LONDON, Nov. 29 Art dealers, members of Parliament and museum officials began a campaign this weekend to save for Britain the Velazquez portrait that was sold Friday for a world record price of $5,544,000.

MANILA, Nov. 29 Pope Paul VI, at the end of his three-day visit to Manila, drove into the city's worst slum today and visited Carlos and Elena Navarro and their eight children in their two-room shack.
Ilya Motyleff, a stage director who had worked with Stanislavsky in Moscow and Reinhardt in Berlin, died late Saturday evening in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 76 years old.

As Maria Callas sees it, there is nothing worse in the whole world than hypocrisy. "I must be truthful," is one of her favorite phrases, and so it comes as no surprise, then, to hear the tempestuous diva tell why she is wearing a gray wool mididress with black leather boots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Senator J.W. Fulbright charged today that the Defense Department had displaced the State Department as the primary formulator of American foreign policy, particularly, in Southeast Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 The Soviet Union, in an unexpected move, voted in favor of a resolution today calling on all nuclear-armed nations to halt the nucleararms race immediately and to cease all testing as well as deployment of nuclear weapons.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 Mrs. Mollie Netcher Bostwick plans to be married next month to Paul C. Wilmot Jr., an account executive with Norman, Craig Kummel in New York.
LISBON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The West German Ambassador, Dr. Hans Schmidt-Horix, 61 years old, and his wife, Barbara, 56, committed suicide early Friday,

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) A spokesman for Senator Edward M. Kennedy today denied as preposterous a report in a British weekly newspaper that the Senator went to nightclubs with an Italian princess the night before he attended the memorial service for de Gaulle.

Mayor Lindsay went to the Washington Heights District Health Center on West 168th Street yesterday afternoon to officially open one of the first of the city's 20 new neighborhood-based methadone maintenance centers for heroin addicts. He described the treatment program as "a breakthrough in the largescale attack on the plague of narcotics."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 (Reuters) The Vietcong said today that they would cease fighting for three days both at Christmas and New Year and for four days at Tet, the lunar new year.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 Following, in translation from the Russian, is the text of a letter from the author Aleksandr I, Solzhenitsyn to the Swedish Academy explaining his decision against going to Stockholm to accept the 1970 Nobel Prize:
Mrs. Evelyn Schiffer Lehman, who was a well-known society figure, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 78 years old and lived at 32 East 64th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 People not lucky enough to have Pentagon folks living in their neighborhoods were probably puzzled last week when Secretary Laird called the bombing of North Vietnam a protective reaction. Didn't our planes bomb the bejeebers out of North Vietnam? they probably asked. Isn't bombing the bejeebers out of somebody a bombing?

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) A 3-point play by Hal Greer with 55 seconds remaining and a basket by Jim Washington enabled the Philadelphia 76ers to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 104-98, in the finale of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 President Nixon called today for a "very full and immediate investigation" of the Coast Guard's refusal to grant political sanctuary to the Lithuanian sailor who tried to flee last week from a Soviet fishing boat.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 30 The annual Yuletide Ball of Nassau Hospital will be held on Saturday in the Garden City Hotel. Mrs. Harlan L. Strader is general chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) The Nixon Administration filed today its first school desegregation suit in the South since the beginning of the current school year.

COPENHAGEN, Nov. 30 Danish authorities have ruled out another currency devaluation to resolve what has been called the "intractable" balance-of-payments deficit and are trying to prepare the nation for the alternative what could be a steep rise in unemployment.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 Joseph C. Swidler, the chairman of the State Public Service Commission, said today that the state's seven major utility companies had committed themselves to working together "to develop a long-range plan for an integrated statewide power system."

PLANDOME, L.I., Nov. 30 Albert C. Nolte, a patent engineer and lawyer, died today in Manhasset Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 38 Willets Lane here and at 475 Park Avenue in New York.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) The largest space telescope ever launched failed to reach orbit tonight when a protective nose cone did not separate from the booster rocket. The failure ruined a $98.5-million project that could have unlocked many secrets of the universe.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 30 (UPI) A Trans World Airlines 707 jet cargo carrier taking off on a flight to Europe crashed early this morning into an Israeli Air Force propellerdriven Stratocruiser being towed on the runway of Lydda Airport. Both planes were destroyed by explosions and fire.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Miami Dolphins blended the power of Larry Csonka, the speed of Eugene (Mercury) Morris and the timely passing of Rob Griese to heat the Atlanta Falcons, 20-7, tonight in the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 High Administration officials privately acknowledge that the United States is establishing and reinforcing a new rationale for American air strikes against North Vietnam.

The National Broadcasting Company Television network announced yesterday that it was altering the prime-time schedules of five of its seven weekly broadcasting nights, beginning in January. Two of its current programs will be canceled and three others will be shifted to different time slots.

Two East Germans, a poet and a graphic artist, have joined in an unusual publishing venture to honor Jewish victims of Nazi extermination with a richly illustrated de luxe edition of German translations of Yiddish poetry.
Ronald D. Laing, the Scottish psychoanalyst famous for suggesting that insanity may be a sane reaction to an insane world, has now taken refuge in poetry and sketch to get his message across.
The Carrier Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to the annual report issued yesterday by the leading diversified air conditioning producer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) The Senate approved today a compromise bill intended to provide increased protection for investors in the $50-billion mutual fund industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 The United States, Britain and France have warned the Soviet Union that East German harassment on Berlin's vital access routes endangered the success of the current four-power talks aimed at improving the situation in and around this isolated city, it was disclosed today.
ROME, Nov. 30 Five years ago, shortly after he introduced the divorce bill that has just become law in Italy, Loris Fortuna was questioned by his 10-year-old son.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Federal Reserve Board an nounced today the second reduction in the discount rate in three weeks, from 5 to 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 A Tennessee Congressman, who visited the Rev. Daniel Berrigan and the Rev. Phillip F. Berrigan three times in prison after reading their antiwar writing, demanded today that J. Edgar Hoover prove or retract his charges that they are part of a kidnapping and sabotage plot.
Dr. Maurice E. Wolf, a professor of medicine in France until World War II, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 50 Central Park West.

A Federal judge here ruled yesterday that when the United States Supreme Court ordered the city's Criminal Court to give jury trials last June 22, its order should have benefited defendants who had been convicted without a jury in the two years before that.
The Soviet Union used a name last week for a previously unidentified city in the steppes of Kazakhstan from which the Russians launch their manned flights into space.

HOUSTON, Nov. 30 The Reisinger knockout team championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals at the Rice Hotel, ended in a technical tie early today between the world champion Dallas Aces and a group led by Peter Pender of Sausalito, Calif.
Edgar T. Higgins has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Corporation. Mr. Higgins, who currently is vice chairman, succeeds DeWitt J. Paul who will retire December 30.

"Everything of value in the black community we must control," the bearded, Africangarbed Imamu Amiri Baraka shouted into the microphone.
A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night as a suspect in the holdup murders of four persons in an East Village bar last week.

Four years of study of the landlocked salmon, lake trout and brook trout population of Maine's famous Moosehead Lake will result in yearly stockings of salmon and a recommendation that the present legal length limit for that species in the lake be dropped to 12 inches.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 Gov. William T. Cahill told Mayor Kenneth B. Gibson of Newark today that there were not enough votes in the Legislature to approve a 2 per cent city payroll tax to be collected from employes.

The "extreme unavailability" of eligible blacks and Puerto Ricans not discriminatory practices by the city school system is the reason why there are relative few minoritygroup members serving as school supervisors here, a member of the Board of Examiners declared last night.
The city's Health Commissioner has warned wholesalers and retailers to remove some 24,000 Italian-made women's and children's chenille berets from sale because of the hats' flammability.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Congress, the Nixon Administration and Secretary of Transportation John Volpe have made a small, shaky start on redeeming intercity rail passenger service from the limbo into which American railroads and national policy have cast it. The designation of a basic national passenger network, to be operated by a single corporation, offers hope for the future but at the same time it suggests the immense problems remaining.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, Dec. I (UPI) A bomb rocked the United States Embassy this morning, ripping through five rooms and knocking out the front section of the white three-story structure.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation cut the basic price of American primary copper late yesterday for the second time in less than six weeks. The latest move was a reduction to 53 cents a pound from 56 cents.
The lengthy negotiations in the taxi industry appeared yesterday to be heading toward an agreement or a breakdown later this week.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced a series of stringent disciplinary actions yesterday against Kleiner, Bell Co. and two of its principal officers.
NIAMEY, Niger, Nov. 20 On a map of West Africa, the dry, landlocked Republic of Niger looks like a natural ally and trading partner for Nigeria, her more prosperous neighbor to the south.
The London stock market was steady yesterday with a firm undertone in very quiet trading. Selective small buying of leading issues helped stabilize the market.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 30 (Reuters) An American official arrived here today to discuss projected aid of $100million for survivors of the tidal wave and cyclone that struck East Pakistan on Nov. 12. The official toll has been put at 175,000, but some estimates are twice as high.

The partial takeover of the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem by the Young Lords was criticized by a state judge yesterday as interfering with the "most precious constitutional rights" of the parishioners.
OXFORD, England, Nov. 30 (AP) Britain's most prominent black power leader quit the movement today, saying his new aim was friendship between black and white.

A Federal judge yesterday barred the New York County District Attorney from asking jail inmates to waive their right to legal counsel in an inquiry of recent riots unless they are "fully advised of [their] constitutional rights."

SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 30 Miss Elaine Susan Klurfeld, whose father, Herman Klurfeld, is a writer, plans to be married in June to Jeffrey Lee Berkowitz, whose father, Paul Berkowitz of Miami Beach, is president of the Old Mr. Boston Corporation, liquor distillers.

With representatives of Florida tomato farmers at their elbows, radar operators have been able to guide cloud-seeding planes to increase rainfall sevenfold on selected areas without drenching the tomato crop.

For much too long the theory has been allowed to go unchallenged in football circles that the New York Jets are nothing without Joe Namath. It becomes increasingly apparent, however, that the New York Jets are still a tremendous football team even without their highly publicized superstar, sidelined for the rest of the year with his wristbone broken but his ego undamaged.

As incredible as it may seem, the New York Jets have a mathematical opportunity to qualify for the National Football League playoffs as the second-place team with the best record in the American Conference, but it will require a combination of several circumstances.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has told the Swedish Academy that he changed his mind about going to Stockholm to receive the 1970 Nobel Prize because he assumed, from the suppression of his books, that he would not be permitted to return.

PARIS, Nov. 30 North Vietnam indicted tonight that it might not oppose international supervision of elections in South Vietnam if they were held under a coalition government a government that the Communists are trying to promote in place of the present one in Saigon.

The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx reported yesterday that the New York State Department of Education has given its approval for the garden to grant state-recognized certificates to its horticulture students.
Acting in concert, the Big Board, the Amex and the S.E.C. appear to have halted permanently the stock ticker of Burt S. Kleiner, flamboyant Beverly Hills purveyor of securities to movie stars.

A liberalization of the rules governing track and field in the United States will be sought by a group of top athletes at the annual national convention of the Amateur Athletic Union starting today in San Francisco.

Heavy profit taking sent soybean futures prices down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a wild spree of selling after prices had risen slightly at the opening of trading. The same was true of corn and wheat futures prices.
The trial of Joseph Colombo Jr. and two others accused of conspiring to melt silver coins began in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday after a fourth co-defendant pleaded guilty to the charge.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 The Tate-LaBianca murder trial limped along today, even though one defense attorney was missing, presumably trapped by flooding at a mountain spa where he had spent the weekend.

Doctors conducting research into possible cures for sickle cell anemia expressed "guarded optimism" yesterday in reaction to the announcement that a treatment for the incurable, hereditary blood disease had been found.
Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh yesterday permitted the jury at the conspiracy trial of 13 Black Panthers to hear a tape recording that he had previously banned.

Underwriters continued to bid aggressively for new offerings of long-term bonds yesterday, indicating a belief that prices were headed for another upswing. However, trading in outstanding issues displayed little trend.

Intelligence. The President appointed former Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas to his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board. The board is composed of 10 members and is headed by Adm. George W. Anderson jr., retired, former Chief of Naval Operations.

Ron Johnson, whose slightly sprained left ankle kept him out most of the second half in Sunday's 27-24 victory at Washington, "should be 100 per cent by this Sunday," the Giants said yesterday.
DALLAS, Nov. 30 Lance Rentzel, the Dallas Cowboys' wide receiver, today was charged with indecent exposure and released on bail.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 30 C.W. Post College's studentrun FM radio station was closed down today at 2 A.M. by Dean Julian Mates "to protect our station license" after obscenities had been broadcast. The shutdown came at the end of the station's regular program schedule.
The adopted daughter of the late Mayor of Jersey City, Frank Hague, was awarded custody of her 12-year-old son yesterday.

Schenley Industries, Inc., a leading liquor producer, announced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent with the Guild Wine Company of San Francisco that provided for the sale of certain assets of Schenley's California wine operations to Guild. Financial details of the transaction were not disclosed ...
BOSTON, Nov. 30 The medical profession was called on today to take an active role in reducing pollution and other environmental hazards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Four railroad unions today moved their threatened nationwide strike date up by one day to Dec. 10 if they are unable to reach a peaceful wage settlement covering nearly 500,000 workers.

Members of both the America-Israel Cultural Foundation and the Israel's Batsheva Dance Company will attend a champagne reception next Tuesday night at the America-Israel Culture House, 4 East 54th Street.

A document said to reflect the views of key Administration officials accuses a group of anti-SST economists of a "basic lack of comprehension" of how the industry works.

Robyn Smith, a 24-year-old graduate of Stanford University, who plays touch football as well as she rides horses, had an eventful day at Aqueduct yesterday. She guided Garcon of the Hobeau Farm to a frontrunning victory in the third race on the card, and many in the crowd of 25,166 cheered her accomplishment. Her mount had a margin of 1 lengths over the runner-up, the long-shot Cakewalk, in the six-furlong sprint.
Stock prices moved dramatically into high gear yesterday, bursting through the top of a narrow three-month trading range to finish at their best level since the market rout in May.
The City Planning Commission yesterday recommended the "mounding" of landfill rather than the use of superincinerators as the best immediate answer to the city's awesome refuse disposal problem.

Following up earlier action by the Board of Estimate, the City Council yesterday agreed to amend this year's capital budget to add an appropriation of $1-million to pay for damage done by rioting prisoners in city jails this year.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement for a $650-million revolving credit with 17 banks headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

BONN, Nov. 30 The new 18-to-21-year-old voters in West Germany appear to be conscientious, highly independent and rather sober, contrary to the fears of some of their elders, who had expected violence or apathy.

La Foret, a new supper club specializing in haute cuisine, will open tonight at 7:30 at the Pierre, 61st Street and Fifth Avenue. The club has been designed by Maurice Carrere of Maxim's in Paris. It will be open Tuesdays through Saturdays for dinner, supper and dancing from 7:30 until 2:30.
The Louis Harris organization reported yesterday that its poll had found President Nixon trailing Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, for the first time since Mr. Nixon had taken office.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 Informed sources said today that President Sekou Toure of Guinea and members of his Government had made it clear to the United Nations fact-finding mission last week that they were deeply disappointed that their call for United Nations troops had not been heeded.

Further depressing events in the Interior Department confirm the view that the recent firing of Secretary Hickel was essentially a blow at conservation and only incidentally the settling of a personal account. Hardly had the pilot been dropped when his last orders were countermanded and an Assistant Secretary dedicated to wildlife conservation made to walk the plank.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Nixon Administration outlined today its proposed basic network of passenger train routes that would be kept running when a new quasi-governmental corporation takes over the troubled intercity service next spring.

RICHMOND, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Virginia Supreme Court upheld today the conviction and 20-year prison sentence of John Patler for the slaying in 1967 of George Lincoln Rockwell, the American Nazi party leader.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 The California Angels continued their offseason dealing today when they completed a six-player trade with the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Liberal Democratic Senators met today to organize a reform campaign that would weaken the seniority system and give them more of the influence in the Senate now held largely by older, more conservative Southerners.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation indicated yesterday that it would reduce permanently the capacity of its mill at Lackawanna, N.Y., by about 28 per cent.

Chloe Owen, soprano, sang radiantly at Tully Hall Sunday night, and she had the stage presence of a grand lady, all grace and ease.

At the 20th annual Hanukkah Festival in Madison Square Garden last night, Sophie Maslow offered one Biblical recitation and two situations from the 20th-century Jewish experience, exile and imprisonment. The story of Samson was clearly the strongest.
HARTFORD, Nov. 30 (UPI) A strike by 700 members of the Hartford Federation of Teachers entered its third week today after the members voted unanimously yesterday to continue the walkout.
The Police Department yesterday asked for the help of the public in trying to apprehend the driver of a car that killed a 58-year-old man in midtown over the weekend.
The American Stock Exchange scored its biggest advance in more than two months yesterday as volume swelled to its highest level in more than a month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 A Presidential commission recommended to President Nixon today that a joint United StatesPanama "unified canal system" be set up to operate the present Panama Canal and a new waterway it proposed be built about 10 miles away.

Danny Kaye will cut a birthday cake on the stage after his Dec. 11 performance of "Two by Two" for everyone who takes part in the theater party that evening at the Imperial Theater in behalf of the United Nations Children's Fund.

A retired captain from the Department of Correction and a staff of 17 14 of whom are former convicts are involved in a rehabilitation probram that they say has drastically reduced the recidivism rate.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that President Nixon was reconsidering the whole question of revenue sharing, and "will be coming up with meaningful recommendations" to enable the states and municipalities to continue essential local services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird declared today that the United States intended to make no substantial cuts in its force of nearly 300,000 troops in Western Europe over the next 19 months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) President Nixon signed today a three-year farm bill that establishes for the first time a ceiling on the amount of Federal subsidy payments a farmer may receive.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 30 Members of the black community joined the police in a cooperative fire-watch patrol of the streets of a blighted section of this city tonight after 38 persons were left homeless last night by the 15th suspicious fire there in nine days.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) The Archbishop of Canterbury reports that apartheid is on the increase in South Africa. "Apartheid isn't diminishing because it's being increased by more ruthless actions," said the Archbishop, Dr. Michael F. Ramsey, in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) Interest rates charged for conventional mortgages for the purchase of new homes increased slightly in October, but the rates on mortgages for older houses declined to the lowest point in five months, the Federal Home Loan Board reported today.
Miss Katharine Skinner Kilborne and James Perry Cornwell plan to be married next June.
DALLAS, Nov. 30 A new business entity with the symbolic name of Omega-Alpha, Inc., will be used by financier James J. Ling as the vehicle for a fresh start.

LOS ANGELES Nov. 30 The Washington Senators, who recently acquired Denny McLain and Curt Flood, added another celebrated "difficult case" to their roster today when they drafted Joe Foy from the New York Mets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Office of Economic Opportunity, sensitive to the controversy that arose last week over the dismissal of two men who directed its legal services program, announced today that it had given new grants to two of the most controversial local agencies in the program.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP) Representative Richard L. Ottinger spent at least $2.7-million on his unsuccessful campaign to win election to the United States Senate, according to statements on file with the Secretary of State.
After six years (by the clock) with MacManus, John Adams the Westclox Division of General Time will be moving Jan. 1 into Della Femina, Travisano Partners.

PALMA, Majorca, Nov. 30 After completion of the 15th round yesterday and most adjourned games today, Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eight-time United States champion, led the 24-man knockout round-robin qualification tournament for the world challenge matches with a score of 10-4 and one adjourned game.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 25 After years of expansion and prosperity, this modern West Coast port city is falling prey to the anxieties and problems of other big cities.

A state has a right to protect "endangered" wildlife, even far from its borders, a Federal judge ruled yesterday in effect, as he refused to enjoin New York State restrictions on the importation and sale of articles made from the skin of such animals.
