The case of the Judson Three, a new cause celebre in local art circles, was aired and discussed last evening by a special panel and an audience of more than 100 at Museum, an exhibition loft that serves as headquarters for the Art Workers Coalition at 729 Broadway.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 30 (Reuters) The Conakry radio reported today that more than 50 mercenaries had been killed in fighting around Koundra in northwest Guinea.

The City Planning Commission, stressing that inflation was preventing some major construction, proposed yesterday a capital budget of $1.6-billion for fiscal 1971-72 It gave "top priority" to education, mass transit and improvement of the environment, as urged by the Mayor.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP) Classes resumed at Ulster County Community College today with negotiators putting the accent on "progress" in a contract dispute that had closed the school two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Prices paid farmers for raw products dropped 1.5 per cent in November and averaged 4 per cent less than a year ago, the Agriculture Department announced today.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 30 The development of a nuclearpowered heart pacemaker about the size of the eraser on a pencil has been announced by the Cox Heart Institute.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 30 Gov. Ronald Reagan declared today what amounted to a state of fiscal emergency to cope with the prospective deficit of $150-million threatening to wipe out the thin surplus left in the current year's state budget.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Agriculture Department announced today a series of mostly voluntary safety precautions to protect against accidents with parathion, a deadly bug destroyer that also kills people when carelessly handled.

Two Cuban exiles pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to a charge of attempted conspiracy to commit murder in connection with terrorist activities here against the Cuban Government of Premier Fidel Castro.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The following table shows the final 1970 resident population census figures and the changes for each state in population since 1960 and in representation in the House:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Senate Finance Committee substantially rewrote the Housepassed trade legislation today in an evident effort to make the bill less objectionable to the Nixon Administration and freetrade forces generally.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., Nov. 30 Helen Mitchell Spencer, a retired teacher, died at her home here yesterday after a short illness. She was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Nixon Administration planned to issue relaxed regulations on oil spills tomorrow, but pulled back late today when William D. Ruckelshaus, the director of the new Environmental Protection Agency, protested that he should have some voice in the matter.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3 Not since before the "Black Monday" of Oct. 5, when separatist zealots kidnapped a British diplomat and followed a few days later with the kidnap-murder of a Cabinet minister, has Montreal shone and sparkled in its well-known joie de vivre image as it did today.

ROME, Tuesday, Dec. 1 The Italian Parliament gave final approval early this morning to the institution of divorce in Catholic Italy, where such legislation has been one of the most bitterly contested changes of the postwar period.
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 30 (AP) Four antiwar protesters accused of breaking into a Pontiac, Ill., Selective Service office July 29 and taking records pleaded guilty today in United States District Court.
The Eastern Tennis Patrons Party, an annual dinner dance, will be held Thursday at the Pierre. The patrons' group tries to encourage an interest in tennis for children in the metropolitan area.

The nation's population has been officially put at 204,765,770 as of last April 1, an increase of about 24 million over the figure of a decade ago. In 1917, as President Nixon recently pointed out in a special message on population problems, the total number of Americans passed 100 million after three full centuries of steady growth. A mere half-century later, in 1967, the 200-million mark was passed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Senate voted 44 to 31 today to approve a $2.2-billion appropriation for economic and military foreign aid in the current fiscal year.
Computerized Intra-industry delivery of American Stock Exchange shares through the New York Stock Exchange's Central Certificate Service has been started, the exchanges announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30 (UPI) President-elect Luis Echeverrfa Alvarez tonight named Emflio O. Rabasa, Mexican Ambassador to the United States, as Foreign Minister in the Government that takes office tomorrow.
"It'll be sort of an earlywarning system," said William G. Kaye, a man who obviously had his radar turned on.

The Children's Workbench and its grownup counterpart, the Workbench, have just opened another branch in midtown, and it is the largest, and one of the handsomest of its seven stores. There are three selling floors in the store on the corner of Park Avenue South and 32d Street, ...
FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 30 On a day more suitable for an opening, the curtain rang down this afternoon on a spectacularly successful harness racing year at Freehold Raceway.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 30 The Guyanan Government's plans to acquire a controlling interest in the bauxite industry, owned by United States and Canadian interests, have been outlined by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The principal planner of the Roman Catholic Church's efforts to develop social and economic programs for the urban ethnic communities said today that the work would be undiminished despite recent organizational changes in the United States Catholic Conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The United States halted flights of U-2 photographic planes over the Suez Canal area three weeks ago, officials here disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended, for 30 days beginning tomorrow, the broker-dealer registration of Financial Programs, Inc., Denver, and suspended Thomas J. Herbert, the concern's president, from association with any brokerdealer for 30 days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The 1970 census counted 204,765,770 Americans, 24 million more than in 1960, the Census Bureau reported today.

A former Army intelligence officer says the Army gave him an expense account, provided him with liquor and offered to supply him with marijuana if it were necessary while he was assigned to infiltrate antiwar groups.

Minnesota's Gary Cuozzo, quarterback of the team with the best record in pro football, does not have a broken right ankle and will attempt to play on Saturday against Chicago. Cuozzo twisted the ankle absorbing a Jet blitz in the first period of Sunday's game. Bob Lee, ...

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP) Maj. Gen. Robert T. Frederick, the Army's youngest division commander in France during World War II, died last evening of a heart ailment at Stanford Hospital. He was 63 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP) A letter signed with the name of Bernardine Dohrn, a Weatherman leader on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's "most wanted" list, threatened today a wave of attacks on police and Federal installations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Sources at the Department of Health, Education and welfare said today that Dr. Roger O. Egeberg would be relieved of his post as the top Federal health officer, probably after the first of the year.

There were 15,000 basketball fans at Madison Square Garden for the preseason game with the Milwaukee Bucks in October of 1969, and before the game most of them stood up and cheered. The shouting was for David Allen Stallworth, the 29-year-old Knick forward, who had sat ...

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. Nov. 30 (UPI) An explosion and fire on a gasoline barge being prepared for unloading took thre lives early today near the resort community of Watkins Glen on the southern tip of Seneca Lake.
Harold Hinton Wilcox, a conservationist, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

The 1970-71 version of Sy Oliver's nine-piece band was introduced to the jazz world by the New York Hot Jazz Society at the Village Vanguard on Sunday. The band is currently playing during the week at the Riverboat, where it alternates with a rock group.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 30 This Bergen County commuter town of 28,000 is going reluctantly into the business of collecting and disposing of its garbage because private collectors have declined to bid on the work.

The Police Department will help, free of charge, to unsnarl traffic tie-ups caused by disabled vehicles during the morning and evening rush hours on both the East River Drive and the West Side Highway.

The Government has formally agreed to pay $20-million to the Great Western Financial Corporation on Jan. 4, "sub-, ject to no conditions or limitations," as an "advance" on its commitment to subsidize Great Western's take-over of the troubled LFC Financial Corporation.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 1 Pope Paul VI, his face deeply lined with fatigue, presided for more than three hours today over a working session of 65 Roman Catholic Bishops from all over Australia, New Zealand and Oceania.

The disparate elements of a kidnapping charge, a Philadelphia murder trial and the discovery of a bound corpse, came together yesterday as squads of policemen trained their weapons on a third-floor Harlem window behind which a frightened gunman was holding three persons hostage.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Some old slogans as well as some recent metaphors are being openly abandoned here as the Nixon Administration scrambles to stimulate some very rapid economic growth. To wit:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 President Nixon moved today to strengthen his uncertain relations with Congress by naming Representative Clark MacGregor as his principal assistant for Congressional affairs.

ROME, Dec. 1-Jerome Hoffman, head of the troubled Investors International Group, left Rome today amid reports that the transfer of his offshore fund's headquarters from London to Rome had not helped the company bolster its position and that his operation might be in danger of collapse.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 The members of the five-man United Nations factfinding mission that visited Guinea last week have reportedly reached the conclusion that there is solid evidence linking the Portuguese armed forces to the armed commando invasion of which Guinea complained.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange managed to finish slightly higher yesterday, although many early gains were wiped out as the session progressed.

A write-in candidate who won a Federal ruling for free radio time worth perhaps $10,000 received a total of four votes in the 19th Congressional District contest, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Federal Power Commission opened today a landmark hearing on an application to import liquid natural gas into the United States.

Campbell-Mithun is splitting itself into two operating divisions, each with its own president, with Raymond O. Mithun, founder-chairman, remaining chairman of the finance committee of the whole show and Albert R. Whitman remaining chairman of the executive committee.

Five more players were sidelined for the season yesterday, bringing this week's total to eight and the season total to 53. The latest casualties were Jim Cheyunski and Tom Funchess of the Boston Patriots, Randy Minniear and Steve Engel of the Cleveland Browns and Jay Bachman ...

OMAHA, Dec. 1 Boys Town, founded by the late Rev. Edward J. Flanagan in 1917, has operated without a state child care license since June 30 but is expected to have the license by Jan. 1, an official of the Nebraska Department of Welfare said today.

The International Business Machines Corporation instituted a lawsuit yesterday against the Memorex Corporation charging wrongful appropriation and use of I.B.M. trade secrets and confidential information. The charge involves disc packs and other computer memory devices.

BEDFORD, Mass., Dec, 1 (AP) The Viatron Computer Systems Corporation announced, today it is unable to pay interest due Dec. 1 on $25-million of convertible subordinated debentures issued one year ago.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (UPI)Jerry West scored 37 points and Wilt Chamberlain blocked some key shots in the final minutes tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers downed the Baltimore Bullets, 97-93, in a National Basketball Association game.
Mrs. Ann Rockefeller Pierson, elder daughter of Governor Rockefelter, was married on Nov. 25 to Lionel R. Coste Jr., who heads Lionel Coste Associates, architects and city planners here.

A detective who pretended to be a Black Panther testified yesterday that his undercover role was nearly discovered when a Panther came close to touching electronic equipment under his shirt while taping a heart-shaped target to the garment.

PARIS, Dec. 1 David K. E. Bruce, the chief of the United States delegation at the Vietnam peace talks, held his first news conference here today and denounced what he called the Vietnamese Communists' "shameful attitude" toward American war prisoners and their refusal to negotiate at the peace table.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 1 The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, warned South African whites today that they faced the choice between violent revolution and voluntary change to remove the injustices and inhumanity in their society.
ROME Pope Paul prefaced his condemnation of the use of torture by governments, in a recent Papal audience, with what amounted to a piece justificatif.
LONDON, Dec. 1-Prime Minister Heath's Government came under political attack today for refusing to supply public funds to rescue the financially troubled Port of Liverpool.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 1 (Agence France-Presse) Diallo Telli, Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, charged here today that "several European and American nations are implicated" in last week's invasion of Guinea.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Senate passed today a bill to establish an independent Federal agency with broad authority to function as an advocate and protector of consumer interests.

When the Nine O'Clocks dance club had its turn-ofthe-century costume ball last year, Sam LeTulle summed up the situation somewhat wryly. "It's clothes, clothes and more clothes more for the women than the men," the Texas-born architect said. Ditto last night's Winter Ball.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 1 (UPI) The Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens expropriated its first Chilean "monopoly" today Bellavista Tome, the nation's largest fabric manufacturer, which had said it was on the verge of bankruptcy.
Cocoa futures prices advanced again yesterday is moderate trading for the second day in a row after dropping last Friday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 1 Miss Hood Yeilding and Horace Seely-Brown 3d will be married next spring.

The protectionist bloc has won another round in the Senate. Although initially advertised by Senate Finance Committee Chairman Russell Long as a bill that would meet Administration objections to the Mills bill passed by the House, the Senate bill is, if anything, even worse.

The crew of an American merchant vessel reported last night that it had recovered two bodies and 18 survivors from a Japanese fishing trawler that caught fire and was sinking about 240 miles southeast of Nantucket.
Mohawk Airlines, Inc.,told holders of its senior subordinate notes yesterday that interest payments due Dec. 1 would not be made unless the airline's senior lenders consented.
The United Church of Canada yesterday completed the sale of its Ryerson Press to the McGraw-Hill Company of Canada, Ltd., placing the 140-year-old textbook-publishing concern in American hands.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1 A Canadian Government spokesman said today that the Nixon Administration's decision to raise Canadian crude-oil imports to the United States would not alter agreements reached at last week's United States-Canada ministerial meeting.
A vernissage of sorts, for children and their parents, was held at the Museum of the City of New York Monday afternoon, to celebrate the opening of a toy exhibition called "Visions of Sugarplums."

Network television, which has tip-toed around the nation's economic difficulties, met the issue head-on last night in a special documentary entitled "Blue Christ mas: The State of the Econ omy" on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The man from the Buffalo Bills was in town yesterday, supposedly to talk about his team's upcoming game with the Giants, but he said he had a more pressing problem to discuss with the television people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 About a dozen former servicemen, appearing here at the start of an informal inquiry into United States war policy, said today that they had witnessed the torture or murder of South Vietnamese civilians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 After months of delay, the House Rules Committee agreed today to allow floor action on a bill to extend the food stamp program.
While there is nothing new about advertiser involvement in television program syndication, there seems to have been quite a flurry of activity in that area recently.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) Officials of the Better Business Bureaus announced today that they were starting a program designed to make its offices more responsive to consumers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The freshest and strongest clues to the existence of conditions suitable for the possible evolution of life beyond the earth were reported today by a team of American scientists.
HONG KONG, Dec. 2 Communist China and Ethiopia announced today that they had established diplomatic relations.

The sixth annual Splendid American Awards will be given by the Thomas A. Dooley Foundation on Dec. 10 at a dinner dance at the Americana. Each guest of honor will receive a crystal abstract sculpture designed by Steuben Glass.
Having forged three weeks of winning after six weeks of losing, the Jets suddenly have become successful at something else avoiding injuries.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 (UPI)-A Shell Oil Company drilling platform with 22 producing wells burst into flames in the Gulf of Mexico 10 miles off the Louisiana coast today. At least two men were killed.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 The National Institute of Mental Health as placed first priority on problems of children's mental health.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP) A Federal grand jury that has been investigating pro football will resume sessions here Dec. 14.

The rumblings of a fundamental change is U.S. nuclear strategy are beginning to be heard outside the confines of our national security structure. Deterrence, the cornerstone of our strategic policies for many years, is now beginning to be decried as deficient. Nuclear "sufficiency" would be extended to include forces to fight a nuclear war, not merely to prevent one.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Wednesday, Dec. 2 (UPI) Several men believed to be Spanish separatists kidnapped Eugen Beihl, the West German consul here, last night after lying in wait for the diplomat in his garage, the police said.

The Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center was established in 1959 but its computers evidently have calculated that this is the year to celebrate its 10th anniversary, so on Monday night the first of two festive concerts took place at Columbia's McMillin Theater. As befits such an occasion, live performers were scarce, the pianist Robert Miller being the only one to appear onstage, in fact.

New York department-store companies last month achieved an average gain of 4 per cent in their downtown stores and 5 per cent in their area stores from year-earlier levels. The results indicated somewhat of a mixed pattern among leading retailers. They tended to agree that apparel sales made a comeback during November. Some stores ...
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1 Up past the minarets of a Damascus mosque floated cries of "rijal al shaab!" or "men of the people!"

OTTAWA, Dec. 1 After four weeks of debate, the House of Commons today approved Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's limited emergencypowers bill to replace the wartime measures invoked in October to combat the separatist Front for the Liberation of Quebec.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) The United States Postal Service, following the lead of the British Post Office, today inaugurated a limited test of long-haul, overnight delivery of business documents.
The stock market's "easymoney" rally kept roaring forward in early trading yesterday but slowed to a near standstill by the closing bell.

ROME, Dec. 1 Pope Paul VI voiced "deep grief" at the final passage of Italy's divorce law this morning, and Roman Catholic opponents of the legislation announced plans to seek a popular referendum to void the law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 In Florida, a key factor may be a state legislator who has designs on a seat in Congress. In Texas, a Congressman who is under Federal indictment may see his district dismembered. In Alabama, the Democrats are out to get a Republican incumbent, but the voters may not cooperate.
Tickets for the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic, featuring Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall, Arthur Ashe and Pancho Gonzales, go on sale at 10 A.M, today at Madison Square Garden.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (UPI)-Coach John McKay of the University of Southern California was appointed codirector of athletics today. He will continue as head football coach.

The Staats-Zeitung und Herold, the daily German-language newspaper published here, announced yesterday that financial difficulties would force it to publish only two issues a week beginning Jan. 1. The newspaper, founded in 1834, is among the oldest in the country.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 The battle of the mini and the midi came to Harvard today, but it was all academic.

QB VII. By Leon Uris. 504 pages. Doubleday. $7.95. Leon Uris's latest novel, "QB VII,' does serve a purpose, it seems to me. It is so undemanding. One can read it while engaged in activities that demand less than one's complete attention-activities like skywriting or climbing the Matterhorn. Conversely, if one wants to sit down with the book in a quiet room, it acts as a kind ...
BUFFALO, Dec. 1 (UPI)Art Williams sank a 22-foot jump shot with five seconds left in overtime tonight as the Boston Celtics, down by 18 points in the first half, edged the Buffalo Braves, 117-116.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) Robert G. Baker was accused today of violating securities and exchange laws in the purchase and sale of stock in a metals corporation.

PARIS The impending release of Regis Debray from a Bolivian jail is of international importance because, for the first time, it could give an experienced, serious leader to the revolt-minded young New Left of the Western World.
TORONTO, Dec. 1 (UPI) William M. Kunstler, the American civil rights lawyer who was a defense attorney for the Chicago seven, was acquitted today of assaulting two leaders of a right-wing group.

The Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with 10 European banks to extend the short-term debt of Levin-Townsend International, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary.

It wasn't so long ago that Thomas Jefferson, sitting in his Greenwich Village apartment, gazed at the gleaming 9-foot-long coffee table he'd made from a slice of an English oak, leaving the bark along the sides.

The new school superintendent of Community District 3 in Manhattan, saying that he did not like the discipline and tone of Joan of Arc Junior High School, removed the principal yesterday and ordered the school closed today for consultations with parents and staff.
Two suspects were arraigned in Criminal Court here yesterday on murder charges as a result of the slaying of four persons on Nov. 23 during the robbery of a bar in the East Village.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Willard Ellington Shelton, a longtime Washington newspaperman and political columnist, died today in George Washington University hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 United States intelligence analysts have reported the establishment of a major Chinesesupplied guerrilla base this month at Dong Luang, in eastern Thailand.

Because the Seattle Sonics wouldn't quit and because their own hot shooting cooled off late in the game, the New York Knicks had to endure a finish that was just a little too close for comfort before winning, 114-109, at Madison Square Garden last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (UPI) While shouting demonstrators waved Vietcong flags outside his hotel, Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam, appealed to Americans today to continue to support his Government against the Communists.

Igor Stravinsky's carefully husbanded collection of his manuscripts and other papers has been thrown on the market at an asking price of $3.5 million. Byzantine maneuvering is reported to be going on among such prospective purchasers as the Library of Congress and the Soviet Union. The archives include the complete, corrected score of "Le Sacre du Printemps," about 7,600 additional pages of manuscript and perhaps 17,000 documents.
Two students were injured and three were arrested yesterday in new disorders at strifetorn George Washington High School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) Senator Henry M. Jackson. Democrat of Washington, said today that he had received assurances from the Nixon Administration that the Alaska land "freeze" would be continued until June 30, 1971.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 1 (AP) Yugoslavia has withdrawn from the women's Federation Cup international tennis tournament scheduled here Dec. 26 to 29.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 1-Loyola College of Baltimore spoiled Coach Bill Raftery's debut as Seton Hall University basketball coach with a 96-73 upset tonight. It was only the Greyhounds' seventh victory in the 38-game series.
Columbia used a balanced scoring attack and a tight manto-man defense to defeat City College, 81-55, in University Gymnasium last night. It was the opening game of the season for both teams.

Ten Harlem youngsters who won a brief reprieve from classes yesterday to attend a dress preview of a Congolese art exhibition to be held Sunday quickly discovered that, like most of us, they knew what they liked.
Two strikebound Off Broadway shows have announced their intention of transferring operations to the Broadway area later this month.
Agi Rado, pianist, who was heard at Tully Hall Monday night, projected a warm and comfortable relationship at all times between herself and the music she played.
Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that the state faced a minimum deficit of $400-million in the next fiscal year even if no additional state spending was authorized.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 1 A former machine gunner testified today that he had seen his platoon commander, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., open fire on unarmed Vietnamese civilians who had been herded into a ditch in the hamlet of Mylai 4.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1?Blanton Collier, the 64-year-old coach of the Cleveland Browns, told a lunch group today that he would retire after the season.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 1 (AP) George Blackburn will not be retained as football coach beyond the end of his contract next Jan. 25, the University of Virginia said today.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Dec. 1 Walter Stuempfig, whose landscapes won him election to the National Institute of Arts and Letters in 1963, died yesterday at the home of his aunt, Mrs. Maude E. Raby, 1 Lagoon Road, after a long illness. He was 56 years old.
It is axiomatic in sports that the best defense is a strong offense. The St. Louis Blues, who play the New York Rangers tonight in Madison Square Garden, are defying the axiom.
Samuel Mitchell, a philanthropist and a retired blouse manufacturer, died on Monday in his home at 3 East 69th Street. He was 85 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 The New York Mets traded Ron Herbel to the Atlanta Braves today for Bob Aspromonte, the last of the old Brooklyn Dodgers, as a bull market in players developed at the winter baseball convention.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 1 Army added surprisingly accurate shooting to its usual tough defense today and opened its basketball season with a 72-47 victory over Lehigh.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 Following is the text of the United States-sponsored resolution on prisoners of war adopted today by the Social Committee of the General Assembly:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Senator-elect James L. Buckley of New York said today that he did not foresee any problem in being seated with the Senate's Republicans when the 92d Congress convened next month.

Two musicians from Uganda, B. A. Kalanzi and J. M. Sendaula, who call themselves the Kars, sang and played music of their country, both traditional and modern, Monday evening at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

There has been no improvement in telephone installation and repair service in the New York City area, the State Public Service Commission said yesterday, "probably because of a shortage of skilled telephone craftsmen in the area."

The Chaparral 2J has been declared legal. The Sports Car Club of America, which sanctions the Canadian-American Challenge Cup for Group 7 sports-racing cars, announced yesterday that the controversial 2J, introduced by Jim Hall in the 1970 series, would be permitted to ...

The corporate bond market plowed through a mountain of new financings yesterday and when the dust had settled half a dozen assorted issues, totaling about $200-million, had been practically all sold and interest rates had moved down another notch.
The Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool, a world leader in Judaism, died last evening at his home, 91 Central Park West. He was 85 years old.
"Where is that short Argentinian?" said Muhammad Ali, compressing his lips to stifle a smile. "He is short, isn't he?"

BRUSSELS, Dec. 1. Ten European nations of the North Atlantic alliance agreed today on a "defense improvement program" calling for the expenditure of close to a billion dollars over the next five years on military installations, communications and additional forces.

The Senate can act today to right an old wrong. It is expected to vote on whether or not to restore to the Taos tribe of the Pueblo Indians their title to a 48,000-acre tract high in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains of New Mexico, a sanctuary nearly two centuries before Columbus first crossed the Atlantic.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 The Mexican Revolution, which began 60 years ago as an uprising for land, bread and political freedom, has turned into a disciplined, productive system of nationalist capitalism.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 Luis Echeverria Alvarez took office as President of Mexico today and said he would steer the booming economy toward greater equity in the distribution of income.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Senate Finance Committee, reversing a day-old tentative decision, voted today to retain a quota on shoe imports in the controversial foreign trade bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The Transportation Department proposed today that all passenger cars starting with 1973 models be designed to operate no faster than 95 miles an hour and to sound horns and flash lights at 85 miles an hour.
Fifty-nine homeowners in Corona, Queens, who had fought vainly for four years against displacement for a proposed high school, won an extraordinary last-minute reprieve yesterday at City Hall.
SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 2 Pope Paul VI told young Australians at an outdoor mass this morning that the Roman Catholic Church shared many values of today's youth culture.
As the Senate nears its critical vote on the money for the supersonic transport, its advocates are making desperate efforts to assure approval.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) The White House said the latest textile negotiations today between the United States and Japan did not offer much hope to the chief American participant.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 1 (AP) A military spokesman said Cambodian troops opened a drive today 20 miles north of Pnompenh and pushed enemy forces from positions they seized two days ago.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1 (UPI)-A nationwide poll of harness writers elected Albatross and Quick Pride as the 2-year-old champions of 1970, the United States Trotting Association announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee unanimously approved today a measure to exempt sales of .22-caliber rimfire ammunition from Federal gun control registration requirements.

The Boise Cascade Corporation announced yesterday that it was deferring plans to build a vast recreational community that would eventually house more than 10,000 people in East Taghkanic, a rural township in New York State that now has a population of 727.
FARMINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 1 A recovery crew found three bodies today in the wrecked Consol No. 9 coal mine, where 78 men were trapped 600 feet below ground by explosions and fire in 1968.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 1 (UPI) A Federal Court jury tonight found all eight members of a conspiracy guilty of all charges in the ransacking of Federal offices and destruction of military draft records.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP) Maryland's Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene said tonight that he had turned down a White House offer of the nation's top health post now held by Dr. Rogero Egeberg.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 Five frail girls emerge from the white van from time to time and feed coins into the parking meter. Sometimes they kneel on the sidewalk and stare blankly at the sky. At other times they stare at the Hall of Justice, where the Tate murder trial is under way.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 The Chrysler Corporation today raised prices for the second time this year on its 1971 cars, this increase averaging $15, or 0.5 per cent, the company said.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 1 (UPI)-An oil slick believed caused by an Italian oil tanker was sighted yesterday off the Florida Keys.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The maximum interest rate that may be charged on home mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration was cut today from 8 to 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The official 1970 census figures on the population of the United States are a dramatic reminder that it is not primarily the decisions of governments that are changing the world, but the fertility of the human mind and body.

CAIRO, Dec. 1 Cairo's position on an extension of the cease-fire beyond Feb. 5 appears to be hardening day by day. Egyptian leaders have declared repeatedly that an extension will not be accepted unless Israel returns to the peace talks under Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 The Israeli military authorities announced tonight that an Egyptian motor launch was sunk Saturday off the Sinai coast of the Gulf of Suez. Four Egyptian crewmen were killed, according to the announcement.
Four members of the undefeated Ohio State team and the first Ivy Leaguer in 19 years highlight the United Press International's 1970 All-America college football team issued yesterday.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 1 (UPI) A group of blacks filed suit in Federal court today asking that their school, Strom Thurmond High, get a new name.
Although Dundee Marmalade was the shortest-priced horse of the day at Aqueduct yesterday, thousands of bettors must have held their breaths after wagering on the chestnut 2-year-old colt.
THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President met with Republican Congressional leaders. He also announced his appointment of Clark MacGregor of Minnesota as his chief adviser on Congressional relations.

The electric power pools of New England and eastern Canada were energized yesterday at 345,000 volts through a 150-mile transmission line. This was the first time the international ties have been made at such a voltage through New England.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 Four Russian painters sat in a darkened room in a Moscow apartment recently and discussed color not the colors of their officially proscribed abstract paintings but the poorly defined reds and blues of the ice-hockey game they were watching on television.

The State Board of Law Examiners announced yesterday that 1,526 of the 1,985 persons who took the state bar examination last July 30 and July 31 had passed. The examiners said that of the 1,802 candidates who took the examination for the first time 1,425 had passed.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 The State Commission of Investigation began public hearings today on charges that the Hudson County Mosquito Control Commission had shaken down the Penn Central and a contractor for the New Jersey Turnpike Commission for $114,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Premier Golda Meir of Israel has sent President Nixon a new message to lay the groundwork for resumption of Arab-Israeli peace negotiations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (UPI)-The Chicago Bulls put on a 17-point spurt against the Philadelphia 76ers in the third period tonight and held on for a 107-91 victory in a National Basketball Association game.

Michael Hellerman, who was indicted by a grand jury last month on charges of being the prime mover of a scheme to take over a Florida investment company with the assistance of three reputed Mafia leaders, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court, and then faced knew charges of fraudulent securities sales and pricerigging.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, served notice today that he would seek Congressional action next year to force a reduction of United States forces in Europe.

Midst music and speeches, the little but exquisite Paul Recital Hall was officially opened at the Juilliard School on Monday evening. The music came from three Juilliard stars. The speeches came from Peter Mennin, head of the Juilliard; Amyas Ames, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center, and Col. C. Michael Paul, after whom the hall is named.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 "I intend to be coaching the Rams in 1971," George Allen, the controversial Los Angeles coach, said without qualification today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The United States employed the full range of its foreign broadcast and information services today to assure the world that the denial of asylum last week to a Lithuanian sailor resulted from a bureaucratic bungle and not a change in United States policy on political refugees.

For a long time, no politician has been so foolhardy as to advocate, within hearing of the press, throwing hundreds of thousands of people out of work as a useful way of restoring social order and discipline and of stopping inflation. But this is not to say that many politicians do not think these ...

EAST HADDAM, Conn., Dec. 1 Rear Adm. James C. Shaw, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Shaw have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Holt Perkins Shaw, to Raymond Grigore Zino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marius A. Zino, also of East Haddam. The wedding is planned for later this month.
A mistrial was declared yesterday in the case of Joseph Colombo Jr. after five jurors admitted they had ignored the judge's instructions not to read or listen to news accounts of the trial.

The renewed stalemate in taxicab labor negotiations is fresh proof of the hash made of collective bargaining when union and employer representatives start squabbling over how to split up other people's money.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The United States is continuing to survey the Suez Canal area periodically by earth-orbiting military satellites, it was reported today.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 1-At 1:30 this afternoon a blue station wagon pulled up in front of the storefront office of a citizens group. A woman jumped out and yelled: "There's a fire on William Street."

Mrs. Minnie Druss Ulanoff, wife of Samuel H. Ulanoff, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of HoppinWatson, died Friday in Putnam Community Hospital, Carmel, N. Y., after a short illness. She was 70 years old and lived at 220 East 57th Street and in Mahopac, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to declare that the city of Jackson, Miss., had violated the Constitution when it closed its public swimming pools rather than integrate them.

The city's Acting Buildings Commissioner said yesterday that he was "mystified" after a two-day investigation as to what had caused two sheets of glass to fall from a 50-story building under construction in Times Square on Saturday night.

The United States Coast Guard sinks into ever-deeper waters as it tries to explain its incredible cooperation with Soviet seamen in their forcible return of a defecting Lithuanian to his fishing vessel off Martha's Vineyard. The commandant now says the hapless defector would have had a better chance of receiving sanctuary if he had leaped from his ship into the water rather than directly onto the Coast Guard cutter Vigilant.
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, reconvened tax negotiators yesterday but said that he was not optimistic about a quick settlement.
BERLIN, Dec, 1 Leaders of the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies flew to East Berlin today for a meeting on the sensitive Berlin issue and East German relations with Bonn.

Just how viable is the nation's rail system anyway? Is it possible that an industry with assets valued at more than $25-billion is just barely chugging along with inadequate working capital to meet its day-to-day operations?
BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) A group of 40 top diabetes specialists charged today that the Food and Drug Administration, by a recent action, had "damaged the welfare of a million diabetic patients."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (Reuters) The Federal Reserve' Board announced today several procedural changes under which member banks borrow funds from the System.
Fort Marcy and Top Bid were picked yesterday as the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' champion turf horse and champion steeplechaser for 1970.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 1 (_AP)-Ray Cullen's goal with 4:03 to play in the game gave the Vancouver Canucks a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (AP) Baseball's rules committee rejected proposals for colored bases and foul lines today at the winter meeting and voted to discontinue a "wild-card," pinch-hitting experiment in the minor leagues.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay went to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night to salute the New York Board of Rabbis at a convocation marking its 90th anniversary.

Milton Steinbach, an investment banker and philanthropist, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 150 Central Park and on Rockledge Road in Rye, N. Y.

Operations of Kinney National Service, Inc. in the quarter and year ended Sept. 30 resulted in record sales and earnings with all divisions showing higher profits, according to yesterday's annual report issued by Steven J. Ross, president of the diversified service company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Nixon Administration is considering expanding, from $5-billion to as much as $20billion, the scope of the Federal revenue sharing plan that it will resubmit to Congress next year.
UNITED, NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 A United States proposal aimed at getting protection for American war prisoners in Vietnam was approved today by a committee of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Some of President Nixon's most influential advisers are advocating an economic policy for next year aimed at exceptionally rapid expansion of the economy a rise in total output of 8 per cent in the last quarter of 1971 over the final quarter of this year.

President Nixon's Task Force on Business Taxation has recommended a major increase in the tax deductions that companies are allowed to take for their investment in capital equipment, a member of the group said here yesterday.
The London stock market moved ahead yesterday in quiet trading and dollar stocks were higher in line with Wall Street's gains.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the Anaconda Company and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company yesterday cut the price of basic copper by 3 cents a pound.
MELBOURNE, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) Paul Lindenberg a skipper from Blake Park, Fla., gained two first-place finishes to lead in the annual Tornado Class world championship catamaran races.

The Dallas Aces, world champions in 1970 and scheduled to defend that title in six months in Taipei, took a step toward the 1972 world Olympiad title at the fall nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. By finishing in a tie for first place in the Reisinger team championship, the final event of the tournament that ended Sunday in Houston, the Aces became probable contenders in the next United States team trials.
The Ford Foundation will help finance fledgling minority-owned businesses in New York, in other large cities and in rural Georgia and Oklahoma.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) At least one member of President Nixon's top White House staff has been given Secret Service protection, presumably to guard against any possible kidnapping attempt.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 The physicians for the 24 major league teams completed two days of meetings here today by forming an organization to exchange ideas and information on the care and feeding of baseball players.

After 10 years in the House of Representatives, Clark MacGregor will move next month to the other side of the fence to become, in his words, "the President's man dealing with the Congress." Representative MacGregor, a native of Minneapolis, whose suburbs he has ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Nixon Administration's second "inflation alert" leveled specific criticism today at wage or price increases in several industries, including construction, oil and automobiles.
The Young Women's Christian Association, in cooperation with the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York, plans to open comprehensive day-care centers in parts of the city next year.
The last Wagner administration holdover on the City Planning Commission began yesterday an effort to pressure Mayor Lindsay into reappointing her.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Senator Edmund S. Muskie accused the Nixon Administration today of violating "the spirit if not the letter of the law" in the fight over the supersonic transport.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The House of Representatives passed legislation today providing insurance for the public against financial losses resulting from the bankruptcies of brokerage firms.

PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 1 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eight-time United States chess champion, maintained a slim lead in the 24-man interzonal knockout tournament here today when he adjourned his 16th-round game with Tudev Uitumen, the champion of Mongolia.

BIRMINGHAW, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP) Federal agents raided the home of a physician tonight and, after finding an unspecifield number of firearms, arrested him on charges stemming from the discovery of an estimated 30 tons of weapons in a suburb Sunday.

Two of the nation's largest banks announced reductions yesterday in their interest rates on consumer loans. Two other major banks (one of them in New York City) indicated that such reductions were being considered. All the banks linked their actions to the general easing in the national money market in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Sir Robert Thompson, the British expert on guerrilla warfare, has told President Nixon that the United States and allied intelligence and police efforts have failed to destroy the Communist subversive apparatus in South Vietnam.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) Jo-Jo White sank a 20-foot jump shot in the closing moments tonight and John Havlicek put in a free throw with six seconds to play for the Boston Celtics as they defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 114-111, for their sixth straight National Basketball Association victory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Three coal miners were crushed to death under a rock fall in the Russellton, Pa., mine of the Republic Steel Corporation, the Bureau of Mines reported today. Three sections of the mine were ordered closed.

An application to acquire the Pacific Northwest Pipeline properties now being operated by the El Paso Natural Gas Company was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Denver by the privately held Paradox Production Corporation.

An American interfaith group said yesterday that the British Government was "firmly committed to the elimination of discrimination in Northern Ireland" and that an outbreak of civil war there did not seem to be an immediate danger.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 2 It is a simple thing to recognize heart transplant recipients here at the Stanford University Medical Center. They wear little blue surgical masks over their noses and mouths to protect them from picking up infections as they stroll through the halls during their weekly checkups.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 2 Dr. Robert Clifford Peale, a Pawling physician, died Monday in Vassar Hospital of a heart attack. Dr. Peale, a brother of the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale, was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-High Administration officials are said to suspect that the Soviet Union is playing a maritime "cat-and-mouse" game with its submarine tender in the Caribbean.

The London stock market drifted lower yesterday because of a lack of support after a firm start that reflected the rally on Wall Street. Special situations dominated trading, but volume remained depressed.
The women's liberation movement took another step forward yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange allowed female pages on its trading floor for the first time since World War II.
Former United States Chief Justice Earl Warren will be guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Synagogue Council of America on Sunday evening at the WaldorfAstoria.

The newest college of the City University of New York, which will open next fall in mid-Brooklyn, was named yesterday for Medgar W. Evers, the civil rights leader killed by a sniper in Mississippi in 1963.

PARIS, Dec. 2 A senior Rumanian diplomat and his wife have requested political asylum in France, official sources disclosed today. The diplomat is Victor Dimitriu, who was Ambassador in Paris from 1964 to 1968.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The House Rules Committee dealt a serious and possibly fatal blow today to legislation to establish an independent consumer protection agency in the executive branch.

PARIS, Dec. 2 (Reuters) France's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 960,000,000 francs in November compared with 224,000,000 francs the previous month, the Finance Ministry said today. (The French franc is currently quoted at about 18.004 cents).

The business manager of a Long Island local of the painters' union and two alleged accomplices were accused yesterday of conspiracy and taking kickbacks on insurance premiums paid by the union's pension and welfare funds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) The Interior Department's ban on imports of products from eight whale species became effective today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (UPI) The Amateur Athletic Union's national track and field committee, headed by Coach Stan Wright of Sacramento State, moved today for liberalization of rules concerning the use of pictures and signatures of athletes in their daily occupations.

MADRID, Dec. 2 Shortly after 3 P.M. on Aug. 2, 1968, Meliton Manzanas, head of the Political Police in the Province of Guipuzcoa, was shot dead on the stairs leading to his apartment in the dingy town of Irun, on the French border.

Charles Mathis, a 41-year-old Philadelphian arrested Tuesday in a Harlem apartment where the police found two hostages and a corpse, was ordered to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for psychiatric examination.

Disingenuous is a charitable word to describe Defense Secretary Laird's explanation of why he failed to tell the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the Nov. 21 bombing of North Vietnam included air strikes in the Hanoi area. "I only answer the questions that are asked," he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Representative William M. Colmer, a Mississippi Democrat, appears to have succeeded in blocking passage this year of a bill to give the Federal Government power to enforce nondiscrimination in employment.

The city announced yesterday that five of its 50 welfare centers would be closed by Feb. 1 because of the "fiscal crisis." Municipal union leaders responded promptly with plans for a "job action" to protest the resulting heavier loads on caseworkers.
BRUSSELS, Dec.2 The North Atlantic Treaty Organization adopted proposals today to strengthen the West's conventional forces in Europe and the Middle East.
The Pearl Gala, 14th annual benefit for the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, will be held on Dec. 15 in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza.

LONDON, Dec. 2 The British and European aircraft industries were dealt a severe blow today when the Government refused to give financial support to either the European airbus project or its all-British counterpart.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 Soviet scientists were warned today that they were aiding "the enemy" if they acted independently of the Communist party line.

Irish reaction had to be mixed last night as Irish Danny McAloon of the Bronx scored his second split decision this year over Irish Bob O'Brien of Bayside, Queens, before 1,800 fans in the Felt Forum.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 Bruce Davis, one of Charles Manson's former "family" members, surrendered to the police here today, and the question was raised whether Mr. Davis would testify to attempt to absolve Manson in the Tate-LaBianca murders.
IOWA CITY, Dec. 2 (UPI) Ray Nagel made the meeting of the University of Iowa athletics board easier today.

Armour Dial, Inc., realized a 12 per cent increase in earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 on a sales gain of 8 per cent, both setting records, the company's preliminary unaudited report disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (UPI) The United Automobile Workers' top negotiator with the Ford Motor Company said today that there would be no further extensions of the union's contract with the company past the strike deadline of midnight Monday.

YONKERS, Dec. 2 Francis J. Wazeter, founder of the annual Pulaski Day Parade on Fifth Avenue in New York and a statewide leader among New Yorkers of Polish origin, died today in St. John's Hospital. He was 63 years old.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) An oil slick covering 760 square miles was located today in the Atlantic Ocean 23 miles off north Florida. A spokesman for the state said that the Navy had deliberately dumped it.

The United Nations hay spoken up eloquently and decisively in behalf of more humane treatment for prisoners of war and for compliance with the Geneva Convention of 1949. Ambassador Charles W. Yost said that adoption of this resolution by the General Assembly Social Committee shows that the plight of American prisoners in Vietnam "weighs on the conscience of the world."

When Jacksonville plays St. Peter's tonight in the second half of the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, John Condon's announcement of the Dolphins' starting line-up will intone:

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 2 Miss Susan Gerli Smith, a great-granddaughter of Joseph E. Gerli, co-founder of E. Gerli Co., silk importers in New York, will be married to Eric Henry Peterson 3d on Dec. 19 in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.
PARIS Early in 1968, American tourists in France had an unpleasant experience: hotelkeepers wouldn't take their dollars without a substantial discount.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 In line with its new emphasis on finding ways to stimulate the economy and reduce unemployment, the Administration is again examining the possibility of liberalizing the tax deductions that businesses may take for depreciation.

TOKYO, Dec. 2 Stung by widespread criticism that official Japanese aid to East Pakistani cyclone victims has been niggardly, the Japanese Cabinet yesterday approved a contribution of $1.5-million in addition to its original gift of $150,000.
A state mediator asked both sides in the Off Broadway theater strike "to move heaven and earth to come in with new propositions" before they resume bargaining sessions tomorrow.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 2 (Reuters) The jailed French writer Regis Debray will be freed around Christmas as part of a general amnesty for political prisoners, high Government sources said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2 (AP) The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today a nationwide campaign to involve sympathetic lawyers in a mopping-up operation on civil rights.

Ten New York Nets basketball games will be televised over WPIX-TV, Channel 11, beginning Saturday night, Jan. 2. The telecasts will mark the first appearances on television for the local representatives of the American Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Senator Clifford P. Case today introduced legislation, first sponsored by conservatives 16 years ago, that would require the executive branch to transmit all international agreements tc Congress.

BURBANK, Calif. "I see this place," said Herbert Blau, "as total theater." Mr. Blau, former co-director of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company, was talking about the California Institute of the Arts, where he is now provost. The institute opened this fall with 630 students in the old quarters of a Roman Catholic girls' school, and there might not be any other college quite like it.

Food prices held steady in October and that may be a little solace to housewives. However, in the last two years food prices have risen more than 10 per cent, cause for some financial headaches. With this and the persistent overall increase in the cost of living as measured by the consumer price index, the typical family has been pinched where it hurts in the pocketbook.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 A compromise housing bill that would make sweeping new provisions for the development of new communities won a test vote in the House of Representatives tonight.

Mrs. Irma Rosenberger Feder, widow of James L. Feder, was married here yesterday afternoon to Nelson M. Harris, vice president of the Sameth Exterminating Company here. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's sister, Mrs. E.J. Liebowitz, by Rabbi Bernard Bamberger of Shaaray Tefila Congregation.

A leading pathologist said last night that a prisoner said to have committed suicide Nov. 3 had injuries not themselves fatal that "could have been sustained during an altercation or a beating" before death.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 2 A long-haired youth who once told Army investigators that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. had ordered the slaughter of Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4 invoked the Fifth Amendment today at the Calley court-martial and refused to answer all questions relating to the alleged massacre.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 A group of Vietnam war veterans continued their efforts today to document charges of widespread murder, torture and terrorism by American forces in South Vietnam.
Several judges, lawyers and organized-crime figures are to be questioned at hearings this month before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 Soviet authorities have announced high-level changes in the Bolshoi Theater and Mosfilm studio, two of the country's leading cultural establishments.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Senate voted unanimously today to require that supersonic transport airplanes be quieter in every stage of operation than the jetliners in common use today.

Daniel Barenboim conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night, and it was hard to believe that so young a man was creating such formidable structures in sound. He has come up as a pianist, and only recently has turned to the podium, but it is on the podium where he belongs. Certainly he conducts with much more freedom and authority than he plays the piano.

CAMP COURTNEY, Okinawa, Dec. 2 (UPI) The court martial, of a United States marine from Brooklyn charged in the rape of an Okinawan girl opened today, and the defense immediately challenged a jury of Marine officers, charging that they were all white and were subject to strong racial ten sions on Okinawa.

Is the National Geographic Society falling behind the times? In conjunction with the Metromedia Producers Corporation the respected public-spirited organization presented last night a program entitled "Ethiopia: The Hidden Empire" on the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Dr. Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences, charged today that the Nixon Administration was allowing the American scientific complex to drift toward decay.
The American public is trusting.

The ousted principal of Joan of Arc Junior High School showed up at her office yesterday morning and remained there all day, in defiance of an order from her district superintendent to report to his office.

TOKYO, Dec. 2 The Japan Socialist party, largest opposition grouping in this country, concluded a three-day congress here tonight with the leadership firmly in the hands of the left wing, which clings to concepts such as proletarian dictatorship at home and an unarmed neutrality leaning toward Peking and Moscow abroad.

"Golf's Tribute to Ike," a fundraising project of the United States Golf Association and the Professional Golfers' Association of America, was introduced yesterday with an oral teeing-off ceremony at the Sky Glub in the Pan Am Building.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI) Nguyen Cao Ky, Vice President of South Vietnam, said today that he was not disturbed by demonstrations against him and indicated he would have liked to have met some of the protesters.

Negotiations in the taxi dispute continued yesterday in an effort to reach a tentative agreement before the scheduled general membership meeting of the Taxi Drivers Union tomorrow morning at Manhattan Center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Senate Finance Committee voted today for a change in the definition of unemployment that could deny welfare benefits to thousands of part-time workers now eligible to receive them.
NEWARK, Dec. 2 A new tax program for helping Newark out of a critical financial situation has been proposed by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and approved by the City Council.

Stephen L. Mayham, retired executive vice president and for many years spokesman for the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., an international cosmetic trade group, died here Tuesday. Mr. Mayham was 78 years old and lived at 85-15 Main Street, Jamaica, Queens.
An intensive citywide campaign to combat the growing problem of shoplifting and pickpocketing was begun yesterday by five department stores, three supermarket chains and 24 labor unions.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 The General Motors Corporation reported today that its dealers sold only 23,589 cars in the final third of November and only 88,645 in the full month, a fraction of the 111,584 and 362,668 car sales in the comparable periods last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) A major oil industry organization today strongly defended recent crude oil price increases as vital to stimulation of United States oil production which has fallen off in recent years while demand has steadily risen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Senate approved today, by unanimous voice vote, the nomination of William D. Ruckelshaus as director of the new Environmental Protection Agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 World trade declined seasonally in the third quarter of this year but continued to show strong year-to-year expansion, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec.2 (UPI) A portrait of President John F. Kennedy will be unveiled at the White House next month along with a painting of his widow, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, it was learned today.
"Skiing has become expensive, but not for me," said Art Tokle, the former national ski-jumping champion. "Ten dollars for a daily lift ticket? That's ridiculous. I go uphill for nothing."

The sidewalk Santas and the department store tinsel and colored lights made it look like the Christmas season, but it felt more like spring when the temperatures rose to 66 degrees, a record for the date, yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday Dec. 3 Pope Paul VI in his last mass in Australia, this morning consecrated the first native-born bishop of the Territories of Papua and New Guinea.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to advance yesterday in active trading in a session that saw more large blocks cross the tape than ever before in the history of the exchange.

Ship Leave bounced back to his form of last year in winning the feature purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Gustave Ring's 4-year-old campaigner romped to a clear triumph in the 1 1/8mile event, beating his nearest rival, Marion Frankel's Wicked Man, by 3 1/2 lengths. Next in the field of nine was Sigmund Sommer's Pleasant Harbour, a length and a ...

VALPARAISO, Fla., Dec. 2 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese prison camp at Sontay, site of an unsuccessful United States prisoner-of-war rescue raid last month, had been vacant for up to three months, an Air Force brigadier general said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) An Administration farm official, speaking after a White House "inflation alert" yesterday, criticized the retail food industry today for keeping consumer park prices up despite record low hog prices.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals squandered a 25-point half-time lead and lost, 119-111, to the Seattle Supersonics tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

The police undercover agent who supplied surreptitiously transcribed recordings said to be of conversations of Black Panthers on trial here was a boyhood friend of one of the defendants, it was disclosed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

TRENTON, Dec. 2 Three witnesses at a public hearing conducted by the State Commission of Investigation testified today that they had paid nearly $100,000 in kickbacks to C. Harry Callari, the executive secretary of the Hudson County Mosquito Extermination Commission.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 The New York Yankees and Mets continued their efforts to obtain Frank Robinson today as the trade market kept booming at baseball's winter convention.

World sugar futures prices dropped yesterday as a result of a decision by the executive committee of the International Sugar Organization, meeting in London, not to release more sugar to the world free-market at this time.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2 (Reuters) A militant Protestant leader was hustled out of the town hall here today after he staged a one-man protest in front of Pope Paul VI.

Not really a serious attempt to capture the electricchair buff audience, Jack Smight's "The Traveling Executioner," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, fails in spite of its little peculiarities rather than because of them.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 (AP) Three major oil companies were fined more than $500,000 in Federal court today after pleading no contest to charges that they had not placed safety valves on some offshore oil wells in the Gulf of Mexico.

Mrs. Charlotte Clark Husted was married in Montreal last Saturday to Edwin C. McDonald, board chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada Trust Company of New York and of Thomson Newspapers, Inc. The ceremony at the Mount Royal Club was performed by the Rev. Dr. Alexander Komthy of the United Church.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 Howard Hughes, one of the richest and most mysterious men in the world, left his hotel suite on the Las Vegas Strip a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Robert Penn Warren received the National Medal for Literature here today, and issued a call for "any kind of poetry that is real for the disease of our time is the sense of being cut off from reality."

The very real pleasure to be found in Leonard Gershe's comedy, "Butterflies Are Free," now in its second year at the Booth Theater, is the effortless elegance with which it achieves everything it has set out to achieve. It is funny, touching and wryly sentimental. It provides entertainment without talking down, it is witty, honest, in that particular way proverbs tend to be honest, and exquisitely written.
The corporate bond market gathered additional momentum yesterday as underwriters priced new offerings at substantially lower interest rates and investors nonetheless rushed to buy them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to give the Taos Pueblo Indians title to 48,000 acres of Carson National Forest in New Mexico, land they have long claimed as part of their cultural and religious heritage.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a suit brought by the Lindsay administration to compel Controller Abraham D. Beame to pay $250,000 to a private consultant for work done for the city.

The Reading Company announced yesterday in Philadelphia that it was deferring principal payments of $2-million each due July 1 through 1973 on its outstanding $28-million collateral notes guaranteed by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The White House said today that President Nixon would set forth a "new, clear policy" on political refugees to prevent recurrence of the incident last week in which the United States Coast Guard refused sanctuary to a Lithuanian sailor.

Someone is the balcony at Fillmore East on Tuesday night yelled "Go, Virgil!" And off went Virgil Fox into a program of Bach's organ music, backed by the chromatic extravaganzas of Joe's Lights. Mr. Fox, whose usual habitat is the concert hall or the church, was invading New York's rock cathedral to sell the gospel of Johann Sebastian.

In the third round of the 24-man interzonal knockout tournament at Palma, Majorca Grandmaster Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles was White against International Master William Addison of San Francisco in an oldfashioned Center Counter Game.

The upward-driving stock market stopped to refuel yesterday morning, then picked up momentum in a dramatic spurt toward the finish that saw it finally crest above the 800 level on the Dow-Jones industrial average.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) The Justice Department today accused the Virginia Electric and Power Company, the nation's 19th largest utility, and its union of discriminating against Negroes in hiring and promotion policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Senate debate on the provision of $290 million for the further development of the SST is part of a process that is more important than the outcome of the vote. This is not because the issue itself is negligible but because it is vital to advanced societies to make political decisions on great technological questions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today details of its new program, to begin in February, of purchasing conventional mortgages.

Mrs. Marianne Bier Keating, widow of John G. Keating, was married here yesterday afternoon to Charles Stoneham McCarty, bandleader of the Brass Instrumentalists, a classical and jazz group. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Iams by Civil Court Judge Leonard H. Sandler.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 2 Ulysses S. Grant the leader of a New Mexico hippie commune near Albuquerque who unnsuccessfully ran for Governor last month, is being sought by the police in the gunshot deaths of two commune residents last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Al, Nick, Pete and Quentin went to an expensively decorated restaurant for lunch. The food was just as expensive as the decor and almost as tasty.
In a series of executive changes at investment firms announced yesterday, Jerome S. Hardy was elected president and chief operating officer of the Dreyfus Corporation.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 Greece's military-backed Government issued a decree today making correspondents of the foreign press, radio or television, whether Greeks or foreigners, liable to heavy prison terms and fines in Greece for "disseminating false reports."

DETROIT, Dec. 2 On one of those nights that coaches have nightmares about, the Knicks went from bad to worse to miserable tonight and took a 101-82 thrashing from the Detroit Pistons before a jubilant crowd of 10,656 at Cobo Arena.

The housing bill approved by the Senate and the companion measure pending in the House provide new substantial Federal help for both public and private corporations to develop entire new communities, the so-called "new towns" which have long been familiar in Britain and Scandinavia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 An army psychologist told a Senate investigating panel today that more than half the enlisted men in a survey of drug abuse in South Vietnam acknowledged having used marijuana at least once and that one in six was a "habituated user."
