Three cakes were waiting downstairs in New York University's Alumni Gym last night in anticipation of Lou Rossini's 300th victory as a coach, and Rory Guma, a 5foot-8-inch senior, put the icing on them with one jump shot.
Night service on the Staten Island ferry will be reduced starting Sunday as part of the city's economy measures, the Transportation Administration announced yesterday.

HUMBOLDT, Tenn., Dec. 3 (AP) Jesse Hill Ford, the novelist, was bound over to the Gibson County grand jury today on a homicide charge in the fatal shooting Nov. 16 of a young soldier on Mr. Ford's estate here.

"I guess we're off to a slow start this season," said Carol Schoenknecht of Mount Snow in southern Vermont. "We're still selling tickets for two of our lower lifts but so far the elements haven't cooperated with us much."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The White House announced today that President Nixon had issued new guidelines to prevent recurrence of an incident like one last week in which a defecting Soviet seaman was refused sanctuary aboard a Coast Guard cutter.

The truth, and nothing but the truth, is what Tiffany Co. wants from its employes these days and, to make sure that it gets it, everyone who is being hired is asked to submit immediately to a polygraph test. The hope is that this will keep down theft in a store that could be a paradise for the acquisitive all those small items, such as diamonds, with big, big prices.

The most notable Tennessee Williams play, "The Glass Menagerie," was produced in 1945, and ever since the playwright has been endeavoring in different ways to capture the sensitivity and ordeals of ordinary people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) The White House said today that Martin G. Castillo, deputy staff director for the Commission on Civil Rights, was leaving his post.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Dec. 3 (UPI) Solomon Terfa scored a tie-breaking goal today to give University of California, Los Angeles, a 4-3 victory over Howard University and put the Bruins into the National Collegiate soccer final.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Dec. 3 Fred H. Snow, a major canner of clam chowder, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The White House confirmed today that Sir Robert Thompson, the British expert on guerrilla warfare, had made a recent trip to South Vietnam for President Nixon and had submitted his findings to him in a secret report.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 President Luis Echeverrfa Alvarez invited a prominent group of Western industrialists and bankers today to invest in Mexico and promote exports to the United States and Europe.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company will acquire an interest of nearly 25 per cent in Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., a leading investment banking concern, under the terms of an agreement announced yesterday.

The Council on Foreign Relations has announced that it is offering a resident fellowship to an American foreign correspondent for the academic year that begins on Sept. 1, 1971, and ends on June 1, 1972.

Pat Ast caused a bit of a stir as she bounded down the runway at Halston's spring fashion show yesterday, and not just because of her frizzy hair. Most of the mannequins had frizzy hair. But most of them had lean, race-horse size 6 or 8 figures. Pat wears about a size 40.

Most people come home from a Caribbean cruise with duty-free Scotch and a straw hat, but 95 cruise passengers docked here on the Santa Paula yesterday with something different with what they hope is a new lease on life.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 The New York Yankees wrote off an experiment today when they traded Bill Robinson to the Chicago White Sox in a minor-league exchange for Barry Moore, a left-handed pitcher.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 1 There is an old Bengali saying: If you come across a Pubjabi and a snake, kill the Punjabi first.
SEATTLE, Dec. 3 (AP) Mrs. Mary Bard Jensen, author of several books, died Sunday after a stroke. She was 66 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3 Six persons, including Tom Dunn, the television newscaster, and Arnold Mann, a New York City real estate broker, were indicted here today for their alleged participation in fraudulent mortgage-loan transactions.

If the New York Jets' game with the Oakland Raiders boils down to a last-minute fieldgoal attempt by George Blanda, don't watch the 43-year-old geriatric marvel. Instead, watch Steve Tannen, the Jets' rookie cornerback who has emerged as their kick-blocking specialist.

State Supreme Court Justice David Ross ordered an Orlando, Fla., cosmetics concern yesterday do offer a total of $3.8million in reimbursements to 1,604 New York State residents who had bought sales franchises from it.

Ken Drake, vice president for sales of Rose-Magwood Productions (which makes commercials mostly), is just back from two weeks in the Soviet Union during which he spent two hours with a couple of Moscow agency men. This gives him more right than most to speak with authority on the Russian advertising scene.

Silence is golden in the 90seat theater at Anthology Film Archives, the new tenant in the ground-floor north wing of the New York Shakespeare Festival Theater complex at 425 Lafayette Street. And the new showcase, in an experimental innovation geared to provide unbroken concentration on the art of film, has the seats to guarantee the silence.
Mayor Lindsay cited the city' fiscal problems yesterday as major obstacles to decentralizing government and shifting some power from City Hall to local neighborhoods.

A report by the Board of Correction to Mayor Lindsay asserted yesterday that a prisoner found dead in a cell at the Tombs had hanged himself but urged a criminal investigation of the events surrounding his solitary confinement.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Dec. 3 Frederick Deane Goodwin Ribble, dean of the University of Virginia Law School from 1939 to 1963, died here today at the age of 72.

The Sanitation Department, which tows away thousands of abandoned cars every year, reported yesterday that it had towed away its first abandoned boat a 30-foot cabin cruiser beached in front of an auto-repair shop in the Bronx.

BUFFALO, Dec. 3 Miss Susan Beckwith Blaine and John Bale Nesbitt plan to be married. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Blaine, parents of the bride-to-be, whose fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl G. Nesbitt.
ATHENS, Dec. 3 The Government apparently declined to apply legal sanctions against "spreading false rumors" abroad only to Greek nationals among the correspondents of foreign news media in Athens.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. Billy Haughton, the star reinsman who left here last Saturday with the intention of doing no more driving this season, has changed his mind. From Pompano Park Fla., where he has been breaking the colts and fillies among the 126 standardbreds Haughton has quartered there, he sent word today that he would return tomorrow and devote most of the weekend to driving in two sports.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 A funeral service will be held tomorrow afternoon in the chapel of the Highland Park Cemetery here for Albert Ayler, who emerged in the 1960's as one of the most prominent musicians in the avant-garde jazz movement. He was 36 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 Two freshman Senators proposed today a series of relatively minor changes in Senate customs and procedures that, they said, would enable the chamber to operate much more effectively.

John W. Mecom Sr., the multi-millionaire Texas oilman, in a surprise development, disclosed last night that he and his wife, Mary Elizabeth, had asked the Federal Court in Shreveport, La., for permission to file for what he termed "a personal reorganization."

The broad understanding Israel is seeking with the United States before resuming peace talks with the Arabs is in the interest of both countries. Premier Golda Meir's lengthy letter to President Nixon and the visit to Washington next week by Defense Minister Moshe Dayan signify that Israel is on the verge of returning to the talks, as the United States has asked.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) Neil W. Kelleher, a Republican As semblyman from Troy, denounced the Ali-Bonavena match today as "a disgrace to the people of New York State."
The United States Trust Company of New York announced yesterday that Charles W. Buek, president, would assume the additional function of chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1.

Thomas B. Campion, who has been director of operations for The New York Times since 1967, will become vice chancellor for administrative services at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst on Dec. 22.

In a move to adjust to market conditions, the Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday it was reducing prices of general purpose polyethylene packaging resins and garment bag resins from 15 cents to 13.5 cents a pound.

Money and bank credit expanded at a moderate pace during the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday showed. But the demand for business loans at the major New York City banks, which normally surges at this time of year, was notably weak, as it has been for some time.

The University of Jacksonville basketball team has scored 284 points in its first two games, but it's difficult to determine just how good the Dolphins really are.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 (Reuters) American battle deaths declined by half last week to 32, the United States command said today.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 The four auto makers reported today only 138,556 sales of American cars in the final third of November, down 38 per cent from 223,873 a year ago. Only the American Motors Corporation showed a Nov. 21-30 sales gain over last year and that was because the company was hurt by strikes last year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 President Nixon reportedly plans to reorganize Republican political operations so as to divorce day-by-day politics from the Presidential staff.
Cliff Richey and Arthur Ashe of the United States placed first and second but Australians dominated the final standing in the Pepsi Grand Prix of Tennis.

BUFFALO, Dec.3 "There's been a slow, almost unobservable, erosion in all the Roman Catholic schools in the state," said Msgr. Leo E. Hammerl, superintendent of Catholic Schools for the Diocese of Buffalo. "Now we have a big, tangible example, as opposed to little closings here and there."
BERLIN Airplane hijackings, street battles, shortlived civil wars have become everyday events. And with the growing violence the terrible simplifiers have made their appearance.
Miss Alma Mary Phipps and Reginald Farr were married here Wednesday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Kenneth O. Jones.

The stock market's eyepopping rally kept rolling forward yesterday to the amazed delight of Wall Street observers who used such words as "phenomenal" and "astonishing" to describe the latest turn of events.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Democratic leadership of Congress called upon President Nixon today to impose a temporary freeze on wages and prices while the Administration worked out a long-term plan for curbing inflation.
WARSAW, Dec. 3 Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish leader, indicated today that the Warsaw Pact meeting had endorsed the present trend toward better relations with West Germany.
The New York Philharmonic has announced the appointment of two new members of the orchestra, Toby Saks, cello, and Michele Saxon, double bass. Both were born and trained in New York.
About 150 building manitenance workers employed in city urban-renewal areas demonstrated downtown yesterday to protest the discharge of eight employes on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 A Special House subcommittee has concluded that there are no grounds for impeachment of Associate Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

When Earl Cheit resigned as executive vice chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley last year to take his sabbatical leave, he had three goals in mind: more reading and writing, getting reacquainted with his family, and picking up his handball game.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., showed earnings declines of 2 per cent in the third quarter and 22.6 per cent for the first nine months this year although sales increased 21.9 per cent and 15.6 per cent, respectively, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 3 (AP) An unmarried woman officer, who went to court to oppose Air Force attempts to discharge her because of her pregnancy, gave birth today to a 6-pound daughter.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 3 When Howard Hughes left here on Thanksgiving eve, he went to Paradise Island, the resort about 100 yards off Nassau in the Bahamas.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 3 The Post Office, reorganized in August, plans to sell $250-million of bonds in the fall of 1971 the first of $10-billion of postal revenue bonds authorized by the Government.

Miss Olivia Hedelind Rutter, who is with the Deltakos division of the J. Walter Thompson Company, plans to be married in the spring to John Garrit Petrasch, an assistant cashier in the petroleum department of the First National City Bank.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 3 Martin J. Remsen, a Wall Street lawyer who retired to become a dairy farmer and gave $1,750,000 to Dartmouth College for its medical school, died here today. Mr. Remsen, a long-time resident of Garden City, L.I., was 78 years old.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman said today that he remembered that the jury in the Chicago conspiracy trial had reported itself deadlocked the day it began deliberations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 There is a break in the rhythm of the Government now. The President is working quietly behind the headlines on the budget, which will carry him through 1971 and almost up to the nominating conventions of 1972. It is too early to say that he is changing the policies of his first two years in office, but he is clearly reviewing and modifying them, and looking to the future.
RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 3 Joseph Lewis Wheeler, a librarian and consultant on the construction and administration of more than 175 libraries in the United States, died here today. He was 86 years old.
The broad decline in the cost of money that has swept through the nation's financial markets this year benefited the man in the street yesterday.

The building in Montreal where the transfer of James R. Cross was concluded yesterday was declared Cuban territory temporarily "as the result of an agreement between the two governments concerned," a Canadian Goverment spokesman said yesterday.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 The seven leaders of the Soviet bloc indicated today that East Germany had been forced to give ground on the issue of Western rights in West Berlin.

The city's 10,000 welfare workers were instructed by their union representatives last night to reduce their case loads on Monday in a "job action" against the Department of Social Services to protest the closing of five welfare centers.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 3 Paul D. Meadlo, who once told a national television audience that he had shot unarmed Vietnamese civilians at Mylai because it "just seemed like it was the natural thing to do at the time," was temporarily taken into custody by the military police today after he refused to testify at the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

Miss Harriet Sigrid Somers Alper was married yesterday afternoon to Richard A. Otto, son of Mrs. and Mrs. Samuel K. Otto of New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at the home here of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Somers Alper.

CONCEPCION, Chile, Dec. 3 (AP) Classes were suspended and tension was high at the University of Concepcion today after one student died and another was wounded in a clash between young Communists and ultra-leftists.
The December dinner dance of the American Cancer Society's Junior Board will be held on Tuesday at the Rainbow Room.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 A Federal Judge, saying that "integration for integration's sake alone is self-defeating," ordered today a new type of desegregated, decentralized school system for the city of Detroit.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 3 (AP) Billy Backus, who quit boxing in 1965 because he couldn't win, scored a stunning upset tonight by stopping Jose Napoles on cuts in the fourth round to win the world welterweight championship.

Raymond Lavon died in solitary confinement in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men (M.H.D.), otherwise known as The Tombs, in the late evening of Nov. 3, 1970. He had been an inmate of that institution since Jan. 10, 1970.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 Eight months of intense lobbying culminated in victory for a coalition of conservationists today when the Senate voted 52 to 41 to strike down the sppersonic transport.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP) Ruth Law Oliver, a pioneer woman aviator, died here Tuesday. She was 79 years old.

Four women who for the most part teach and perform in northern New Jersey make up the Llewellyn Chamber Players, which made its debut on Wednesday night at the New York Cultural Center. They are Nancy Clarke, violin; Lori Berkowitz, viola; Mary Wortreich, cello, and Dorothy Priesing, piano.

When the American sculptor William Zorach died in 1966 at the age of 79, he had long been established as an important figure in the art of his time. His work was represented in more than 50 American museums, and his name was a fixture in the standard texts and chronologies of modern American art. Few American sculptors of his generation had received so much attention and acclaim.
Major producers of methanol, an important chemical intermediate going into fibers, coatings, adhesives and antifreeze, announced yesterday that they would lower prices beginning Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 4 Lord Thomson, publisher of the ailing Times of London and chairman of the Thomson Organization, Ltd., tonight announced the appointment of his son, Kenneth, to serve as joint chairman of the publishing empire.
ALPINE, N.J. While "For Men Only" are fighting words these days, the Tamcrest Country Club opened here last summer with just such a membership restriction.
Frank Reynolds, in his last appearance yesterday as the evening news anchorman for the American Broadcasting Company, said of his transfer from the job: "I would prefer to pick my own time to leave."
Dr. Theodore H. Lang, deputy superintendent for personnel, will leave the city school system Jan. 31 to become a professor of education at Baruch College of City University.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) Consumer installment debt declined $82-million in October, the first drop in more than nine years, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

The RCA Corporation has become the latest major casualty in the field of solid-state component manufacturing. The giant electronics company said it planned to phase out solidstate operations in its Cincinnati, Ohio, plant next February.

The 16th week of the Metropolitan Opera season will be highlighted by a revival of Offenbach's "La Perichole" in a nonsubscription performance on New Year's Eve. Cyril Ritchard, who staged the production, will return in his familiar part of Don Andres.

John W. Mecom Sr., the Texas oil man, said yesterday that he and his wife, Mary Elizabeth, would "personally guarantee" the obligations of their privately held United States Oil of Louisiana group, now in the hands of a bankruptcy trustee.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 4 Wheelock Whitney, chief executive officer of Dain, Kalman Quail, Inc., a Minneapolis-based securities concern, was elected today as president of the Investment Bankers Association for 1971. He succeeds Andrew J. Melton Jr., chairman of the executive committee of Smith, Barney Co., Inc.

The annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar in Old Greenwich, Conn., an event that has not lost its style and charm from its first to the current 13th edition, will end its run today with a replenished stock of collectibles, on sale from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

His name had an aristocratic ring. And perhaps better than anyone else he exemplified E.M. Forster's "aristocracy of the sensitive, the considerate and the plucky." A pioneer of the sky in the predawn of the space age, he breathed the romance of the air as no one had done before or has since.
Three shotgun blasts were fired into an East Harlem church by unknown assailants last night while services were being held. No one was injured.

We all know that when the lights go green, every intersection in New York is barely more active than a parking lot. We are all aware that this mass of cars belches out exhaust containing, among other things, lead, carbon monoxide, and soot (which is approximately what "particulate matter" boils down to). Various ailments result from the exhausted air we breathe in New York.
The Armco Steel Corporation yesterday became the first major domestic steel producer to announce that it would build a direct-reduction plant in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Defense Department announced today that it would begin, probably next month, to move 13,000 tons of nerve and mustard gas stored on Okinawa to oJhnston Island, an atoll in the mid-Pacific.
Federal agents and the local police were investigating yesterday the cutting of cables at 30 locations in Queens Thursday night that knocked out service to 10,000 telephones.
City detectives posing as drunks arrested six men and women outside an Upper East Side bank before dawn yesterday and charged them with attempting to fire-bomb the building.

CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., Dec. 4 (UPI) Jerry McGee, who learned to play golf on his stepfather's nine-hole course on an Ohio farm, shot a six-under-par 65 today to take a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $125,000. Coral Springs open golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) Msgr. Mykolas Krupavicius, president of the Supreme Lithuanian Liberation Committee, died today in suburban Cicero after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 James Farmer, who is the Nixon Administration's most prominent Negro official, and the two chiefs of a White House committee on opportunities for the Spanish-speaking are resigning, the latter because of what they describe as weariness from dealing with bureaucrats.
OTTAWA, Dec. 4 (Reuters) New unemployment benefits were announced here in a special budget presented to the House of Commons by Finance Minister Edear J. Benson.

PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 3 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles led the field today with one game remaining in the knockout round robin. Fischer, who has held the United States chess championship eight times, had 12 points. Yefim Geller, of the Soviet Union was second with 12, and Robert Huebner of West Germany third with 11 .

Ill Will is festering on a thumb of land jutting into Little Neck Bay that has seemed almost idyllic since the turn of the century to city residents who also want serene living.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 4 (AP) Howard Hughes, the multimillionaire who is Nevada's biggest casino owner, is reported to be in the Bahamas on a secret business trip involving the $25-million Coral Harbour development on New Providence Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board formally announced today a series of new policies designed to make 1971 "housing's year" in the United States, according to the board's chairman, Preston Martin.
A Queens school district superintendent yesterday withdrew the charge of criminal trespass he had brought against a principal who came to her school last month in defiance of his order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 President Nixon has reportedly given Premier Golda Meir renewed assurances that the United States will not allow Israel to be put at a diplomatic or military disadvantage if Arab-Israeli talks are resumed.

ANMOORE, W.Va., Dec. 4 The Union Carbide Corporation became liable today for about $400,000 in new taxes here over the next few years, and Buck Gladden, the Mayor of this one-ompany factory town of 960 persons, called it a blow to "corporate colonialism."

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 The Soviet Union tonight charged the North Atlantic Treaty Council with creating "artificial obstacles" to an improved atmosphere in Europe by in sisting on a Berlin settlement before steps can be taken for convening a European security conference.

An alternative to communal living, together with a concept of day care centers organized on a family pattern, rather than age groups, is in the experimental stages among a small numher of families in Sweden.

CAIRO, Dec. 4 A somewhat mysterious controversy over United States U-2 reconnaissance flights along the Suez Canal, which Washington insists have been halted, was intensified today by the Government of the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) The House minority leader, Gerald R. Ford, said today that efforts to impeach Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas were "far from finished" despite a judiciary subcommittee report that found no grounds for such action.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 4 No Brag Just Fact, owned by Edwin F. Richards, stepped up in class today and scored his third straight triumph, taking the one mile Thwarted Purse at Laurel Race Course. His margin was six lengths.

Mahon Bishop, who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, has a cultivated to somewhat superficial approach to lieder singing. He looks the part, and now and then sounds it, too. But neither the baritone's vocal equipment nor his artistic temperament really lived up to appearances.
James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted yesterday that a resurgence in consumer demand next year would lift the automobile industry to records.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 The Supreme Court, with which President Nguyen Van Thieu has clashed frequently in the last year, today elected a court president more to his liking.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 4 A sudden cold snap, in which the temperature had dropped 26 degrees in four hours, assured the opening of the snowmobile racing season tomorrow at Monticello Raceway. The series of Saturday-Sunday meets continues until mid-March, with races running from 11 A.M, to 4 P.M.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 Eddie Maple moved into second place in the jockey standing at Liberty Bell Race Track today with a pair of triumphs that raised his total to 12.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Unemployment continued to rise in November, reaching a total of 4.6 million persons and a rate of 5.8 per cent of the labor force. The rate was the highest in seven and a half years.

The Travelers Insurance Companies announced yesterday the resignation, effective immediately, of J. Doyle De Witt, its $225,000-a-year chairman. Mr. De Witt, who is 68 years old, will continue as a director.

The Academy for Educational Development, a nonprofit research and consulting organization with offices in New York and Washington, announced yesterday the formation of a management support service to help colleges and universities to cope with rising operational costs.

A Swiss Team Championship under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the New York Hilton. Sessions of play are scheduled today at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.

Those who love Bruckner's music must have had a wonderful time in Philharmonic Hall on Thursday evening. Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, starting his stint as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, led the orchestra in a performance of the Bruckner Fifth Symphony, all hour-plus of it. The Fifth is one of the less-played of that composer's nine.

Scores of patrolmen assigned to the East 67th Street station house, bitter over publication of a statement made by the special commission investigating police corruption, refused to patrol the streets of the Upper East Side for about four hours yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 (AP) Fire fighters began pumping sea water on a cluster of flaming oil wells today, hoping to cool the blaze enough for experts to move in to try to put it out.
Senator Barry M. Goldwater charged American industry yesterday with what he called its greatest challenge producing better quality defense equipment at less cost.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, recently appointed chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, saw two of his home-breds visit the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday.

Mrs. Frances Seifert Gums, wife of the Rev. Reuben H. Gums, director of radio and television for the Council of Churches of New York City, died of cancer Thursday at her home, 615 West 145th Street. She was 40 years old.

BERNE, Dec. 4 Smiling and relaxed after two telephone calls from her husband, Mrs. Cross said today that she hoped to have a Christmas holiday in Switzerland after a reunion in London with her husband tomorrow.

ROME, Dec. 4 Italian finance guards, the enforcement agency of the Finance Ministry, put official seals today on all entrances to the Rome headquarters of the International Investors Group, an offshore mutual fund organization that suspended yesterday all sales and redemptions in shares in its major fund, the Real Estate Fund of America.

HOUSTON, Dec. 4 A report released here today by the American Jewish Committee said that "considerably more systematic implementation" should be given to the Declaration on the Jews adopted by the Ecumenical Council Vatican II, although it found some positive developments.

George C. Wallace, in his first public appearance in New York since his 1968 Presidential campaign, told a sympathetic audience at the John Birch Society's annual dinner last night that the "silent majority" should be silent no longer.

Counselors at the city's three juvenile detention centers in the Bronx walked off the job yesterday after a dispute over security against assaults by the children. A union spokesman said that all 278 counselors had participated in the walkout.
Miss Hildegarde Wenning Goepp, daughter of Mrs. John Wells Davidson of Princeton, N.J., was married on Nov. 27 in London to Terry Meech, assistant director of the Mountview Theatre School of London.

Philip N. Buckminster, vice president Europe, has been named to undertake special assignments on the staff of the president at the Chrysler Corporation. H. Arthur Wormet who has been staff executive international group, has been named to assume the duties previously held by Mr. Buckminster and as managing director Europe will be responsible for directing the administration of all Chrysler activities in Europe.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 (UPI) Charlie Greene, a former University of Nebraska track star, equaled the men's best listed indoor world time of 6.5 seconds in the 60-meter dash tonight and Heide Rosendahl of West German set a mark of 8 seconds for the women's 60meter hurdles at an international meet.
LONDON, Dec. 4 Backers of the Concorde, the BritishFrench supersonic transport, were worried today by the Senate vote against funding of the American SST.
Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations," given for the first time this season by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, is a work of both biography and comment.

A gadget that should be awarded the prize for being the most contrived and startling antique of the year is one of many interesting glass ceramic and furniture items in the extensive Channing Hare collection, which is now on display, until auction on Dec. 11 and 12, at the ParkeBernet Galleries.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 4 Brisk westerly winds pushed a large oil slick out to sea today and diminished the danger it has posed for three days to Florida beaches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Prominent scientists, philanthropists, businessmen and labor leaders urged Congress today to mount a multibilliondollar Federal cancer crusade on the magnitude of the Manhattan project to build the atomic bomb and the Apollo project to put a man on the moon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) President Nixon announced today the names of 12 directors of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation he plans to nominate, starting a publicprivate venture to promote new American investments in developing countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 House opponents of the supersonic transport opened a drive today to retract early next week the House's endorsement of the project, even before conferees meet to consider a compromise on the $290-million appropriation rejected yesterday in the Senate.

The campaign of 1970 so strident and yet so empty failed to meet the issues of the seventies. It was as though there were no war, no inflation, no recession, no unemployment, and no cities in deep trouble. The campaign substituted tough talk for real debate and double talk for real programs.
HONG KONG, Dec. 4 Pope Paul VI headed homeward from Asia today after addressing a "message of unity and of love" to Chinese everywhere at a mass less than 20 miles from the Chinese Communist border.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (Reuters) An armed gang hijacked an airline truck carrying $250,000 worth of gold bullion at Hyde Park corner London's busiest traffic junction at the height of the rush hour tonight, the police said.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4 (AP) A strike by Local 413 of the teamsters union today closed the two daily newspapers here, The Columbus Evening Dispatch and The Columbus Citizen-Journal.
True to his style as an original, Muhammad Ali sparred 12 rounds yesterday only three days before his Madison Square Garden bout with Oscar Bonavena on Monday night.

Pharmacies throughout the country reported yesterday that sales of vitamin C were booming in response to Dr. Linus Pauling's recent advocacy of large doses of the vitamin as a means of preventing and curing the common cold.

The American Stock Exchange announced disciplinary actions yesterday against the Garvin Bentel Corporation, a member house, and two individuals for violating exchange rules through the improper use of certain trading-floor records of another member firm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Senator Albert Gore, seeking "one last notch on my gun," opened his last stand on the Senate floor today by opposing an Administration bill to increase United States contributions to four international financial institutions.

"The classic look will come back when they get finished with carnival time," Jack Lazar remarked in his office yesterday. He's the man responsible for the Kimberly fashions that women collect with the same devotion and passion they used to devote to cashmere sweaters.

From the outset, Portuguese Government authorities categorically denied any involvement in the recent commando-type attack on Guinea. "The imagination of the people of the Republic of Guinea has no limits," a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Lisbon said scornfully.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Department of Justice announced today that it would ask the Supreme Court to review the case of Earl Caldwell, a New York Times reporter onvicted of contempt by a Federal District Court whose conviction was then reversed on appeal.
Joel Krosnick, the cellist who made his recital debut at Town Hall on Thursday night, showed why he has earned respect as a valued ensemble player around town over the past few years.
Given a choice, Phoebe Neville would opt for less movement rather than more in a dance. She is an excellent allegro dancer but prefers to work in an adagio tempo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Senator Birch Bayh is considering running for President in 1972. He is not certain that he is fully qualified, but he is sure that he is better qualified than Richard Nixon.
SALINAS, Calif., Dec. 4 Cesar Chavez went to jail today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 The major leagues rejected a plan today to bring all umpires under one roof and took steps to schedule part of next year's World Series at night for the first time in baseball history.

Tektronix, Inc., the world's leading producer of cathode ray oscilloscopes, which are electronic testing and measuring instruments, showed a larger decline in sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 14 than in the previous three months, according to the company's report issued yesterday from its Oregon headquarters.
The Polytechnic Data Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Chicago charging the Xerox Corporation with violation of the antitrust laws and asking $30million in damages.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Dec. 4 Dr. Joseph P. Nelson, a physician here for 25 years, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 60 years old and had been ill for several years.

Rarely has a strike made less sense than the one that began taking all the city's unionized taxicabs off the streets last night. Both the union and the fleet owners recognize that the money limits for any strike settlement are fixed by the fare increases recommended three weeks ago by Mayor Lindsay.
The London stock market closed mixed in quiet trading yesterday, but prices were a bit lower, reflecting a lack of followthrough after a firm start in line with Wall Street.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 4 (UPI) A Florida judge won permission today to carry a pistol, declaring he planned to "take somebody with me" if anyone tried to shoot up his courtroom.

Police sources said yesterday that Sharon Krebs, one of six suspects arrested in an alleged bank bombing plot, had been employed by RAT, the underground newspaper that closely follows revolutionary movements.
Bayard Rustin, executive director of the A. Philip Randolph Institute, will be guest of honor at a dinner Dec. 14 at the New York Hilton.

BUFFALO, Dec. 4 Donnie May received his National Basketball Association championship ring tonight at half-time of the game between the New York Knicks, with whom he played last season, and the Buffalo Braves, the team that claimed him last spring in the expansion draft.
Irving Allen of Monroe Street, Hewlett Neck, L.I, died Thursday in University Hospital after open-heart surgery. He was 64 years old.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 4 (UPI) A team of snake-bite specialists were among the greeters gathered at the airport today for the visit of Pope Paul VI.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 4 The North Atlantic alliance formally declared today that even the first steps toward an EastWest conference on European security, as sought by the Soviet bloc, must await a satisfactory conclusion to the fourpower talks on Berlin's future.
A first-grade pupil at Public School 11 in Queens shot a 7-year-old classmate in the hand yesterday with a 22-caliber pistol he said he had found near the school.

The Police Department will not be allowed to station uniformed patrolmen outside the Club Orgy, 110 West 24th Street, under an agreement reached in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday between the city and the club's lawyer.

The Workshop of the Players Art (W.P.A.) is a permanent theater with its own company of actors presenting a full season of plays off off Broadway. This year the W.P.A. is in a new home, on the Bowery (between Second and Third Streets). Outside it looks like a shabby storefront, but inside it is a comfortable, flexible theater.

The kettle of pre-Christmas social activity that has been simmering since the Nine O'Clocks' ball at the Plaza Tuesday came to a boil again last night when Mrs. Albert D. Lasker threw open her townhouse for some 100 of her closest friends.

Sidney Goodman, who is having his seventh one-man show at the Dintenfass Gallery, 18 East 67th Street, is an American figurative painter who looked very good in his first show and has looked better and better ever since. With half a dozen other painters across the country as leaders whose success has encouraged increasing numbers of followers, Mr. Goodman represents a solidly established school of American realism.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 (UPI) George Thompson scored 35 points and John Brisker 28 to lead the Pittsburgh Condors to a 117-111 victory tonight over the Memphis Pros.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 4 (AP) A Cambodian military spokesman reported today that the Communist command was pouring reinforcements into the Cambodian Government's northern front.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 4 If tomorrow afternoon's nationally-televised game between Texas and Arkansas is decided late in the fourth quarter by less than a touchdown, it will come as no shock to the sellout crowd in this state and college-football capital.
A fire poured dense smoke through a 49-story midtown office building yesterday, killing three persons and injuring 39 of hundreds of persons trapped on the upper floors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Oil supplies available to the nation will increase soon by at least 300,000 barrels and by as much as 500,000 barrels a day because of the decisions announced tonight by the President, Interior Department officials disclosed.

BRUSSELS Like some intricate Richard Strauss opera, with characters and symbols operating on different levels and the stage machinery creaking, the negotiations to bring Britain into the European Economic Community are slowly unveiling the realities. What it all means at this point may depend on where the observer sits.

The New York City Housing Authority, which runs lowincome public housing, announced plans yesterday to deposit $10-million in several banks here with the condition that the money be used for loans to businesses owned by blacks and Puerto Ricans.
SANDHURST, England, Dec. 3 By 7:30 each morning the playing fields of Sandhurst are alive with the sounds of trotting cadets and a drill sergeant's sharp bellow: "lef'righ'-lef' righ'-lef' righ'!"

It used to be that we talked about the weather; today, the subject is crime. In New York, as in most large cities, it's a rare social gathering at which somebody can't report a mugding, holdup or burglary if not to himself, at least to a friend.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 4 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks, led by Lew Alcindor's 10 points in overtime, defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 128-122, tonight after scoring two baskets in the last three seconds of regulation play to force the extra period.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 (AP) South Vietnamese infantrymen pushed deeper into the U Minh Forest, 140 miles southwest of Saigon, today and reported 59 Vietcong killed in the first three days of the 7,000man drive into the enemy stronghold.

NELSON, N.H., Dec. 4 Mrs. Arthur Iselin Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Iselin, to Jonathan Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hall of Wilton, Conn., and Castine, Me. The wedding is planned for Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The State Department conceded today that "misunderstandings" on all sides may have led to its "preliminary" decision that Yehudi Menuhin had lost his United States citizenship for having accepted a honorary Swiss citizenship.
Soybean futures prices advanced sharply in the early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but some of the gain was trimmed in a late wave of profit taking.
LONDON The tenant at 10 Downing Street is one of Britain's most eligible bachelors, but recently a trim, attractive woman in her forties has been spending considerable time in his apartment.
The discouraging business of trying to cope with pollution continues and grows in fervor with each passing day.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 4 Sonny Dove scored 36 points, including 9 in the last quarter, to lead the New York Nets to a 115-110 American Basketball Association victory tonight over the Floridians. It was the Nets' fourth triumph in a row.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4 James Richard Cross, who was rescued yesterday after two months in the captivity of kidnappers, was declared in "excellent health" today and prepared to return to Britain tomorrow.
Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, declared yesterday that school decentralization had "no value at all in terms of educational change."

The stock market, continuing to amaze and confound 30 million shareowners, boomed yesterday to its best level of 1970 as it rounded out the heaviest trading week in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. "Breathtaking," said a Wall Streeter who had run out off words.

The Government of the United States has justly imposed heavy fines on three major oil companies for negligently polluting the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. It now remains to be seen whether it will deal as drastically with another culprit of the same sort, namely, the Government of the United States.
President Nixon's speech before the National Association of Manufacturers marks a decisive turn in his Administration's economic policies.
The city's 36,000 unionized taxi drivers went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, leaving hundreds of thousands of riders to find other means of transportation.

When radio station WBAIFM's five-day, nonstop reading of Leo Tolstoy's "War and Peace" was temporarily thrown off the air for an hour and 14 minutes on Thursday morning because of a faulty remote cable connection, only the station's listeners became upset.

Herbert L. Barnet, former chairman of the board of the Pepsi-Cola Company and a director of the parent company, Pepsico, Inc., died at New York University Hospital on Thursday evening after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 898 Park Avenue and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 4 The Seoul District Criminal Court imposed death sentences today on two American soldiers convicted of murdering and robbing a South Korean couple last March at Tongduchon, 25 miles north of Seoul.
A Federal court refused to place blame yesterday for a collision of two airliners five years ago over Carmel, N.Y., in which four persons were killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The White House said today that other commitments made it impossible for President Nixon to be photographed with a 13-year-old child from Wichita, Kan., who appears on a charity fund poster.

ROME, Dec. 4 (UPI) Carlos Duran of Italy survived butts that opened cuts over both eyes and one in the middle of his forehead tonight to regain the European middle weight title with a 15-round decision over Tom Bogs of Denmark.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 (Reuters) Israeli archeologists working in the ancient town of Eshtamao in the Judean wilderness have discovered silver and jewelry believed to be nearly 3,000 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 An Alaska businessman and two Arizona co-inventors were granted patents this week on a method and apparatus for producing race horses capable of optimum ...
The American Stock Exchange scored its seventh consecutive advance yesterday as the list closed with modest gains in lighter volume.

Hundreds of Sicilians are being smuggled into the United States through Canada by organized crime families in the Northeast seeking cheap labor for Mafia-controlled businesses and recruits for underworld duties, Federal law enforcement officials and immigration authorities said yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 Almost from the moment that militant separatists in Quebec kidnapped a British official two months ago, Jerome Choquette, the Justice Minister of Quebec Province, has been in the forefront of the continuing fight against political terrorists.
The new-issue market failed to participate this week as listed stocks soared in heavy trading. Only a few companies made first public offerings, none of them meeting exceptional demand.

DUBLIN, Dec. 4 The Irish Government tonight assumed emergency powers of internment without trial to counter "a secret armed conspiracy" that it accuses of plotting a campaign of kidnapping and lawlessness.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 4 Before a hushed court, a former soldier described today the allebed massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai and said that he had seen First Lieutenant William L. Calley Jr. pour automatic rifle fire into a ditch full of people and "blow the head off" a woman who tried to rise from a pile of corpses.

American Judaism, long divided on the question of government aid to religious schools, is approaching the point of agreement on Federal support for nonpublic schools, according to an influential Jewish scholar here.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) A Federal judge issued a 30day injunction today against a New England railroad seeking to remove itself from the custody of the Penn Central Transportation Company.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 4 Arthur N. Hosking, a magazine publisher, composer and artist, died here Monday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 96 years old, and lived at 75 White Oak Street.

A score of witnesses told a hearing yesterday how they had enrolled in computer training schools with the promise of gaining high-paying jobs, borrowed to pay tuition of up to $1,600 and then received only limited instruction before the schools closed.
The Commonwealth Telephone Company of Virginia announced yesterday that Continental Telephone Corporation has made an offer to buy Commonwealth through an exchange of stock worth about $39-million.

VIENNA, Dec. 4 Dr. Kurt List, the Vienna-born musicologist, conductor and producer of records of classical music, died in Milan on Nov. 16 of cerebral hemorrhage, it was learned here today. His age was 57.

President Nixon pledged last night efforts to move the economy "up to its full potential for growth" and announced a major new effort to reduce prices by relaxing Government restrictions on oil production and imports.
Warren Wells and Fred Biletnikoff come to Shea Stadium tomorrow with 15 touchdown catches between them. If the Jets' rookie cornerback corps has its way, they'll leave with the same numher.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that Japanese television sets were being dumped in the United States market at less than their fair value.

WASHINGTON Dec. 4 (UPI) Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor dismissed today a soldier's charges that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander in Vietnam, had condoned inhuman treatment of prisoners.

Lou Rossini, who coached Columbia's varsity before becoming the head basketball coach at New York University, will be honored for 300 victories in his coaching career before today's meeting between Columbia and N.Y.U. in the second half of a college doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

The New York Social Register, that quasi-official listing, albeit incomplete, of the upper class in the metropolitan area, published its 85th edition yesterday. And for a number of reasons, including marriages and the population explosion, about 600 new listings have been included in the 1971 edition.

As a result of cramped spaces, spiraling real-estate values and more than a little territorial and moral disenchantment, several galleries have moved out of their thick carpeted, expensive mid-Manhattan and uptown locations and sought cheaper, more capacious shelters elsewhere.

SAN JUAN, P.R. Dec. 4 (UPI) The National Conference of State Legislative Leaders approved a resolution today calling for a constitutional convention in 1971 to add a revenue sharing provision for states to the Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 By the time a knock on her hotel room door awakened Debra Jean Sweet again early this morning, she had resigned herself to a sleepless night because of interruptions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Three Coast Guard officers closely associated with the decision to deny political asylum last week to a would-be defector from a Soviet fishing vessel have been relieved of their duties pending the results of an investigation.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec, 5--Miss Marion Lansing Jordan was married here this afternoon to Chester Nimitz Lay, a grandson of the late Admiral of the Fleet Chester W. Nimitz. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

LINDEN, N.J., Sunday, Dec. 6--A series of powerful explosions ripped through a portion of the Humble Oil Refining Company facilities here just after 11 o'clock last night, sending out shock waves felt throughout the metropolitan area.

SAUNAS, Calif., Dec. 5-- Congestion and the other urban evils that drove men to the suburbs are now forcing some California wine makers off what was prime vineyard land and into the wilderness. It may turn out to be the best thing that ever happened to a handful of nationally known wineries.
WASHINGTON--"In attempting to get to the floor today, I had to elbow my way through a swarm of lobbyists in the corridors. It was all I could do to get to the floor."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam is relaxing in Hawaii this weekend at the end of a visit to the United States that, contrary to expectations, proved to be quiet, low-key and uneventful.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5--The first "Freedom Bird" flight carrying soldiers home from the war for two weeks left here today with 200 of the happiest men in Indochina.

Recently, after years of neglect, the poet Louis Zukofsky, whose "Autobiography" is one of this year's most valuable literary events, has come into a certain vogue, especially among younger writers known as the Black Mountain Poets and among their followers.

WASHINGTON--Senator Edmund S. Muskie, as author of most past and pending environmental legislation, has acquired the journalistic sobriquet of 'Mr. Clean." Last week, he told William D. Ruckelshaus, director of the new Environmental Protection Agency: "I hope that you pre-empt the title."
EUTAW, Ala., Dec. 3--If memory serves him correctly, so one ever told the Rev. William McKinley Branch that politics was a more comfortable pursuit than the clergy.

Penn Central commuters whop spend four and five hours getting to work when the New Haven Division breaks down, take heart. Some days, it takes Hanley Norins six or seven hours to get to his job at Young Rubicam on Madison Avenue. But then, Mr. Norins, a vice president and associate creative director of the advertising agency, lives in San Francisco.

One of the few American passenger trains that still breaks even is the handsome Champion between New York and Florida's West Coast, but the new Federal rail passenger plan makes no mention of continuing this service.

John Brodie of the San Francisco 49ers, John Unitas of the Baltimore Colts, Daryle Lamonica of the Oakland Raiders and Bill Nelsen of the Cleveland Browns, all premier National Football League quarterbacks, will compete in the $30,000 American Airlines Astrojet Golf Classic.

AN artist working from black and white prints, but who didn't "research the flags," has once again stressed the obvious: Stamp collectors and students of stamp design begin an immediate study, once a stamp has appeared, to see if it has flaws--in its production or in its design.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5--Today was Constitution Day, a Soviet National holiday, and virtually every newspaper and radio station endorsed Lenin's words that the Soviet political system is "a million times more democratic than any bourgeois democracy."
Jack A. Kalb, president of Oil Accessories, Inc., Long Island City, Queens, died on Friday in Memorial Hospital of a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived at 330 East 43d Street.

WASHINGTON--Because a Democratic liberal--Representative Richard Bolling of Missouri --refused to return from a vacation in the French West Indies, a bill to create a consumer protection agency died last week in the House Rules Committee by a 7to-7 vote.
HARTFORD, Dec. 5--A threeweek strike of one-third to one-half of Hartford's 1,700 elementary and high school teachers is over.

Children's theater, like baby food, seems flavored more for parents than for children. The parents recognize the taste and while not savoring it themselves feel compelled to forcefeed it to their youngsters. The problem is that it is more "childish theater" than theater for children.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4--"Communists seek U.M.W.A. takeover," says the headline in Michael Budzanoski's four-page campaign newspaper. "Previous efforts failed."

HAUPPAUGE, L. I, Dec. 5 --The year-old Suffolk County Legislature, 17 of whose 18 members had no previous countywide political experience, has confounded many political analysts who had forecast that it would prove inept.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5-- Howard R. Hughes's departure from Las Vegas, Nev., last week came amid a big-stakes power struggle between competing executives and lawyers in companies controlled by the billionaire.

It was a stroke of genius to give a new name to the awkwardly designated "Confraternity Version of the Bible" and call it, in its final definitive edition, "The New American Bible." The incentive for the change was, clearly enough, the recent appearance of "The New English Bible."

PARIS. THE same day that director Costa-Gavras returned here from Hollywood, Oscar in hand for "Z," his next film, "The Confession," opened on the Champs-Elysees and began a quite remarkable career of its own.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 5 --North Korea repeatedly demanded today the return of one of its pilots who flew to South Korea in a MIG fighter Thursday.
Even if they win their final three games, the best the Jets can do this season is finish with a .500 record. But if they I beat Oakland today, their spirits will soar to a.t least 1.000.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 5 (AP)--Charles W. Bradbury Sr., a former member of the New York law firm of which President Nixon was also a member, died here today. He was 78 years old.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 3--Farreaching ideas for a Palestinian state--independent of Jordan and Israel, but at peace with both--are gradually taking shape among Arab intellectuals in the Israeli-occupied west-bank area of Jordan.

OTTAWA. "WELL, to be more precise . . ." Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau tented the tips of his fingers and reformulated my question. It was a characteristic phrase. Trudeau exemplifies what might be called the politics of the post-industrial era. Since he took office in 1968, his style has been pragmatic, logical,

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 --Jack Kelly, the Olympic sculler and a son of a multi-millionaire bricklayer, was elected president of the National Amateur Athletic Union today. In his acceptance speech he called for changes that startled older members and gladdened the hearts of the young.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 5-- At dawn last Sunday, as Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens began his fourth week in the presidency, farm workers led by armed strangers occupied a ranch in the green, rolling country of forests and farms in southern Chile.
HONG KONG, Dec. 5--Communist China has asserted sovereignty over the little Senkaku Islands in the East China Sea where Japanese and United States companies have been prospecting for petroleum.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J. Dec. 5 --Edward J. Bindhimmer, 28 years old, was charged with two counts of murder and one count of arson following a fire in a two-family home early today in which Mr. Bindhimmer's wife, Clara, 21, and Glenn Walton, 21, of Peterson, died and Joanne Rogers, 18, of nearby Bradley Beach, was critically burned.

YONKERS, Dec. 5--The engagement of Miss Margery Joan Schwartz to Neal Eric Chalofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Chalofsky of Willingboro, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Schwartz. A wedding next June is planned.
CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., Dec. 5--Lee Trevino and Bill Garrett matched three-underpar 68's: today and moved into a tie for the third-round lead in the $125,000 Coral Springs open golf tournament.
In St. James' Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Penelope Pearce Griswold was married to John Pollard McWilliams Jr. by the Rev. Almus Thorpe.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 5--Mrs. John McCoy Shaner has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Elaine Shaner, to William John Von Klemperer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Von Klemperer of Mill Neck, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 5 (AP)--Maurice Williams, chief of the United States relief operation in East Pakistan, ended a five-day tour of the stormstricken region today and said: "The task is much larger than I had realized."

With the expensive failure of their telescope satellite last week, American space officials are conceding that 1970 is the Russians' year in space, from earth orbit to the moon and perhaps even on Venus.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Defense Department has secretly directed the Air Force to begin a substantial effort to increase the protection of nearly 500 Minuteman missile silos against possible attack.

BOCA RATON, Fla.--In the coconut palms at the glistening pink Boca Raton Hotel and Club, coal-black crows sat hunched amid the fronds last week like prophets of doom, watching a convention of securities-industry leaders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) --A man in Oklahoma City, who is not the handsomest or smartest guy in town, had trouble getting dates.
New York City hopes to have in operation by next spring a terminal in lower Manhattan where seaplane travelers would depart for and arrive from such nearby cities as Boston and Philadelphia.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5--Vice President Ky's current visit to the United States has received little public attention among the Vietnamese, except from his habitual partisans, who are favorably disposed toward the visit, and habitual detractors, who are not.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 5--The Cornell track team erased substantial deficits on the third leg of the mile and two mile relays--the meet's two final events--to clinch a 59-50 victory over St. John's in Barton Hall last night.

Miss Jane Cockburn Houston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Houston of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard French McCready Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCready of Winchester, Ky.
EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Dec. 5 (AP)--St. Louis University retained its National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer championship by beating University of California, Los Angeles, 1-0, today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- Robert Elliot Worden, a partner in Worden Risberg, management consultants, died today in Lankenau Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in suburban Wynnewood.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5--After Mildred Harmon's husband was killed in a boating accident last summer, she decided to have his body cremated. "It just seemed a lot purer," said Mrs. Harmon, who is 30 years old. "I didn't need all of that ritual and all of that sobbing around the gravesite."

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Dec. 5--Every nation has its nightmare. Britain's is unemployment, Germany's is inflation, and America's is probably Pearl Harbor, The successful attack on that island fortress just 29 years ago ended the ancient assumption that America was immune from military attack from across the seas and established the supremacy of the military in Washington for over a quarter of a century.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 6 Colin Adair of Montreal, the 1968 winner, prevailed over John R. Reese of New York in the five-game final today of the 39th gold racquet squash singles tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Eager to accomplish what Joe Frazier could not, Muhammad Ali will be trying for an impressive knockout of Oscar Bonavena tonight in their scheduled 15-round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden before a sellout audience of 19,000.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (UPI) About 5,000 tank truck drivers in 13 states walked off their jobs today. As a result the Middle West faced a possible early shortage of gasoline and fuel.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 The St. Louis Cardinals fumbled and lost today, adding further life to the race for the National Football League playoffs. The Detroit Lions won a difficult game, 16-3, the big play being Mel Farr's 28-yard touchdown run late in the final period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) The White House plans to issue a report early this week on the Administration's investigation of the denial of asylum to a defecting Lithuanian seaman.

Mary McCarty, the brighteyed, rubber-faced comedienne who has been missing from New York for all practical purposes (i.e., viewing purposes) since "Bless You All" closed early in 1951, is back and is in more ways than one bigger than ever.

SALINAS, Calif., Dec. 6 (UPI) Nearly 3,000 Mexican-American farm workers held a candlelight mass tonight outside the jail where Cesar Chavez, director of the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee, is being held.
BONN, Dec. 6 Before boarding his plane to Warsaw this afternoon, Chancellor Brandt declared that the Polish-German treaty he is to sign tomorrow is "an end and a beginning."

Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, will circulate today an interoffice memorandum decrying suggestions that commercial TV is "a once-powerful institution that has passed its prime and is on the way down and out."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 6 Mrs. Adrienne Easton Nordenschild of New Rochelle was married here this afternoon to Dr. Reuven K. Snyderman, a surgeon, Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

At the start of the third week of school this fall the children of Class 4-4 were told by Miss Dorothy Boroughs, their teacher, that a new student was about to join them. His name was Shaun Sheppard and, as the teacher explained it, he was really in the fifth grade but was going to remain in their class.

When Congress convenes in January, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. will not be there and his absence will scarcely be noticed, if at all. Such is the fate of politicians. Most seem to exist only in newspaper headlines and when those headlines are not there to remind us (and them?) of their existences, they are quickly forgotten.

George and Richie and Louise and Bea sat on the mattresses that covered almost the entire bedroom floor in their three-room apartment on Ridge Street on the Lower East Side and told of how it was with their commune.
