LONDON Some months ago, Joan Littlewood announced her intention of staging a documentary comedy, at her newly re-acquired Theater Royal in London's East End, inspired by the Ronan Point disaster.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 6 Israel's Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, told her Cabinet today that additional clarification of United States commitments would be required from President Nixon before Israel could agree to resume peace talks with the United Arab Republic.

In time, the Vancouver Canucks may learn to start a line rush that can travel 90 feet without being broken up. But last night, in the first game of their rivalry with the Rangers, they proved only that they could fight as the New Yorkers overwhelmed them, 4-1.

GARY, Ind., Dec. 6 About 1,500 working-class white ethnics, students, suburban liberals and conservatives labored through the night yesterday and early today to create the Calumet Community Congress, a working-class pressure group designed to gain political, social and economic power.
The 59th annual appeal for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened yesterday with $386,958,60 already on hand from early gifts by 264 contributors.

HELSINKI A devaluation followed up by a riogrously enforced incomes policy, has helped this small northern country achieve what larger states are seeking; full employment combined with price stability.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:
The trim, crisp St. Paul Chamber Orchestra gave a concert at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon. As a performance, it was everything such a concert should be. The program, though, was curiously bland.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Under pressure from the House Commerce Committee; the Federal Communications Commission has ordered an investigation into the activities of Don W. Burden.
Mayor Lindsay and other city officials were censured in absentia yesterday at a forum that was billed as a "housing crimes trial" at Columbia University.
A child-care center in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, named for a soldier who was killed in action in 1968 after only two weeks in Vietnam, was dedicated yesterday.
Most of the state boards primarily responsible for cleaning up the nation's air and water are markedly weighted with representatives of the principal sources of pollution.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 Fighting was reported between Jordanian and commando forces in Ammnan, the capital, and in Kerash, a city in the north, for the second successive day today. Both sides accused the other of having started the fighting.

PARTIES Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers' Union, representing 36,000 drivers and 1,200 inside workers; the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, representing 69 of the 72 fleet owners who operate 6,816 cabs; the City Council, which has the responsibility for setting taxi fares, and Mayor Lindsay, who recommended a fare increase at an earlier stage in negotiations.
A transformer exploded in a basement at 1 Gulf Western Plaza early yesterday, causing a brief flash fire that injured four persons. Fifteen firemen were treated for smoke inhalation and exhaustion.
Adoption agencies across the country report a recent sharp drop in the number of white infants being placed for adoption.

Fred Stewart, an actor and director, died Saturday evening at the Actors Studio, 432 West 44th Street. He would have been 64 years old today. His home was in the Whitby Apartments, 325 West 45th Street.

NAIROBI, Kenya The tall, skinny kid sitting at the next table asks to shake my hand. Then he adds he is a student from Tanzania. He is one of 48 children, he explains, and his father, a village chief, has nine wives.
City Councilman Robert I. Postel has been ruled in violation of the municipal code of ethics the first such finding against a Councilman in the 10 years that New York has had the code.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I, Dec. 6 Miss Ghislaine Rosmarin of Melbourne, Australia, was married here this afternoon to Gilbert Michael Joseph, a law student at Harvard University. The couple met last year in Melbourne, where the bridegroom was attending Monash University as a Fulbright scholar.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Phil Esposito registered his third three-goal performance of the season and became the National Hockey League's first 20-goal scorer tonight in leading the Boston Bruins to a 6-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

Paul Gallico, the novelist, has donated his literary papers to Columbia University. The collection embraces more than 10,000 manuscripts, research notes and papers, among them his early sports columns for The New York Daily News and the original copy of "Mrs. "Arris Goes to Paris," "Thomasina," "The Snow Goose" and "The Poseidon Adventure."
Adoption agencies across the country report a recent sharp drop in the number of white infants being placed for adoption.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 6 An effort to keep cars off the crowded highways by providing luxury bus service between points in Nassau County and Manhattan during the morning and evening rush hours will start tomorrow.
A cold wind blew fiercely down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon but Mayor Lindsay and thousands of other people strolled in the middle of the boulevard enjoying the holiday spectacle of lights.
HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 7 (Reuters) China today accused the United States of three separate acts of aggression against North Korea in the last week.
TOYKO, Dec. 6 (Reuters) Japanese engineers are experimenting with methods of tunneling through mountains with microwaves and with highpressure water jets.

The census is a report on the pattern which the natural tides of population have created. The gerrymander is the politician's effort to rearrange that pattern as cleverly as he can for the benefit of his party.

One of the most noticeable things about the peacock revolution in men's fashion has been its effect an the professional athlete. Formerly one of the world's worst dressed men, he now seems to be among the most fashionable.
LONDON, Monday Dec. 7 (Reuters) Electricity workers began a work slowdown today that could deprive families of heat and light over the Christmas period.

Paul Gallico, the novelist, has donated his literary papers to Columbia University. The collection embraces more than 10,000 manuscripts, research notes and papers, among them his early sports columns for The New York Daily News and the original copy of "Mrs. "Arris Goes to Paris," "Thomasina," "The Snow Goose" and "The Poseidon Adventure."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (UPI) Two drill bits cut into the soft bottom 55 feet below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico today toward two oil wells burning out of control on the Shell Oil Company's Baker drilling platform.

BURGOS, Spain, Dec. 6 "You have told us about torture, Mr. Abrisqueta," thundered Juan Maria Bandres, one of the defense lawyers at the court-martial of members of ETA, the Basque guerrilla group. "Now tell us: If you were Francisco Izco, and under this kind of treatment, would you have admitted killing Inspector Manzanas?"

CAIRO, Ill., Dec. 6 Under the green plastic tinsel and gold Christmas stars strung above Commercial Avenue, the people marched past the business district's parking meters docorated with red and white stripes and red bows.
CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) Bill Garrett, who had never even come close to wining before, shot a two-underpar 69 today said won the $25,000 first prize in the Coral Springs open golf tournament.

Quite a few business concerns are omitting or trimming their Christmas bonuses this year because of the recession. Wall Street, which has been wrestling with a big bear, is practically a disaster area for bonuses.

BRUSSELS The builders of postwar Western Europe used to say, as their continent revived in strength and unity, that in gratitude they really ought to erect a statue of Stalin. The point of the joke was of course that Soviet intransigence had spurted the Marshall Plan, the North Atlantic Treaty and the beginnings of collaboration in Western Europe.
Texas and Ohio State, each beaten, were named co-winners of the MacArthur Bowl yesterday as the top college football teams in the country.

The president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association warned yesterday that there would be a "job action" by the city's 11,300 firemen if they did not have a satisfactory new contract when their present one expired Dec. 31.
IN THE NIGHT KITCHEN. By Maurice Sendak. Illustrated. Unpaginated. Harper Row. $4.95.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 5 Two days before Pakistan's most important election, no telephone rings in the multicolored tent that is the third-ward headquarters of one of Karachi's leading slates. There is no telephone.

Frank Palizzotto, the manager of the Sav-On Drugs discount center at the Forest Avenue Shoppers Market in Port Richmond, Staten Island, closed up at 10:15 Saturday night after what had been a particularly busy evening.

No one at The Times is quite sure when Frank S. Adams stopped being a "temporary" employe the status assigned to him when he started as a reporter fresh out of Princeton in 1925 but there can be no question at all of the permanence of the imprint his 45 years of dedi cated service made on the integrity and quality of this newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, recommended today that the United States propose a truce in Vietnam from Christmas through late January to help reach a permanent cease-fire. The proposal won prompt support from the Nixon Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec.6 High Administration officials do not expect significant cutbacks in the Defense Department's $8billion-a-year budget for strategic arms as a result of any arms limitation agreement that may be signed with the Soviet Union.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 6 (Reuters) A Cambodian military spokesman said tonight that the military district headquarters at Peam Chikang, on the northern bank of the Mekong River about 40 miles northeast of the capital, was under attack. A spokesman said air strikes had been called during the battle.

PARIS The November 21 bombings were not a surprise in Hanoi. The commotion aroused in Washington by the downing of an American plane an the 13th had given the impression that something serious was in the offing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 Communist China, but not Nationalist China; has been invited to a major international conference to modernize the 1949 Geneva Conventions on the protection of human rights during war.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (UPI) Earl Monroe and Kevin Loughery combined for 55 points as the Baltimore Bullets stretched their Central Division lead to 5 games tonight with a 126-118 victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

Vick Chemical's quietlymade decision to balance its agency assignments has turned out to be very nice for Baten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, which on March 1 will take over Vicks Formula 44. Cough Syrup and Discs. The two products are backed by about $4-million in TV advertising, most of it in network.
Most commodities markets were mixed yesterday in light trading.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 James Farmer, the founder of the Congress of Racial Equality, resigned today as assistant secretary for administration of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

An exciting finish and a small mystery marked the Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association played at the New York Hilton Saturday and Sunday. Going into the final match, two teams were tied on victory points, and team No. 10 captured the title by winning, 16-14, while its rivals could win only by 12-8.

Taxi fleet owners yesterday disclosed further details of their final offer to the city's striking taxi drivers, indicating that the average driver would have received an increase of $36.80 per week, exclusive of tips, if the proposal had been accepted.

The Fire Department issued a summons yesterday to a sheetmetal worker who served as a fire watch while his partner operated an acetylene torch on the fifth floor of a midtown office building where a fire took three lives and injured scores last Friday.

Steel production last week rose 3.9 per cent, compared to output the week before, when it was reduced by the Thanksgiving Day holiday. Major steel mills are not normally shut down for one day, but many smaller operations can be curtailed or halted.

MIAMI, Dec. 7 Premier Fidel Castro tonight suspended Cuba's celebration of Christmas and New Year's, declaring, in a three-hour and 20-minute speech in Havana, that Cuba could "not afford the luxury of having fiestas" during sugar harvests.

As Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay know so well, the cities and the states are the twins of the American governmental structure, sharing alike the fiscal plight of neglect at the hands of the Federal Government. Washington collects most of the tax revenues; cities and states supply most of the domestic services.

Although Miklos Schwalb has pursued an active career, concertizing, making musical films for television and teaching (he is Artist in Residence at Northeastern University), his Carnegie Recital Hall program Sunday afternoon marked his first New York appearance since 1957.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Conservationists won a victory in the Supreme Court today as the Justices declined to disturb a lower court ruling that prohibited the construction of the proposed Hudson River Expressway.

PARIS, Dec. 7 Antoine Bourseiller, a French theater director just back from the States, has brought back a meandering, monotonous spectacle, "Oh! America!" which opened at the Theatre de France the other evening.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 Dr. Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commissioner of Education, today urged adoption of an informal British approach to schooling in which elementary school children essentially work on their own at whatever they desire.

Pink-cheeked from wind gusts, Erte, the artist-designer, arrived at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue, yesterday morning to put the finishing touches on the third retrospective show of his work held here since since 1967.

The daring commando raid on the P.O.W. camp near Hanoi just before Thanksgiving could be termed a failure militarily in that it did not achieve its primary objective the rescue of Americans held prisoner there. But in terms of morale, the raid was outstanding.

The New York Racing Association closed the thoroughbred season yesterday at Aqueduct with a crowd of 35,362 braving the freezing weather. Enjoying the status of co-heroes on the final card were Johnny Campo, who saddled three winners, and Braulio Baeza, who won three of the nine races.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Kai Warras, vice chairman of the League of Red Cross Societies, said today that about $50-million $20-million more than previously reported had been contributed by governments, international organizations and private agencies for the relief of East Pakistani storm victims.
OTTAWA, Dec. 7 A Government commission on the status of women called today for radical reforms to make women the equal of men "in every area of Canadian society."
Bond prices declined yesterday as the credit markets cooled off a bit after their hot rally for the last five weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 News that the always troublesome Doctor Frankenstein had taken an abandoned castle somewhere in the United States and renewed his attempts to produce a monster capable of walking at twice the speed of sound was largely ignored by the public at first.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 7 General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced today that its world headquarters would be moved from New York City to a 10-story building to be built in downtown Stamford. The new central offices will be in the southeast quadrant of this city's urban renewal project.
France has issued a challenge to the United States for the 1973 America's Cup yacht race, Bruno Bich, son of French yachtsman, Baron Marcel Bich, said yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Eighteen persons were killed today when a Rumanian airliner on a flight from Tel Aviv crashed at Constanta, in Rumania, according to officials at Lydda airport.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7 The lawyer for Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther leader, asked today that murder charges against his client be dismissed because it had become "impossible" for him to receive a fair trial. The motion was denied.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Psychiatric staff members at Lincoln Hospital were sternly warned yesterday that they would not be allowed to oust Dr. Gabriel Koz as their chief of service or to dictate the choice of his successor.

Muhammad Ali won his fight with Oscar Bonavena just as he said he would. But he was off schedule by six rounds and hardly enhanced the magnificent image he had created six weeks ago with his swift and elegant disposal of Jerry Quarry in Atlanta.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 The Security Council was asked by five African and Asian members today to issue a formal condemnation of Portugal in the reported "invasion" of Guinea by Portuguese armed forces.

There is a kind of irony in the fact that while Actors Equity is striking Off Broadway producers, it continues such productions itself at the Equity Library Theater. This, with the actors unpaid, and the audience making an optional donation into a bread basket, is probably the purest form of Off Broadway, and it may very well one day be the only form left.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Dec. 8 An East Pakistani party advocating autonomy for that province and a West Pakistani party promising a redistribution of national wealth along Marxist lines took leads early today in the country's first direct nationwide election in 23 years of independence.

A dispute over student demands to be allowed to display a flag depicting a black panther at their functions touched off disruptions that forced the closing of Charles Evans Hughes High School yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Folowing is the text made public here of a speech in Los Angeles tonight by Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before the Pepperdine College "great issues series" of lectures:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (UPI) A class-action suit has been filed here against the Chrysler Corporation and its major affiliated companies accusing the company of numerous violations of the antitrust laws and a conspiracy to create a nationwide system of captive dealers.
DETROIT, Dec. 7 The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company reached a new contract agreement today, averting a second major strike in the auto industry.
Rube Goldberg, the cartoonist, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 169 East 69th Street. He was 87 years of age.

HONOLULU, Dec. 7 (AP) George R. Ariyoshi, citing "an impossible dream come true," was sworn in here today as the nation's first Lieutenant Governor of Japanese ancestry on the 29th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif., that its directors had voted to omit the company's quarterly dividend of 37.5 cents a share on the common stock. They declared the usual dividend of 36.5 cents a share on the preferred stock, payable Dec. 31 to holders of record Dec. 15.

The United States Supreme Court declined yesterday to order the removal of State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh as the presiding judge at the trial in Manhattan of 13 Black Panthers because of defense allegations that he was "hand-picked" by the prosecutor.
Utilizing exclusive Soviet film, Doubleday Co., the book publisher, will produce documentaries on the Soviet space program and on the German-Soviet fighting from 1941 to 1945.
The outcome of pro football's 12 weekend games eliminated only four of the 18 teams eligible for the playoffs and the Super Bowl. Out went the Jets, San Diego, Denver and Green Bay.

LINDEN, N.J., Dec. 7 Comparisons of a tape-recorded threat with the voices of possible bombing suspects were ordered today by the police investigating the fiery explosion Saturday night that swept the Humble Oil and Refining Company plant here.
WASHINGTON Dec. 7 (AP) Carl E. Bagge has resigned from the Federal Power Commission to head the National Coal Association, a trade organization of bituminous coal producers and dealers.
KLEVE, West Germany, Dec. 7 (Reuters) A Hamburg shipping line owner today was given an eight-month suspended prison sentence and fined $1,400 at the end of West Germany's first waterpollution trial.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 7 Dr. Thomas N. Graham of Wilson Point, who retired in 1966 after 38 years of medical practice in Manhattan, died last Tuesday in a Norwalk convalescent home after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The State Department said today that discussions were under way between the United States and South Vietnam on the possibility of proposing an extended holiday truce in Vietnam.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The Laotian Government reported today the loss of a strategic intelligence outpost at Muong Moc, about 20 miles from the border with North Vietnam.
Volunteers working to keep the services of New York charities at top efficiency are facing a serious drop in public support and income because of the recession.

Meyer Drucker of the State Mediation Board said last night that the 23-day-old Actors Equity strike against Off Broadway theaters could become the longest strike in the union's history, surpassing even the four-week strike in 1919.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 7 (AP) A general court-martial today reversed an earlier military court ruling and found a marine not guilty of a charge of raping an Okinawan mess hall waitress.
Alka-Seltzer, with all its tiny little bubbles and big, big billings, is going to Wells, Rich, Greene for the biggest account switch of 1970 so far.

Valentino hasn't given up his V's they're woven into his skirts and stockings and they dangle in metal from zippers but otherwise he's a new man. At least the boutique collection he brought over from Rome yesterday doesn't look like Mr. Sobersides.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 A panel of business executives was cautious today in its prediction of better things to come for the economy in 1971.

Renewed increases in the city's relief rolls were attributed in an analysis by a union official yesterday to "resumption of tacit encouragement" of illegitimate births and illegal abandonment of families rather than to the "Nixon recession" blamed by the city's welfare chiefs.

CASMA, Peru, Dec. 2 Half a year ago the worst earthquake in Peru's recorded history laid waste to several northern provinces, taking a toll estimated at more than 50,000 lives and depriving about 800,000 people of shelter.

SAUSALITO, Calif., Dec. 7 (UPI) A former assistant to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York has been charged with illegal possession of marijuana, dangerous drugs, narcotics paraphernalia and tear gas, the police here said today.
A suspect in a heroin-smuggling ring was ordered held here yesterday in $1.5-million bail, "the highest amount ever set in the United States," according to United States Attorney Edward R. Neaher.

The attack by Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, on Harvey Scribner, Chancellor of the city school system, can only have the effect of permitting genuine disagreements over policy to be distorted by personal feuding. The Council of Supervisory Associations has already exercised its rights by challenging Dr. Scribner's appointment policies in court.
The heads of the nation's five biggest airlines appealed to Congress yesterday not to cancel the program to build two test versions of a supersonic transport.

TORONTO, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press) A spokesman for the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company said today that the company had completed the previously announced agreement to pay $27.5-million to settle the final claim against the Kidd Creek mine.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 7 The Governor of Nevada said that Howard Hughes had unexpectedly telephoned him from the Bahamas early today and told him that he had personally intervened in a power struggle among his aides by ordering the Hughes Tool Company to take control of his Nevada properties.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) A railroad union leader said early today that he would order a nationwide rail strike in defiance of any action by Congress, the White House or Federal courts.

The four members of the Vermeer Quartet (Shmuel Ashkenasi and Pierre Menard, violins; Scott Nickrenz, viola; Richard Sher, cello) are young musicians with a wide background of solo and chambermusic experience. At present they are in residence at Northern Illinois University and on Sunday night the foursome performed at the New School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, and 29 other Senators, in a biting letter to the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that the agency had "imperiled the future of rail transportation in the United States."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the eighth consecutive session.

Howard Robard Hughes sits alone at the top of a highly complex maze of financial holdings reputed to be worth $2billion, thus making him one of the two richest men in the world, along with J. Paul Getty, the oil man.

While a thousand fists were held high last night in the blackpower salute, Muhammad Ali finally struggled past the Madison Square Garden well-wishers, who looked, in their stance, as if they were holding imaginary torches to light his way.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The first suit brought by the Justice Department to win equal employment rights for women has ended in an agreement that provides such rights.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP) Gen. Thomas S. Power, retired commander of the Strategic Air Command, died here last night at the age of 65. General Power, who had a heart ailment, was stricken at his home and died before he could be taken to a hospital.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 7 Claiming that Muhammad Ali wouldn't be able to "jive me the way he did Bonavena tonight," Joe Frazier predicted tonight that he'd come on in the sixth round to defeat Ali when the pair meet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 John Banzhaf 3d, an aggressive antismoking crusader and consumer advocate, has been denied tenure as a faculty member of George Washington University's National Law Center.

Earnings of the Fedders Corporation in the first fiscal quarter, ended Nov. 30, were up about 27 per cent and sales were up about 10 per cent, Salvatore Giordano, chairman and president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Edison, N.J. This means the air-conditioning manufacturer expects to report net income of about $4.4-million, or 42 cents a share, on sales of some $78million.
Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday a new line of lowerpriced color television sets to be in production in January. Some would be priced as much as $80 below current comparable models.

Giordano's "Fedora" may not be the worst 19th-century opera to survive in the international repertory, though then again it may be. On a grand-opera stage, taken too seriously or not seriously enough, it can be a silly bore.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) Ben O. Howard, an airplane racing pilot of the nineteenthirties, died on Friday after a long illness. He was 66 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy of New York City appealed today for "a strong uniform policy of domestic disarmament" to "take away the guns from the people."

With the death in custody of the leader of the National Liberation Alliance last month, Brazilian authorities wrote off that terrorist group and said they expected no more political kidnappings. Now the supposedly moribund Alliance has struck anew and the Swiss Ambassador to Brazil has become the fifteenth political kidnap victim in the Western Hemisphere in fifteen months.
Activities. The President proclaimed the week of Dec. 10 as Human Rights Week. The President received a courtesy call from Gov. Melvin Evans of the Virgin Islands.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and Senator-elect James L. Buckley met alone over breakfast for the first time yesterday and agreed later that the unannounced meeting had been at least cordial.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 7 (UPI) Erbito Salavarria of the Philippines knocked down Chartchai Chionoi, the champion, three times for a knockout victory in the second round tonight to win the World Boxing Council's version of the flyweight title.

An offer by John B. Kelly Jr., newly elected president of the Amateur Athletic Union, to settle the differences between the A.A.U. and the National Collegiate Athletic Association was considered "reassuring" yesterday by Walter Byers, executive director of the N.C.A.A.

WARSAW, Dec. 7 The drama of the signing of the Polish-West Germany treaty today was almost overshadowed earlier in a touching incident at a memorial to the Jews who died in the Warsaw ghetto under the Nazi occupation.

Don't let the word "Lives" in the title trouble you. This book is not a series of biographies in miniature. Mr. Schonberg, music critic of this paper and author of two other studies, of pianists and conductors, makes the word mean what he wants it to mean.
The Lindsay administration announced further belt-tightening yesterday this time an $880,000 reduction in funds for parks, recreational and cultural programs.

HOUSTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) Leroy Kelly-raced for 108 yards and one touchdown, and Bill Nelsen made the key thirddown plays tonight to lead the Cleveland Browns to a 21-10 victory over the Houston Oilers before 50,582 Astrodome fans.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 7 (UPI) Horace Parker testified today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation paid for two cases of paint sprayed on the United States courthouse in Seattle during a riot last February.

Led by Willy Schaeffler, their new coach who guided Denver University to domination of the National Collegiate ski championships, 17 members of the United States Alpine squad arrived at Sestriere, Italy, yesterday.

WESTPORT, Conn. Bette Davis has played many bad women in her nearly 100 films. Still women admire her and empathize with her characters. Because even when she kills a man ("The Letter") or nearly destroys one ("Of Human Bondage"), it is because she has been buffeted by Life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The House adopted a resolution today praising those who took part in the unsuccessful effort last month to free United States prisoners of war near Hanoi.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 7 Dr. Walter D. Ludlum Jr. of 10 Woodbine Circle, retired chief surgeon of the New York City Transit Authority, died today in Bridgeport Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
MADRID, Dec. 6 The Basque court-martial in Burgos, marked yesterday by accounts of torture and statements of opposition to the regime, was suddenly adjourned today for at least 24 hours.

A man who walked into a Brooklyn bank and handed a woman teller a note reading, "Give me all the money you have," has been acquitted of attempted holdup charges because he failed to frighten the teller.

A New York City detective was arrested yesterday on charges that he offered a $5,000 bribe to a state trooper to have him testify falsely to a Federal grand jury about an indictment accusing a businessman of making regular sales of cocaine.

Along the approach to Madison Square Garden from Seventh Avenue, the usually ever-present hawkers of Knick and Ranger pennants were not visible last night. In their place black vendors held up portraits of Muhammad Ali and Angela Davis.
The Firestone Tire Rubber Company posted record sales in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, but earnings declined for the second year in a row.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 8 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam returned from the United States today to report he had received assurances that American officials would keep hands off the presidential elections here next year.
Don Denbo, a senior psychology major at the University of Tennessee, does not consider himself typical of present-day undergraduate psychology students.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 The flare-up between the Government troops and guerrillas today was generally considered the most serious since the September conflict.

Jose de Cubas, the new chairman of the Council of the Americas, asserted yesterday that the council "views the restrictionist trade legislation pending in Congress as very detrimental to world trade and particularly harmful to the developing countries, as in Latin America."
SHARON, Conn., Dec. 7 (AP) The bodies of two New York men were found here today in the wreckage of a single-engine airplane.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The Indonesian woman who escaped from custody not long after her "miracle baby" hoax was uncovered, has been recaptured, a police spokesman said today.

The one thing New York would seem to need least at this time of year is another "Messiah". On the other hand, when a performance is as luminous as the one Sunday night at Philharmonic Hall, when all the disparate elements in Handel's oratorio come together so perfectly, there can be only gratitude to everyone concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The head of the new Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus, said today his organization would suggest to states that it was undesirable for their regulatory boards to include representatives of pollution sources.
Mayor Lindsay rehearsed his role of narrator yesterday for a musical version of Charles Dickens's "A Christmas Carol," and said that he would prefer to play the role of Scrooge.

Why is Mona Lisa smiling? What is the riddle of the Sphinx? Where is Judge Crater? And who is Howard Hughes?

Carlo Gambino, 67-year-old reputed "boss of all bosses" in the New York Mafia hierarchy, won a court order yesterday that makes it unlikely he will ever stand trial on charges of conspiring with four other men last year to hijack a Brinks armored truck full of money.
MOSCOW, Dec. 7 The Soviet Communist party today set next March 30 as the starting date for the 24th party congress, which will chart the country's policies until the middle nineteen seventies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was starting a limited check of canned tuna fish after a preliminary test confirmed the presence of unsafe levels of portions of mercury in one brand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 A $2.2-billion major medical insurance program that would protect about 95 per cent of the people under 65 years old against the cost of catastrophic illness was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Two documents issued by the White House today appeared to confirm earlier reports that Rear Adm. William B. Ellis, commander of the First Coast Guard District, gave the crucial order to return a Soviet defector to the fishing vessel from which he sought to escape two weeks ago.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 7 A Federal grand jury resumed today its investigation of the violence at Jackson State College last May after being warned by a Federal judge not to "dillydally."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Nature Conservancy announced today that it had bought for conservation purposes three islands off Virginia that had been slated for commercial development.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 7 (AP) India's Foreign Ministry angrily denied today reports from Pakistan that Indian police and civilians killed 300 Pakistanis and wounded 700 last Wednesday in the Pakistani enclave of Battrigach, which is in India's West Bengal State.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 Joseph Corson Jones, a commercial artist who was the design director of Discover. The Philadelphia Sunday Bulletin's magazine, died today at his home here. He was 57 years old.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 7 Hamdi Canaan, one of the most influential Arab leaders of the Palestinian west bank, has publicly renounced any wish to return to Jordanian rule. He challenged King Hussein to grant legal autonomy to the west bank even before the Israeli occupation ends.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 7 The Swiss Ambassador to Brazil, Giovanni Enrico Bucher, was kidnapped by leftist commandos today and his Brazilian police guard was seriously wounded.

TOKYO, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., winner last month of the first International Lawn Tennis Federation Grand Prix, withdrew today from a $50,000 round-robin tournament involving the top six Prix finishers. Doctors said they suspected Richey had hepatitis.
Texas, its mighty offensive machine having ground down its 10 opponents this season, is United Press International's national champion for 1970.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with the initial rates set by the Federal Power Commission for natural gas from the Southern Louisiana area, the source of a third of the nation's total supply.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Hearings that will determine the future control of Channel 11 in New York resumed here this morning, with a Federal Communications Commission examiner hoping to complete testimony on WPIX-TV's news practices in a few days.
Barney's is bringing in the business, not only for itself but also for its ad agency, Jack Byrne Advertising.

LOS ANGELES Dec. 7 (UPI) The chief defense attorney at the Tate murder trial said today that he thought it "probble" that the missing defense attorney, Ronald Hughes, had been killed by floodwaters in a canyon of the Sespe Hot Springs Mountain wilderness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has scheduled hearings to investigate charges that Ling Co., a Dallas broker-dealer, violated antifraud, registration and other provisions of Federal securities law.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI) A $10-million international automobile racing complex to be built in this northwest Florida area was disclosed today, with the first race scheduled for October, 1972.

PARIS, Dec. 7 The French racing industry is in a fearful and angry uproar over an unprecedented legal decision awarding damages to a bettor who successfully sued a losing jockey.

WARSAW, Dec. 7 Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany signed a treaty of reconciliation with Poland today and expressed the hope that it would "close the book on the sufferings and sacrifices of an evil past."

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 7 Maurice Picard, a retired philosophy professor at Dartmouth College, died last night in the college infirmary. He was 80 years old.

Ed Searcy, the metropolitan schoolboy basketball player most sought by college recruiters last season, will enter St. John's for the semester starting in February after having made a brief stop at Duquesne.

HAVANA, Dec. 7 The seven members of the left-wing Quebec Liberation Front who were flown to Cuba Friday in exchange for the release of James R. Cross, a kidnapped British diplomat, are in a comfortable hotel under official isolation.

LISBON, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The Portuguese Government, which has formally denied involvement in an invasion of Guinea last month, today rejected the conclusions of a special United Nations investigating mission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The Senate became involved today in a debate over the priorities between sewers and space and decided in favor of further manned space flight.
When Christa Ludwig sings lieder, as she did at Carnegie Hall Sunday night, the listener is guaranteed a number of pleasures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today 11 possible additional steps that might be taken by the Government to help slow inflation as the economy expands.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Agreement has been reached between the Jordanian Government and the Palestinian commandos to "stop provocative actions and end tension," it was officially, announced here tonight.

Still trying to achieve a consistency of performance that has eluded them through the first 31 games of the National Basketball Association season, the Knicks take on the Portland Trail Blazers tonight at Madison Square Garden.

MOORHEAD, Minn., Dec. 7 (AP) Bristling because of what he termed "defiance of the purpose and goals of the college," Joseph L. Knutson, president of Concordia College, suspended today publication of the student newspaper.

LOME, Togo The women's liberation movement is old hat in this WestAfrican country. Togo's women have long ceased to worry about equal opportunities in business for a simple reason: as "market women" many of them own and operate the most important businesses the wholesaling and retailing of food, clothing and other consumer products.

Borden, Inc., announced plans yesterday to sweeten its corporate operations through acquiring North American Sugar Industries, Inc. The two companies announced the merger proposal yesterday and later disclosed details.

The election of Richard B. Levine, 39 years old, as president of the New York, Mercantile Exchange was announced yesterday by Llewellyn Watts Jr., chairman of the board of exchange. Mr. Levine formerly was vice president for corporate development and assistant to the president of Blair Co., Inc.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 The Ford Motor Company raised the prices today on its 1971 cars an average of $15, its third price increase since the 1971 model cars went on sale. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 Attendance and handle at Liberty Bell race track took a pronounced jump today when Eagle Downs Racing Association opened its winter meeting on the day following Aqueduct's close.

And Lansburgh's, whose downtown store clientele is 70 per cent nonwhite, is pushing a "Tuesday StandOut Value" promotion.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. At 38th Street and Mersington on a chilly, dark afternoon recently, three teen-age boys stalked an elderly woman as she walked home carrying a bag of groceries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) Senator J.W. Fulbright said today there were indications that United States officials knew that no prisoners were in an alleged P.O.W. camp at Sontay, North Vietnam, and that a rescue attempt there last month "had other purposes."

ATLANTA, Dec. 8 President Nixon's top domestic policy adviser, John D. Ehrlichman, told a convention of Mayors and other local officials today that it would take an "extraordinary effort" to push the Administration's revenue-sharing program through the next Congress.
It was Alfred W. Wilkes's ambition, half a century ago, to be a writer. That dream has proved, at last, not to have been just a raisin in the sun.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) A broken part of Charles A. Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis plane, replaced just before takeoff on the historic first solo crossing of the Atlantic, has made its way to the Smithsonian Institution after 43 years.
Pierce H. Power, a Queens civic leader, died Monday at his home, 146-14 Laburnum Avenue, Flushing, after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.
FLORENCE, Mass., Dec. 8 Dr. Philip E. Smith, a pioneer in research on the pituitary gland in this country, died today at his home here. He was 86 years old.
WARSAW, Dec. 8 Poland and West Germany took steps today to carry out the improvement in their relations called for in the treaty signed yesterday.

The chairman of a City Council committee on public transportation and the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed after a tour of subway maintenance facilities yesterday there was much room for improvement.
Scrooge himself would have smiled last night at the Felt Forum, an ideal setting for the Moscow Circus on Ice. The show, which plays through Jan. 3, was simply delightful.
SUWEILIH, Jordan, Dec. 8 In the fourth day of fighting, Jordanian troops and Palestinian guerrillas clashed near this crossroads town today while army clean-up operations continued in Jarash.

"It's a wonder I don't get my head chopped off for the things I do," the wife of Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina said laughingly. The auburn-haired First Lady was recounting her recent efforts to raise money for the restoration of the Governor's mansion and a nearby guest house in Columbia, S.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Czechoslovakia's former economic planner told Congress today that United States restrictions on trade with Communist countries supported "Stalinist forces" and did not impede the Soviet military machine.
HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 8 (UPI) Apollo 15 astronauts are practicing for next July's lunar mission on Kilauea volcano, where the terrain is said to closely resemble the moon's surface.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Seattle Supersonics overcame a 14-point deficit and beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 107-104, as Dick Snyder scored 11 points in the final period tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) Teamster's union members in the gasoline and fuel oil tank truck industry reached an agreement today on a new three-year contract, ending a drivers' strike in two states and heading off a threatened walkout in 11 cities.
Nearly 100 staff members in the city's Planning Department sent Mayor Lindsay a petition yesterday asking him to reappoint Beverly Moss Spatt to the City Planning Commission.

The commanding officer of three Manhattan precincts has been called to testify before the special commission investigating allegations of police corruption, but he has moved in court to prevent the commission from questioning him.

TRENTON, Dec. 8 New Jersey officials and planning consultants have agreed that the plan to develop the Hackensack Meadows into New Jersey's third largest urban center could begin without any massive infusions of state or Federal funds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Any Presidential campaign that George C. Wallace runs in 1972 will have the avowed purpose of paralyzing the Electoral College machinery and forcing a political bargain on a major party candidate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 A move to abandon all but the central core of the mammoth Social Security - trade - welfare bill, which is still growing in committee, gained strength in the Senate today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8 New nightclubs are blossoming in this cosmopolitan capital. In Damascus, the talk is of civil liberties. In Cairo, the papers have been full of reports about the tea and sugar supply, while in Amman, the Government has banned tea-drinking by officials during office hours.

The Dow-Jones industrial average did something different yesterday. It went down, thus breaking a string of 12 straight gains that had rolled up a phenomenal advance totaling 64 points. Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe made available late today the department's final statement on the environmental impact of the supersonic transport, together with comments from other agencies.

A 1968 court order putting Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., into receivership and enjoining the defunct company and three of its officers, Victor Muscat, Edward Krock, and Roy M. Cohn, from violating the Federal securities laws was upheld yesterday by an Appeals Court.
The Allied Chemical Corporation, the nation's largest producer of sulphuric acid, announced yesterday a rise in the price of this basic chemical by $2 a ton, effective immediately.

ROME, Dec. 8 (AP) Benno Cardinal Gut, a Swiss-born member of the Roman Curia and the prefect of the Vatican Congregation for Divine Worship, died tonight in a hospital. He was 73 years old and had been suffering from a circulatory ailment.

Texas and Ohio State, undefeated and untied, settled last night for a share of the MacArthur Bowl, which is presented annually to the No. 1 college team by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Roger McRea is not wealthy, not on a Seattle schoolteacher's salary. So when his old second car broke down last spring, the remedy seemed obvious: a small economy car. But he promptly bought a full-size $3,500 station wagon.
New York University combined an effective fast break with rebounding superiority to defeat City College, 81-69, last night at the loser's Wingate Gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The decline in wholesale prices in November was not so large as estimated earlier but the index of wholesale prices nevertheless did go down during the month, the Labor Department reported today.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 Two brands of canned tuna obtained from supermarkets in Broome County during the last week have been found to contain a mercury level higher than the allowable maximum set by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, the State Health Department said today.

For those who live in the land of the open palm apartment supers, doormen, delivery boys Christmas looms a little colder this year. The specter that haunts them is not the ghosts of Christmas past, but the ghost of their Christmas presents.
KENT, Ohio, Dec. 8 On the other side of the hill where four students were killed by the National Guard last May, the Governor-elect of Ohio met the students of Kent State University today.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 8 (UPI) With Zelmo Beaty scoring 23 points, the Utah Stars, leaders of the American Basketabll Association Western Division, handed the Memphis Pros their fourth straight loss tonight, 125-106. The closest the Pros could get was 12 points in the third quarter.

A Brink's armored truck scheduled to pick up a $1-million gold shipment at Kennedy International Airport arrived yesterday with a guard who, the police said, was using a false name, had a police record for burglary, and was carrying a pistol with the serial number filed off.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 The economy is expected to resume its growth in 1971 after a mild recession in 1970, a panel of economists said here today. They also predicted a continued decline in the rate of inflation, a further drop in interest rates, a steel strike next summer and an unemployment rate above 6 per cent before it begins to drop next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) Senate-House conferees agreed today on a bill to permit the President, rather than Congress, to raise the pay of Federal employes.

The potential of a $2-million gate from an audience of 70,000 spectators and a $200,000 tax saving has projected the Houston Astrodome ahead of Madison Square Garden as the site of what looms as the most compelling bout in boxing history a world heavyweight title showdown between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier.
Borough President Sidney Leviss of Queens said yesterday that there was overwhelming opposition on the Board of Estimate to expansion of Kennedy International Airport into Jamaica Bay.
Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 557, New York, N.Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

Top management of Trans World Airlines conceded to its creditors last night that the troubled carrier was going to suffer a loss this year of between $60-million and $65million. However, the airline sought to reassure the creditors that rumors that the company faced collapse "are completely unfounded."

BURGOS, Spain, Dec. 8 The court-martial of the 15 Basques accused of terrorist activities resumed here today after a one-day recess, but with the presiding officer cutting off the kind of defense testimony he had permited on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The chief counsel of the United States Coast Guard told a House committee today that a Soviet ship captain's allegation that a would-be Soviet defector had stolen 3,000 rubles ($3,333) was no ground for returning him to the Russians.

Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and L. Joseph Overton, a union business agent who is regarded as one of the most powerful men in Harlem, were indicted with four other persons yesterday on charges of participation in "a labormanagement fraud that has been operating in the Harlem community for approximately five years."
Kenneth T. Gordon of Montclair was re-named president of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the 73d annual meeting of the organization at the Biltmore Hotel.

The Association of Assistant Principals challenged yesterday the constitutionality of the new decentralization law under which appointments to supervisory positions in the city school system are to be made on a qualifying basis instead of by competition.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 30 A new lesson in man's unwiting disruption of nature is being learned in northern Alberta, in the delta of the Peace and Athabasca Rivers.

A group of American historians have cabled the Soviet Union to protest the imprisonment of Andrei Amalrik, the dissident Soviet author. He was convicted last month on charges of having defamed the Soviet Union and was sentenced to three years in a prison camp.

Seventy feet below the street level of its new $100million skyscraper headquarters in midtown, McGrawHill, Inc., is constructing a special chamber that will combine the elements of a planetarium theater, concert hall, art gallery and museum.

What may have been the opening guns of the forthcoming 1971 annual meeting season were fired yesterday morning when the management and directors of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., greeted their stockholders.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 8 (UPI) Federal Judge S.C. Pointer Jr. today declared Alabama's anti-miscegenation laws unconstitutional and ordered officials to quit enforcing them.

BUFFALO, Dec. 8 The Common Council adopted an ordinance today requiring every gasoline station in Buffalo to have at least one pump supplying low-lead gasoline by next Sept. 1, and prohibiting the sale of all leaded gasoline in the city after Jan. 1, 1980. Councilman William B. Hoyt, sponsor of the ordinance, said it was the first of its kind in the nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 President Nixon's efforts to avert a strike against the nation's major railroads, scheduled for 12:01 A.M. Thursday, made progress on Capitol Hill today despite all-out attempts by railroad unions to head off Congressional action.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 The Soviet Union announced today that defense spending next year will remain unchanged at the current record level but that the military share of the budget will be the lowest in postwar years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The time-honored Army practice of having a bugler call soldiers out to stand reveille in the cold dawn is about to disappear by order of the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 President Nixon will hold his first news conference in four months at 7 P.M. Thursday, the White House announced. It will be nationally televised on all three networks.

You may have suspected this all along, and a recent study confirms it: The fact is that, when the new-issues market is bubbling, nobody gives a tinker's damn that some of the public offerings of stock in new companies are close to being "con jobs."

Zapata Norness, Inc. which is increasing its stake in marine activities with the current construction of 10 more vessels scheduled for delivery beginning in 1972, suffered a sharp drop in earnings for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, primarily because of a loss on heavy construction operations in West Virginia exceeding $7-million.

The suspension of eight black athletes who boycotted football practice at Syracuse University last spring was "an act of institutional racism unworthy of a great university," a special investigative committee at Syracuse has concluded.

Just three years ago the Government Printing Office, a venerable red-brick fortress that stands in the Swampoodle area north of the Capitol and whose long, musty corridors are pungent with Ben Franklinesque memories, was one of the more staid enterprises in the Washington labyrinth.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 Every year since 1959, Vasily F. Garbuzov has gone before the Supreme Soviet, this country's nominal legislative body, and outlined the budget for the next year. His two-hour performance today was no different from those of other years, and, as usual, the Supreme Soviet will adopt the budget with only minuscule changes,

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 8 The Government rested its case against First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. late today after rigorous cross-examination by defense counsel failed to shake the testimony of two witnesses who said they had seen the lieutenant fire into a ditch filled with South Vietnamese civilians during an alleged massacre at Mylai.
The 2500 lay teachers in the Roman Catholic schools of the New York Archdiocese have joined an independent local of the American Federation of Teachers.
Former Chief Justice Earl Warren said last night that polarization on the issue of law and order, spawned in the recent election campaign, could result in "another wave of hysteria" in the nation.

PARTIES Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union, representing 36,000 drivers and 1,200 inside workers; the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, representing 69 of the 72 fleet owners who operate 6,816 cabs; the City Council, which has the responsibility for setting taxi fares, and Mayor Lindsay, who recommended a fare increase at an earlier stage in negotiations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 8 The kidnappers of Giovanni Enrico Bucher, the Swiss Ambassador to Brazil were believed today to be demanding the highest ransom for a diplomat yet asked in Brazil the freedom of 70 unidentified people held on charges of terrorism and subversion.
Prices closed lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, marking the first decline in more than two weeks.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 Britain told the six-nation Common Market today that, if accepted for admission, she would agree to a five-year transition period for tailoring her industry and agriculture to the market's standards.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8 When Mrs. Eleanor Jackson Piel, a former deputy attorney general of California, finished her summation of a criminal case in a Federal court recently, the judge warned the jury not to be misled by her beauty and charm when delivering the verdict in the case.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8 A special committee of top officials of Harvard University and Radcliffe College reported today that a merger "is not desirable at this time."
The Metropolitan Opera's 10th performance this season of "A Masked Ball" shifted focus somewhat as three singers assumed important roles in the Verdi work for the first time with the company.
The extradition to California of Angela Davis, the 26-yearold black militant and former assistant professor of philosophy, on charges of murder and kidnapping was temporarily blocked yesterday.

A 37-year-old unemployed man was charged with arson and homicide yesterday in a two-alarm fire Monday night at the apartment building where he lived. A young fireman fell to his death while trying to control the flames.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The Democratic party ran more strongly in last month's elections than it initially seemed. That is the principal conclusion that emerges from a detailed analysis of precinct returns compiled from boards of elections, party headquarters, the National Broadcasting Company election unit and other sources.

Trading on the London stock exchange was almost at a standstill yesterday due to a slowdown by electrical workers, who are seeking wage in creases, that sharply reduced the power supply to homes, offices and industrial plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Senate and House conferees agreed today on a multibillion dollar bill to train the unemployed and underemployed that some supporters feared might face a Presidential veto.

For obvious reasons most experts choose their partners from their own city or geographical area. The opportunity for regular practice and discussion is clearly a major factor in success at the national level.

The Sports Car Club of America's professional series for Formula A cars openwheel racers with a single seat in an open cockpit will run next season with a 75 per cent increase in guaranteed purses. The series will have the same sponsor but a mouthful of a new name ...
GREEN BAY, Wis. The problems of the environment seem far away from the sparkling new buildings on the University of Wisconsin campus on 600 rolling, wooded acres here.

The endorsement by State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist of the informal British approach to elementary education ought to reassure New Yorkers about the openmindedness of their chief education official. State education "establishments" share with local school bureaucracies a tendency to be parochial and fearful of change.

Finding in the Portland Trail Blazers an offense-minded opponent not too well equipped to play defense, the New York Knicks followed suit at Madison Square Garden last night and outshot the National Basketball Association expansion team, 139-121.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 8 Sheik Mujibur Rahman, political leader of the East Pakistani autonomy movement, tonight appeared close to winning a majority in the national assembly that will draft Pakistan's first democratically prepared constitution.
Facsimile Transmission Network, Inc., announced yesterday the establishment of a high-speed facsimile network that covers more than 200 cities throughout the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Secretary of State William P. Rogers told Congress today that the United States must assume a long-term program of assistance in Cambodia, but he emphasized that the Administration was intent on avoiding direct military involvement there.

KFAR RUPPIN, Israel Nov. 28 The farmers of this border kibbutz are savoring a peaceful panorama these days, the sights of Arab farmers and shepherds returning to their fields along the muddy waters of the Jordan River.

SEATTLE, Dec. 8 (UPI) A dozen black University of Washington athletes held a 2 -hour meeting last night with the school's regents; its president, Dr. Charles Odegaard, and its athletic director, Joe Kearney.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The Treasury Department ruled today that Japanese capacitors are being sold in the United States at a cheaper price than in their home market.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP) Federal mediation officials in Washington informed Mohawk Airlines today that talks with striking pilots would resume Monday after a two-week breakdown.

The Chemical Bank said yesterday that a "class action" lawsuit against the bank charging civil violations of the antitrust, securities and banking laws was "entirely without foundation." Chemical said the facts would show that the bank was "solely interested in acting in the best interests of those for whom it has fiduciary responsibility."

Is it possible in these days of Women's Lib to speak of a pianist's playing as being womanly, and intend it as praise? It is a quality that could be attributed to the artistry of the late Myra Hess. It made her performance special and valuable, and never detracted from her eminence in the music world.
"I thought of hiring a bus to transport everyone, but it didn't seem necessary. Everybody I talked to was planning to hire a car for the night or take their own."

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 8 (UPI) The New York Rangers, with a chance to move past the Boston Bruins into first place in the National Hockey League East, played the Vancouver Canucks tonight for the second time in three days. A victory would give the Rangers 37 points to 36 for the Bruins, who did not play tonight.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7 With Bob Wenzel leading the way with 19 points, Rutgers handed Columbia its first basketball defeat tonight in three games, 74-61.

Goran Gentele, 53-year-old head of the Stockholm Opera is the leading contender to succeed Rudolf Bing as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Bing's contract expires at the end of next season. Although the choice of the Swedish stage director and administrator was reported in opera circles here to be imminent, the Metropolitan's president, George Moore, said the decision had not yet been made.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 8 Spokesmen for the Jordanian Government and the Palestinian guerrillas, in separate statements today, rejected a proposal that the west-bank area of Jordan be granted autonomy while under Israeli occupation.
SHANGHAI In the main hall at the Shanghai Industrial Exhibition, a huge white statue of Chairman Mao Tse-tung surveys a display of well-polished heavy machinery.
Don't laugh. Men are buying pantyhose. What's more, they're wearing them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) House Speaker John W. McCormack's Democratic friends and associates turned out tonight for a big reception to bid him farewell. He, in turn, wished them success in efforts to elect a Democrat to the White House in 1972.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The House refused to go along with the Senate today and declined to retract its earlier support for the $290-million appropriation for development of the 1,800mile-an-hour supersonic jet transport.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The State Department announced an internal reorganization program today that it said was designed to create a "new breed of diplomat-managers" for the diplomacy of the Seventies.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) Bob Love celebrated his 28th birthday with a 30-point performance tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 98-87 victory over the San Francisco' Warriors.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 7 With the rice paddies drying out along the Mekong northeast of here, Communist troops have apparently opened a drive to extend their supply lines south toward Pnompenh.

It is entirely possible that historians of future generations will come to regard Richard Nixon's Presidency as the exquisite irony of the twentieth century. Back in 1970, they will point out, amidst the chaos of change, there ruled a relic, the vast Victorian chamber of his mind composing passe rhetoric to be announced, on behalf of his fear-shocked constituency, over one tinny megaphone from some White House window. Irony? Absolutely, the historians will agree.
I.W. Burnham 2d, senior partner of Burnham Co., said yesterday that he was opposed to the elimination of fixed commissions on stock exchange transactions and their replacement with negotiated rates.
LONDON, Dec. 8 The Government of Prime Minister Heath took a firm line today against growing strike turmoil.

In the past days' economic policy speeches by President Nixon and Chairman Arthur F. Burns of the Federal Reserve Board, we are witnessing the emergence of what should go down in the history books as the Accord of 1970.
Investors balked yesterday at the lower interest rates resulting from the pronounced advance in the bond market in November and early December.

From Long Island, where open spaces are so rapidly vanishing, it is refreshing to hear of plans, however local, to arrest that deadly process. Southampton, a resort and rural town at the eastern end of the island, is considering a new ordinance to preserve its farms in perpetuity while allowing for the inevitable boost in population.

PHOENIX, Dec. 8 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain's 36 points led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 121-112 victory tonight over the Phoenix Suns.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 8 Mrs. Albert Lowenthal's Pete's Chick took the lead shortly after the start and pulled away in the stretch to score a 3 -length victory today in the $11,000 Brazen Brat Purse for Maryland-bred 3-year old fillies at Laurel Race Course.
New treatment methods are saving the lives of the vast majority of victims of a mysterious neuromuscular disease, myasthenia gravis, even though doctors know little about its cause or cure.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 (AP) Ken Rosewall of Australia defeated Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 6-3, today for his second victory in the $50,000 round-robin tennis tournament involving the top Grand Prix finishers.
Henry Varnum Poor, the artist, died yesterday at his home in New City, N.Y. He was 82 years old.
With liquidation hitting nearly all commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, soybean, corn and wheat declined in fairly active trading.

Two physicians and two druggists in the Bronx were arrested yesterday and charged with a total of 863 counts involving the illegal prescribing and sale of a potentially dangerous drug known as Doriden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 President Nixon met with King Hussein of Jordan today for talks that were thought to have centered on their mutual desire for resumption of the Middle East peace talks and on Jordan's hopes for further military assistance.

Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent, daughter of former President Lyndon B. Johnson, has written a 5,000-word memoir of her father's final year in the White House as visualized through the eyes of his pet mongrel dog, Yuki.
A helicopter with electronic sensing gear criss-crossed the waters of the metropolitan area yesterday, trying to track down some of the thousands of potential water polluters.

HAMBURG If you take a jet from Boston to Hamburg these days, the customs officials frisk you at both ends geographically and physically for concealed weapons. In Boston they are rather apologetic about it, and in Hamburg slightly officious, but slowly and unevenly a crude system of police control is being established over international air transportation.
Martha Graham, the dancer and choreographer, received a special award from the America-Israel Cultural Foundation last night at the opening of the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel at the City Center.

Herbert J. Blitz, director of international affairs for the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Memorial Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Washington.

Certain customers of Robinson Co., a brokerage house involved in bankruptcy proceedings, will receive their holdings as a result of a ruling in Philadelphia yesterday by Thomas J. Curtin, Federal Court referee in bankruptcy for the concern.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) House Speaker John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced yesterday that he was giving his official papers to Boston University.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 The Security Council's condemnation of Portugal Tuesday for her alleged invasion of Guinea and its demand that she pay reparations was one of the strongest actions ever taken by the Council against a member of the United Nations. But it was not unique.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 King Hussein of Jordan was reported today to have asked the United States for $125-million more in military aid over the next five years.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, indicated for the first time today that there was a prospect for success in the arduous East-West talks on the perennial problem of Berlin.

At WNBC-TV, Channel 4, anxiety is in the air, as various proposals are being made to rejuvenate a limping news operation. But at WABCTV, Channel 7, they're chuckling with satisfaction because they're the cause of it all.

A former law partner of President Nixon and now president of a leading West Coast one-bank holding company declared yesterday that despite some restrictive aspects in the one-bank holding company bill just cleared by a joint Congressional committee, he felt confident banks could live with it.

The France, the luxury-liner flagship of the French Line, is resuming service after a sixweek absence caused by a wildcat strike that forced the cancellation of two trans-Atlantic crossings and two cruises.

BURGOS, Spain, Dec. 9 The defense in the courtmartial of 15 Basque nationalists came to an abrupt end here today after one defendant advanced on the tribunal and his manacled companions struggled with policemen.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 9 The president of C.W. Post College accepted yesterday the recommendation of a studentfaculty committee that the director of the campus radio station dismissed for allegedly broadcasting obscenities be rehired.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 (UPI) Rod Layer outplayed Arthur Ashe today to gain his second straight victory in the $50,000 Masters Grand Prix roundrobin tennis tournament, The scores were 6-4, 6-2.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 9 Maj. Cecil MontgomeryMoore, who served as a pilot with the Royal Flying Corps in World War I and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, died here last night after a brief illness.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 The South Vietnamese Government has decided on oneday truces for Christmas and New Years despite Washington's officially expressed interest in an extended holiday cease-fire.

A group of lawyers who collect bad debts asked yesterday for a State Supreme Court order nullifying a part of the city's Consumer Protection Law that prevents them from getting in touch with a debtor's employer before obtaining a final court judgment against him.

Representatives of the public school systems in the state's six largest cities met with Governor Rockefeller yesterday and told him they might need as much as $1-billion in additional state aid for education in the next fiscal year.
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, arranged yesterday for a new mediation session in the taxi strike, which is now in its sixth day.

OTTAWA, Dec. 9 A special Senate committee declared today that Canadian news publishing and broadcasting must be revitalized, if possible with more competitive, nationally oriented reporting, to protect freedom of the press and promote Canadian identity.

The membership of the New York Stock Exchange has voted overwhelming approval of a $30 million indemnification agreement to Induce Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., to acquire Goodbody Co., a major brokerage house in financial distress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The House Internal Security Committee issued today a revised list of what it called "radical and/or revolutionary speakers" who appeared on college campuses over the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Senator William Proxmire announced today that Senate opponents of the supersonic transport would filibuster against the Administration's entire transportation budget if it contained any restored funding for the program.

The Special commission investigating police corruption, facing what may be a tough battle to win a six-month extension from the City Council, yesterday issued a letter from United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. stating that its work was important to the fight against organized crime.
