WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) Rejected by their male colleagues, women journalists here turned the other cheek last night and tentatively voted to allow qualified men to join the Women's National Press Club.

Marsha Heller's oboe program at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night was a model of how an event of this sort should be. It was varied in musical style, in instrumental and vocal color, and each work created an expectant atmosphere for the next.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 9 Arthur Barber, a former official of the Barber Steamship Lines of New York, which his father Herbert Barber had founded, died today here at Englewood Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 69 East. Hamilton Avenue.

Mrs. Bess Meyerson Grant, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, declared yesterday that her department's backlog of consumer complaints was "frightening," but she asked the city for less money for fiscal 1971-72 than the department is getting now.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it planned to increase prices by 1 to 5 per cent on a number of appliances, including refrigerators, clothes dryers

ROSEMONT, Pa., Dec. 9 Avery Strakosch Denham, who for many years was a contributor of articles and short stories to many national publications, died yesterday. Her late husband, William Denham, was a real "estate broker.
STONY BROOK, L.I. Dec. 9 The campus bookstore at the State University Center here has announced that any student caught shoplifting will be prosecuted under Suffolk County law "with no exception."
The police and fire forces so vital to New York City's safety have displayed both their best and worst sides in recent days.
He wriggles, he squirms, he jiggles and jumps, and when he's embarrassed and at 10 it's not hard to be embarrassed he grins sheepishly, dimples deepening, and says, "Uh, I forget."
The aviation world took the spotlight yesterday in corporate mergers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Bryce N. Harlow, counselor to President Nixon and a longtime friend, resigned today from the White House staff to return to private life.

Albert E. Gurge, president of the Northeast Marine Terminal Company, and a vice president of the William J. Rountree Company, died Tuesday of a heart attack at DowntownBeekman Hospital. Mr. Gurge, who lived at 346 81st Street, Brooklyn, was 50 years old.

One of the early news stories of this year was the opening of Harper Rosenfeld Sirowitz, which toward midyear became Rosenfeld/Sirowitz with the departure of Marion Harper, its president. With the new year, it will become Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Lawson with the arrival of Tom Lawson from Ogilvy Mather.

Bennett Cerf stepped down yesterday as chairman of the board of Random House, a post he has held since 1965. He will be succeeded as of Jan. 1 by Donald Klopfer, who has been vice chairman of the board for the last five years. Mr. Cerf and Mr. Klopfer were co-founders of the publishing house in 1927, and Mr. Cerf had been its president until 1965.

The death of Frank S. Adams last week deprived the New York Times not only of a member of its editorial board but also of its most enthusiastic bridge player. When not exercising his journalistic prowess, which brought him many honors, he was never happier than when holding 13 cards.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 9 The new director of the Metropolitan Opera House comes from an operatic world that those who struggle with the Met's problems would hardly recognize.
Profit taking and consolidation pressures pushed stock prices lower during most of yesterday's session, but a surprise recovery brought the market back to an even keel at the close.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 Yugoslavia and Italy have agreed to an 11th-hour postponement of a state visit President Tito was to have made to Rome tomorrow, according to a joint announcement this evening.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 9 A negotiated settlement was under discussion tonight between executives of the Hughes Tool Company and Robert A. Maheu, the man they have tried to dismiss as director of the Nevada operations of Howard Hughes.

Commercial paper was one of the great growth markets in Wall Street in the nineteen-sixties. From less than $4-billion at the beginning of the decade, these unsecured corporate I.O.U.'s soared close to $40-billion last spring. They truly formed a "second banking system," largely immune from the Government's efforts to cool the economy and control inflation-and a possible source of financial instability as well.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 (Reuters) Belgium cut its discount rate today from 7 to 6 per cent, effective tomorrow. The rate was last reduced on Oct. 22 when it was cut from 7 to 7 per cent.

Dresser Industries, Inc. achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, with the final quarter contributing a moderate gain of 2.2 per cent in earnings on a sales increase of 18 per cent, according to preliminary annual results issued from Dallas headquarters yesterday.

Cinderella couldn't go to the ball in Brooklyn yesterday because she lost her city job and only the handsome prince in the ornate hall across the East River was powerful enough to get her back on the payroll.

The University of Pennsylvania's basketball team, winner of 35 of its last 39 games, will play New York University tonight in the opener of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. Manhattan and Rutgers are the rivals in the second game.
A budget of $23,112,000 was adopted by the Joint Distribution Committee yesterday to finance its programs for more than 300,000 needy Jews in 25 countries next year.

A total of 144,500 commuters in the metropolitan area were expected to switch to private cars and buses today as all suburban commuter lines except the Long Island Rail road and the PATH lines into New Jersey were shut down at midnight by the rail strike.
The Board of Education directed yesterday that only the American, state and city flags could be flown on school buildings.
DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 9 (UPI) -Tom Harp was dismissed today as Duke University's head football coach.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 9 The Swiss Embassy announced today that it had confirmed the authenticity of a handwritten note received from the kidnapped Ambassador, Giovanni Enrico Bucher.

Lawyers for two of 13 Black Panthers on trial for an alleged bomb conspiracy tried to show yesterday that an undercover police agent who testified against them had persuaded them to check department stores and railroad yards for suitable locations for bombs.

BRONXVILLE; N.Y., Dec. 9 Edward E. Simmons, known professionally as Steve Edwards during a long career in film industry publicity and advertising, died today in Lawrence Hospital after a short illness. He lived here at 36 Penfield Road West.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 10 A nationwide rail strike began at 12:01 this morning.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 9. Joseph H. McIntosh, a reporter of The Plainfield Courier-News, The Newark Star-Ledger and The Elizabeth Daily Journal for more than 50 years, died last night in a nursing home in Elizabeth after a brief illness. His age was 78 and he lived at 135 Madison Avenue.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 (Reuters) The Awami League, led by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, today won three more seats in Pakistan's first general elections attaining a majority in the new National Assembly.

LONDON, Dec. 9 Hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings and schools in Britain were partly blacked out today in the worst disruption of power since dissatisfied electrical workers began a slowdown on Monday.

Sheila Davis recently spent three months working with children in a leper village near Katmandu, Nepal, She hated to leave but she was due back at her job. Miss Davis is a stewardess on the Dallas-New York route of Braniff International.

The League of New York Theaters agreed yesterday to submit its contract dispute to arbitration, but Actors Equity Association declined to accept the proposal unless several conditions were excluded from arbitration.
The corporate bond market, shouldering a heavy schedule of new financing, held yesterday the ground it gained in its recent month-long rush toward lower interest notes.

An order requiring the State Department of Social Services to pay the same welfare grants to residents of upstate counties as it does in New York City was upheld yesterday by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 9 A winning spurt of five games in a row clinched first place today for Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles in the Palma 24-man knockout round-robin elimination tournament for the world challenge chess matches. Fischer, an eight-time United States champion, posted a score of 16 -4 with two rounds to go, consisting of 13 victories, one loss and seven draws.

ANJEAN, W. Va., Dec. 9 (UPI) One of three miners trapped by a massive rock fall was rescued in good condition tonight from a coal mine in this southern West Virginia village. Another was brought out dead.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 Israeli Arabs who have cooperated with the Israeli Government and those actively hostile to it retained their relative strength in the local election held yesterday in Nazareth. The polling was for the Municipal Council in the predominantly Arab Galilee city of more than 30,000 people.
DUBLIN, Dec. 9 The Irish Parliament was adjourned in uproar today over Prime Minister John Lynch's explanation of a reported kidnapping conspiracy and his threat to intern extremists.

The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, arrived here yesterday for a brief visit that will include meetings with President Nixon, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird in Washington tomorrow, and a speech at the United Jewish Appeal's annual conference dinner Saturday at the New York Hilton Hotel.
Added proof that the experienced skier is a careful shopper when frequenting ski shops is provided by the cognoscenti's reaction to the new customized foam boot.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9 (AP) Former President Lyndon B. Johnson has declined, for the time being, an invitation to become a Chubb Fellow at Yale University, a spokesman said today.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -A makeshift line comprised of Rod Seiling at left wing, Jean Ratelle at center and Ron Stewart at right wing rescued the Rangers late in the third period tonight to give New York a 2-2 tie with the Los Angeles Kings.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 (UPI) -Billy Casper, Gary Player and a young Australian, David Graham, will be among the favorites tomorrow when 72 golfers tee off in the annual Argentine Masters tournament. The home town player, Roberto de Vicenzo, will also be high on the odds list over the 6,542-yard, Par-70 Olivos Golf Club course. He is a three-time winner of the event.

Two stockholders of Brown Company filed a $16.8-million damage suit Tuesday an Federal District Court in New York against that company, its directors and Gulf Western Industries. Inc., which controls it.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the second straight day after 12 consecutive sessions of advance.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 9 (UPI) Citing economic necessities and the failure of the retail television market to grow as projected, RCA said today it would close its $20-million plant here, putting about 1,600 persons out of work.

Helen Hayes entertained the Salvation Army yesterday with a few bars of a song from a 1906 musical, "The Belle of New York" The musical, she said, starred "the exquisite Edna May, who played a Salvation Army lass."

Auburn's Pat Sullivan, who is a threat to score a touchdown every time he touches the football, was named the total offense leader for the 1970 season yesterday by the National Collegiate Sports Services.
Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

TORONTO, Dec. 9 (AP) The Toronto, Maple Leafs, with their goalie, Bruce Gamble, turning back 33 shots, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4-0, tonight as the National Hockey League teams hooked up in a rough, penalty-laden game.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 9 (AP) The Minnesota Supreme Court upheld today a state law prohibiting strikes by public school teachers and threw out a settlement that was reached with about 1,800 striking Minneapolis teachers last April.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin alternately fingered a pencil, smiled broadly at remarks whispered to him by another Soviet leader, and clasped his hands and listened, as members of the Supreme Soviet today discussed the economic plans and budget for 1971.
Shortly before his ritual suicide last month, Yukio Mishima, the renowned Japanese novelist, wrote letters to friends here foretelling his death.

Manuel Casiano, director of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's Division of Migration here, has been appointed to head the island's industrial development corporation, one of the top posts in the administration of Gov. Luis A. Ferre.
There was a time when a Fordham-Seton Hall basketball game would be as close as any fan could hope for, but times have changed.

A talented choreographer, Pat Catterson, presented a program of five new works at Judson Church last night. Her creative voice is soft but firm, understated but distinct and pleasureful. She uses dancers with intelligence and a special feeling for the weight and bounce of bodies in motion.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 9 Thomas H. Raynor, a member of the Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission since 1956 and a leading real estate man, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived on Grove Lane here.

BURGOS, Spain, Dec. 9 Two-thirds of the way north from this drab Castilian town, where 15 Basques are on trial, the train hurdles one of those sharply defined geographic boundaries that are more common in fairy tales than in life.

NEWARK, Dec. 9 Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he would have to resort to "some form of tax increases" early next year to head off an impending fiscal crisis faced by New Jersey that was precipitated by spiraling welfare and Medicaid costs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Fifteen to 20 members of the Democratic party's left wing are planning to meet in Chicago Saturday to discuss their future approach to politics.

Duncan Suttles, the 24year-old Canadian master, and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, split a bitterly contested point during the first round of the interzonal tournament in Palma, Majorca. As White, the Canadian chose the old-fashioned Vienna Game, and it led to a complex middle game without knights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 A bipartisan drive opened today to force House action this year on a bill giving the Federal Government power to enforce nondiscrimination in employment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Post Office plans to introduce new services to improve the handling of business mail after it becomes a public corporation next year, a top official has disclosed.
A jury found William A. Maynard guilty of manslaughter yesterday at the end of his third trial on a charge that he murdered a marine during a streetcorner dispute in 1967.
OTTAWA, Dec. 9 Following are excerpts from the recommendations in the report of the Special Senate Committee on Mass Media published today after being submitted to the Canadian Parliament:
SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 9 (UPI) The Air Force has the right to discharge an unwed officer who becomes pregnant a United States Appeals Court ruled today.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Dr. Robert C. Wood, former chairman of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, was installed today as president of the University of Massachusetts.
By any reasonable standard, the debut of the American Basketball Association in Madison Square Garden, the traditional glamour site for any kind of basketball, was a rousing success.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 9 A petition to unseat the chairman of the Board at Education here began circulating today after the chairman cast the deciding vote to bring 25, Bridgeport slum children into the nearly all-white Burr Farms Elementary School.
DETROIT, Dec. 9 The Chrysler Corporation has laid off 3,167 workers in the last two weeks and plans to stop most of its automobile production in the last two weeks of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The chairman of the House Census Subcommittee accused the Nixon Administration today of trying to "rejuggle" the release of 1970 census data in order to benefit lame-duck Republicans in Ohio, Florida and other states.
Artem I. Mikoyan, co-designer of the MIG jet planes, died yesterday in Moscow after a long illness, it was reported in a broadcast by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency. He was 65 years old.
Prison wards in Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric division are described in a new state inspection report as dangerously overcrowded and understaffed.

The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame promised college football fans a building to house its Hall of Fame many years ago. Rutgers University donated 10 valuable acres as a site. Thousands of persons and many colleges donated to the project, which was to be
After dropping sharply early in the session, futures prices of soybeans, corn and wheat recovered much of the lost ground before the day's activity was halted, but closed lower nevertheless.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 Security officers and secretariat officials were embarrassed this morning when they learned that a speaker addressing the General Assembly was a casual visitor from South Vietnam and not the delegate of Laos.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec., 9 -The struggle for control over Howard Hughes's $150million investment in Nevada has cracked the shell of secrecy around the eccentric billionaire and provided new insights into his mysterious style of life.

The Metropolitan Opera yesterday chose Goeran Gentele, 53-year-old head of the Royal Opera House in Stockholm, to replace Rudolf Bing as general manager. The ruddy-faced Swedish administrator and stage director immediately said that he planned to modernize the Metropolitan's repertory, and to stress the theatrical and dramatic aspects of opera as much as the music.
LONDON, Dec. 9 Leslie Cannon, president of the 365,000-member Electrical Trades Union, died of cancer today at Northwood, Middlesex. He was 50 years old.
RICHMOND, Dec. 9 (AP) The World Boxing Association withdrew its recognition of Bob Foster today as world lightheavyweight champion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing accused the White House today of blocking efforts by George Romney and other officials to open suburban communities to low-income families.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) An earthquake almost as strong as one that killed an estimated 50,000 persons in Peru last May struck a border area of Peru and Ecuador last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The militancy of the automobiles is rising. Anyone who still does any walking must surely have noticed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 Seven-foot Bill Phillips, who played only 23 minutes last season, was the big star for St. John's tonight as the Redmen defeated highly regarded St. Joseph's, 66-53, before 5,000 at the Palestra.

Proposals for a year-end cease-fire in Vietnam, now under "active consideration" by the Nixon Administration, could make a major contribution to peace in Southeast Asia. But the bid for a five-week halt in hostilities is doomed from the start unless implemented with imagination and courage.
Reports on millions of people who live in poverty and misery are commonplace in the news. Yet sometimes just one instance of despair is what hits home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Senator Walter F. Mondale told delegates to the White House Conference on Children today that, unless they got tough, engaged in power politics and put direct pressure on President Nixon and Congress, their proposals would gather dust on Government shelves.
The theater party, long a favorite of charity fund raisers, has picked up one supporter and lost another.
Peter L. Tea, professor emeritus of drafting at City College, died yesterday in a Long Branch (N.J.) nursing home after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 860 West 181st Street.

LAMU, Kenya They said that if you wanted to learn about the best safari table in Kenya, you'd have to track dawn Bunny Allen and his wife, Jeri. It was quite a trek, Mr. Allen, reputedly the most famous game hunter in Africa, end his wife have a hideaway in this outlandish Island called Lamu.
In response to a court order, the Young Lords began yesterday to move out of the East Harlem church they seized in October to dramatize their demands for reforms in the city's prison system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9, (AP) The Federal Reserve Board held today that a member bank may count as reserves only the currency or coin that it has an unrestricted right to use.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 9 (AP) Former Assemblyman and State Senator A. Gould Hatch died last night at his home. He was 74 years old.

LONDON, Dec. 9 Britain's Press Council, a model for a similar council recommended in Canada today, is a voluntary organization that was set up in 1953. It has the dual role of preserving the freedom of the press and safeguarding professional standards.

SAIGON, South VietnamThe price of a bottle of "33" beer increased recently for the second time in a year in an attempt to keep pace with galloping inflation. The increase, however, is unlikely to affect consumer attitudes because demand for beer in Vietnam far exceeds production.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 Louis Antal, the candidate of a rebel group in the United Mine Workers of America, held a 514-vote lead here today in a bitter contest with Michael Budzanoski, the incumbent, for presidency of the union's District 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst says he would recommend that any victims other than the President, Vice President or their families be sacrificed rather than ransomed if they were ever kidnapped by political terrorists.
For the first time, the response of one of the new generation of high-rise buildings to an earthquake has been recorded with precision instruments.
The London stock market moved sharply lower yesterday in slack conditions. Selling in reaction to Wall Street's retreat on Tuesday and almost complete lack of support depressed prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Director of Health Affairs of the Office of Economic Opportunity is expected to resign next year from the agency, which has developed many innovative programs to improve medical care for the poor.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 9 The South African Government today lost the last of three legal rounds in its effort to prosecute 19 black Africans on charges of subversion and terrorism.

English-bred dogs owned on opposite sides of the continent, Saighton Sizzler and Misty Muffet, have become this year's national champions in English springer spaniel field trials. Mrs. Evelyn Monte of New York, secretary of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial
Roy Ayers, who pounded his vibes in Herbie Mann's group for several years, Is now leading a quintet of his own, Roy Ayers Ubiquity, which is at the Village Vanguard through Sunday.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 9 Lawyers defending First Lieut. William L. Calley, Jr. said today that they would try to prove the killing of unarmed South Vietnamese noncombatants at Mylai had been a result of "legal and justifiable acts of War."

A Manhattan woman who says she instigated the investigation and conviction of a concrete mixing company for polluting the East River claimed yesterday half of the $25,000 fine levied against the company by the United States Government.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 9 A surge in the last 10 minutes of the game enabled the Syracuse basketball team to defeat Cornell tonight, 93-71. The Orange scored 11 straight points in three minutes with their 6foot-11-inch center, Bill Smith, sidelined with foul trouble.

Hugo Weisgall's music was the subject of the "Composers in Performance" concert in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum on Tuesday night, and Mr. Weisgall was on hand to conduct the two works presented. The first was "Fancies and Inventions," a cycle of 10 songs to poems from Robert Herrick's "The Hesperides," and the other was "The Stronger," his one-act opera of 1952 based on Strindberg's play.

Reading the page proofs of a new edition of Leisenring and Hidy's "The Art of Tying the Wet Fly" (which will soon be published by Crown), I was reminded again that a wet fly is sometimes more effective than a dry when trout are rising.

Among the blackboards and the movie screen that fill the center of the Giants' locker room is a sign nearly as large as the screen. It looks like a plastic window shade and it strikingly reaffirms the Giants' belief in themselves and their immediate goal.
About 13,000 longshoremen tied up the Port of New York yesterday in a one-day wildcat strike resulting from a hiring dispute with stevedoring companies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Government expects the "real" gross national product to decline in the current quarter, entirely because of the General Motors strike, it became known today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The United States and the Soviet Union formally confirmed today their agreement to study means of docking their spacecraft in orbit.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 9 A panel of students from five central Massachusetts colleges will meet Friday to discuss the propriety of accepting a $25,000 grant from the John D. Rockefeller Fund to organize a student-run corporation to solve environmental problems of the area.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 9 (AP) Wes Unseld set the pace tonight as the Baltimore Bullets routed, the Milwaukee Bucks, 127-97, in a National Basketball Association game.

ATLANTA, Dec. 9 Mayor Lindsay of New York and other big-city mayors banded together today in an effort to forestall a threatened veto by President Nixon of a manpower bill that would provide $200-million for public service jobs in the next six months.
The city's Board of Ethics was assailed yesterday as unethical.
Charles writes to Santa Claus from Athens, W. Va. "Deer santa," he says, "dont bring me a kar plees bring us sum shos are feet get cold in the hols ... cum in thru the bustd window in the kitchen..."
Quietly and carefully, Weeb Ewbank discussed yesterday the National Football League gagrule that subjects owners, coaches and players to fines for public. criticism of game officials.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 9 A Federal bankruptcy referee today approved a transaction in which Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. would give the Michigan National Bank title to an undeveloped tract of land an Houston, and the bank would cancel Mr. Copeland's $500,000 debt under a mortgage the bank held.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 With Administration support, the House Appropriations Committee set in motion today a legislative maneuver around the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to obtain Congressional approval of a large-scale military aid program for Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Senate Finance Committee approved today a big, complicated, expensive, controversial bill that would make major changes in the nation's Social Security, medical assistance, health insurance and foreign trade laws and point toward extensive welfare reform.

Just back from a triumphal, whirlwind tour of the Continent and a sojurn in Merrie England, John E. O'Toole, the top knocker of Foote, Cone Belding, was ready yesterday to share his philosophical overview of the advertising scene.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community, with some 4,500 officials, went on strike today to press claims for higher salaries. Coming after a series of warnings, it is the first full-scale strike by Common Market technicians since 1958.
A $57-million high-rise and townhouse residential complex of 1,320 housing units in the Washington Street urban renewal area of lower Manhattan was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

During the decade in which the late Fritz Reiner built the Chicago Symphony into the supreme orchestra that it remains to this day, Mahler sym phonies were not its forte. For Dr. Reiner, the Mahler symphonic story began and ended with the relatively amiable No. 4, which left plenty of time for Bartok, Strauss and other Reiner specialties.

One day the Soviet cellist, Mstislav Rostropovich, gallantly declares that he will continue to stand by his old friend, Aleksandr Solzhenitzyn; a few days later Solzhenitzyn writes Stockholm that he dares not come out to receive his Nobel Prize today lest he be prohibited from re-entering his own country.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 9 (AP) Chi Cheng, the track star from Nationalist China concerned about how much her injured left leg would hamper her in the Asian Games, took a day of rest today for her first race tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) An enemy force blasted a South Vietnamese command post in the Fishhook area just inside Cambodia, killing or wounding at least half the defenders and destroying several trucks, the military command reported today.

The city's and the state's highest ranking housing officials all portrayed the housing shortage yesterday as reaching crisis proportons and they assailed the Federal Government for not providing more assistance.

A school in the Jamaica section of Queens was the target at 2 A.M. yesterday of home made fire bombs that caused slight damage. Seven hours later, stones and eggs were thrown at a nearby school by some of the 150 pupils and adults who have been conducting a boycott.

PARIS, Dec. 9 (UPI) Ambassador Arthur K. Watson complained today that America's European allies sometimes turned a deaf ear when the United States wanted to discuss the important and pressing problem of United States trade policies.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 9 Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the head of Nigeria's military government, told delegates from 41 African countries here today that the invasion reported by Guinea last month was "an insult, an affront and above all, a challenge to Africa."

WESTBURY, L. I, Dec. 9 Because Maida Million won both her preliminary starts in the fall pacing festival at Roosevelt Raceway, the 6-year-old Australian-bred mare had the highest average earnings in the series. Since berths were determined on the basis of average money-winning, this distinction automatically placed her in the No.8 post for Saturday night's $25,000 final at the Nassau County course.

The General Electric Company announced here yesterday a new process for automatic mass production and packaging of integrated circuits. The company's integrated circuits department also showed the first two products in the line.
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, national director of Operation Breadbasket, announced yesterday a black "economic withdrawal" a substitute term for a boycott of the A. P. food store chain in 20 cities.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 (UPI) Tommy V. Smith, Commissioner of the Texas Bureau of Labor Statistics, said today a suit filed by Muhammad Ali last December prohibited him from issuing Ali a boxing license without a court decision.
American Ballet Theater will present three premieres and two revivals in its three-week season at the City Center from Dec. 22 through Jan. 10.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 10, (AP) Muhammad Ali was granted a boxing license in Texas today clearing the way for a possible match between him and Joe Frazier, the recognized heavyweight champion, in the Houston Astrodome.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 10 (AP) Mike McGee, head football coach at East Carolina University, was named today as head coach at Duke University, where he starred as a lineman a decade ago.

A city judge has ruled in Brooklyn that a standpipe extending from a building over a public sidewalk "without warning to the pedestrian" constitutes a public nuisance that justifies negligence action against the building owner.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 10 (AP) John E. Corbally Jr., chancellor of Syracuse University, said today that a committee report on racism in the school's athletic department was not anti-athletics and that he saw no need for personnel changes.
Rear Adm. William Langfitt Freseman, U.S.N., retired, died Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived at 1600 Boulevard East, West New York, N. J.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 10 (AP) An earthquake that rocked the coastal areas of northern Peru and southern Ecuador killed at least 81 persons, Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) President Nixon said tonight that he was "outraged and shocked" at the incident last month in which a Lithuanian seaman trying to defect to a United States Coast Guard cuter was returned to his ship.

Six of the 11 City Councilmen from Brooklyn urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to reappoint Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt, the maverick member of the City Planning Commission.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 A South Vietnamese Army doctor, carrying four hand grenades and a copy of the Constitution of South Vietnam, succeeded in reaching President Nguyen Van Thieu today to complain about corruption in this country.
PARADISE ISLAND, the Bahamas, Dec. 10 Whatever Howard Hughes's long-term plans are, his representatives have been looking for property in Nassau to convert into office and living facilities.

The London stock market rallied late yesterday in anticipation of a settlement of an electrical workers' dispute. Losses among the leaders were regained or reversed, but the movement was not general and trading remained limited.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 10 The wife, daughter, mother-in-law and one of two sons of a 44-year-old New Canaan man were found slain at their home this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on a $210-million compromise appropriation for the supersonic transport $80-million less than the Administration requested and the House has approved, but enough to keep the program alive.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 Allegations that American servicemen here are being denied their right to civilian counsel in court-martial trials were made today by an American lawyer who came to South Vietnam to defend them.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) The estranged wife of Murray Chotiner asked today for a divorce.
Ed Marinaro of Cornell is the major college football rushing champion although Don McCauley of North Carolina set a single season total rushing record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The initial phase of the WPIX license hearings ended here today with the New York television station being dealt a strategic blow when its final exhibit, a filmed reconstruction of some of its controversial newsfilm, was not permitted to be introduced into evidence.
HAVANA, Dec. 7 Cubans have begun their great annual effort to harvest sugar, the island's main crop, but this time in a grim mood.

Yale University is considering a plan that would allow students to finance their college education after they graduate through annual payments of a fixed percentage of their income over a long period of time, perhaps 30 years.

The North American Soccer League, the offspring of the unsuccessful National Professional Soccer League and the United Soccer Association, expanded to eight teams yesterday for the 1971 season by granting franchises to New York and Toronto.

In time he may develop into an effective representative for the United States at the United Nations but there seems to be nothing in his record that qualifies him for this highly important position.

A world auction record for an American artist was posted Thursday night worth the sale of Thomas Eakins's "Cowboys in the Badlands" for $210,000. The painting, created in 1888, was recently seen in an Eakins retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
Henry S. Wingate, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the world's largest nickel producer, made it official yesterday a four-year shortage of the alloying metal is ending.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The Treasury Department ruled today that Japanese electronic tuners were being dumped on the United States market at lower prices than they were sold at in Japan.
Written disclosure of their sources of income would be required of city Councilmen or candidates for the Council under legislation proposed yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 11 (AP) Chi Cheng of Taiwan, racing on injured legs, won her first gold medal of the 1970 Asian Games today in the 100-meter dash, but Japan continued to dominate the medals race, setting three more games' records.

Not all department store miracles take place on 34th Street. In a week, the darkened windows of the old Georg Jensen building at Fifth Avenue and 53d Street had been transformed into a glittering introduction to the Lighthouse Christmas Boutique, which opened here yesterday.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 11 (UPI) Enemy pressures on the highway linking the capital to Cambodia's only oil refinery forced the Government to ration gasoline today for the first time. Thousands of motorists swamped service stations, whose pumps quickly ran dry.
Snowfalls of up to eight inches fell in wide areas across the state yesterday, ending one of the mildest preChristmas seasons in the records of the National Weather Service.
An old three story building near the tip of City Hall Park exploded yesterday, then burst into flames.
A 21-year-old Bolivian woman was arrested at Kennedy Airport yesterday and accused by the Customs Bureau of trying to smuggle into the United States cocaine having a street value of $500,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) Red Sox led the American League with a 592 slugging percentage and Ron Perranoski of the Minnesota Twins set a single season league record of 34 saves, according to official league statistics issued today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 11 (UPI) Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, received an artifical heart value today in a successful operation to correct "an advanced stage of heart failure."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Before House and Senate conferees agreed last night on a compromise $210-million appropriation for the supersonic transport, the Department of Transportation warned them that so low a figure would add $160-million to the over-all cost of the project and "would destroy the prototype program as we know it today."

LONDON I wonder whether those billboards calling for the impeachment of Earl Warren, which used to disfigure the public highways of the Deep South, have yet been amended with the name of the new Chief Justice. Probably he is too recently in office; but I doubt wheather, in the longer term, the Burger Court will prove any less controversial or more popular than its predecessor.

An unusual exhibition of 45 recent collages by the American artist Joseph Cornell opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Organized by Henry Geldzahler, the museum's curator of 20th-century art, the show consists entirely of works on loan from the artist himself. It is installed in Gallery 12. on the second floor of the museum, and the installation is, for a happy change, modest, straightforward, and entirely sympathetic to the art itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Ralph Nader and other consumer advocates asked the Federal Trade Commission today to issue a regulation prohibiting advertisers from making assertions that were not "fully and completely substantiated by scientific tests."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 A report accusing Israel of maltreating Arabs in territories occupied since 1967 and calling for some international supervision was approved here today by a vote of 49 to 14 with 37 abstentions.

Twelve-year-old Carl Williams threw his schoolbooks in a corner, took down a box with his name on it from a shelf, withdrew a length of brown fabric, and began stitching the edges together. His friend, Anthony Thomas, 13, was confidently stitching away on another piece of brown fabric. He was making his fourth scarf.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The Civil Aeronautics Board has established a consumer affairs office to improve communications with consumers and provide more effective handling of their complaints against airlines.

PARIS, Dec. 11 An emissary of President Nixon, stepping up the American assault against discriminatory Common Market farm policies, has warned that protectionism cannot be beaten back in the United States without a positive response from Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 11 In a world of megatons and onrushing technology and new forms of political control, words still have their mysterious power. That was the unexpected and moving lesson at this year's Nobel Prize ceremony.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 11 Discussions by students at five central Massachusetts colleges ended today without a firm decision on whether to accept a controversial $25,000 grant offered by the John D. Rockefeller 3d Fund.
Soybean and grain futures prices for the most part did an about face yesterday in rather dull trading after having dropped for four days in a row.
Jimmy Murphy, a sportswriter and sports editor here for more than half a century, died at his home yesterday. He was 79 years old and lived in Rockowaya Beach, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Significant new information on more than 200 Americans captured or missing in the Vietnam war has been received here from Hanoi through Sweden; United States officials said today.
After a firm start, the London stock market closed narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Dec. 11 (AP) Five coaches at Coe College resigned today in a dispute over long hair and a grooming code for athletes. Resignations were turned in by Glenn Drahn, football coach, Dave Etienne, basketball, Bob Thurness, track, Merle Masonholder, wrestling, and Al Kloppen, baseball.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The nation's trains and mails were moving almost normally today following an 18-hour strike that was called off last night.

Disappointed by the production performance of the Soviet economy in 1969, Soviet Communist party chief Leonid Brezhnev began insisting many months ago on a sharp improvement in 1970. The statistics cited at this week's meeting of the Supreme. Soviet indicate that the pressure must have had some positive results as industrial and agricultural output increased 8 and 6.5 per cent respectively over last year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Congress has approved a system, to be administered by the Department of Agriculture, for the protection of rights to new varieties of plants grown from seed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Some 250 technical papers in several languages are being presented this week at the second International clean Air Congress. But this avalanche of verbiage tends to obscure rather than illuminate the...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Inventors will receive a record total of 80,000 patents in the current fiscal year, more than double the annual output of the early nineteentwenties. Weekly patent volume (they are issued only on Tuesdays) will reach 1,800 early next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The House voted today to continue the excise taxes of 10 per cent on telephone service and 7 per cent on new automobiles through 1972 and to speed up estate and gift tax collections to produce $4.1-billion in additional revenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 President Nixon today announced the appointment of Representative George Bush as United States delegate to the United Nations, succeeding Charles W. Yost.

The NLT Corporation announced yesterday it has agreed to purchase 3 million common shares of the Ralston Purina Company from the Danforth Foundation of St. Louis for $73,125,000. This would give NLT, a holding company whose major property is National Life and Accident Insurance Com-...

The two Brazilian Indians who, are known as Los Indios Tabajaras stressed cultural ecumenism in their program Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Playing their guitars with a warm, mellow tone and, on occasions, singing, Natilico and Antenor Lima roamed through...

Lenient treatment of gangsters in the courts, corruption of police and public officials, and lack of emergency wiretapping authority seriously hamper the war against organized crime in the city, two city police officers testified yesterday before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

Like every branch and division of government in the United States today, the judiciary is suffering a series of problems all of which may be appropriately labeled as crises. Mr. Chief Justice Burger in his "state of the judiciary" message clearly described one the incapacity of the Federal courts expeditiously to handle the myriad of cases now brought before them for resolution and certainly none can deny that the American courts are ineffectively trying to...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 A State Department official said today that the United States had no information that Portugal had used herbicides to destroy crops grown by rebels in Angola.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) The key to Cleveland's continued mastery over the Dallas Cowboys is Bill Nelsen, a gimpy-kneed quarterback, who hasn't lost to the Texas team in three starts.

Delinquency rates on one-tofour-family home mortgages climbed during the third quarter as purchasers were hampered by rising unemployment and lower take-home pay, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported yesterday.
Bottle collecting is attracting more and more antiques enthusiasts, and the prime reason for the great interest seems to be the low price of some examples.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Dec. 11 Russell, E. Watson, a lawyer, government official and trustee of Rutgers University, died today at the Somerset Valley Nursing Home. He was 85 years old and lived in the Belle Meade section of Somerset County.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 A computer that keeps track of a machine's health is being adopted to the heavy construction industry. The Bissett-Berman Corporation,...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The Nixon Administration, which has declined to challenge the legality of hundreds of dismissals and demotions of Negro teachers in the South, offered instead today $3.2-million to retrain the displaced educators.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 (UPI) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina shot a one-under-par 69 today for a one-stroke lead at 137 over Gary Player of South Africa and two others in the second round of the $10,000 Argentine Masters golf tournament.
Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., and Gramco Management, Ltd., two troubled offshore mutual-fund organizations, are planning to merge, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) Raul Rojas, former featherweight and junior lightweight champion, called it quits after Mando Ramos, former lightweight titleholder, knocked him out last night in a 135-pound match.
LONDON, Dec. 11 Former Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Longmore, a pioneer in British Naval aviation, died yesterday at his home in Sunningdale, Berkshire. He was 85 years old.

PARIS, Dec.,11 An organization representing private industry in 80 countries is seeking to prod governments into a new round of trade liberalization after conclusion of negotiations to enlarge the European Economic Community.
William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, called yesterday for greater emphasis on two-year college programs and for the elimination of "much redundancy" in college studies.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 11 Mrs. Helen Winsor Williams, a former buyer in the New York office of the T. Eaton Company, Ltd. of Canada, department stores and mail-order concern, died of a heart attack Monday in White Plains. She was 66 years old and lived at 235 Garth Road.

Coward-McCann, Inc., the book publisher, will acquire a new name Jan. 1 Coward, McCann Geoghegan, Inc. The "Geoghegan" is for John J. Geoghegan, the 53year-old president and editor in chief of the company since 1961.

Mrs. Florence Durstine Hamilton, a welfare and church leader, who was the widow of Dr. B. Wallace Hamilton, former secretary of the New York County Medical Society, died yesterday at the Courtland Gardens Convalescent Home in Stamford, Conn, She was 89 years old and had lived at 52 East 66th Street for 50 years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon started mailing out their Christmas cards today to thousands of persons.

For anyone interested in what Spanish theater groups are doing in the city, "Los Invasores" ("The Invaders") by Egon Wolff, the contemporary Chilean playwright, provides a thought provoking evening of theater.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 11 E. Earl Udall, former village manager here, was listed by the police as an apparent suicide today, pending a final report by the county medical examiner.
The formation of a new $1.1 billion bank-holding company in upstate New York was proposed yesterday by major banks in Albany and Syracuse.

The board chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday described as "outrageous" an attempt by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in Washington to block the company's request for rate increase on the ground that the Bell System engaged in "pervasive" discrimination in the employment of blacks, women and Americans with Spanish surnames.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 11 Sally's Truce, a 4-year-old filly from the Audley Farm Stable, drew out in the final yards for a 1 -length victory in the Too Bald Purse at Laurel Race Course today.

DETROIT, Dec, 11 (UPI) Passenger-car production in the United States moved upward again this week as the General Motors Corporation stepped up its output after a 67-day strike, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

QHINHON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP) The United States Army charged an enlisted man with negligent homicide today in the killing of a Vietnamese boy that set off two days of anti-American rioting here earlier this week.
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday that there was an "absolute impasse in financial areas" in the negotiations between striking taxi drivers and fleet owners.
Mutual-fund shareholders have grown accustomed to depending on their holdings for income.
DENVER, Dec. 7 The nation's most unlikely group of aging "student radicals" is preparing to graduate Saturday from a new school that was created at the suggestion of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 The East German Communist party's Central Committee ended a three-day session in East Berlin tonight with the unanimous passage of a declaration expressing hope that the fourpower talks on West Berlin will reach "a mutually acceptable agreement."

BATON ROUGE, Dec. 11 (AP) Dr. Leslie Glasgow, an environmental expert dismissed by the Nixon Administration, said today that he had been pushed out of the Department of the Interior by political and business interests in a shakeup that represented a "definite step backwards for environment."

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 Last night and today the Montreal police seized 102,000 copies of the January issue of Scanlan's Monthly, an American maga zine given over to a single article, "Guerrilla War in the U.S.A." and containing information on how to make bombs.
Six survivors, of an officebuilding fire last week in which three persons died gave a party yesterday for the firemen who saved their lives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Dec. 8:
Don Maynard, sufficiently recovered from a strained calf muscle, will fly to Miami with the rest of the Jets today and undoubtedly will play in at least part, of tomorrow's game with the Dolphins.

DUBLIN, Dec. 11 Dublin has become a sad, romantic city of dreams not quite fulfilled, and when the rain washes O'Connell Bridge and a cold wind whips the leaves in St. Stephen's Green, some might feel discouraged and recall the lament of Yeats back in 1913: "Romantic Ire-...

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 The Soviet Union today canceled planned visits to the United States by the Bolshoi Theater's opera and ballet companies next spring, charging that the American authorities had failed to stop "provocations by Zionist thugs."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 A Soviet-American agreement on fishing rights off the Middle Atlantic Coast of the United States was signed here today amid complaints by Senators and American fishing interests that Washington had failed to bargain hard enough with the Russians.

The taxi strike is turning out to be more of an ordeal for the drivers, and probably for visitors, than for the inhabitants of this city. For many New Yorkers, in fact, it has been a refreshing interlude. Driving is brisker, the streets are safer and the air is sweeter.

The breast-beating champions of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in the City Council, notably Matthew J. Troy Jr. of Queens, are doing both the city and the police force a gross disservice by seeking to kill the Knapp Commission's inquiry into police graft.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Sir Francis Chichester, the first man to sail alone around the world, set off this evening to seek another record.

Dartmouth, Delaware and Edinboro State players and coaches were honored at the annual Lambert awards luncheon yesterday as each institution received credit for "outstanding performance this season" in Eastern intercollegiate football.
NEWARK, Dec. 11 Charles M. Grosman, senior partner in the law firm of Grosman Grosman, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived at 44 South Munn Avenue, East Orange.
The Los Angeles Dodgers who obtained Richie Allen two months ago, added more power yesterday when they acquired Duke Sims in a three-man trade with the Cleveland Indians.

The immediate reaction to the news item stating that the students of five Massachusetts colleges had rejected a $25,000 gift from the John D. Rockefeller Fund is to ask whether the young ingrates had taken leave of their senses. Coming on the heels of persuasive evidence of higher education's unprecedented fiscal crisis, the only thing less rational than refusal of a benevolent gift would be a deliberate effort to insult the donors.

ALSDORF, West Germany, Dec. 11 (Reuters) A state prosecutor agreed today to drop proceedings in the two-yearold trial against the manufacturers of the drug thalidomide on charges that it led to deformation in children.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11 The sixth panel of prospective jurors in the Bobby G. Seale murder trial was exhausted today without the selection of any member of the panel.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 11 Connecticut policemen searched Boy Scout camp sites and ski areas today for a 17year-old honor student who disappeared after his mother, grandmother, sister and brother were found murdered yesterday in their home here.

An expression of disappointment by the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner and a statement of determination by the Jewish Defense League marked the reaction yesterday to the Soviet Union's cancellation of appearances here next year by the Bolshoi ballet and opera companies.
The new-issue market, where shares of companies that had never before offered their stock to the public are traded, edged up slightly this week in moderate activity.
American Jewish philanthropic leaders yesterday called on Jewish communities throughout the country to increase the financial aid for Israel's social welfare, education and health needs.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The Detroit Pistons came from four points back with 11 seconds left to tie in regulation time and then rallied behind Bob Lanier and Dave Bing for a 121-118 overtime victory over Boston tonight, snapping the Celtics' l0-game streak.

White House advisers will be aiding neither President Nixon nor the nation if they persuade him to veto the manpower bill just agreed on by Senate-House conferees. It would be far more sensible for the President to embrace this urgently needed measure as the first fruit of the three-part social program he sent to Congress in August 1969.

A Queens prosecutor charged yesterday that a, New Jersey couple and a man had worked a home-repair swindle on an 82-year-old Queens woman, and defrauded her of almost $125,000. Two other men are being sought, he added.
The special commission investigating allegations of police corruption is revising and simplifying an eight-page financial questionnaire that has stirred resentment among city policemen.

The Yale Prom, a 19thcentury tradition that stumbled into the second half of the 20th, has run its course. Its demise at the age of 127 is being attributed to nothing more virulent than lack of interest.

After 10 months of negotiations, the Treasury Department has granted an exemption to New York State Urban Development Corporation bonds to be issued for construction projects that include some industrial and commercial programs.

WASHINGTON It is open season on the courts. The judges are blamed from all sides for the crime wave, the clogging of court dockets, the overcrowded jails, excessive bail, short sentences and downright indolence. If I were called upon to identify the culprit I would first point to the fiscal authorities who decide the amount of money the courts receive.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 12 Curtis W. Tarr, director of the Selective Service System, said today that five days of talking with American soldiers in the field has convinced him "more than ever" that educational deferments from the draft should be abolished.

ST. LOUIS, Dec 11 (UPI) The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced today that an agreement had been reached with a British aerospace company, Hawker Siddeley Aviation, Ltd., to be a member of the McDonnell Douglas group working on a space shuttle design.
LONDON, Dec. 11 Hopes for an early settlement of Britain's power crisis collapsed tonight and the Government moved toward a declaration of national emergency.

ARDMORE, Pa., Dec. 11 Denise Cahill of Baltimore gained first place in school figures, leading Alice Stockfleth of Wilmington, Del., in the senior ladies singles of the South Atlantic figure skating championships today at the Philadelphia Skating Club and Humane Society. The free skating will be held tomorrow. night.
LONDON, Dec. 11 The Air Transport Licensing Board today rejected applications for higher fares on British domestic routes, saying that increased fares would spur inflation.

The recent raid on Guinea for which Portugal was blamed helped a Harlem-based African nationalist organization achieve in two weeks a goal it had sought for l4 years a federation of African-oriented black groups.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 11 A Federal grand jury apparently closed the door today on prosecution of any law-enforcement officers in the shooting that killed two blacks and wounded 12 at a dormitory at Jackson State College last May 14.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 11 An isolated group of Soviet bloc states voted today against a proposal urging speedy completion of a treaty covering damages caused by objects launched into space But the proposal was approved by the General Assembly's top political committee in an 85to-8 vote.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 President Nixon today told a group made up mostly of Governors that he might call Congress back for a special session after Christmas if it adjourned without approving his welfare reform program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 High Pentagon officials said recently that an unsuccessful attempt was made in the spring of 1969 to have the Federal Bureau of Investigation take over from Army investigators the task of looking into the prospects of riots in major American cities.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 11 (AP) Rick Barry, continuing his comeback after an injury, scored 27 points tonight and led the New York Nets to a 128-99 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 11 The Ministerial Council of the Organization of African Unity condemned the North Atlantic allies today, charging them with complicity in "attacks by Portugal against African territories and states."
Pretentiousness is rioting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where last night the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn ill-advisedly opened a musical called "Tarot."

FREEPORT, Bahamas, Dec. 11 (UPI) Chris Blocker equaled chte course record of 66 today and vaulted in to a one-stroke, lead after 36 holes of the $136,000 Bahamas Islands open golf tournament. Doug Sanders was second and Arnold Palmer third another stroke back.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 11 A former helicopter pilot, testifying for the defense at the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., said today that a large group of Vietnamese strewn along a trail at the southern edge of Mylai had been killed before any American troops reached the scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Thomas James Hauser, President Nixon's nominee to fill a long-standing vacancy at the Federal Communications Commission, confirmed this evening that he was being appointed only to fill out the six months remaining on an unexpired term.

PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 12 The Paris Municipal Council ended a special session in complete deadlock early this morning after a majority had voted to reconsider a month-old deci sion to give the name of Charles de Gaulle to the Place de l' Etoile.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 At the Security Council's meeting last Saturday on Guinea's charges of a Portuguese invasion, the United States representative, Charles W. Yost, wore a lavender shirt of wallpaper design and a wide purple tie for the first time in his life. His preference had normally run to gray suits, white...
Labor conditions in the port returned to normal yesterday following a week of stoppages including a wildcat strike Wednesday by 13,000 longshoremen.
CAPETOWN, Dec. 11 Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, South Africa's heart transplant pioneer, performed four open heart operations here this week all on members of the same family.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 11 A morals charge against a 32year-old psychiatrist was dismissed in City Court here yesterday when for the third time in the last two weeks not enough people showed up for a jury to be drawn.

In order to bring a greater degree of democracy into the nominating procedures of the Democratic party, and through that party into politics generally, the New York State Democratic Committee will meet in Albany today. The committee will consider a number of badly needed reforms. These reforms have been drafted to accord with recommendations made earlier by the McGovern Commission which grew out of the debacle at Chicago in 1968.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 11 The court battle between the Hughes Tool Company and Robert A. Maheu, an executive whom Howard Hughes apparently wants to dismiss, was recessed tonight in an air that forecast a negotiated settlement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 When the George Bush family arrived in Washington one snowy day in 1967, Barbara Bush had to dash out and buy extra sheets. Her husband had insisted that the workmen on the moving van spend the night with them.

RICHMOND, Dec. 11 (AP) A Federal Appeals Court held today that the death penalty for rape when the victim's life was neither "taken nor endangered" violates the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.

The Knicks' opponent tonight at Madison Square Garden will be the Philadelphia 76ers, whose weak start in the first two months of the National Basketball Association season has been one of the league's biggest surprises so far.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 11 (UPI) The Oakland Raiders and Kansas City Chiefs, who in 11 years have created one of the most bitter rivalries in the history of pro footballs will tangle tomorrow in the "one that counts" for 1970.

To find the best discards when the declarer is running a long suit is often beyond the powers of the defenders. On the diagramed deal, played Wednesday at the Mayfair House of Bridge, West could have put the declarer to a much more severe test if he had discarded well.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 11 (UPI Jack Egers tallied two goals in the final period tonight to give New York a 2-1 victory over the California Golden Seals and move the Rangers) into a first-place tie with Boston in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

Equipped with red armbands and a giant placard that read "Women Now," a small bevy of women artists invaded the invitational opening of the Whitney Museum's 1970 Sculpture Annual exhibition last evening. Waving the placard, they circulated among the guests and staged a five-minute sit-in before a massive piece of sculpture.
Viscountess Gladys de Maublanc, a sister of the late Elizabeth Arden, the cosmetics manufacturer, died on Thursday at the American Hospital in Paris. She was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird suggested today that the absence of progress at the Paris peace talks could provide another justification for renewed bombing of North Vietnam.
Mrs. Violet Lindo Eder, the wife of Phanor J. Eder, an international lawyer, died yesterday in their home at 29 Washington Square West. She was 78 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 Carl Chapman, whose brother John is a harness horse drivertrainer at Roosevelt Raceway, saddled two winners today at Liberty Bell Race Track where 9,069 fans wagered $1,084,712 on an eight-race program.

Placido Domingo will assume the title role in Verdi's "Ernani" for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House in the performance to be given on Jan. 8 in the 17th week of the company's season. Bonaldo Giaiotti will appear as Silva for the first time here in the same performance, and other leading members of the cast will be Martina Arroyo and Sherrill Milnes.
The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that by the end of 1970 it will have cut its worldwide employment by 10 per cent to 48,000 workers.
Samuel T. Watson, retired national manager of First Three Markets Group, died Wednesday night in his home at 5 Tudor City Place, after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) Officials of the Food and Drug Administration say two major manufacturers of bubble bath for children have agreed to reformulate their products in response to complaints of irritation and infection in the urinary tract.

Alberto Ginastera's "Estudios sinfonicos" were inspired by Schumann's "Symphonic Etudes." Mr. Ginastera says so right out in the program notes to this week's New York Philharmonic concerts in which the first New York hearings of "Estudios" are being given.
THE GRASPING IMAGINATION: The American Writings of Henry James. By Peter Buitenhuis. Illustrated, 288 pages. University of Toronto Press, $12.50.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11 (AP) A New Haven man was charged with murder today in the buldgeon slayings of three mentally retarded young persons in a park last summer, the police said.
CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 11 Roger Q. Pease, a retired papermill executive, died today in Concord Hospital of a coronary attack after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Warner, near here.

The Pennsylvania Company, the investment subsidiary of the Penn Central Transportation Company, omitted action yesterday on the $1.15625-a-share dividend on its 4 5/8 per cent cumulative preferred stock.
Thirty-one months after his original run for the roses, Dancer's Image charged toward a final, unequivocal, asteriskless victory yesterday in the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

Mallick J. Fitzpatrick, who retired in 1966 as buyer for Institutional Commodity Services, Inc., purchasing department of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese, died here Thursday. He was 82 years old and lived at 94 Suffolk Lane, Garden City, L.I.
KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Dec. 11 Werner W. Hutz, a lawyer, died Wednesday in Delaware Hospital, Wilmington, Del. He was 63 years old and lived on Chandler Mill Road here.

A Forest Hills housewife told a hearing called by State Attorney Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday how both her automobile policy and homeowner's insurance coverage had been "arbitrarily" canceled although she had never filed a claim under either policy.

Lucile Collette, a former concert violinist-teacher and pianist who, despite her failing eyesight, had provided piano accompaniment in musical programs of The Lighthouse, died Thursday after a short illness at her home, 11 West 69th Street. She was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Moshe Dayan, the Israeli Defense Minister, reportedly urged the Nixon Administration today to put future arms supplies to Israel on a long-termcontract basis, like Soviet supplies to the United Arab Republic, rather than to negotiate each arms deal piecemeal when crises occur.

Albert Shanker the president of the United Federation of Teachers, has declared that Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, whom he has frequently criticized, "must succeed" as city school Chancellor because "if he fails, there's trouble ahead."
GENEVA, Dec. 11 Econ omy-class air travel between the United States and the Caribbean area is to cost 5 per cent more beginning April 1, the International Air Transport Association announced today.
The City Council's Housing Committee approved yesterday a measure that would allow plastic and paper bags to replace the standard metal garbage can.
An East Side housewife and her 16-year-old son are to receive $12,500 jointly for providing information that led to the conviction of a concrete company for polluting the East River.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week on an uptick yesterday as the list advanced on modern trading.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, stressed last night the importance of worker education programs but said that "unfortunately" America's educational system had not responded adequately.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 A General Assembly committee adopted a proposal tonight to improve the United Nations' ability to rush help to countries stricken by natural disasters.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Dec. 11 W. Arthur Riehl, former secretary of the Building Trades Employers Association of the City of New York, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 29 Old Colony Road.

We are now living in an age which is markedly, different from the 40's and 50's. History in our time has accelerated at a bewildering rate. The crucial drama enacted in the theater of the law is not the same today. Events have changed the plots, the story lines, the music and types of characters.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 11 (AP) An explosion ripped the University of Kansas computer center tonight three minutes after a telephoned threat of a bombing. Three persons were injured.
Meat operations in Argentina that lost $6,717,000 in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30 continued to depress results of Deltec International, Ltd., the company reported yesterday.

DALLAS, Dec. 9 Ph.D.'s are driving cabs in downtown Dallas, Electronics engineers are pumping gas in local filling stations and working as salesmen at Sanger-Harris, one of the city's biggest departmentstore chains.

The taxi strike went through its ninth day yesterday with no end in sight. No joint negotiations were held and none are scheduled.

A basic document of unusual frankness and precision sets the tone for the White House Conference on Children, which opens in Washington today. He will certainly be one of the youngest presidents in the league's 44-year-history, and he gives promise of being one of the most energetic.

The death toll on the nation's highways is expected by traffic safety experts to show this year its first significant drop since 1958. As the Senate enters its final crowded week before adjournment, the outlook is uncertain for two bills to establish new national parks. Nigga" given its premiere yesterday at Clark Center. But he aspires to a fusion of the two. It is the latter that currently eludes his creative grasp.

The Republic National Bank is offering, in "unlimited quantities." $20 United States gold pieces and gold English sovereigns. Most of them were obtained from European sources, apparently from Geneva.

The Health Department, jubilant over the results of a pilot project to exterminate rats in four blocks of central Harlem, announced plans yesterday to expand the program to 1,600 blocks of slum tenements across the city.

FREEPORT, Grand Bahamas, Dec. 13 (AP) Doug Sanders broke a three-year victory famine with a playoff triumph in the Bahama Islands open golf tournament today while Arnold Palmer's 15-year victory string went by the boards.

Elizabeth of New Jersey, the United States soccer champion, and New York Hota, the only undefeated team in the German-American League, engaged in a defensive duel yesterday and played to a scoreless tie.

Ogilvy Mather, the country's 12th largest agency, is on the verge of acquiring Carson/Roberts, the West Coast's largest shop.

A 20-year-old man tried to commit suicide by leaping from the Williamsburg Bridge into the East River, 150 feet below, yesterday, but was rescued from the water uninjured. Policemen had tried unsuccessfully for a half-hour to talk him out of the suicide attempt.
Cardinal Cooke, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, left by plane last night to visit American servicemen and their families in the Pacific area during the Christmas season.

PARIS, Dec.14 The Place de l'Etoile Will be renamed Place Charles de Gaulle tomorrow. It required the combined pressure of President Pompidou and the late President's family to subdue a rebellious municipal council.

A group of Roman Catholic and Protestant theologians has issued a 15-point statement of "consensus" on the meaning of Holy Communion indicating that they no longer regard traditionally divisive issues such as "transubstantiation" as ecumenical obstacles.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14 Syria warned today that she would not remain idle in face of what a Government spokesman in Damascus described as "plans to liquidate the Palestinian commando movement" in neighboring Jordan.
Three teams, Minnesota, Oakland and Baltimore, have qualified for the pro football playoffs while 10 others remain in contention for the additional five positions.

It is not for nothing that Martha Graham is the artistic adviser of the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel, now on its first visit to New York at the New York City Center. Miss Graham was the very first person consulted by the company's founder, Bethsabee de Rothschild, and she has been associated with this young Israeli troupe from the start.
HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Dec. 10 The supersonic strike version of the MIG-23 fighter is now being used by the Soviet Air Force in central Europe, according to qualified military sources.

HONG KONG, Dec. 14 (AP) Usually reliable Roman Catholic sources reported today that two Italian priests flew from Pakistan to Communist China last week, said mass in a Canton hotel room and then left the country by way of Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in September to seek some "easing of conditions" in the money market in order to bring about a growth in the money supply at a rate of 5 per cent, it was disclosed today.

SAIGON, Tuesday, Dec. 15 (AP) A United States infantry patrol was virtually wiped out when it inadvertently entered an old American mine field last Saturday night a mile south of the demilitarized zone, the United States command said today.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 The League of Red Cross Societies is drafting a plan for immediate use in the event that a tragedy comparable to the East Pakistan cyclone should hit other "disaster-prone" countries.

Something was added to the professional golfing scene yesterday when it was revealed that a $200,000 national match play championship would be held at the Country Club of North Carolina in Pinehurst from Aug. 25 through 29.

Reacting to a Government statement that resale privileges would not be extended beyond next spring for commercially stored wheat, corn and soybeans, most futures prices of those commodities dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Duncan G. Harris, chairman of the Manhattan realty concern of Brown, Harris Stevens, died Sunday at his home, 3 Beekman Place, after a short illness. He was 93 years old.
Mrs. Andrew Shiland of this city and Watch Hill, R.I., died Sunday at her home, 1 East 66th Street, after a long illness. She was 78 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 14 Some harness racing buffs wore a worried look as they spun the turnstiles at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. They were fretting over where to go for action after tomorrow night's final card of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Senator William Proxmire, leader of the drive that knocked out new funds for the supersonic transport in the Senate two weeks ago, offered today to schedule a fresh test of support for the project when the new Congress convenes next month.

ALGIERS, Dec. 1 Algerian officials say the nation's main handicap in its drive for industrial development is a shortage of engineers, technicians and skilled supervisors.

"Little Big Man," the film adaptation of Thomas Berger's epic comic novel, is Arthur Penn's most extravagant and ambitious movie, an attempt to capture the essence of the American heritage in the funny, bitter, uproarious adventures of Jack Crabb, an irritable, 120-oddyear-old gentleman who may or may not have been the sole survivor of Custer's Last Stand.

The London stock market moved sharply higher yesterday after an erratic performance at midday. Prices had dropped with the announcement of Britain's large trade deficit in November, but trading rallied with the news of the end of the electrical workers' dispute.

ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 12 A way of life as American as the farmhouse lightning rod, the corn crib and yellow squash put up in Ball jars died here on the spent farms of eastern Ohio a generation ago. Now it is literally being buried.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 14 The Nassau County Board of Supervisors adopted a budget for next year that will result in a tax increase of about $105 for the average homeowner.

WARSAW, Dec. 14 Poland's leaders approved major economic reforms today and Wladyslaw Gomulka, First Secretary of the Communist party, said the step "closes the old and opens a new stage in our economic development."

MANILA, Dec. 14 (UPI) Directors of the Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation voted today to suspend payment of cash dividends and recommended a 5-for-4 split of the common stock, to be distributed Feb. 26 to holders of record Jan. 29.

A pre-Civil War mansion in Greenwich Village than has been designated a historic landmark began receiving yesterday some of its latest occupants young people seeking rehabilitation from narcotic addiction.

The Bank of Buffalo, a $110million institution controlled by Financial General Bankshares, Inc., announced yesterday a reduction in its prime lending rate to 6 per cent from 7 per cent, effective today.

The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices for packaged custom-brand antifreeze by 5 cents a gallon, beginning Jan. 2. Shipments covered by current contracts will not be affected, the company added.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (UPI) Capital spending by the British manufacturing industry rose by about 1 per cent in the third quarter of 1970 compared with the previous three months, Government officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The United States has told the International Committee of the Red Cross that the American Government has a "residual" responsibility for South Vietnamese civilian detainees whom it turns over to the Government of South Vietnam.
SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 14 (AP) Patrick Russel, despite suffering an elbow sprain, won the special slalom race today, giving France its fourth victory in three days of ski competition.
