ALGIERS, Dec. 1 Trade and business relations between the United States and Algeria are flourishing despite the break in diplomatic ties three years ago.

Dr. J. Hamilton Crawford, director emeritus of the Long Island College Hospital Department of Medicine and professor emeritus of the department of medicine of the Downstate Medical Center, State University of New York, died yesterday. SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 (AP) Highly placed sources here reported today that the United States had formed a provisional air cavalry brigade with more than 200 helicopters to patrol 10,000 square miles around Saigon.

Dylan Thomas once called the Obernkirchen Children's Choir "Angels in Pigtails," and although there are not so many pigtails in the 1970 edition of the choir, the singing is still angelic.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) The Assembly Banking Committee is discussing possible legislation to permit banks to charge more interest for conventional mortgages.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) Nate Ramsey, 29-yearold captain and defensive back for the Philadelphia Eagles, was shot today as he stood on a street corner in West Philadelphia.

PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 14 Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the winner of the Palma knockout tournament than ended here yesterday, was voted the world's outstanding chess player of 1970 today by 70 jour nalists. Fischer, who led the six qualifiers for the competition that will determine the challenger for the world title, finished with a score of 18 4 , with 15 victories, four draws and only one loss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Office of Economic Opportunity, under sustained criticism, announced today that it was abandoning for the second time its plans to give nonlawyers control over its program of legal services for the poor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The chairman of a Senate subcommittee investigating 25 salmonella deaths in a Baltimore nursing home in July said today that he had seen no evidence of any wrongdoing by the nursing home in connection with the outbreak of the disease.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14 Ted Manakas, a sophomore guard, scored 25 points tonight to pace Princeton to a 78-68 victory over New York University.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Dec. 14 A 17-year-old New Canaan, Conn., youth sought since Thursday in the murder of four members of his family walked into police headquarters here this morning and told the officer on duty he had no idea how he had come to be in Arkansas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) A Philadelphia scientist reported today that a new rabies vaccine had shown dramatic success in laboratory animals, perhaps opening the door for protection of humans before and after exposure to the deadly virus.

The same wave of nostalgia that produced granny glasses and granny dresses has brought forth a rash of granny dolls and other paraphernalia reminiscent of the days when grandmothers sat in rocking chairs instead of jet planes. Sears Roebuck's Christmas catalogue, for one, ...

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Dec. 14 A. Edith Kingsland of 21 East Webster Avenue, this borough's first librarian, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital, Elizabeth, after a brief illness. She was 86 years old.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 14 (UPI) One of the nation's largest magazine subscription services, a subsidiary of Time Inc., has agreed to refund as much as $2-million in subscription fees in an agreement announced today by the Michigan Attorney General, Frank J. Kelley.
LONDON, Dec. 14 Field Marshal Viscount Slim, who led the campaign that liberated Burma in World War II, died in a hospital here today. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Government announced today plans to challenge the proposed $65-million merger of the two largest container-ship operators in the North Atlantic.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 City Councilman Louis Mason Jr. became today the first black man elected president of Pittsburgh's City Council.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation accused the Justice Department today of demanding last week that the company allocate 50 per cent of all office and clerical jobs at its plant in Fairfield, Ala., to blacks hired during the next five years.

The surprise ending to yesterday's 22d annual staff meeting of Ogilvy Mather was the announcement of the creation of the annual David Ogilvy Prize $10,000 for the campaign that created the most sales for a client.

By the end of this month the New York State Arts Council will announce the last of its grants from the special $18-million fund voted this year by the Legislature on Governor Rockefeller's recommendation for local assistance to cultural organizations.
Bayard Rustin, the civil rights organizer, declared last night that the American people "must get rid of black rage and white fear simultaneously, or we will not get rid of either."
Since the Soviet Union is geographically the world's largest country, the Supreme Soviet's adoption of a comprehensive water conservation and protection code is of international interest.

The Cleveland Cavaliers, who have already suffered through losing streaks of 15 and 12 games in their first National Basketball Association season, will bring a modest one of four games into Madison Square Garden tonight against the Knicks.

SYLVANLA, Ohio, Dec. 14 (UPI) Masao Ohba of Japan, Carlos Monzon of Argentina and Billy Backus of Syracuse, who won world titles, were named today as co-boxers of the month in the World Boxing Association ratings.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 14 Five defense witnesses at the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that when they stormed the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai they were under the clear impression that their company commander, Capt. Ernest L. Medina, wanted everyone killed, including women and babies.

Henry Ward Beer of 2768 East 16th Street, Brooklyn, a retired lawyer who was president for more than two decades of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, died Sunday after a long illness in a nursing home here. He was 89 years old.

Five children of a couple who vanished from West Germany last week while facing imprisonment on charges of torturing their maid arrived at Kennedy Airport from Frankfurt yesterday for a secret reunion with their parents.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 15 (AP) A ferry boat with 276 persons aboard sank early today in icy seas of the Korean Straits, police said. Early reports said Japanese fishing boats had picked up four survivors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if states may constitutionally deny welfare benefits to people because they are not United States citizens.
Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,424,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Most bridge experts achieve their best performances in their 30's and 40's. After the age of 50 stamina and power of concentration begin to decline somewhat. Technical knowledge and judgment may be unimpaired, but nevertheless few players capture national titles after the age of 60.

A financier and three business associates were convicted yesterday of a conspiracy to defraud the Securities and Exchange Commission by filing false statements concerning the acquisition of a $50-million conglomerate corporation.
Some of the merchants who cater to the carriage trade are now providing the carriages.

MIAMI, Dec. 14 (AP) Bill Hartack, a five-time winner of the Kentucky Derby, reached another milestone today when he rode his 4,000th winner, rallying from last place aboard Roart to win the seventh race at Tropical Park.
Almost 100 parents blocked traffic for more than two hours yesterday morning at West End Avenue and 96th Street to protest hazards their children face in going to school.

Vice President Agnew had a long private luncheon meeting here yesterday with the top executives of 15 major corporations and banks in the home of William F. Buckley Jr., editor in chief of the magazine National Review.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 14 A county judge who failed to place the names of Negro candidates on a ballot in 1968 went on trial here today on charges that he had deliberately ignored a Federal court order instructing him to include them.

In the middle of the week the St. Louis football forces were feted at their annual awards dinner and enthusiasm got so high that it developed into a pep rally worthy of yesteryear's collegiate traditionals. It was all aimed at the hated New York Giants, the next opponent, and the Cardinal old grads were blistering in their attacks and exhortations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Supreme Court has been informed that a case that it refused to hear involving taxes on Irish and Scotch whiskies may be taken to the World Court at the Hague, the Netherlands.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 Violette Jackson, formerly an oboist with the Little Orchestra Society of New York, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 33 years old and lived at 510 Wilcox Street in suburban Rochester.
Weeb Ewbank indicated yesterday that the Jets' first-round draft choice might be auctioned.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 14 In a move that could bring a direct confrontation with Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller plans to propose legislation permitting the State Controller, Arthur Levitt, to audit the fi- nances of New York City, Buf- falo and Rochester. These are the only three municipalities now exempt from his audit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The National Conference of Catholic Bishops issued today guidelines aimed at easing the burdens of marriages between Roman Catholics and nonCatholics.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. has made a substantial recovery in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, following a major reorganization and implementation of substantial economies initiated by James T. Aubrey Jr., who took over the presidency on Oct. 21, 1969.
FRANKLIN, N.J., Dec. 14 (AP) Alfred B. Littell, a former State Senate President, died Saturday in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he was on vacation with his wife, Dorothy. He was 77 years old.

A newspaperman was seriously injured and four other persons suffered minor injuries yesterday when the gangway between a new container ship and a tugboat became discon nected, throwing two persons into the water and pitching the others on to the deck of the tug.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 The Israeli Government remains opposed to any direct political dealings with Arab leaders of the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River, Israeli officials said today. They insisted that the Palestinians' political future must be worked out only between them and the Jordanian Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) The Defense Department today left open the door for a slowdown or even a complete stop in troop withdrawals from South Vietnam in the next two months in face of an enemy build-up of men and supplies before Tet, the Lunar New Year.
President Nixon's decision to replace Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy with John B. Connally Jr., former Governor of Texas, came as a complete surprise ...

WASHINGTON Not even fourteen years of service in the United States Senate prepared me for the kind of propaganda blitz that was organized against America's participation in the development of a supersonic transport plane.

Prices finished mostly lower on the American Stock ExExchange yesterday as the list eased throughout the session in slightly stepped-up trading. Brokers attributed most of the weakness to profit taking following the market's recent strong showing.
Fuel oil truck drivers who serve 40 per cent of the city's homes and businesses went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today after they had rejected angrily a $60a-week increase in wages and benefits.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Broadcasters will no longer have to carry antismoking messages once the ban on cigarette commercial begins Jan. 2, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 President Nixon signed today a bill restoring to the Taos Pueblo Indians the use of 48,000 acres in the Carson National Forest.

The Batsheva Dance Company of Israel has just started its second and last week at the New York City Center. It really should be seen although, as I say that, I must admit to some uncertainty as to whether there are any tickets left. Last night, at least in the orchestra, empty seats were few and far between. And deservedly. This is, without any qualification at all, a troupe of simply wonderful dancers.

LONDON When President Nixon reviews the world this week with Prime Minister Edward Heath he will find the latter perhaps less worried about the chances of a military confrontation in the Middle East between the United States and Russia than by the possibility that the Soviets might get their way in that key area without any confrontation at all.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 15 Bridgeport's antipoverty agency was the target last night of an apparent fire-bombing, which burned out an office and a porch at the back of the agency's headquarters in a former mansion across the street from City Hall.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 Reliable sources said tonight that the trial of 11 persons, most of them believed to be Jews accused in a plot to hijack a Soviet airliner in June, began today in Leningrad.

ROME, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Thousands of demonstrating students marched through the streets of major Italian cities today while half the nation was paralyzed by strikes called to demand social reforms from the Government.
STREATOR, Ill., Dec. 15 (AP) Reuben G. Soderstrom, former president of the Illinois A.F.L.-C.I.O., died today. He was 82 years old and made his home here.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 15 Hyman Katz of 557 Dow Place, owner of the Tenafly Department Store, which he operated until his retirement in 1967, died today in Englewood Hospital after a short illness. He was 90 years old.

Signings. The President signed a bill restoring the Blue Lake lands to the Taos Pueblo Indians. He signed legislation giving the Government greater powers to regulate the fees charged mutual funds investors. He also signed a bill increasing Interior appropriations and authorization for domestic travel promotions.

The marriage of Miss Frances Porteous Rogers to Daniel Obdulla Zilkha took place at the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday afternoon. The bride is the daughter of Andrew Y. Rogers, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis Polk Wardwell, and Mrs. Rogers of New York and Prouts Neck, Me. Mr. Zilkha is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abdulla K. Zilkha of Paris. His father is an investment banker.

An international team of experts has made a practical proposal for advancing the United Nations into a more meaningful role in the control of population growth. The mission, appointed by U Thant, believes the Secretary General already has authority under General Assembly and Economic and Social Council directives to establish a World Population Institute as a semiautonomous body within the United Nations system.

He is 200 years old today, and more alive than he ever was. He came from the provincial town of Bonn, in Germany, went to Vienna, where the action was, and within a few years changed the face of music. He also helped change the face of society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Trustees of the financially troubled Penn Central Transportation Company threatened today to curtail Christmas shipments and shut down the railroad completely within a few weeks unless Congress votes emergency cash help for the largest line in the nation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) The Republican national chairman, Rogers C.B. Morton, announced today that Jim Allison Jr. had resigned as deputy chairman.

PARIS, Dec. 15 The new street sign reading "Place Charles de Gaulle" was unveiled today in the presence of Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas and other Gaullist faithful at what was formerly the Place de l'Etoile. At the same time, hostile shouts went up from the crowd massed behind police barricades in a confrontation between partisans and opponents of the change of name.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the financially troubled International Investors Group Management, Ltd., said here yesterday that he would be a member of a new four-man "management committee" that will administer the affairs of I.I.G.'s Real Estate Fund of America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Interest yields declined today in the Federal National Mortgage Association's regular auction of $124.8-million in mortgage purchase commitments.

The numbers game, played daily by a million bettors in this city, does a gross annual business here of $250-million and provides the livelihood of more than 10,000 employes of organized crime, the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime was told yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 15 (UPI) Wittenberg University, which completed the football season undefeated and shared the Ohio Conference championship with Capital, forfeited its nine victories today because its all-Conference tackle, Rick Mako, had not registered for fall classes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 Dr. Edoardo Weiss, who introduced psychoanalysis in Italy and had practiced here since 1941, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 Senator Jacob K. Javits declared today in the General Assembly that he would urge Congress to remove a major impediment now restricting fuller use of the International Court of Justice at the Hague.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 The game ball, the token of one of the Detroit Lions' sweetest-victories, went to Steve Owens by acclaim. The acclaim for the popular rookie came from his teammates following the Lions' 28-23 victory over the Rams in Los Angeles last night.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 Dr. Clarence W. Mendell, a Latin scholar and former dean of Yale College, died Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. His age was 87.

A national commission of medical experts recommended in a report released yesterday that Americans make "safe and reasonable" changes in their diets to lower blood cholesterol levels in the hope of stemming the current "epidemic" of heart disease.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 15 (UPI) The United States consul here said today that an American couple who fled to the United States to escape prison terms in West Germany had received a fair trial in Frankfurt on charges of mistreating their Turkish housemaid.

Ashland Oil, Inc., had higher sales in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, but earnings from operations fell 10.2 per cent to $51,090,000, or $2.09 a share, from $56,880,000, or $2.42 a share, in the preceding fiscal year, its report yesterday showed.

The president of an association that represents public school principals and supervisors took a court order to the Joan of Arc Junior High School yesterday in an attempt to reinstate a principal, but instead had to leave under threat of arrest.
TAPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 15 A conference on developments in Communist China opened here today with some participants from the United States demanding that working sessions be closed to the press.

MWEKA, Tanzania During the last few months of his college life Balogu O'Neil has shot four elephants, struggled with the mysteries of parametric statistics and the rules of evidence, diverted the unwelcome attentions of a rhinoceros by throwing his binoculars at it and gone on safari with George Plimpton.
LONDON, Dec. 15 The House of Commons gave a nod of approval today to a plea for stricter measures to discourage the use of tobacco.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Charles H. Older today ordered that the Sharon Tate murder trial resume on Monday after a two-week break, but a newly appointed attorney said he would move for a mistrial for one of the women defendants, Leslie Van Houten.

Benjamin M. Hall III, a writer and historian of American movie theaters and an expert on old theater organs, was found dead in his apartment early today with his throat slashed, according to the police.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, parent company of the $13-billion Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, announced yesterday a two-forone stock split and an 11.4 per cent increase in the dividend rate.

Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eight-time United States chess champion, who has just won the Palma, Majorca, interzonal knockout round robin, is paired with Grandmaster Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union in the first step of the world championship elimination matches.
Two cabbies were arrested yesterday in a fracas involving about 150 striking cab drivers and the police at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 15 The trial of J. Dennis Herndon, an Alabama judge charged with contempt of Federal Court, ended here today, with a verdict from a threejudge panel expected in early January.
Plans for the National Football League's four divisional playoff games the weekend of Dec. 26 and 27 were further clarified yesterday.
Weekend golfers waste too much time idly watching other weekend golfers line up their shots, Billy Casper suggested here yesterday.

A program to improve the nutrition of 200,000 East Harlem slum dwellers mostly Puerto Ricans was announced yesterday as a joint endeavor of Cornell University, New York Medical College and the East Harlem Health Council.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's largest trust bank, with close to $20billion in assets under its administration, was charged yesterday in a civil suit with violations of the antitrust and securities laws in its allocation of brokerage business in the buying and selling of securities.
THE HAGUE, Dec. 15 (UPI) An international conference on air law today approved a convention calling for "severe penalties" for air hijackers and ruling out any excuse because of political motives.

The principal of Jamaica High School in Queens was threatened with contempt charges yesterday for allegedly harassing students who remained seated during the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 Three more long-time members of Governor Rockefeller's cabinet plan to resign soon to make way for younger men as part of Mr. Rockefeller's plan to make his fourth term in office "a period of change, of innovation, of creation to meet changing needs."

An American Airlines executive said yesterday that the continuing slump in air travel was prompting the nation's air lines to review orders for large jet airliners, creating a situation that may add further problems for the aerospace industry.

H. Ross Perot, chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, sold 500,000 shares of his company's stock $28.25million worth yesterday in a secondary offering managed by R.W. Pressprich Co., Inc., at $56.50 a share. The industrialist's holdings in the Dallasbased concern were thus reduced to 73.7 per cent, or 8,537,990. Pressprich reported the stock entirely sold.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 15 (AP) "I only regret I didn't sink the ship," one of the seamen who hijacked a United States munitions freighter said today as he walked into the American Embassy here to surrender.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 (UPI) Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., playing his last tournament before entering the armed forces, won the $50,000 Grand Prix Masters today, although he lost his final match with Arthur Ashe.

A lawyer's plea to hold off a client's one-year jail term until after Christmas for family reasons was rejected yesterday when the District Attorney countered that the man was also an "heir apparent" to a major Mafia family.
The National Cash Register Company announced yesterday a new computer for small businesses that will rent for $1,500 a month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., the Nixon Administration's new Commissioner of Education, said today that busing to achieve school integration was generally desirable but could become "counterproductive" if large groups of children were hauled long distances.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 A declaration of principles envisioning for all countries a just share in the wealth of the unexplored depths of the sea was approved in the General Assembly's main Political Committee today by a vote of 90 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The House voted 205 to 185 today to block a move to send back to conference the proposed $210-million compromise appropriation for the supersonic transport. The measure now goes to the Senate.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has promised not to write letters threatening debtors with lawsuits when no such legal action is intended by the bank, according to Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

Rent increases retroactive to August now in effect for nearly one million rent-controlled apartments in the city were challenged as unconstitutional yesterday by the Legal Aid Society and a Government financed antipoverty group.

The Board of Education promised last night to investigate a charge by parents that 300 students attending George Washington High School in upper Manhattan would be transferred Feb. 1.

The commission investigating charges of widespread corruption in the Police Department says that one reason it has called top police commanders to testify is to determine whether bribes "filter upward to higher ranking officers."

John D. Harper, chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, predicted yesterday that United States shipments of aluminum next year should show a gain of at least 5 per cent in contrast to an expected 5 per cent decline this year from 1969.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15 (AP) The price for dropping a thoroughbred's name into the Kentucky Derby entry box went up today from $500 to $1,000.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 15 (AP) The Vancouver Canucks defeated the Philadelphia Flyers tonight, 3-2, in a National Hockey League game.
The RCA Corporation yesterday eliminated its holdings of 250,000 shares of the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) through an unregis tered secondary distribution.

ROME, Dec. 15 The Vatican disclosed today that it had made what it termed insistent requests to the Spanish Government to show clemency if death sentences are passed in the trial of 15 Basque nationalists in Burgos.
A gambling conspiracy said to have taken up to $30-million a year in bets was broken up yesterday with the arrest of nine men and a woman, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today an investigation of railroad freight-rate structures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Robert W. Lishman, chief counsel of the House Commerce Committee's subcommittee on investigations, died today of cancer at Sibley Hospital. He was 67 years old.

Bell-ringing, music, lights, dancing and a midnight display of fireworks are planned for this year's New Year's Eve party at the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park, Dore Schary, Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, announced yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15 (Reuters) South Vietnam was reported to have sent a 3,000-man force deep into Cambodia today in response to an appeal for help from Premier Lon Nol.

John Neville will make his American musical stage debut as star of the new Alan Jay Lerner and John Barry musical based on Vladimir Nabokov's "Lolita," it was announced yesterday by Norman Twain, the producer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Many Czechoslovak refugees in the United States, Canada and Western Europe, who fled their country after the Soviet-led invasion in 1968, are being advised from Prague that they face criminal proceedings for "illegal" presence abroad.

DENVER, Dec. 14 A group of 118 practicing physicians have just completed a two-day course here that taught them how to use a new international code to classify the abnormal white spots that appear on chest X-rays of coal workers with black lung disease.
TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 15 (AP) Federal District Court Judge George Boldt denied bail today for seven persons convicted of contempt of court in connection with a conspiracy trial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The Food and Drug Administration announced today that, as a precautionary measure, a minimum of almost one million cans of tuna fish contaminated by mercury were being withdrawn from the market. The agency insisted, however, that the product was still safe to eat.
Four outstanding horses from the Stanley Dancer Stable will be among the 240 standardbreds to be sold at the Winter Old Glory Sale tomorrow at Yonkers Raceway.
A one-day deer hunt scheduled for this Saturday in the Great Swamp Wildlife Refuge Wilderness in Morris County, N.J., was temporarily barred yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 15 The president of Rutgers said today that an increasing number of bomb threats were likely to "bring the university to a standstill."

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 15 (Reuters) England struggled to save the second cricket test today against Australia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15 New measures went into effect this morning easing restrictions on civil liberties and permitting Syrians to travel abroad freely for the first time in nearly 20 years.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 15 John Kingsley Livingston, who retired in 1953 as a director, vice president and secretary of the American Express Company, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 82 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) The police charged Jimmie Louis Harrison today with the wounding of Nate Ramsey, the star defensive back of the Philadelphia Eagles.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 15 Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis officially won re-election today when a recount that had begun on Nov. 23 showed he had defeated his Republican opponent, Attorney General James S. Erwin, by 500 votes. Mr. Erwin conceded his defeat.

A civil complaint was filed in Federal court yesterday charging the General Motors Corporation with dumping paint-spray residues into the Hudson River from its assembly plant at Tarrytown, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The Justice Department announced today the establishment of a Consumer Affairs Section in its Antitrust Division to centralize functions now performed by several departmental units.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Hamer H. Budge, the departing chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is again on the brink of taking a position with the mutual funds managed by Investors Diversified Services, Inc.
HONOLULU, Dec. 15 (UPI) Hawaii became today the first state in the nation to provide a prepaid medical care plan for welfare families.
Under heavy public buying and short-covering, soybeans futures prices advanced nearly 5 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
There will be no public sale of tickets for championship playoff games at Yankee Stadium if the Giants do qualify, but season-ticket subscribers have been sent ticket applications in the mail.
The chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company said last night that people should turn off their lights to help reduce air and water pollution.
The New York Knicks' practice sessions sometimes are more interesting than their 110-92 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers was last night at Madison Square Garden.
Some fresh and enlivening additions to the normal bluegrass repertory were brought to New York on Monday evening by a young group from Lexington, Ky., J.D. Crowe and the Kentucky Mountain Boys.

Is Beethoven still relevant 200 years after his birth? Even to pose the question seems ludicrous, for his works remain a staple of the repertory and in the traditional hierarchy of values they represent one of the glories of civilization. But to a former music critic like...

American space scientists hope that the penetration of Russia's Venus 7 capsule into the atmosphere of Venus will help resolve some of the more stubborn questions regarding that planet, in particular the nature of the clouds that completely conceal its surface.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 15 C.W. Post and New York Tech scored semifinal victories today and advanced to the final of the Schaefer Long Island basketball tournament at Island Garden.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 The 200th anniversary of Ludwig van Beethoven's birth tomorrow will be celebrated all over the world, but surely nowhere with more fervor than in this ancient capital of music where the composer lived for most of his life, did his greatest works and died lonesome in the gloom of a Danubian winter.

Two-thirds of The Old Smoothies, the probable rookie of the year and the player hockey fans love to call "The Wild Man" will be playing for the Sabres tonight when they make their second Madison Square Garden appearance against the Rangers.

ALLENHURST, N.J., Dec. 15 Kenneth H. Creveling, director of the New Jersey State Division of Natural Resources and chairman of the board of Allaire State Park, died at his office at the park yesterday apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived at 309 Norwood Avenue here.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 The Soviet Union's latest Venus probe, Venus 7, reached its destination today but apparently did not improve on the performance of the twin Soviet missions to the planet last year.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 Volkswagen announced today the second price increase for its 1971 Beetle models.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 15 A homemade fire bomb went off early today in Army R.O.T.C. offices at the University of Connecticut, causing damage to military records that officials described as modest.
Lukas Foss says in the program notes for his new work, "MAP," that "for the performer it is a game, for the listenerviewer it is a piece of music."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 15 (UPI) Track and field events in the sixth Asian Games ended today with Japan taking six more gold medals for a total of 19 over the six days of the competition.

The National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, a citizens' group that has been one of commercial broadcasting's more consistent gadflies, is moving to Washington, where the ongoing change in its stance from public to legal advocate will become more apparent.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers built an early 19-point lead, withstood a third-period rally and went on to beat the San Diego Rockets, 122-98, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Industrial production declined further in November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, and this time the blame could not be placed on the General Motors strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced today that he would visit South Vietnam early next month to confer with Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the American field commander, on the prospect for troop reductions.
GREENVILLE, N.C., Dec. 15 (UPI) Sonny Randle, former all-pro pass receiver for the St. Louis Cardinals, was named today to succeed Mike McGee as head football coach at East Carolina University.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 15 A witness testified today that he saw a bizarre scene the night Howard R. Hughes departed from his penthouse sanctuary in the Desert Inn on the Las Vegas Strip.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Capt. Susan Struck, unmarried nurse who became a mother, appealed today to Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas to block her discharge from the Air Force.
Price increases covering certain paper products and chemicals were announced yesterday by a number of companies.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15, (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today that time had proved President Nixon right in ordering American troops into Cambodia last spring.
NORTH HAMPTON, N.H., Dec. 15 (AP) A breeding mare in foal was destroyed today in a fire at the farm of Peter Fuller, the owner of Dancer's Image, the 1968 Kentucky Derby winner.
LONDON, Dec. 15 The House of Commons approved in principle tonight the Government's broad proposal for reform of labor-management relations in Britain.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 15 The University of California, facing a financial crisis, announced today a series of stringent budgetary measures, including a freeze on hiring.

The "Motown Sound" of Stevie Wonder singing his hit recording of "Signed, Sealed, Delivered I'm Yours" is now applicable to all the New York Jets except Pete Lammons, tight end, and Verlon Biggs, defensive end, but nobody seems to be worried.

The London stock market yesterday continued Monday's strong trend. Renewed small buying and a lack of selling pushed prices ahead, but the total trading volume remained depressed. Second line issues as well as leading ones received support and the industrials were generally very firm.
Basil A. Paterson, whose term as State Senator ends on Dec. 31, will join The New York Law Journal the following day as executive vice president and special features editor.
A Federal judge here has ruled that a three-judge court must be convened to consider whether a 15-year-old youth has the right to a jury trial on a charge of juvenile delinquency.

The finding of a House Judiciary subcommittee that no convincing basis exists for the impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas should bring to an end this sorry episode in the relationship of the Nixon Administration, the House of Representatives and the Supreme Court.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia There's incense in the air, and we were feasting on things called yebeg alicha, a tender lamb dish flavored with Bishops weed and saffron; doro watt, the Ethiopian chicken and hard-cooked egg dish with a light pepper sauce; and minchet abish, a ground beef dish that tasted lightly of cinnamon and pepper. The gomen watt, made with spinach and shallots, was delectable, and the native drink, tej, made with gesho hops...

In the current hunt for a viable "incomes policy," the proposal for a tax to discourage excess wage increases has achieved some modest notoriety. On the assumption that the way it works is broadly familiar to raise the profits tax for firms that grant excessive wage increases I would like to examine some of its strengths as well as defects.
The settlement of "a large portion" of the Government's securities violation lawsuit against the Parvin-Dohrmann Company and 13 individuals was handed yesterday to a Federal judge here.
The City Planning Commission, reacting to appeals for more classrooms, indicated yesterday that more new schools would be added to its list of six approved for construction next year.

Not since 1963 97 games ago have the New York Giants played a game with a championship at stake. Not since Dec. 15, 1963, has there been such a game at Yankee Stadium. On that Sunday, the Giants clinched the Eastern Conference title by beating the Pittsburgh Steelers 33-17, in their final regular-season game.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 15 Roosevelt Raceway, concluding its 31st year, realized its first $3-million single-card mutuel handle tonight as a crowd of 24,600 wagered $3,118,346. The card ended the New York harness racing campaign of 297 nights, 142 of which were presented at Yonkers Raceway.
The Masco Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire Comonwealth Industries, Inc., a Detroit metallurgical company for common stock worth about $11-million.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 15 Six officials of a teamsters union local were arrested today and accused of waging a two-and-ahalf-hour "reign of terror" to force the employes of a Long Island company to withdraw their applications to leave the union.

DENVER, Dec. 15 (AP) A Federal judge has ordered the Colorado Corporation, headed by John M. King, to pay a $1.1million debt to a Michigan bank by Friday or the court will place Mr. King's 117-acre mountain ranch near Granby, Colo., on the auction block.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 It was Kids' Day today at the White House Conference on Children.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Dec. 15 Karl L. Beisbart, founder of the K.L.B. Tool Manufacturing Company of Union, died yesterday at East Orange General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 500 Meisel Avenue here.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, has introduced a note of reason into the conflict between some of the city's professional educators and Dr. Harvey Scribner, the new chancellor. Writing in his new column (published as a paid advertisement), Mr. Shanker has appealed to the professional staff to think of Dr. Scribner's success as essential to the future strength of public education in New York.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. Dec. 15 Mrs. Rosino Brice West Hastings, widow of George Aubrey Hastings, who was an administrative assistant to President Herbert Hoover and later public relations counsel to educational and social service organizations, died today at the home of her daughter after a brief illness. She was 82 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 15 Brazilian soldiers and state policemen spent the day today searching a jungle-covered area of the city for the kidnappers of the Swiss Ambassador, but most of the searchers were withdrawn tonight.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 15 The shooting at Mylai of wounded Vietnamese children was described today at the murder trial of First Lieut, William L. Calley Jr. by a former squad leader who acknowledged that he had helped "put 'em out of their misery."

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 16 Three hundred and eight persons were still missing this morning and feared drowned after a South Korean ferryboat carrying a total of 320 passengers and crewmen sank early yesterday morning in the Korea Strait.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 A House subcommittee released today what it termed "a mountain of evidence" on which it based its conclusions that there were no grounds for impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Wednesday, Dec. 16 A Polish radio station reported today that militiamen had clashed with rioters in three Polish cities on the coast of the Baltic Sea, resulting in an unknown number of deaths and at least 150 injuries to militiamen.

How's that again? Morris Schapiro against the world? That's the way it seems at this point as the scrappy bank-stock dealer battles an impressive array at talent from the New York Stock Exchange over the investor protection legislation.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 15 (AP) Jim Maloney, a hardthrowing right-hander of the Cincinnati Reds, was dealt to the California. Angels today for Greg Garrett, a 22year-old left-hander.

ROME, Dec. 15 A Vatican spokesman said tonight that Pope Paul VI was suffering from influenza and had canceled his weekly general audience that was scheduled to be held in St. Peter's Basilica tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 A House-Senate conference committee introduced a possible loophole today in the proposed legislative restraints on President Nixon's power to send ground troops to Cambodia.
The stock market, in a virtual copy of Monday's performance, pulled back slightly yesterday as it consolidated recent strong advances.

Eastern Air Lines named a new president and chief operating officer, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company shifted its top management and the American Can Company added two new top-line vice presidents. These were among the top executive promotions announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 President Nixon celebrated today a landmark economic statistic that has been achieved, in part, by the inflation that he has spent two years trying to control.

Senator-elect James, L Buckley, who proclaimed himself a member of the "Nixon team" the day after his election, indicated yesterday that he was ready to oppose the President on two controversial programs welfare reforms and the financing of a supersonic jet transport.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 "Banzai for the Emperor!" a rightist youth shouted at a memorial meeting for Yukio Mishima here last week.

Weird distributions at the bridge table often give rise to weird episodes. Many of the contestants in the Open Pairs at the Fall Nationals in Houston last month had strange stories to tell about the diagramed deal.
The Communist party, which ran a state ticket for the first time in 28 years in the Nov. 3 election, polled 7,760 votes for Rasheed Storey, its candidate for Governor.
Policemen who were called to help a city marshal evict an elderly couple from their Lower East Side apartment yesterday took up a collection instead to keep the couple in their home.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (UPI) Bill Sutherland scored two goals for St. Louis tonight as the Blues avenged their worst loss at home this season with a 2-1 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

The Midwest Stock Exchange, a leading regional securities market in Chicago, issued a challenge yesterday to the positions taken recently by top officials of the New York Stock Exchange on major issues confronting the securities industry.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) Illinois voters approved today a new state Constitution streamlining the revenue system, granting home rule powers to local governments and banning employment and housing bias.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Treasury Department took the first step today in determining whether Canadian pig iron is being dumped on the United States market.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 Aeronaves de Mexico, the Mexican Government airline, announced today that fares would be reduced by up to 20 per cent on flights from New York and other United States points starting next April 1.

An important bill to insure investors against losses of cash and securities in the event of brokerage house failures is now in conference, having been passed in different versions by both houses of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Capt. Robert T. Norris, Coast Guard Deputy Chief, Office of Boating Safety, and chairman of the National Safe Boating Committee, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Arlington, Va. His age was 49.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Stephen Hess, chairman of the Seventh White House Conference on children, finally said "No" today to increasingly noisy demands from caucuses that there be a full session of all 4,000 delegates to give President Nixon a "mandate" for action.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc. expects to receive an extension of a $23-million bank loan maturity due Jan. 31, according to Paul Thayer, chairman and president. He said yesterday that the proposal received favorable response during meetings this week with the banks in its credit lines.
The head of a Government panel studying supersonic transport noise said yesterday that the technology was now available to make the SST almost as quiet as the best of the subsonic jets.

Jim Hall's Chaparral 2J, the radically designed race car that threatened the McLaren team's domination of the Canadian-American Challenge Cup, has been banned by the Commission Sportive Internationale, the world governing body.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Representative Martin B. McKneally, Republican of Newburgh, N.Y., was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to file Federal income tax returns for 1964 through 1967.

VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 16 Betsy Clifford, her blond pigtail stretched out flat behind her, charged to the women's special slalom victory today at the Criterium of the First Snow and proved that the French won't win every Alpine skiing race this season.

MADRID, Dec. 16 In a crowded Bilbao restaurant a couple of weeks ago, a Swedish journalist asked a Basque lawyer why the Basque guerrilla group known as ETA should be judged any differently from, say, the French Canadian extremists who recently kidnapped a...
The New York State Insurance Department has modified its approval of a novel program at Cartier, Inc., the Fifth Avenue jewelry concern.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 16 C. W. Post College, paced by Ed Klimkowski and Russell Wilson, rolled to a 67-49 victory tonight over New York Tech in the final of the Shaefer Long Island basketball tournament at the Island, Garden.
The chant of "Digger, Digger, Digger" rang out in Columbia's University gymnasium last night, a tribute to Dick (Digger) Phelps, who has brought new life to Fordham basketball.
SAIGON, Thursday, Dec. 17 High-ranking American officials here reportedly have recommended a complete halt in the program of crop-destroying herbicides long used to deny food to the enemy.

At 11 o'clock yesterday morning, Margaret Siss, a secretary, was busy hanging pictures in the 11th-floor offices of Irving R. Boody Co., exporters and importers of raw materials. In an adjoining room, Frank Ramirez was hunched over his desk checking out invoices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that a $2billion cut in the defense budget voted by a House-Senate conference committee and approved by the House today would "increase the risks to our national security."
George E. Ford of Rochester, president of The Ruffed Grouse Society of America, believes the population of grouse in New York State is at an all-time low.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 16 (UPI) The Kentucky Racing Commission voted unanimously' today to appeal a State District Court ruling that awarded first-place money in the disputed 1968 Kentucky Derby to Dancer's Image.

ROME, Dec. 16 Small, pugnacious bands of young neo-Fascists have been parading in front of Spanish diplomatic and consular buildings in various Italian cities, and clashing with antiFranco demonstrators and the police. The trial of Basque separatists in Burgos, Spain, has spurred protests against the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Of the 10 teams vying for the five remaining playoff positions and a shot at the Super Bowl riches, the Detroit Lions deserve on merit to qualify more than the others. Yet the Lions, second behind Minnesota in their division, are in one of the most precarious positions.

If Maria Pia Buccellati called her husband, Luca, and asked him to bring home a cabbage and a couple of pheasants, he wouldn't consider going to market. Nor would he be alarmed that she had taken leave of her senses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Justice William O. Douglas announced his intention today to remain on the Supreme Court and urged young Americans to "keep the faith" by working for racial justice and a pollution-free environment.
TOKYO, Dec. 16 Japan's protracted textile negotiations with the United States have reached a point where the outcome could well cause the downfall of the Eisaku Sato cabinet.

Dr. Yale Kneeland Jr., professor emeritus of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, who contributed notably to the understanding of respiratory diseases, died Tuesday at his home in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

When preparing for one game to settle the championship, football teams diligently seek out, any possible tiny edge, mental or physical. And when Fran Tarkenton, in the center of the spotlight, lines up at quarterback for the New York Giants at Yankee Stadium Sunday, he will have at least this going for him: a personal history of success against the Los Angeles Rams.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 17 The acting skipper of the Namyong-Ho, the ferryboat that sank in the Korea Strait Tuesday with a loss of more than 300 lives, was arrested today, and the police began to question several officials of the Maritime Agency.
The Dow-Jones industrial average, down by almost 5 points at noon, displayed some of its recent bounce yesterday by staging a strong recovery before the closing bell.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 16 (UPI) South Carolina crushed previously undefeated Maryland, 96-70, tonight is a game halted with 4:52 remaining by a brawl that involved players, fans and police.

DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 16 Mrs. Marioara Cole Conovich of 64 Arrowhead Way, a goddaughter of the late Queen Marie of Rumania, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital after a long illness. She was 59 years old. Her parents, the late Mr. and Mrs. Almerson Hyde Cole of Morristown, N.J., and East Norwalk, lived in Rumania before World War I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that the power of grand juries to investigate crimes could be endangered by a landmark lower court ruling in favor of Earl Caldwell, a reporter for The New York Times.

Dedicating a newly devised "G.N.P. clock," President Nixon observed with pride that the United States has become the world's first trillion-dollar economy. Informed that even as he spoke, the clock would race ahead at the rate of $2,000 a second, the President was carried away with the thought of "how much that is going to mean if we just keep it moving and perhaps move it faster in the years ahead."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 An angry group of Republican Senators is working to block the selection by President Nixon of Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas as the party's new national chairman.

The complicated and still deadlocked taxi dispute appears almost unique among recent strikes here affecting the general public: Relatively few people have been complaining, and these few not very loudly. Public officials are feeling little pressure. And some people are even cheering.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for the three and 12 months ended Nov. 30. Net income for the quarter topped the year-ago level but fell slightly behind the amount reported in the 12 months ended Nov. 30, 1969.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec, 16 (AP) The Soviet Union has increased its manpower in the United Arab Republic to more than 20,000, reports reaching here said today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 President Nixon's popularity has slipped to 52 per cent, the lowest level since he took office, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
The City Planning Commission completed hearings on its $1.6-billion capital spending program yesterday after three days of being denounced, harangued, accused, ridiculed, prodded and cajoled.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Youngsters will sing carols and read Biblical lessons at a White House Christmas service on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Whatever else it may be doing with its recent flurry of statements designed to justify a substantial resumption of the bombing of North Vietnam, the Administration is flirting with the same tactics that opened President Johnson's fatal credibility gap the halftruth, the untruth and anything but the truth.

SYRACUSE Al Butler stopped slicing ham in the back of his small familyowned supermarket on Gertrude Street, wiped his fingers on a long white butcher's smock and recounted his latest encounter with the police:
LONDON, Dec. 16 The Government pressed today for an end to free admission to national museums and galleries amid a mounting outcry from artists.

The most solid of tributes to Beethoven on his 200th birthday, a new production of his only opera, was the Metropolitan Opera's contribution to the centennial. "Fidelio" was given last night, timed to the exact day. Thus this city held up its head on a day when Beethoven anniversaries were being celebrated in many cities of the world.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 16 Vice President Agnew met for almost three hours this morning with 21 Republican Governors and Governors-elect, many of whom criticized his campaign tactics and the remoteness of the White House.
BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Fare increases for Northeast Airlines beginning Jan. 11 have been approved on an interim basis by the Civil Aeronautics Board, pending an investigation.

LONDON, Dec. 16 Religion is gaining strength in the Soviet Union, particularly among the young, according to a report published here tonight. Nevertheless, it added, "the militantly atheistic Soviet state is still bent on ultimately rooting religion out of society altogether."

An independent investigating group charged in a 400-page report that was released yesterday that the paper industry was one of the nation's major polluters and was lagging far behind in the clean-up effort.
Vermont Royster, a reporter and writer of The Wall Street Journal for 35 years and the paper's editor for the last 12, announced his retirement yesterday, effective in mid-January.

George Balanchine's "The Nutcracker," given by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater, is terribly good. I like it, much more significantly, my children adore it, and it is one of the best two or three productions ever to grace the face of the earth. Why then do I not respond to it with the easy eagerness I bring to the two other Tchaikovsky ballets, "Swan Lake" and "The Sleeping Beauty?"
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 16 The fire on Dec. 5 at the Linden, N.J., refinery of the Humble Oil and Refining Company today forced a slight cut in Texas oil production for January.

Arriving late for last Sunday night's "Republican Victory Dinner" at the Meadowbrook Lodge, near Newburgh, N.Y., Representative Martin Boswell McKneally quickly made it clear that he felt a bit out of place. The unhappy fact was that Mr. McKneally had little to feel

BRUSSELS, Dec. 16 Five and a half years after President de Gaulle withdrew the French delegation from Brussels to protest supranationalism in the Common Market, the member states are locked today in a new struggle over the power of their institutions.

Representatives of H. Ross Perot, chairman of Electronic Data Systems, Inc., announced yesterday that they had fulfilled a previous commitment by making a $10-million loan to F.I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 16 (UPI) James Noel (Jim) Pittman, who coached Tulane to an upset victory over Colorado in the Liberty Bowl, resigned today to accept a five-year coaching pact with Texas Christian University.
TOKYO, Dec. 16 "Religion is absolute," Hiroshi Hojo said, "But politics is relative. Therein lies the difference between the two."
The Baltic cities of Gdansk, Sopot and Gdynia are Polish show windows to the world, normally brimming with tourists, industry and international trade.
MIAMI, Dec. 16 Mrs. Hazel Kast Estill, widow of Reuel C. Estill, who founded the Estill fund-raising company in New York, died today at her home here after a short illness. She was 82 years old.
TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP,) Communist China today announced the death of Sung Yu-ho, a member of the standing committee of the Chinese People's political consultative conference.

Warning of "traumatic" effects on the city, the chairman of the State Mediation Board issued a sharply worded request yesterday to both sides in the fuel oil strike to appear at his office this morning for negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 After 12 days of meetings, House and Senate conferees reported out tonight a strong clean-air bill that retained a requirement for the development of a nearly pollution-free auto engine within six years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Treasury Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission have decided to support the brokerage industry and fight against a high assessment on brokers to finance the proposed insurance against bankruptcies of brokerage concerns.

The St. Paul's School hockey team made its annual Christmas vacation appearance in New York yesterday, and the visit to Madison Square Garden was a successful one. The Concord (N.H.) institution, which has been called the cradle of hockey in this country, extended a tradition that began 75 years ago, when it made its first local appearance at the now defunct St. Nicholas Rink.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 President Nixon should grow a beard. After all, Lincoln did.
Tommy Milligan, a former British Empire and European boxing champion, died Monday in Glasgow, Scotland, of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

WAYNE, N.J., Dec. 16 Dr. Jahn M. Chapman, professor emeritus of banking of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, died yesterday in Chilton Memorial Hospital, Pompton Plains. He was 83 years old and lived at l9 Juniper Road, Pines Lake, here.

SUEZ, United Arab Republic, Dec. 16 "If you want to see some Israeli or maybe American planes, come out here," shouted an Egyptian escort to a group of visitors relaxing in the bar of the Bel-Air Hotel here today after a tour of this war-shattered city at the southern end of the Suez Canal.
PARIS, Dec. 16 More than 30 million Poles are still being called on to make economic sacrifices a quarter of a cenury after World War II.

A Penn Central lawyer accused the state's Public Service Commission yesterday of "a complete shirking of responsibility" after a commission examiner adjourned to Jan. 4 a hearing on a request for higher fares on the New Haven division.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 16 John R. Rice Jr., a 17-yearold honor student and highranking Boy Scout, was returned here today to face a murder charge in connection with the slayings of his mother, brother, sister and grandmother.

PARTIES Local 553 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 2,200 oil truck drivers and 600 oil burner repairmen, and the New York Oil Heating Association, representing 300 independent companies that serve 40 per cent of the city's homes and businesses using fuel oil.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 The East Germans announced today that they had invited Egon Bahr, Chancellor Willy Brandt's diplomatic trouble-shooter, to come to East Berlin Dec. 23 for a new round of talks.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 For the first time in 100 years the State of Illinois will have a new Constitution.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 16 Robert A. Maheu took the witness stand in District Court today to explain his relationships to the Hughes Tool Company and to Howard Hughes, the mysterious, secretive billionaire who owns it.

WARSAW, Dec. 16 Poland said tonight that order had been restored in Gdansk, the northern port city torn for two days by rioting and arson. The Government said that six persons had been killed in the clashes with the police while scores had been injured, many of them seriously. The toll was believed by unofficial sources to be higher.

A union president, three other union officials and a lawyer were indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of embezzling funds from Local 2947 of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 A group of Indians took over the Airlie Conference House in the rolling hills of Warrenton, Va., late last night, breaking into the liquor supply and cash box.

Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House's Office of Telecommunications Policy, sharply criticized the Federal Communications Commission yesterday as a "pretty vague" arbiter of public communication, and called for a re-examination of governmental policy toward communications and commercial broadcasting.

A man fatally wounded by three other men in a holdup at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday evening was identified yesterday as Julius Jesse Gordon, 47 years old, of 422 Albermarle Road, Cedarhurst, L.I.

The large Larry Rivers exhibition, currently at the Marlborough Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is the artist's first one-man show in New York in five years. The catalogue lists 40 items, many of them of sizable dimensions, and these are said to constitute only a small part of the artist's production during this five-year interval.

Among the 24 men in the round-robin tournament at Palma Majorca, none could be taken for granted. Because they did not fear loss of prestige, the lower-ranking masters fought with impunity and abandon, often speculating against a higher-rated foe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The State Department said today that it was looking into reports that the Czech Government was dunning Czech refugees abroad for money.
Julius Rosa, a 43-year-old cab driver, tried to blink back tears as he stood yesterday amid the confusion in a Bronx welfare center.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 (Reuters) A panel of three judges today found three persons, including a Roman Catholic priest, guilty of charges in connection with the kidnapping of former President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu.
Recent rundowns of corporate profit trends suggest that the economy has touched bottom. Nothing would please John Wright more. The only trouble is he doesn't believe it.

ALGIERS A new stress on Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting, was clearly evident this year in this capital, not so much as a return to religion but rather as part of a general reaction to what is called the depersonalization of Algerians.

Julie M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, announced yesterday that the city had been ordered by the United States Department of agriculture to eliminate the half-price purahase provision for new participants in the food stamp program next year.

LONDON, Dec. 15 Prime Minister Heath arrives in Washington tonight on his first official visit, and he comes with a glow of success that London expects to interest and please President Nixon when they meet.
Some in the fabeled world of advertising are approaching Christmas in the same spirit as a marathon runner approaches the finish line. The year is almost over and it's been some haul.

THE HAGUE Dec. 16 Fifty nations today signed an international convention making hijacking of civilian aircraft a criminal act and requiring the participating nations to mete out "severe punishment" to the offender.
The police used tear gas to disperse black power demonstrators in St. George's, Grenada, yesterday for the second consecutive day.

Carmen Vila is a pianist who sensibly scales her playing to the music at hand. At Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, her Mozart (Nine Variations on a Minuet by Duport) was graceful and shone warmly. In it, she showed that she is a musician's pianist, if not a pianist's pianist. She avoided all temptations to dazzle at the expense of the music.

For some persons with outside income there is a chance for an instant tax deduction if they move fast before the end of the year.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 16 Even for Las Vegas, the scene is bizarre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Army intelligence agents have spied on Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois and about 800 other civilians in Illinois alone, Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today.
The Police Department asked yesterday for a record $626.6million for operating expenses for the next fiscal year. This is $31.7-million more than the department's current budget.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The National Highway Safety Bureau confirmed reports today that some of its officials and engineers are testing cars supplied by automobile manufacturers by driving them to and from work.
BONN, Dec. 16 Even after he left here in 1792 at the age of 22, Ludwig van Beethoven planned to return to his native city. As he wrote to a Bonn friend from Vienna:
