Mayor Lindsay urged the City Council yesterday "to move promptly" to authorize compulsory arbitration in the event of an impasse in current labor negotiations with the city's uniformed forces.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) The Soviet Government denounced President Nixon today for his warning last week that the bombing of North Vietnam might be resumed if United States appeared to be threatened by a build-up of enemy forces along the South Vietnamese border.

The credit markets, groping for some new sense of direction, seemed to have found it late yesterday when the Federal Reserve purchased couponbearing Treasury securities and gave prices a moderate lift.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) Directors of Western Airlines approved tonight a $150-million merger with American Airlines that would make American the nation's second largest commercial air service behind United Air Lines.

Members of the United Federation of Teachers gave Dr. Harvey B. Scribner a cordial reception and frequently interrupted him with applause when the School Chancellor appeared yesterday before the union's delegate assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Saints and Sinners Club set out to roast Mrs. John N. Mitchell today for her celebrated earlymorning telephone calls. Instead, she was praised as "the first lady of the President's Cabinet."
Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 557. New York, N.Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

New York City Councilman Carter Burden proposes to meet a nasty, nagging issue head-on by suggesting that the municipal lawmakers adopt a code of ethics similar to the existing and proposed rules for Congress.
The 31-day-old off Broadway theater strike ended yesterday as actors and producers agreed to submit their differences to binding arbitration.
"My husband says our apartment gets to look more like a nursery school every day," said Mrs. Bjorn Olson, as she sat down at her work table.

Harpur College of the State University of New York at Binghamton is celebrating its 20th anniversary, and on Tuesday night several prominent members of its music faculty came to Tully Hall to present a program of chamber music. There were the New York Woodwind Quintet, the Lenox String Quartet, Jean Casadesus, pianist, and William Lewis, tenor.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16 A Lebanese newspaper reported today that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, was threatened, his jeep was burned and his guards were beaten by Jordanian saldiers Sunday during a visit to Jarash, in northern Jordan.

Taylor Belcher, president of the Garrison (N.Y.) Oil and Coal Company, died Sunday of a heart attack in Miami on his way to visit his son, Taylor Garrison Belcher, United States Ambassador to Peru. He was 86 years old and lived at Bear Mountain Bridge Road in Garrison.
Those searching for Christmas gifts for bridge-players or potential bridge-players can find items other than books. Many instructional devices, including the following, are available.

Despite changes of "union busting" by the United Federation of Teachers, the Board of Education last night created two new job classifications designed to admit more members of minority groups to jobs as substitute school secretaries.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 Governor Rockefeller today, announced the appointment of Russell G. Oswald, an expert in criminal rehabilitation and currently the chairman of the, State Board of Parole, as the state's new Commissioner of Correction.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 16 (AP) The search continued today for a fourth juror in the Black Panther kidnap-murder trial of Bobby Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins. The seventh panel of veniremen was exhausted in the process.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Nixon Administration is considering cutting off funds for VISTA as part of a 23 per cent trim in antipoverty fund requests in the 1972 budget.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 16 (AP) Yoshimi Nishigawa, a 17-year-old Japanese girl swimmer, became the first athlete ever to win five gold medals as Japan continued to dominate the Asian Games today.
The extradition of Angela Davis to California on an indictment charging kidnapping, murder and conspiracy was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

WARSAW, Dec. 16 The violence in Gdansk for the last two days recalls the 1956 Poznan riots in which 53 people died and 300 were wounded in clashes with the police. The Poznan riots, like the new ones, were officially attributed to hooligans and adventurers.

An ex-convict testified yesterday that a man with whom he had shared a 33d-floor luxury apartment on the Upper East Side had tried to set fire to a neighbor's apartment because "he hated the man next door."

The conviction and five-year sentence of a union official for perjury was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division, which criticized the trial judge for allowing a "hostile atmosphere," including references to the "Vito Genovese family."
After two years of deep financial distress, the crisis on Wall Street apparently has been resolved.
Increased buying late in the session helped the American Stock Exchange to finish mixed yesterday in slow trading.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec.16 Jack Stroud Jr., 18-year-old son of the former New York Giants' guard, died last night a few hours after undergoing surgery for an old shoulder injury.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 16 Hundreds of former Soviet Jews who managed to immigrate to Israel converged at the Wailing Wall today for hours of lament and fasting to honor 11 prisoners facing possible death sentences at a trial in Leningrad.

A combination of bullish factors sent futures prices of soybeans and grains up again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. However, profit taking in the last hour trimmed very large advances made early in the day.
A middle-income housing development containing as many as 1,200 apartments is planned on land owned by the Consolidated Edison Company along the East River adjacent to Stuyvesant Town.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16 Mrs. Mollie Netcher Bragno Bostwick, the departmentstore heiress, was married here last Saturday to Paul C. Wilmot Jr., who is with Richard Finnis Enterprises, an advertising agency in New York. Paul T. Douglas, judge of Palm Beach County, performed the ceremony at the bride's home. The couple plan to return to New York the first of the year.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 (AP) The state reaped $172-million in tax revenue from pari-mutuel racing in New York this year, the Tax Department reported today.
That strange form of hockey that has mushroomed at Madison Square Garden this season inelegant, labored and onesided didn't improve last night when the Rangers trounced the Buffalo Sabres, 4-0.

What to do with a film based on the life of Beehoven, or any other composer, for that matter? Too much music, and you lose your audience. Too much talk, and everybody yawns. Too much fact, and it's like reading from a musical dictionary. Too much glamorization, and integrity has gone. It's a problem.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Senate, in an increasingly testy mood, found itself confronted today with six potential filibusters that could keep Congress in session until the new year.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 16 A defense witness testified today at the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that after the four-hour assault on Mylai 4, Capt. Ernest L. Medina received a radio query, apparently from his superiors in Task Force Barker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The House Commerce Committee approved today a bill to permit the government to guarantee $125-million to aid financially troubled railroads, headed by the Penn Central.
A spot check of shoppers in five supermarkets here yestersay suggested that the sale of canned tuna had dropped sharply.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Phil Esposito, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, notched his 27th and 28th goals within 49 seconds midway in the second period tonight, helping the Boston Bruins to a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. It was Boston's sixth straight triumph.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 16 (AP) The Senate quickly passed today the compromise version of the job safety bill establishing the first all-embracing Federal program in this field.
Pace College announced yesterday that it was letting 25 faculty members go next year because enrollments were down.

If in every middle-aged woman there is a young girl trying to break out, then every 20-year-old yearns for the loves of her childhood. This turning back of time is bringing about a lot of fashion whimsey for all ages. Storybook characters are marching around on belts,...
The Baltimore Orioles, already the ranking team in baseball, obtained even more pitching depth yesterday when they got Grant Jackson and two other players from the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 President Nixon vetoed a $9.5billion employment and manpower bill today because it bore little resemblance to his own proposals and because, he said, it "perpetuates and extends the deficiencies in our manpower programs."

BOSTON, Dec. 16 In remote valleys and canyons or cluttered city apartment houses, thousands of young adults, seeking economic advantages, social revolution, love, pot, God or themselves, are creating a new life style in America.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (UPI) A grand jury returned a secret indictment today against three persons in the apparent slaying of a hand at the Spahn movie ranch, one-time home of Charles M. Manson's "family"

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 (AP) Oscar Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight who got a hero's welcome here after his loss to Muhammad Ali on Dec. 7, said tonight he would not fight Floyd Patterson on Jan. 22 as was announced in New York earlier today.
Charles Edward Smith, a pioneer writer on jazz, died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 32 West 91st Street.

Although consumer confidence remains depressed, there is reason to believe that there will be an increase in spending for "discretionary items" during 1971, the University of Michigan Survey Research Center reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) Jimmie Louis Harrison, soughtby the police on charges of shooting Nate Ramsey, the Eagle's defensive captain, surrendered today. Ramsey was wounded Monday afternoon as he walked along a West Philadelphia street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 A report by Senate investigators said today that the United States was providing "close air support" for Cambodian armed forces and carrying out a wide variety of other combat missions under the "camouflage" of acting to prevent movements by Communist troops into South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Commerce Department officials testified today to the apparent satisfaction of Democratic critics that the Administration had not forced the production of 1970 census data for partisan purposes.
Individually, are the Jets rooting for the Giants to keep winning?

The city applied yesterday for $800-million in Federal funds to help finance a $2-billion subway expansion program, it was announced by Mayor Lindsay and Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 American reconnaissance satellites have picked up evidence indicating that the Soviet Union has slowed the construction of long-range strategic nuclear missiles and is dismantling a modest number of intermediaterange missiles.

Mrs. Bessie Levy Warner, widow of Albert Warner, one of the four founding brothers and former vice president of Warner Brothers Pictures, died yesterday at her home in Hampshire House at the age of 83.
PLYMOUTH, Montserrat, Dec. 16 (AP) In a father-son contest, Austin Bramble has won control of the Government of this 39-square-mile island in the Caribbean.

RENSSELAERVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 16 Joseph Monserrat, a member of the New York City Board of Education, and a contingent of Puerto Rican community leaders yesterday walked out of a conference on the problems of Puerto Ricans to protest the absence of high Federal and state officials.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 16 The United States and the Soviet Union today concluded their discussions at this round of strategic arms-limitation talks and prepared to adjourn Friday without any sign of progress toward an accord on halting the nuclear arms race.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 The Mayors of the state's six largest cities met here today with Governor Rockefeller in their joint effort to get more state funds and were told by the Governor that "the state is in the same boat they are."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) Today was Beethoven's birthday and, as he has done for 25 years, Dr. James W. Skaggs took the day off for "a personal celebration of genius."

The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday that Chauncey J. Medberry 3d, a 53-year-old native of Los Angeles, had been named chairman of the board to succeed Louis B. Lundborg, who is to retire next April 1.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 Coming to defensive life in the second half tonight the Knicks shut off the Cleveland Cavaliers with 34 points in the final two periods to post an easy 108-84 victory before a crowd of 3,556 at Cleveland Arena.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Ernest D. Fears Jr. was named today as Virginia's Selective Service director. He becomes the first black to head a statewide system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 A food stamp bill embracing a stringent "must work" requirement cleared the House tonight after last-minute support from the Nixon Administration. The vote was 290 to 68.

Late in Gordon Watkins's "Caught in the Middle," Mrs. Thomas, blowsy and streetwise, sitting across a pint of gin from William (Bear) Walker, welfare worker turned fugitive, sneers in a voice thick with scorn, "You know, I did have your number. Everything is fine until you got to pay a little dues."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 16 (Reuters) The Ethiopian Government declared a state of emergency today in several areas of the northern province of Eritrea, alleging that foreign governments had sent armed infiltrators into the territory.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 (AP) One of the main United States military housing sections here came under a grenade attack and a bombing tonight, and bomb squads and military policemen responded to what turned out to be four false alarms from other American installations.

John A. Assheton, who retired in 1963 as president of the Caracas Petroleum Corporation, died Tuesday in the DeWitt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street. He was 86 years old and lived in Cuernavaca, Mexico, and Tuckerstown, Bermuda.
Summit Mortgage Investors, a unit of the Drew National Corporation, announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to aquire the Ridge Manor Development Corporation and two of its affiliates.
The London stock market consolidated recent strength yesterday, but price movements were generally narrow and trading volume was low.
Demand for business loans at major New York City banks slumped during the week ended Dec. 9, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

Operations of the Alco Standard Corporation in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 resulted in earnings estimated at $12.6million, or $1.45 a share, it was reported yesterday by Tinkham Veale 2d, chairman, Extraordinary items will not be a material factor in fiscal 1970 results, he said.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 16 Dr. Raphael R. Goldenberg of 32 Overlook Avenue, professor of surgery and head of the orthopedics department at the Medical College of New Jersey in Newark, died last evening of a coronary attack. He was 66 years old.
Spot audits by the state of some New York City agencies have turned up widespread mismanagement, waste and fraud over the last two years.
MUNDELEIN, Ill., Dec. 17 Five cardinals and 36 bishops of the Roman Catholic Church converged on an isolated retreat house here today to discuss the financial crisis in parochial school education.

The Seabord Coast Line Railroad announced yesterday that its directors have approved in principle an offer to buy all the outstanding stock of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, one of the nation's most profitable carriers. Seaboard Coast Line has for years owned 33 per cent of Louisville Nashville's ...

The Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the New York Hilton with the following schedule: today, Men's and Women's Pairs at 2 P.M. and Mixed Pairs and Novice Pairs at 8 P.M.; tomorrow, Swiss Pairs at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M., and Sunday, Open Teams at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.
Profit taking sent soybean and grains futures contracts down yesterday after several advances.
The American Stock Exchange scored its first advance of the week yesterday as prices finished slightly higher in more active trading.
CAIRO, Dec. 17 The people of Cairo, tormented by overcrowded buses and trolleys, are to be urged to put aside status considerations and ride to work by bicycle.
MADRID, Dec. 17 The largest crowd Madrid has seen in 25 years, except perhaps at football games, gathered today to shout its support for Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Darryl F. Zanuck, chairman and chief executive officer of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, issued a letter to the company's employes yesterday amid wide speculation that top-level management changes are in the works.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest here last night of Judith A. Clark, one of 12 leaders of the Weathermen who were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Chicago last April 2 on charges of conspiracy and violation of the Federal anti-riot act.

The decision of the British electrical workers to call off their slowdown is an important symbolic victory for Prime Minister Heath and the new Conservative Government. The Heath strategy to halt wage inflation depends heavily upon the Government's setting a good example to private employers in its own dealings with unions in the nationalized industries.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) Louis E. Wolfson filed a $50-million damage suit today against 72 partners of a New York brokerage house and a Jacksonville employe of the firm, blaming them for events that contributed to his serving a Federal prison term.

The most obvious need and the most obvious lack in the crucial wage negotiations now under way between the city and the unions representing its uniformed forces is a united front on the governmental side of the table.

Eight-year-old Janet Miner, a tiny girl with flowing blond hair, ran her fingers over a ceramic figure at a new exhibition in the Brooklyn Museum yesterday morning and announced confidently: "This is a dog."
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city would sponsor a major research program to develop a long-lasting, nonaddictive drug for heroin addiction to replace methadone.
NEWARK, Dec. 17 A Federal grand jury indicted two reputed top associates of Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante today on charges of extorting kickbacks from a New Jersey apartment house developer.

Money and bank credit expanded at a moderate pace during the last few weeks, banking figures published yesterday showed. But corporate loan demand at major New York City banks was notably slack over the Dec. 15 date, when company tax payments are due, thus heightening the expectation that one of these institutions will shortly take the initiative to cut its prime rate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The House concluded a threeyear battle between Congressional supporters of business interestsa nd organized labor and gave final approved today to a broad occupational health and safety bill establishing Federal supervision over working conditions.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Dec. 17 S.S. Khalid Khan, an executive of the American Express bank here, has taken issue with an article about the political situation in Pakistan that appeared in The New York Times last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Through a Congressional barter over American assistance to schools and nursing homes in Israel, the Administration may at long last obtain its desired authority to extend easy credit to foreign countries purchasing American arms.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 17 (UPI) Premier Golda Meir met with United States Ambassador Walworth Barbour today and formally received the latest United States note on proposed resumption of Middle East peace taller. Mrs. Meir said later that Israel would return to the talks only after "careful examination" of all the issues involved.

The Bach Aria Group marked Beethoven's 200th birthday Wednesday night at Tully Hall with a generous program of, not surprisingly, Bach arias. Ludwig himself, wholehearted admirer of the Leipzig cantor, probably would have approved: the uplifting nature of Bach's cantata texts and music seemed an entirely fitting celebration of the occasion.
Vincent D. McDonnell, the 51-year-old chairman of the State Mediation Board, put his feet up on his glass-topped desk and pulled out a sheet of bluelined notebook paper.

A list of members of the Italian-American Civil Defense League and of contributors to the league, purportedly belonging to Joseph Colombo, an alleged Mafia leader, was seized by F.B.I. agents Wednesday from a man who was conversing with Colombo in a car parked in Foley Square.
The tax-exempt bond market, which has been adrift for much of the last week, reached solid ground yesterday.
DALLAS, Dec. 17 (AP) Rod Laver of Australia, voted the top international tennis player for 1970, has become the first professional to win more than $200,000 in prize money in one year.

Errol John's "Moon on a Rainbow Shawl," first produced oft Broadway in 1962, and now revived by the Urban Arts Corps, is a highly atmospheric play about the disappointed and rejected black inhabitants of a back district in Trinidad. The canvas is small but crowded with life.

MOSCOW The name of the most prestigious newspaper in the Communist world is Pravda, which means "Truth," and Pravda has published in the last few days a savage editorial against its Nobel Prize winner, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, describing him as "a spiritual emigrant hostile to the whole life of the Soviet people."
LONDON, Dec. 17 Poisonous mercury has been found in samples of tinned tuna fish taken from British shops for analysis by the laboratory of the Government Chemist.

Random House yesterday gave its publishing archives to Columbia University. The gift comprises more than 300,000 pieces of authors' correspondence, editorial and publishing records and other documents, covering the period from the founding of the publishing house in 1927 to the mid-nineteen-sixties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Ralph Nader and six teen-age women assistants told Congress today that the federal Government should apply financial leverage as well as administrative leadership to improve conditions in nursing homes because Federal dollars pay half the bills.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 17 (Reuters) The Northern Ireland Government tonight proposed to Parliament reforms to help end discrimination against the Roman Catholic minority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The aerospace industry reported in a self-analysis today that it had a bad year in 1970 and that 1971 would be worse.

Martin Freyberg, a former president of the City Tax Commission, received an unconditional discharge yesterday, after he pleaded guilty to a perjury charge that grew out of an investigation of a former Water commissioner, James L. Marcus.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17 (AP) With battlefield action continuing at a relatively low level, the United States command reported today that 29 Americans were killed in fighting in Indochina last week.

Once when Anne Fremantle was at college, she thought she'd like to try an essay on J.M. Synge. She went to Lady Augusta Gregory for help. The lady felt that an heiress with such obvious ability should be speedily served with a husband and she set out to secure one.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 (AP) Robert Goldsborough Henry Jr., a boat designer and builder, died at Anne Arundel General Hospital today after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Nixon Administration's major effort under its minority capitalism program suffered in the fiscal year 1970 because of the economic slump, Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 17 On the type of icy, hard and fast track on which he is almost unbeatable, Patrick Russel of France won the men's giant slalom today at the Criterium of the First Snow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 Dr. Harold H. Morris, a retired medical missionary for the Episcopal Church, who had served at St. Luke's Hospital in Shanghai and as professor of medicine at St. John's University there, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at St. Simons Island, Ga.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Housing starts rose strongly again, to an annual rate of 1,692,000 in November, the Commerce Department reported today.
Striking cabbies clashed with policemen again yesterday as the standoff continued in the 13-day-old taxi strike.
Faced with increasing operational costs and a need to provide expanded services to the trading public, the Chicago Board of Trade has approved a new exchange service fee on all transactions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17 The 25th-anniversary session of the United Nations General Assembly ended on a pessimistic note today with an appeal by Secretary General Thant to member governments to save the world organization from financial insolvency.

Toledo, unbeaten in 22 game relied on speed and quickness to finish as the national football leader in both total defense and pass defense for 1970, according to statistics issued yesterday by the National Collegiate Sports Services.

The formation of a Committee to Save the New York Shakespeare Festival was announced yesterday under the chairmanship of Roger L. Stevens. Among those who have agreed to serve are Julie Harris, Marian Logan, Stuart Ostrow, Basil Paterson and George C. Scott.

Edwin H. Gott chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday painted a gloomy picture of the chances for a peaceful, noninflationary labor settlement with the United Steelworkers of America next summer.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 Dr. John R. Silber, the philosopher who gained national attention last summer when he was dismissed as dean of arts and sciences at the University of Texas in a battle with the school's conservative regents, was appointed today as the seventh president of Boston University.

Benet Polikoff Sr., a partner in the law firm of Polikoff Clareman, 6 East 45th Street, who specialized in business and theater law, died yesterday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

Jimmy (The Greek) Snyder, the oddsmaker from Las Vegas, has made the Giants an even-money bet in Sunday's game against the Rams. The Giants' leading rivals in their battle for a playoff position, Dallas and Detroit, are 12-point favorites over Houston and Green Bay, respec- ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The chief critic of President Nixon's welfare reform plan, Senator John J. Williams, sprang a parliamentary trap on its supporters today, virtually insuring that it would not come to a Senate vote this year, much less become law.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 17 (UPI) Charles (Lefty) Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach, called today for suspension of any college player caught throwing a punch in a game.
LAS VEGAS, Dec. 17 The submission of evidence was completed today in the legal battle for control of Howard Hughes's Nevada business holdings and final arguments were scheduled for tomorrow.

BONN, Dec. 17 The political shock waves of the violence in Gdansk rolled across Eastern and Western Europe today and in the view of knowledgeable Europeans of both East and West they bode little good.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) House-Senate negotiators killed a $750-million program today under which the Federal Government, for the first time, would have helped cities cover the deficits of mass transit systems.

There have been mother and daughter, and father and son fashions, but Saks Fifth Avenue has the answer for families who believe in ageless, unisex togetherness. The store recently unpacked a boot for casual wear, designed to go on male and female feet of all sizes.

PARIS, Dec. 17 North Vietnam invited the United States today to suggest a "reasonable deadline" for the withdrawal of its forces from South Vietnam since it had rejected the deadline of next June 30 that the Communist side had proposed.

One of the legendary chapters in the history of modern art the pioneer collecting efforts of the American writer Gertrude Stein, her brothers, Leo and Michael Stein, and her sister-in-law, Sarah Stein (Michael's wife) during their expatriate years in Paris-has now been commemorated in a stunning exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
The New York Chamber of Commerce urged the city yesterday to face the reality of a budget deficit and not grant "untenable salary and pension increases" to city employes.
Bache Co., the nation's second-largest brokerage house, issued a financial report yesterday that put a dollars-andcents evaluation on the turnaround in the profitability of the securities industry.

YONKERS, Dec. 17 Three year-olds brought the four top bids at the third annual winter Old Glory Sale at Yonkers Raceway today. With 1,200 persons in attendance, 208 standardbreds were sold for $578,800, an average of $2,782 a head.

CULVER, Ind., Dec. 17 (AP) John G. Best, chairman of CTS Corporation of Elkhart, was found dead today in his car in the garage of his summer residence on Lake Maxinkuckee. He was 49 years old.

The Lesbian issue, which has been hidden away like a demented child ever since the women's liberation movement came into being in 1966, was brought out of the closet yesterday.

DALLAS, Dec. 17 A Dallas securities concern filed a suit today charging that a decision by the National Association of Securities Dealers to exclude listed securities from a new automated quotation system was illegal under the Federal antitrust laws.

Kenny Kosek, fiddler and erstwhile leader of the Living Stone Cowboys, a young city bluegrass group, gave his first concert as "just me," as he put it, on Wednesday at the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15 It took the 115 men in a North Vietnamese infantry company almost 90 days to come down the Ho Chi Minh Trail, and no man reached South Vietnam without knowing the fevers of malaria and an exhaustion that sleep did not quickly cure.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Friday, Dec. 18 A party that seeks full regional autonomy for East Pakistan and another that pledges a redistribution of wealth along Marxist lines took big leads early today over other political parties and hundreds of independent candidates in elections to five provincial assemblies.

Michael F. Keating was dismissed yesterday as news director of WCBS-TV. He was replaced by Ed Joyce, a radio newsman for the station's parent company, the Columbia Broadcasting System.

As an expansion team, the Vikes had virtually nothing.

If the toss of a coin is needed to determine which second-place finisher in the National Conference of the National Football League goes on into the playoffs, it will take place immediately after Sunday's games through a telephone hook-up, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced yesterday. Details of the exact procedure were still being negotiated by the parties concerned.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 17 The court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. adjourned until Jan. 11 today with the defense still seeking to prove that any slaughter of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai was done on orders from the company commander, Capt. Ernest L. Medina.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 In an almost empty hearing room on Capitol Hill today, Senator Lee Metcalf quietly assailed the Nixon Administration for having named a former White House aide, Daniel W. Hofgren, to the financial advisory panel of the new National Railroad Passenger Corporation.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 Saratoga Raceway filed suit in State Supreme Court today to have the New York Off-Track Betting Law declared unconstitutional.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (UPI) Court officials said today that most of the defendants on trial in Leningrad for attempting to hijack an airliner had pleaded guilty and had admitted working for "international Zionism."

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 The Soviet leadership threatened today to crack down on a small group of political dissidents who have become increasingly outspoken in the last two years and have attracted considerable attention in the West.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 A Lebanese Army intelligence officer was killed today by masked men with machine guns as he waited for a taxi in a Beirut suburb. The police said the men escaped in two cars.

MIAMI, Dec. 17 (AP) Dust Commander, the 1970 Kentucky Derby winner, made his winter debut in the ninth race at Tropical Park today and finished next to last. The 9-5 favorite was 17 lengths back of the winner.

CAIRO, Dec. 17 A news agency dispatch from Beirut, Lebanon, yesterday reporting that several thousand Soviet soldiers and antiaircraft missile technicians had arrived in the United Arab Republic in the last few weeks was dismissed today by an Egyptian official spokesman as "not worthy of comment."

Doing research on forced repatriation of anti-Communist prisoners of war and displaced persons during and after World War II, I discovered early in 1954 in the Army's Historical Records Branch in Alexandria, Va., as index card marked "Forcible Repatriation of Displaced Soviet Citizens Operation Keelhaul 383-7-14."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican leader, led a petition of 19 Senators today for an end to the filibuster against the supersonic transport.

FORT MCPHERSON, Ga. Dec. 17 (UPI) An attorney for Captain Medina indicated today that the captain would not deny that he had ordered the leveling of My Lai and the slaughter of the Vietnamese village's inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 17(AP) A chaotic rump session of the White House Conference on Children adopted resolutions tonight against the Vietnam war and the supersonic transport. The delegates also demanded programs "to feed all the hungry people in America."

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17, (UPI) Cardinal Cooke, Archbishop of New York, presided at mass today at the compound of the Eighth United States Army headquarters and flew to the front lines to visit troops of the Second Infantry division.
Pan Am has run a direct mail advertising campaign, which they think might have been a first for the market Moscow.
The New York Jets will leave today for Baltimore, where they will try to salvage some last-minute successes tomorrow afternoon in their final game of the season against the Colts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 The board of directors of the Philadelphia 1976 Bicentennial Corporation scrapped today its $1.2-billion master plan for an international exposition to celebrate the nation's 200th birthday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) The Maxwell Club named Jim Plunkett, the Stanford quarterback, and George Blanda, the quarterback and place-kicker of the Oakland Raiders, as the outstanding college and pro football players of 1970.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 A joint Senate-House conference committee agreed today to impose on brokerage firms a higher assessment than the securities industry had hoped to bear to finance the new plan of insurance against brokers' bankruptcies.

Placement counselors at colleges in the metropolitan area, alarmed by a sharp drop in job offers for students, are warning members of the class of '7l that they will be graduating into a bleak, recessionconstricted career market.
The two sides in the fuel oil deliverers' strike resumed negotiations yesterday as city officials reported an increasing stream of complaints of no heat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Mrs. Verna E. Hickenlooper, wife of former Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, died today in Georgetown University Hospital. She was 73 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment for several years.

Until Wednesday night, this listener, in 20 years of professional concert-going had not heard a piano glissando played so seductively that it sent shivers down his back. But Alicia de Larrocha did one that way is her interpretation of Ravel's "Alborada del Gracioso" at Philharmonic Hall, and it was something never to be forgotten.
Off Broadway curtains will go up tonight on two of the original 17 shows darkened by the month-long Off Broadway theater strike settled on Wednesday.

Snowmaking, which had become a daily routine at ski areas in the Catskills, the Berkshires and the Green Mountains, ground to a halt yesterday. The reason was an abundant snowfall that gave the North Country its first heavy blanket of white cover.
Dr. Bernard Goldbaum, a general practitioner, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home 991 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 68.
Wagner battled Manhattan on even terms through the first half last night, but bowed to the Jaspers' second-half attack, 90-78, at Sutter Gymnasium, Staten Island.

Worker explained that as long as he lives in the Torres household he and his children must have a separate category. Worker asked him why he was living in the Torres household part of the time and with another woman the rest of the time. He shrugged his shoulders."
The man who has everything doesn't have these!
AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 17 Students from five Massachusetts colleges have voted to accept a controversial $25,000 grant from the John D. Rockefeller 3d Fund.
WARSAW, Dec. 17 Poland declared a virtual state of emergency tonight as anti-Government rioting spread and the toll of dead and injured rose.

The London stock market moved lower in quiet trading yesterday. Profit taking following the market's recent rally and general lack of buyers were the main reasons for the decline in which special situations dominated trading.

Twelve leading rendering companies that make soap and other products from meat trimmings were indicted yesterday on charges of a conspiracy to rig bids and suppress competition in the New York metropolitan area.
WARSAW, Dec.17 The riots that began Monday in Gdansk were touched off by a weekend price rise that represented a last straw to some Poles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. l7 The leader of a so-called "dissident" black faction at the White House Conference on Children today called it "the most successful" in the 61-year history of such meetings and praised its chairman, Stephen Hess, as a man of "certified integrity" and fairness.

Oscar Lewis, the anthropologist famous for his unsparingly vivid accounts of family life among Mexican and Puerto Rican slum dwellers, died of a heart attack Wednesday evening at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 55 years of age.
The New York Times obtained a temporary restraining order last night that prohibits its pressmen from interfering with the production of the newspaper.

COCOA, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) Space agency officials tightened security at Cape Kennedy Space Center tonight after a telephone caller warned the Federal Bureau of Investigation of an attempt to blow up the facility.
Dr. Hermann Schuelein, who retired in 1960 as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Rheingold Breweries in 1960, died Tuesday at his home, 1136 Fifth Avenue. His age was 86.

The Federal Government and the oil companies are again playing Texas roulette with the nation's marine resources. After a two-year hiatus, the Interior Department has auctioned off new oil and gas drilling leases in the Gulf of Mexico. The oil companies bid more than $850 million.

A young woman English teacher at the recently opened ninth-grade annex of troubled George Washington High School was found badly beaten and unconcious yesterday afternoon in a third-floor staff washroom.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Dec. 12 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he would recommend a bill to the 1971 Legislature to provide for supervision of all art exhibitions here.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 17 (AP) For the first time in eight days of Asian Games competition, Japan failed today to win a single medal. However, the Japanese gave India a surprisingly stiff battle in the field hockey semifinals.

The members of the New York Yacht Club learned the itinerary of their annual racing cruise, elected all their officers and got a little additional information last night about the current situation in the America's Cup, which their club will defend in 1973.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Dec. 17 (UPI) Four high schools that have only 157 pupils among them meet this weekend in what is billed as the world's smallest holiday basketball tournament and is known locally as "the tourney of good losers." The finals will be broadcast Saturday by a local radio station.
Democrats and Republicans paid $500 a plate to bid farewell to New York's Senator Charles E. Goodell, a Republican, last night at a dinner attended by 125 persons in the St. Regis Hotel here.
Coincident with the Stein family collection at the Museum of Modern Art are a number of related events.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Defense Department issued tough directives today to enforce racial equality in the armed forces after it had received a report detailing "frustration and anger" among black troops in West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The United States today rebuffed a stern Soviet denunciation of American bombing policy on North Vietnam and urged Moscow to persuade Hanoi to stop shooting at American reconnaissance planes.

Three men believed to be narcotics pushers were shot, one of them fatally, yesterday afternoon when they allegedly attacked and slashed an undercover narcotics detective who was attempting to arrest them in a hallway on the Lower East Side, the police reported.

Lawrence S. Huntington has been elected president of the Fiduciary Company of New York. He succeeds Harry W. Fowler who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Huntington, 35 years old, has been executive vice president in charge of the investment department since 1968, and a member of the board since April of this year. The company has $1.5-billion under management, and an additional $1-billion in custody accounts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin said today he was optimistic that the European Common Market would move in the near future to liberalize some trade policies with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Army Secretary Stanley R. Resor denied today that Army intelligence agents had ever conducted political surveillance of three prominent political figures in Illinois as reported by by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.

LONDON There was a lesson for all advanced technological societies in Britain's slowdown by electricity workers which narrowly avoided a dangerous crisis. The lesson is simply that as nations enter the post-industrial age they must find new labor relations formulas which safeguard the workingman without unduly threatening operations of the state.

BUFFALO, Dec. 17 (UPI) Dick Duff's goal on a relay from Gerry Meehan with 6 minutes 49 seconds remaining enabled the Buffalo Sabres to snap a five-game National Hockey League losing streak tonight, with a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 105.4 Tuesday from 105.6 last week.

A correction officer trainee, used by rebellious inmates of the Tombs two months ago to deliver a list of their grievances to Mayor Lindsay, has been dismissed by the Correction Department because his work was "below the standard required."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Vice President Agnew said today that "division can be constructive" in American politics.
More than five million residents of New York State who buy their automobile insurance in the normal market may get a slight rate reduction next year, it was disclosed yesterday.
On the eighth day before Christmas, sentiment, charity and commercialism have already spread through the metropolitan area like windblown tinsel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17 Frank A. Cosgrove, former treasurer of Johnson Johnson, dried last night at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 77 years old and lived at 148 Hodge Road here.

Mayor Lindsay called on communities surrounding the city yesterday to ease their zoning restrictions on apartment houses and "make room" for blue-collar workers whose jobs have taken them to the suburbs.

Army's tough, physical defense was not enough last night at Madison Square Garden. The cadets didn't have the shooting to go with it. Shut off without a basket for the final 5 minutes 34 seconds of play they were beaten by St. Bonaventure, 58-51, in the second game of a double-header in which a total of 100 turnovers were committed by the four teams.
SEATTLE, Dec. 17 (AP) The former Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel, said today the nation was at a turning point that required "a new breed of national leader."

Merging storms from the Carolinas and the Ohio Valley struck the Northeast Wednesday night and yesterday, dumping up to 15 inches of snow upstate and in New England and a mixture of snow, sleet and rain over the New York metropolitan area, which was lashed by winds up to 55 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Following, as monitored in Washington, are the texts of a speech to the Polish people delivered today by Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz and a communique issued by his office:
The reverberations of I.B.M.'s new capability in computer memory devices and a Memorex earnings trim continued to take their toll in Wall Street yesterday.

The International Harvester Company attained record sales in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, with higher fourth-quarter volume, but annual earnings fell 17.8 per cent and the quarter profit plunged 42 per cent, the report disclosed yesterday.

The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that a city official had violated the Code of Ethics because he operated a home remodeling corporation that was subject to inspection and supervision by the Buildings Department, a city agency.

OTTAWA, Dec. 17 The legal adviser to the Montreal Police Department said tonight that it had no objection to the release of 102,000 seized copies of Scanlan's Monthly, an American magazine, once a formal registration requirement was satisfied.
CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 17 Richard J. Daley announced today that he would seek a fifth term as Mayor of Chicago.
Mrs. Lucy Harrison McLoughlin, wife of Kevin McLoughlin, a management consultant, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital, after a short illness. She was 55 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.
The 10th victim of a blast and fire that wrecked an old three-story building at the tip of City Hall Park died yesterday.
FINNEYTOWN, Ohio Tom Stevens is a husky 40-year-old salesman who used to play guard for his high school football team.

It was a riot set off by hard living conditions that began the events that Poles now nostalgically call the "golden October" of 1956. Workers in the industrial city of Poznan took to the streets in June over low wages and high prices, and by October the issue had broadened into an uprising against the Soviet Union's political, military and economic stranglehold.

Bob Blackman, whose undefeated Dartmouth football team won the Ivy League title, was given the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award yesterday as the East's major-college coach of the year. The New York Football Writers Association, which named Blackman for the award, also gave Bill McDonald of Edinboro (Pa.) State the trophy as the East's small-college coach of the year.
The Mets decorated several Christmas trees at Shea Stadium yesterday while General Manager Bob Scheffing continued to spread the spirit of a third-place Santa Claus by signing three more players.

Vermont Royster, who has been teaching the humanities and other graces on Wall Street for a long time and making them love it there, is sure that he still has a great deal to say about the odd shape of many things.

If so much didn't depend on Sunday's game against the Los Angeles Rams in Yankee Stadium, Alex Webster, the New York Giants coach, could well afford to spend all his time just worrying about the aches and pains of Fred Dryer, Willie Young and Scott Eaton.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 17 A white policeman was acquitted today on charges of violating the civil rights of a Negro teenager killed in rioting last May. Tha white community was relieved but not surprised by the verdict.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (AP) The Interior Department today accepted 108 bids for drilling space in the oilrich sea bottom off Louisiana's western coast. They totaled $845,832,785. Bids on 11 tracts were rejected as being too low.
Hours before the extradition stay of Angela Davis expired yesterday, a Federal judge here granted a stay until today.
Howard J. Samuels, head of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday that legislation would be sought to exempt all offtrack winnings from state income taxes.

BONN, Dec. 17 Chancellor Willy Brandt told his Cabinet today that the outlook for an East-West agreement on the Berlin, problem had improved as a result of information he had received from the four powers currently negotiating on the issue.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The Boston Celtics rallied with the help of John Havlicek and Dave Cowens tonight after Jo Jo White had kept them in the game to post a 102-93 victory over the Buffalo Braves in a National Basketball Association game.
A group of 110 of the 166 staff nurses at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn resigned yesterday because a salary increase was rescinded.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms, a group of nearly 500 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, indicated yesterday that it would press for a consolidation of the clearing corporations of the New York and American Stock Exchanges.
